text:
October Retail Sales Seen Up 0.1%

 

  NEW YORK -DJ- Retail sales are expected to have moved up 0.1 pc in October, according to the average of estimates of 14 economist surveyed by Dow Jones Capital Markets Report. 

  A drop in consumer spending has been reflected in the sales of department stores - one of the largest components of the Commerce's Department's monthly retail sales report, analysts say. 

  Economists' forecasts for the Commerce report, due Wednesday at 8:30 a.m. EST, range from one call for a decline of 1.5 pc to one call for a 1.1 gain. 

  The September rise of 1.1 pc followed a 0.4 pc decline in August and a 0.1 pc gain in July. 

  Economists stress that within their estimations, higher gasoline prices offset sluggish consumer spending - which accounts for two-thirds of gross national product - along with weakness in general merchandise and apparel sales. 

  "The downtick would have been more pronounced had it not been for the gasoline," says Kathleen Stephansen, senior economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp., who estimates a decline of 0.2 pc. 

  The figure, she adds, "reflects widespread weakness in the economy." 

  The continuing Persian Gulf crisis caused a surge in energy prices - gasoline prices skyrocketed during the month. 

  Michael Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities Inc., sees retail sales down 0.2 pc. He says that despite a weak economy, firm auto sales prevented a further decline in retail sales. 

  Last month, domestic car sales amounted to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.1 million units, from 6.4 million units a year ago.

text:
PacifiCare Health Sees Fiscal 4Q Net Over 45C Shr Vs 36C

 
   By David J. Jefferson 
   Dow Jones Staff Reporter 
 

  CYPRESS, Calif. -DJ- PacifiCare Health Systems Inc.  will post net income in excess of $5.5 million, or more than 45 cents a share, for the fiscal fourth quarter ended Sept. 30, Wayne Lowell, chief financial officer, told Dow Jones. 

  The earnings are "slightly ahead" of industry analysts' expectations that the company would earn between $5 million and $5.5 million, or 41 cents to 45 cents a share, for the quarter, he said. 

  In the year-ago quarter, the operator of health maintenance organizations had net income of $4.1 million, or 36 cents a share.  Revenue climbed to between $260 million and $270 million, from $190.6 million a year ago, he said. 

  Lowell attributed the strong results to increases in both HMO memberships and prices during the past year. Memberships increased 22 pc in 1990 compared to the prior year, and price increases averaged between 10 pc and 20 pc, he said. The company also reduced the amount of hospital services it uses - "one of our efficiency measures" - but that was offset by an increase in administrative costs "related primarily to digesting the growth we've had," he said. 

  Given the rate of growth, PacifiCare expects revenue to increase about 20 pc in fiscal 1991, "and we are hopeful that our bottom line will also grow by 20 pc," Lowell said. 

  For the year ended Sept. 30, net income "slightly exceeded" analysts' high expectations of $17.4 million, or $1.45 a share, and revenue was between $970 million and $980 million, he said.  Net income for the year included a net gain $1 million, or nine cents a share, from the sale of the company's Austin, Texas, operations. 

  In the prior year, the company had net income of $10.9 million, or 96 cents a share, on revenue of $650.2 million. 

  PacifiCare has HMO operations in Southern California, Oregon, Washington state, Oklahoma and Texas. The company is looking to add a Medicare program in Oklahoma and perhaps expand into Northern California, Lowell said.

text:
Oil Service Stocks - Outlook -2-

 

  "The prospects for the service side are very favorable," says George Gaspar, an oil service industry analyst for Robert W. Baird & Co. 

  Oil service companies have undergone a major consolidation since drilling activity peaked in the U.S. in 1981.  Gaspar says renewed activity will provide the opportunity for service companies to cease discounting and extend their margins.  He suggests the activity already generated by hostilities in the Persian Gulf is enough to boost service company revenues by 15 pc to 20 pc and earnings by 20 pc to 35 pc. 

  Gaspar expects to see service companies trading at about 17.5 times 1991 earnings. 

  Analysts say most major oil companies now are in the process of calculating their 1991 exploration budgets assuming an oil price in the low $20-a-barrel range.  The real measure of what 1991 will hold for oil service companies will come when major oil companies decide their budgets in the coming weeks. 

  Analysts say even if oil prices drop from the mid-$30s to the low $20s, benefits will accrue to the service industry. 

  The Soviet Union, long one of the world's leading oil producers, has a decaying production infrastructure badly in need of modernization. Even if those repairs don't come immediately, lost Soviet production will have to be replaced elsewhere. 

  Analysts don't see demand for oil abating soon.  So they project instead new production around the world, some of it from the U.S.  How much will be determined by the economics of oil prices. 

  "I believe the upswing is real," Wertheim Schroder's Simpson says.  "It's going to last a very long time - through most, if not all, of the 90s."

text:
Bundesbank's Tietmeyer Cites Risks Of Fixed Currency Rates

 

  FRANKFURT -DJ- Economic imbalances among European Community nations could go uncorrected if the EC tries to fix currency rates as part of its proposed European Monetary Union, a Deutsche Bundesbank official warned today. 

  "If exchange rate changes are ruled out, authorities lose an important instrument to deal with regional imbalances within the community," said Hans Tietmeyer, member of the directorate of the German central bank. 

  Divergences among EC members relate mainly to "inflationary cost and price trends, excessive budget deficits in some countries and large external imbalances," he said, adding that "deep-seated divergences still remain and are actually widening again in some areas." 

  The concept of European economic and monetary union, with a European central bank at its center, has "widespread appeal," Tietmeyer said.  But he added that he wanted to highlight the potential risks associated with the proposed European monetary system. 

  The speech, which also reiterated the Bundesbank's position that any European central bank must be independent, was delivered at a seminar sponsored by the International Monetary Fund in Washington.  An advance copy of his prepared speech was made available in Frankfurt.

text:
Group Says Oct. Housing Affordability Index Rises

 

  WASHINGTON -DJ- Declines in the median home price and average interest rate and an increase in the median family income lifted the National Association of Realtors' Housing Affordability Index in October to its highest point in more than two years, the association said. 

  NAR's Housing Affordability Index, which measures the ability of a typical family to purchase a median-priced resale home, was 113.4 in October, up from 110.8 in September. At 113.4, the index shows that a family earning the national median income of $35,353 in October had 113.4 pc of the income needed to qualify for conventional financing covering 80 pc of a home priced at $92,800, the median existing-home price for that month. 

  The October index rose due to a change in three major components of the purchasing power measurement - the median resale home price, median family income and the average mortgage rate.  Each change had a positive effect on the index last month.  Not since September of 1988, when the index was 113.5, has it been higher than October's reading. And, prior to that, the index had not been higher than 113.4 since December 1977 when it was 116.0. The October increase in the index this year was the greatest since December 1989. 

  "Objectively, market conditions are excellent, and are at odds with home sales activity," said NAR President Harley E. Rouda. "The missing link is consumer confidence - the housing affordability index indicates that conditions are better than they've been in over two years," he said. 

  "With home prices relatively low right now, and fixed-rate mortgages available at less than 10 pc, the market is ripe for buyers who have been waiting for the best time to buy a home," Rouda, the newly elected 1991 NAR president, said. 

  The September index, now estimated at 110.8, previously had been estimated at 110.9. 

  The October median home price of $92,800 is down from a median price of $94,400 in September, according to the Realtors Association.

text:
Analysts See Bank Of Canada Rate Down 25 Points Tomorrow

 
   By Rose Tamburri 
   Dow Jones Staff Reporter 
 

  OTTAWA -DJ- The Bank of Canada's bank rate is expected to decline by about 25 basis points tomorrow from its current level of 12.01 pc, following a decline in the U.S. discount rate yesterday, money-market analysts said. 

  The expected bank rate drop follows a 15-point decline last week and would bring the rate to its lowest level since February 1989. 

  The bank rate is set each week at 25 basis points above the average yield on three-month treasury bills at the Thursday auction.  It is the rate the central bank charges on loans to financial institutions. 

  Canadian money-market rates are sharply lower today partly because of a one-half percentage point cut in the U.S. discount rate to 6.5 pc, said John McCarthy, chief 

money-market dealer at Toronto-Dominion Bank.   The discount rate is the levy the U.S. Federal Reserve Board charges on loans to banks. 

  Michael Gregory, Royal Bank of Canada economist, said lower U.S.  short-term rates will create "a window for the Bank of Canada" to allow further declines in Canadian rates. 

  "We're in a phase of significant rate declines," Gregory said.  He predicted that Canadian short-term rates will fall an additional 100 basis points over the next two months because of continuing weakness in the Canadian economy. 

  With U.S. rates also declining, the spread between Canadian and U.S.  short-term rates is expected to remain little changed, keeping the Canadian dollar firm, Gregory said.  At mid-day, the Canadian currency was trading at 86.27c (U.S.). 

  Gregory predicted the decline in Canadian short-term rates would continue until February when the inflationary impact of the government's 7 pc goods and services tax is expected to push up Canada's consumer price index.  Then, the central bank will begin to exercise "some caution," Gregory said. The tax will take effect Jan. 1 and is expected to boost Canada's CPI on a one-time basis by 1.25 percentage points. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
Newsprint Prices Seen Weaker As Strikes End In Eastern Cda

 
   By G. Pierre Goad 
   Dow Jones Staff Reporter 
 

  MONTREAL -DJ- The end of lengthy strikes at several large Canadian newsprint mills could effectively wipe out a scheduled Jan. 1 industry-wide newsprint price hike in the U.S. and Canada, analysts and industry executives said. 

  Downward pressure on prices would cheer struggling newspaper publishers and hurt the North American newsprint industry, which is trying gamely to climb out of a cyclical trough. 

  The scheduled newsprint price hike of about 5 pc will probably go through on Jan. 1, analysts and industry executives said.  But after the reopened Canadian mills return to full operations in January, producers will likely have to offer increased discounts from list price or formally roll back the price increase, they said. 

  "The world is going to be afloat in newsprint," said Homer Taylor, vice president, supply at Knight-Ridder Inc. "I can't imagine how the price increase will go through." 

  Led by Stone Container Corp., most major North American newsprint producers announced this fall that they would raise the benchmark eastern U.S.  list price to $720 a metric ton from $685.  Prices were raised by similar amounts in other markets.  A metric ton equals about 2,204.6 pounds. 

  Newsprint producers raised list prices by about 5 pc on June 1, their first increase in more than two years.  They made that price hike stick largely because of the threat of strikes at mills in eastern Canada, many analysts and newsprint buyers argue. 

  Labor negotiations in the eastern Canadian paper industry did turn out to be difficult, and at one point this fall, as much as 15 pc of North American capacity was shut by strikes. Supplies were tight newspaper buyers said, but there weren't any big shortages. 

  This week striking workers at four mills representing about 10 pc of North American capacity signed new labor agreements. 

  Tribune Co. unit Quebec & Ontario Paper's mill at Thorold, Ontario, reopened after a four-month strike. 

  Workers at two big Canadian Pacific Forest Products Ltd. mills, on strike since September and October respectively, ratified new contracts.  And striking workers at a third CP Forest mill reached tentative agreement on a new pact. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
U.S. 3rd Qtr GNP Growth Rate Revised To 1.4% From 1.7%

 

  WASHINGTON -DJ- The nation's Gross National Product expanded at a revised seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.4% in the third quarter, after inflation is taken into account, the Commerce Department said. 

  The department's latest estimate of economic growth in the July-September period, its third and final estimate, was down from the 1.7% increase estimated last month. 

  A Dow Jones Capital Markets Report consensus of 13 economists published Monday found an average expectation that GNP would grow at a 1.7% seasonally adjusted annual rate during the third quarter. 

  The GNP grew at real seasonally adjusted annual rates of 0.4% in the second quarter and 1.7% in the first quarter of 1990. 

  In comparing the current GNP estimate to last month's estimate, Commerce said that a downward revision of its consumer spending estimate essentially accounted for the drop. 

  The U.S. trade deficit widened, the department noted, but that was offset by increased federal government spending. 

  Commerce also said prices, as measured by the GNP-based implicit price deflator, rose at a revised 3.7% annual rate in the third quarter, compared with a 4.0% rise estimated last month. 

  Prices, as measured by the fixed-weight index, rose at a revised 4.2% rate in the third quarter, the same as in last month's report. 

  Commerce reiterated that due to its methodology, the sharp third-quarter increase in oil prices isn't apparent in the GNP price indexes. 

  Following the revision, Commerce estimates third quarter GNP, adjusted to 1982 dollars to account for inflation, at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.170 trillion, compared with $4.173 estimated last month and $4.155 trillion in the second quarter. 

  Before inflation adjustment, Commerce estimates GNP at $5.515 trillion, compared with $5.521 trillion in last month's report and $5.443 trillion in the second quarter. 

  Real final sales, defined as GNP minus business inventories, was $4.165 trillion in the third quarter, compared with $4.168 trillion in last month's report and $4.146 trillion in the second quarter. 

  Third quarter GNP stood 0.4% ahead of second quarter GNP, while second quarter GNP gained 0.1% from the first quarter of 1990. 

  The after-tax profits of U.S.  corporations rose a revised 8.0% in the third quarter to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $179.4 billion, compared to the 6.7% increase to $177.2 billion estimated last month. 

  Third quarter profits before taxes rose a revised 6.4% to a $318.5 billion rate, compared with a 5.4% increase to $315.4 billion estimated last month. 

  Profits from current production fell a revised 1.9% in the third quarter to a $300.7 billion rate, compared with the 3.8% fall to $294.9 billion estimated last month. 

  Net corporate cash flow decreased a revised 2.0% in the third quarter to a $392.0 billion rate, compared with a 3.2% drop to $387.2 billion in last month's report.

text:
OPEC Expected To Continue To Ignore Production Quotas

 

  RIYADH, Saudi Arabia -AP- Oil sources said that the Organization of Oil Exporting Countries is likely to reaffirm its policy of letting oil supplies gush while the Gulf crisis persists. 

  At the cartel's August meeting, called after Iraq invaded Kuwait, OPEC members agreed to ignore production ceilings and quotas to make up for the 4-million-barrel daily loss of Kuwaiti and Iraqi oil, which is being kept off the world market by a U.N.-ordered boycott of Iraq and Kuwait. 

  Saudi Arabia alone has boosted production by about 60 pc, from 5.38 million barrels per day just before the Aug. 2 invasion to 8.3 million barrels per day. 

  Since the invasion, oil prices have fluctuated wildly between $25 and $40 per barrel, well above the OPEC benchmark price of $21 per barrel. 

  Sources here said today the agreement should hold at the cartel's meeting next week. 

  The Organization of Oil Exporting Countries meeting opens Wednesday in Vienna, but ministers are expected to start gathering on Monday for informal discussions. 

  Gulf sources said OPEC is currently producing about 23 million barrels per day, 500,000 barrels over the ceiling agreed to in July.

  The dollar stumbled much of the fourth quarter and several times posted new post-war lows amid concerns about the state of the U.S. economy.  The weakness came despite saber-rattling by both the U.S. and Iraq that subsequently led to some of the highest oil prices in history, and later, war. 

  The dollar, which sank to a low of 1.4625 marks Dec. 10, ranged during the quarter between 1.4625 marks and 1.5645 marks and 123.70 yen to 137.88 yen. 

  Early in the fourth quarter there were concerns about whether a U.S.  budget accord would be forthcoming.  After a budget compromise was hammered out in late October, outright pessimisim about the state of the U.S.  economy also cut the dollar's value, as did market expectations of lower U.S. interest rates. 

  On Dec. 4 the Federal Reserve Board cut banks' reserve requirements on certain deposits, which was in effect a credit easing.  On Dec. 19, the Fed eased again with a 0.5-percentage-point cut in the discount rate to 6.5 pc. 

  During the quarter, the persistant standoff in the Persian Gulf forced crude oil futures prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange as high as $41.15 a barrel in October. The price had slipped to $28.70 a barrel by quarter's end. 

  The surprise resignation of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on Dec. 20 added a fresh dimension to the Soviet Union's problems and helped damp the strength of the mark, which lost more than 3.5 pfennings against the dollar on that day.

text:
Soviet Union Buys 3.72 Mln Metric Tons Of U.S. Corn

 

  WASHINGTON -AP- The Soviet Union has bought a large quantity of U.S.  corn, a day after receiving the go-ahead on a $900 million credit deal, the Agriculture Department said. 

  Private exporters reported selling 3.72 million metric tons of corn and 550,000 tons of soybean meal for delivery to the Soviet Union in 1991, the first year of a new long-term grain agreement signed June 1. 

  Exporters are required by law to report large sales of grain to USDA on a daily basis.  However, no selling prices or other details are provided. 

  Although the announcement didn't say the grain and meal were covered by the new credit guarantee, terms of the deal clearly showed the commodities were eligible for the financing, according to one official who demanded anonymity. 

  Thus, it appeared that a large portion of the $900 million approved for USDA guarantees - the actual loans are handled by private banks - is being used quickly. 

  For example, corn last month was valued at more than $100 per metric ton delivered to export ports at the Gulf of Mexico.  The 3.72 million tons of corn could have an export value of around $380 million. 

  Last month, President Bush announced the Soviet Union would be offered up to $1 billion in credit guarantees to buy U.S.  commodities. In announcing the $900 million yesterday, the USDA said the remainder would be allocated later. 

  The credit package includes $530 million for feed grains, primarily corn; $165 million for wheat or flour; $130 million for protein meals, mostly soybean; and $25 million for poultry meat.  Also, $50 million was earmarked for transportation costs. 

  Under the five-year agreement reached in 1990, the Soviet Union is committed to buy a minimum of 10 million tons of U.S. grain each year. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  January 09, 1991 17:35 ET (22:35 GMT)
label: non-inflation-related

text:
German State Central Banker Sees Scant Room For Rate Boost

 

  FRANKFURT -DJ- Helmut Hesse, president of the state central bank of Lower Saxony, said there isn't much room for an interest rate increase in Germany because of the trend toward lower interest rates in other nations. 

  Hesse, who is also a member of the Deutsche Bundesbank's policy-making Central Bank Council, made his comments in an annual New Year's speech to bankers in Hanover, where the state bank is based. 

  An increase in Bundesbank's offical lending rates could weaken the dollar again, which should be avoided, he said. He added that higher rates would strengthen the Deutsche mark and exacerbate pressures within the exchange rate stabilization arrangement of the European Monetary System. 

  Despite the lack of room for a rate increase, Hesse also acknowledged there are "strong attractions" for such a move, including attracting new capital to finance Eastern Germany.  Higher rates also would help damp strong demand in Germany that could feed inflation and offest the potential inflationary impact of growing wage and salary demands. 

  Hesse's comments contrast with those of other Bundesbank officials.  On Dec. 30, Bundesbank vice president Helmut Schlesinger said higher interest rates might be needed if the mark suffered because of reliance on further state debt to finance German unification. 

  Many Bundesbank watchers expect an increase in the Bundesbank's discount rate in coming weeks, possibly as soon as a scheduled Jan. 17 meeting of the Central Bank Council. The discount rate is the cheapest form of bank refinancing. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  January 09, 1991 10:36 ET (15:36 GMT)
label: inflation-cause-dominant

text:
China Extends Two-Year Austerity Program

 

  BEIJING -AP- A strict austerity program begun two years ago will be extended for another year or more because it has failed to fully achieve intended results, China's government said today. 

  The basis for China's economic upturn is still rather fragile, an official told a news conference.  Some problems are yet to be resolved and others are still far from being resolved, he said. 

  China plans in 1991 to achieve a moderate 4.5 pc growth rate in the gross national product, 3.5 pc in agriculture and 6 pc in industry. 

  At a national economic planning meeting last month, Premier Li Peng told the meeting that the Communist Party suggested the austerity measures be extended into a third year or even longer. 

  Implemented in the fall of 1988 to bring down runaway inflation, the program succeeded in bringing inflation from a high of nearly 40 pc down to 3 pc for most of last year, but economists are warning of a resurgence. 

  Serious stockpiling, continued poor industrial growth and a large infusion of loans despite budget difficulties "might result in potential inflationary pressure," the government said. 

  By the end of last November, China's stockpiles of unsold goods had increased by 30 billion yuan from the beginning of the year. No total figures were released. 

  Official reports have said new loans last year totaled 250 billion to 290 billion yuan, the highest ever in the 40 years of Communist rule.  The loans were made at a time when the budget deficit was estimated at about 10 billion yuan. 

  The massive injection of credit in the second half of 1990 helped boost last year's industrial growth rate to the planned 6 pc, the government said.  But an official report yesterday said some enterprises artificially sped up production to meet the target, merely adding to stockpiles. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  January 10, 1991 13:25 ET (18:25 GMT)

text:
Energy Dept. Sees 5% Yearly Oil Price Increase Over Decade

 

  WASHINGTON -DJ- Deputy Energy Secretary W. Henson Moore said the Energy Department projects an inflation-adjusted 5 pc a year increase in oil prices over the next decade. 

  He said the forecast was based on the probability that world consumption will continue to rise and that oil production won't be able to keep up.  Moore's statement came in response to a question about what the department could do to stabilize oil prices to encourage drilling by independent producers. 

  Moore, testifying before a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on the National Energy Strategy, said the administration's plan doesn't specifically address the price of oil but that research and development on oil discovery should spur more drilling by independent producers. 

  Energy Secretary James Watkins said that he foresees a new emerging relationship with Arab leaders that will help stabilize markets and market projections. He said he expects the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to reassess "what they do in the way of quotas," adding he doesn't expect their actions to result in a fall in oil prices. 

  Separately, Moore said proposed legislation by Rep. Phillip Sharp, D-Ind., chairman of the subcommittee, to set aside a certain amount of oil imports to fill the Strategic Petroleum Reserve might not be helpful. Moore said the department is currently reviewing the legislation, but that "our gut feeling right off the bat" is that such legislation might be more regressive than helpful. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  February 28, 1991 13:07 ET (18:07 GMT)
label: non-inflation-related

text:
Unisys Suspends Its Dividend On Preferred

 

  BLUE BELL, Pa. -DJ- Unisys Corp.  said its board has voted to suspend dividends on its Series A, Series B and Series C cumulative preferred shares "to provide additional funds for our debt reduction effort." 

  The company also said its debt reduction efforts include the sale of non-core assets from a list valued at more than $1 billion. 

  "We and our advisers have initiated discussions with potential purchasers," the company said in a press release. 

  Unisys said it had reduced debt, net of cash, by $600 million in 1990 and has set a goal of a minimum of another $600 million reduction in 1991 through internally generated funds and the sale of non-core assets. 

  A "large portion" of this reduction may come from asset sales, the company said.  Unisys added that it did not know what portion of the non-core asset list will actually be sold this year. 

  The company last paid a 93.75-cent dividend on the series A preferred Jan.  15.  The series B and C shares are all held by Japan's Mitsui & Co.  Altogether the dividends suspended represent an annual payout of about $120 million, Unisys said. 

  "While we made significant progress in reducing debt during 1990, in this weakened and uncertain economic climate suspension of the dividends is a prudent step to provide additional funds for our debt reduction effort.  Debt reduction is central to the progress now being made in implementing strategic product programs and related customer service initiatives," the company said. 

  -0- 

  The decision underscores the depth of the trouble in which Unisys finds itself because of its overly aggressive expansion campaign in the late 1980s.  That can be especially dangerous in the computer industry, where customers depend so much on their suppliers that they get nervous at the first signs of financial troubles. 

  Unisys common stock, which has nearly doubled since Feb. 1 on rumors of possible asset sales, rose a further 50 cents to $4.50 in composite trading on the New York Stock Exchange -- but the move left some securities analysts puzzled. 

  "You have to wonder what the traders have seen in the past few days that those of us who have been following this for a while haven't seen," said Dan Mandresh, a securities analyst at Merrill Lynch & Co. "You can argue about whether the right price is 2 1/2 or 4 1/2, but nothing has changed" in the past few days to account for the stock price's jump. 

  Unisys is within about $200 million of violating a net-worth covenant in a major bank loan, but its banks have so far been supportive. Unisys also reiterated yesterday that it has begun talking with companies that might buy some of its assets and that it has put more than $1 billion of assets up for sale. 

  Unisys cut its debt by $200 million last year, while also increasing its cash by $400 million, and has said it hopes to cut debt by at least $600 million this year. 

  Unisys hasn't identified what assets it might sell, but the speculation has centered on its $2.5 billion-a-year defense business, its one-third share of a large marketing company in Japan or its Timeplex network business. The company also has plant capacity to sell, because of consolidation among its facilities as it has laid off workers. 

  Unisys has been talking about selling assets for several quarters now, however, and the deteriorating economy has clearly made it more difficult for Unisys to get the sort of prices it wants. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  February 11, 1991 15:17 ET (20:17 GMT)
label: non-inflation-related

text:
Bush Wants Fed To Sustain Money And Credit Growth

 

  WASHINGTON -DJ- President Bush, continuing a stream of unrelenting administration pressure on the U.S.  central bank in recent weeks, called for the Federal Reserve to "sustain money and credit growth" as a means of combating the sluggish economy. 

  Lower interest rates alone may not signal easier money in an environment of weak loan demand, his Council of Economic Advisers said, arguing in favor of a stronger expansion of the money supply. 

  The president also repeated assertions that a cut in the capital gains tax and various other revenue concessions are needed as "pro-growth initiatives" to help assure a rebound in the economy later this year.  Depicted lately as wavering on the tax issue, Bush declared himself to be "firmly committed" to lowering the cost of capital. 

  Writing in his annual economic report to Congress, the president argued that the Fed's credibility as an inflation-fighter is sufficiently high that the central bank can now pursue policies adequate to "significantly" mitigate the current economic downturn without engendering fears of a fresh price spiral. 

  The underlying rate of U.S.  inflation was showing "clear signs" of falling at the end of 1990 and price pressures are expected to ease further this year, Bush said. 

  Elsewhere in the report, the president's Council of Economic Advisers maintained that lower interest rates alone aren't necessarily indicative of easier money, but rather may reflect declining demand for credit.  The three administration economists, led by Michael Boskin, called for money supply growth "well within" the target ranges to be set shortly by the central bank for 1991. 

  Easier money policies in the U.S., combined with a recent rise in West German interest rates and firm rates in Japan, have served to put considerable downward pressure on the dollar in foreign exchange markets, but the administration is apparently prepared to live with that situation in the interest of getting the U.S. economy moving again. 

  Bush didn't mention the U.S.  currency in his personal introduction to the annual economic report and his advisers, who wrote the bulk of the lengthy document, only touched on the dollar.  Achieving strong non-inflationary domestic economic growth requires, among other things, "a sustainable trade balance and relatively stable exchange rates," the White House economists said. 

  The G-7 group of major industrial nations, where foreign exchange rate policy has at times been coordinated, was mentioned only briefly - as "a framework within which economic issues of mutual concern can be discussed." 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  February 12, 1991 10:01 ET (15:01 GMT)

text:
J.M. Peters - S&L Stake -2-

 

  J.M. Peters has, since August, put much of its much of its land and its inventory of unsold houses on the block. "We're trying to shrink the company at this point as fast as we can," vice president and chief financial officer Petersen told Dow Jones. 

  "Cash reserves are now at a critical level," J.M. Peters said in its SEC filing. It added that "certain payments may need to be deferred to maintain what cash reserves are available." 

  Cash and short-term investments totaled $15 million at Nov. 30, off from $63.8 million at Feb. 28, 1990.  Losses in the nine months ended Nov. 30 totaled $6 million, or 43 cents a share, compared to net income of $14.2 million, or $1.02 a share, a year earlier. Revenue declined 14 pc, to $161.9 million from $188.2 million a year earlier. 

  Petersen said that housing interest has picked up since the end of November, when the statements for the latest-reported fiscal period were closed. "Sales are continuing to be rather strong," he said. "Low interest rates and buyers' perception that the inventory of available homes is dwindling" have sparked demand, he added. 

  Moreover, the company has been reducing prices on houses in some areas and offering sales incentives on many units. Gross margins have plunged, to 8.8 pc in the three months ended Nov.  30 from 21.3 pc in the similar period a year earlier. 

  J.M. Peters inventory of unsold houses stood at 211 units at Feb. 15, down sharply from 388 completed houses at Nov. 30 but still higher than the 196 completed houses in inventory at Nov. 30, 1989. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  March 19, 1991 15:31 ET (20:31 GMT)

text:
Fed's Forrestal Sees Slower Progress Against Inflation

 

  NEW YORK -DJ- The U.S.  likely will have to accept slower progress against inflation, said Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Robert Forrestal. 

  Forrestal, speaking to the Jacksonville branch of the Atlanta Fed, said that the U.S.  "may need to tolerate slower progress against inflation than we had earlier hoped for" because of the need to reduce the federal deficit. 

  "As a nation, we must devote a growing portion of any expansion we might experience to servicing our debt," but without adding to inflation, Forrestal said. 

  Forrestal said he sees growth in real gross national product averaging 0.5 pc for fiscal 1991. He also expected to see improvement in GNP in the second half of the year, adding that he believes "the recession will be over by the end of 1991." 

  GNP declined at a 2.0 pc annual rate in the fourth quarter of 1990. 

  Forrestal said, "there is little likelihood in the near term that we will return to the kind of performance we enjoyed in the mid-1980s." 

  Forrestal also said he sees the unemployment rate at 6.5 pc by year's end. The jobless rate was at 6.1 pc in January, the last month for which data is available. 

  But the Atlanta Fed president added that inflation will drop back to an annualized 4 pc rate by the end of the year. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  March 01, 1991 07:38 ET (12:38 GMT)
label: inflation-related

text:
4th Qtr GNP Seen Left Unchanged At -2% Rate

 

  NEW YORK -DJ- Fourth quarter gross national product is expected to remain unchanged at a 2 pc annual rate of contraction when the Commerce Departement releases its second GNP revision, according to the average estimate of 13 economists surveyed by Dow Jones Capital Markets Report. 

  Commerce's two inflation measures in the report, the GNP implicit price deflator and the fixed-weight index, are both seen being left unchanged at 2.8 pc and 4.7 pc, respectively. 

  Fourth quarter GNP previously was revised to a negative 2 pc annual rate from the original estimate of negative 2.1 pc. When Commerce made its previous revision, the implicit deflator was left unchanged at 2.8 pc while the fixed-weight index was revised to 4.7 pc from 4.1 pc. 

  Estimates for revised fourth quarter GNP range from a call for 1.6 pc rate of contraction to one call for a 2.2 pc decline. Almost all of the economists surveyed look for the two inflation gauges to be unrevised. 

  Commerce will release its report on second and final GNP revisions Wednesday at 8:30 a.m.  EST. 

  One of the major factors that caused the first revision to fourth quarter GNP, and which is seen as the most likely candidate to create further revisions, is the change in the pace of inventory liquidation in the three-month period. 

  Non-farm inventories in the fourth quarter were revised to show a decline at a $24 billion rate, compared with the original estimate of a $19.8 billion contraction pace. 

  While inventory liquidation is a drag on GNP, it often portends a pickup in growth in future periods. 

  Final sales, which are total GNP minus inventories, and which accounts for about two-thirds of GNP, is expected to have been left unchanged at a tepid 0.7 pc rate. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  March 25, 1991 15:02 ET (20:02 GMT)
label: inflation-related

text:
USDA Says March Farm Prices Rose 2.1% From February

 

  WASHINGTON -DJ- The Agriculture Department said farm prices in March rose 2.1% from February as beef cattle prices soared to record highs. 

  Cattle prices averaged a record $78 a hundredweight, up $1 from February, the Department said.  The previous record was $77, set last month. 

  Steer and heifer prices averaged $81.70 per hundredweight in March, while cows averaged $53.80. 

  Calf prices averaged $106 per hundredweight, eclipsing the old record set last month by $2. 

  The Agriculture Department said fruit prices rose 10% in March, led by price rises for oranges, lemons and grapefruit. Orange prices averaged $7.41 a box, up $1.43 from February. 

  "Higher citrus prices reflected shorter supplies caused by the December freeze in California and also higher-quality Valencia oranges moving to market," the department said in its monthly report. 

  Cotton prices hit their highest level since January 1981, averaging 73 cents a pound in March, an increase of 5.1 cents. 

  Slight rises were also registered by corn, oats, and sorghum as well as rice and wheat. 

  Egg prices jumped 14.8 cents a dozen to 74.9 cents in March as a result of strong seasonal demand, the department said. 

  Milk prices fell to their lowest levels since July, 1988. Milk sold to dealers and processing plants averaged $11.50 a hundredweight, down 20 cents from February and down $2.40 from March 1990. 

  -0- 

  It was the sharpest month-to-month increase in farm prices since July 1988, reflecting very strong demand for cotton and freeze damage to the California citrus crop, among other things. 

  Consumers can expect no respite from high beef prices as meatpackers pass on the costs of buying cattle in one of the tightest markets in memory. 

  "We're at a 10-year low in beef production and close to a 30-year low in total cattle numbers," said Tommy Beall, a livestock market analyst for Cattle-Fax Inc., Englewood, Colo. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  March 29, 1991 15:00 ET (20:00 GMT)
label: non-inflation-related

text:
Arctic Alaska Fisheries Interview -2-

 

  Arctic Alaska Fisheries hasn't seen a decline in regular seasonal demand for its products despite the recession, president and chief executive Jensen told Dow Jones. 

  He said U.S. and foreign demand continues to increase at a 6 pc rate per year, although he said that rate could go as high as 10 pc a year in the next 18 months as consumers become more conscious about cutting fat from their diets. 

  Increased demand is coming at the same time as a shortage of white fish, due partly to demand and and partly to government regulation.  Restaurant chains, such as Red Lobster and Shoney's, that are big customers for the company's products are concerned about the continuity of supply, Jensen said. 

  This is increasing prices for Arctic Alaska, which has about 13 pc of the 4.2 billion pound North Pacific bottom fishing harvest, up from about 10 pc last year. 

  Pollock fillets a year ago were selling for 90 cents a pound wholesale, compared with $1.50 to $1.60 now, Jensen 

said.   "Up to six months ago, it was a buyer's market," he said. 

  Jensen said while demand for fish is up, the industry still has to deal with a resource that is highly regulated by the federal government, which can cause the supply to fluctuate for various species. 

  For example, this year for the first time, the pollock season was divided into two segments, one in the first quarter and the other beginning June 1 until the quota is reached. 

  Cod may also face some defacto regulation this year because other species with a lower government quota often get caught in nets at the same time. 

  "So the by-catch issue is very important to this industry," Jensen said.  "It can affect a major amount of tonnage of other fish." 

  Jensen said the company is coping with the lull in pollock fishing by sending four vessels to the Washington and Oregon coasts in the next two weeks to begin processing whiting into fillets and hake into surimi, a protein base manufactured from bottomfish and used to make such seafood products as imitation crab, shrimp, scallops and lobster tails. 

  The company is also researching the commercial marketing possibilities of other species of fish that aren't in short supply, such as the flounder and the turbot. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  March 21, 1991 15:52 ET (20:52 GMT)
label: non-inflation-related

text:
Bundesbank's Issing Sees No Room To Consider Easing Policy

 

  FRANKFURT -DJ- Following sharp warnings from Bundesbank President Karl Otto Poehl today, another member of the German central bank's directorate, Otmar Issing, said there isn't any room to consider easier monetary policy in Germany at this time. 

  In remarks prepared for address to a bankers gathering outside Frankfurt, Issing remarked that given the ongoing buoyant increases in annual wage increases, "There is no room to allow for a self-reinforcing process of cost and price surges.  There is no consideration of a loosening of the reins of monetary policy," he said. 

  But Issing didn't specifically say German interest rates should be increased either.  In fact many economists don't expect the Bundesbank to boost its rates at this time despite intensifying warnings from monetary officials about potential inflationary pressures in Germany. 

  The official cited continuing labor negotiations in Germany, under which some contracts for 1991 already have been concluded at relatively high increases. Some major unions had agreed on wage boosts this year of 7 pc, or more, compared with an inflation rate that is expected to run between 3 pc and 4 pc. 

  Government and monetary officials have expressed concern over the extent of the wage increases this year, which are nearly double what is considered by some policy makers. 

  Issing asserted that the Bundesbank will continue to follow a monetary policy aimed at keeping the country's M-3 money supply growth in 1991 within a target range of an annualized growth of between 4 pc to 6 pc. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  April 19, 1991 08:22 ET (12:22 GMT)
label: inflation-related

text:
Fed Cuts Discount Rate One-Half Point To 5.5%

 

  WASHINGTON -DJ- The Federal Reserve Board cut its official discount rate to 5.5% from 6%, effective immediately. 

  The Fed said the action was taken in light of continued weakness in the economy, especially in the industrial and capital goods areas, "and evidence of abating inflationary pressures." 

  The central bank also said the reduction "in part" realigns the discount rate with market interest rates. 

  The Fed Board of Governors approved the reduction following requests from the Boston, New York, Atlanta, Chicago and Dallas regional reserve banks. 

  The discount rate is the interest rate the Fed charges depository institutions when they borrow from their district reserve banks. 

  The vote in favor of the fresh 1/2-point cut in the discount rate was 4-1. 

  Fed Governor Wayne Angell dissented. There was no immediate explanation for his negative vote. 

  -0- 

  In conjunction with the move, the Fed also lowered its target for the important federal funds interest rate to 5.75% from 6%. Other interest rates are expected to fall in turn. 

  The Fed's action comes as the Bush administration has begun considering whether to reappoint Alan Greenspan as Fed chairman when his term expires in August. Some administration officials -- including Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and White House Chief of Staff John Sununu -- have been critical of Greenspan because of the Fed's reluctance to cut rates. But administration officials said Bush's praise yesterday is a sign that he is likely to reappoint Greenspan. 

  Officials familiar with the Fed's deliberations say the board has been debating the rate-cutting move for several weeks. Greenspan and Fed Governor David Mullins are said to have become increasingly concerned about signs of continued weakness among manufacturers. But Governors Angell, John LaWare and Edward Kelley were all reluctant to move. 

  LaWare and Kelley finally agreed to the rate cut Tuesday. 

  Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said in an interview Tuesday that he still believes "there is ample room for lower interest rates." 

  Tuesday's action was unusual: The Fed wanted to engineer a small cut in the federal funds rate, but was forced to cut the discount rate first in order to prevent the federal funds rate from dropping below it. The Fed usually keeps the funds rate higher than the discount rate, and Fed officials feared any change in that practice would confuse people in the financial markets. 

  The discount rate is set solely by the Fed governors in Washington. But the more important funds rate is set by the Federal Open Market Committee, which includes the governors plus five of the 12 regional Fed presidents from outside of Washington. 

  In recent months, Greenspan has been under criticism from several regional presidents, who argue that he exceeded his authority earlier this year to alter the funds rate target between meetings of the committee. The Fed chairman skirted that issue yesterday by cutting the funds rate only a quarter percentage point; the directive adopted by the committee at its last meeting on March 26 gave him the authority to cut the rate that much, but no more. 

  Angell reportedly voted against the move because he was afraid Fed easing might increase worries about inflation and cause bond traders to drive up interest rates on long-term bonds. He believes the best way to ensure an economic recovery is to bring down long-term interest rates, which affect the housing market, rather than reducing short-term rates. 

  But the bond markets, at least yesterday, were encouraged by the Fed's move, and long-term rates declined. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  April 30, 1991 09:30 ET (13:30 GMT)
label: inflation-related

text:
Bank Of Canada Outlines Anti-Inflation Goals

 

  OTTAWA -DJ- The Bank of Canada reaffirmed its commitment to its new inflation reduction targets and said it is now taking measures to assure that the goals will be met. 

  Action has to be taken now because of the "long and variable lags" in monetary policy, Charles Freedman, the central bank's deputy governor, told the Canadian Association for Business Economics today. 

  The anti-inflation targets call for the rise in the consumer price index to slow to 3 pc by the end of 1992, 2.5 pc by mid-1994 and 2 pc by the end of 1995.  Thereafter the objective would be further reductions in inflation until price stability is achieved.  In 1990 the consumer price index showed an average rise of 4.8 pc. 

  "We will be keeping a close eye on nominal spending, credit aggregates and monetary aggregates," Freedman said. He said the monetary aggregates are expected to grow "relatively quickly over the coming year" because of a decline of more than 400 basis points in short-term interest rates in the past year. 

  M1 is expected to show particularly rapid growth because it is "very interest sensitive," he said.  M1 includes demand deposits and the public's holdings of currency. 

  Freedman said the Bank of Canada can be held accountable for the inflation reduction targets and doesn't intend to fudge them. "If in two or three years you come back and say you blew it we are accountable for that.  We have said we are going to achieve this." 

  The executive said the central bank was committed to stable  prices because of the benefits it would bring to Canadian business and individuals.  In the past decade, he said inflation has distorted investment decisions and financial markets, eroded savings, and burdened consumers and businesses with new costs.  The 25-year mortgage has disappeared and the long-term corporate bond market has weakened, he said. 

  Freedman said that if some event, such as a major hike in indirect taxes, were to push the consumer price index higher than next year's price target of 3 pc, there would be no upward adjustments of the 1994 and 1995 targets.  "It will make the task tougher, but the key point is we are going to bring it down," he  said.

text:
Trade Deficit With S. Korea Narrows But Frictions Remain

 
   By Carl Johnston 
   Dow Jones Staff Reporter 
 

  WASHINGTON -DJ- The U.S.  continues to charge South Korea with unfair trading practices, but is enjoying the best trade performance with the East Asian nation since the early 1980s. 

  Although Korean trade barriers remain high, and some reports show that frictions have actually increased, South Korea's bilateral trade surplus with the U.S. has been progressively whittled away since its peak in 1988. 

  The reasons are numerous and have more to do with the nations' domestic economy than international factors.  The factors include: the appreciation of the Korean currency, the won; domestic inflation; labor disputes; rising labor costs and a relative slowing of economic growth, according to Renato Amador, South Korea Desk Officer at the Commerce Department's International Trade Administration. 

  "There's really not one factor, there's a whole range of reasons," for the narrowing of South Korea's trade surplus, says Amador. 

  Amador notes that South Korea is in an "evolutionary" phase of its economic development as it begins to increase domestic consumption and labor wages rise.  In the meantime, Gross National Product (GNP) growth has slowed from its blistering double-digit pace in 1986-1988 to a more "moderate" 9 pc expansion rate in 1990. 

  The Commerce Department said that the U.S. had a $39.6 million trade deficit with South Korea in January 1991, continuing a trend of sharp improvement in the U.S. bilateral trade performance.  The U.S. hasn't had a monthly surplus with South Korea since a $1.5 million surplus in April 1983. 

  For all of 1990, the U.S.  had a deficit of $4.1 billion, down substantially from $6.3 billion in 1989 and a peak of $8.9 billion in 1988. 

  Measured in other ways, the U.S.  trade performance has improved even more. The Korean Ministry of Trade and Industry estimates that the U.S.  actually registered a $143 million surplus in January.  The ministry also says that its overall trade deficit widened to $1.6 billion in February, from $573 million in February 1990. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
Bank Of Canada Says On Track To Meet 1991 Inflation Target

 
   By John Urquhart 
   Dow Jones Staff Reporter 
 

  OTTAWA - The Bank of Canada is believed to be on track to meet its 1991 guidepost for inflation reduction, official sources said. 

  The guidepost requires that the rise in the consumer price index by the end of this year be held to less than 4 pc from a year earlier after adjustment for indirect taxes, including a 7 pc goods and service tax introduced Jan.  1. 

  The Bank of Canada set only a provisional inflation benchmark for this year because of the price impact of the new value-added tax.  The government has estimated that the new levy will push up consumer prices by an additional 1 1/4 pc this year. 

  The sources said that after eliminating the estimated impact of the new GST tax and other new indirect taxes, they were reasonably confident that the 1991 inflation guidepost would be reached.  The central bank is expected to announce later this year its estimates of the 1991 price impact of the various new indirect taxes imposed by the federal and provincial governments. 

  The Bank of Canada's formal inflation reduction targets, announced with the Finance Department in late February, call for the rise in the consumer price index to be held to 3 pc by the end of 1992, 2.5 pc by mid-1994 and 2 pc by the end of 1995.  Thereafter, the objective would be further reductions in inflation until price stability is achieved. 

  The sources said the Bank of Canada remains concerned about the potential inflationary impact of Canadian wage settlements.  Major wage contracts negotiated in the first quarter provided an average annual base rate increase of 6.2 pc, up from 5.9 pc in the 1990 fourth quarter. 

  The sources predicted that the level of wage settlements would drop before long.  In the 1981-82 recession, wage settlements showed a sharp decline after four quarters of economic decline, they noted.  The current recession is now in its fifth quarter. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
Kemp Reported Concerned Over Administration Pressure On Fed

 

  WASHINGTON -DJ- Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp, well known for his willingness to publicly criticize the Federal Reserve for high interest rates and an alleged lack of concern about economic growth, is now reported to be in the opposite camp. 

  According to Washington Post columnist Hobart Rowan, Kemp is currently experiencing discomfort over the degree of pressure the Bush administration, in which he serves, is putting on the U.S.  central bank to ease money. 

  "Kemp explained to me," Rowan said in a column published today, "that if policy is limited solely to achieving lower short-term interest rates, it will weaken the long-term bond market, threatening the housing industry, and raising the specter of inflation." 

  "You can't inflate your way to economic growth," Kemp is quoted as saying. 

  In fairness, the "supply side" economic theories to which Kemp unabashedly subscribes, generally envisage steady growth of the money supply.  With a "sound" monetary policy in place, economic growth can properly be stimulated by lower taxes, Kemp and other supply siders maintain. 

  But in practice, Kemp has generally found the Fed off course in the direction of excessive restraint, allegedly as a result of "excessive" concerns about inflation among central bank policymakers. 

  Indeed, the Fed chairman with whom Kemp most frequently sparred was Paul Volcker, who consistently argued exactly what the HUD secretary reportedly now sees at issue: lowering short-term rates too far could be counterproductive if the long end of the market reacts badly to such moves. 

  Do the HUD secretary's currently views presage a shift in the administration's posture? 

  According to Rowan, Kemp admits to "marginal" influence within the administration on such matters. 

  "If I were the Secretary of the Treasury, what I said would be really important," Kemp is quoted as saying.  "But I'm not," he concedes with his usual splash of candor.

  Bank of Canada Governor Crow told the March 22 meeting that Canada's economy was "weak." He cited national accounts data, which showed a 1-pc decline in gross domestic product in the 1990 fourth quarter from the previous quarter. 

  Regarding money and credit aggregates, he said their growth "remained at a moderate pace."

But as market sentiment shifted away from the anticipation of large additional declines in interest rates, the central moved to "a more neutral posture," he said.

text:
May CPI And Core Inflation Rate Both Seen Up 0.3%

 

  NEW YORK -DJ- Apparel and gasoline price gains are among factors seen boosting the Consumer Price Index by 0.3 pc in May, according to the average of forecasts of 16 economists polled by Dow Jones Capital Markets Report. 

  The core rate of inflation - CPI less the food and energy components - is expected to also have risen by 0.3 pc in May, according to 14 of the economists surveyed. 

  The projected CPI advances would be "the biggest gains in the last couple of months," notes Kevin Flanagan, money market economist at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. 

  May's consumer price data will be reported Friday at 8:30 a.m. EDT. 

  In recent months, CPI rose 0.2 pc in April, declined by 0.1 pc in March and advanced 0.2 pc in February. 

  The core rate, meanwhile, increased by 0.2 pc in April, rose 0.1 pc in March and spiked up by 0.7 pc in February. 

  Flanagan, who forecasts a 0.4 pc rise in CPI and a 0.3 pc core inflation rate increase for May, expects that "gasoline 

provided a supporting influence.   Food pressures, apparel, medical care and mass transit fees" also likely boosted the consumer price measures last month, he says. 

  Overall CPI forecasts from 16 economists surveyed ranged from three calls for a 0.2 pc rise to four estimates for a 0.4 pc increase. Of the 14 predictions for the core rate, CPI less food and energy, there were eight estimates for a 0.3 pc upturn and six calls for a 0.2 pc advance. 

  Analysts at Mitsubishi Bank write that "there is a potential for a large 0.8 pc increase in May apparel prices, which could edge up the core rate modestly to 0.3 pc." 

  They add that some of the expected apparel price rise would be offset by a relatively "small increase in food prices following April's hefty 0.7 pc increase." 

  The April food price gains were "heavily concentrated in the volatile fresh fruits and dried vegetables category," the analysts write. "Fresh vegetable prices rose 15.4 pc in April due to adverse weather impacts in California and 'insect infestations' that resulted in some shortages."

text:
Housing Starts Rise In Line With Sales Gains

 
   By Andrew Sobel 
   Dow Jones Staff Reporter 
 

  WASHINGTON -DJ- Housing starts advanced slightly in May, more evidence that the sector has partially recovered from its steep 1990 slide. 

  The modest 0.1% May rise to a seasonally adjusted 982,000 unit annual rate was expected because it follows three months of rising new home sales, says Michael Moran, chief economist, Daiwa Securities America Inc., in New York. 

  Sales of new homes encourage builders to replenish their inventories to meet demand. 

  The May starts pace was slightly lower than the Dow Jones Capital Markets Report consensus, which called for a 995,000-unit rate. 

  Michael Niemira, chief economist at Mitsubishi Bank, Ltd., in New York, agrees with Moran that increased new home sales are spurring starts. 

  The key for builders is that new homes are becoming increasingly attractive to potential buyers when compared to existing homes, Niemira says. 

  "A narrowing of the price gap between new and existing home prices makes the new-home price premium relatively less onerous than it was even six months ago," Niemira says. 

  Over the year ending April 1991, that gap has narrowed to $21,800 from $34,300. In April, the median new home price was $122,000, while the median price of an existing single-family home was $100,200. 

  A rebound in home construction won't be held back by a lack of workers. The industry has lost about one-tenth of its jobs over the past year. 

  Many of those residential construction workers may return to work soon, as builder inventories have declined to 7.4 months at the current sales pace from a high of 9.3 months in January. 

  The Commerce Department revised April housing starts upward to show an increase of 8.2% to a 981,000 starts rate. The April gain was originally estimated at 6.2% and the level at 957,000. 

  The April-May gains in housing starts constitute the first back-to-back monthly increase in starts since June-July 1989, Commerce said. 

  Building permits data included in the starts report provide more evidence that residential construction rebounded in May. 

  May permits rose 7.2 pc to a seasonally adjusted 979,000 annual rate, after a 2.4 pc gain in April to a 913,000 annual rate. 

  The April permits data are unchanged from that released by the Commerce Department late last month.  The department revises permits data about six days after the starts release. 

  About 75 pc of permits in a given month are issued for single-family homes and are thought to be contemperaneous with starts. That means the strong rise in May single-family permits might not translate into a sizable rise in June starts. 

  Multi-family permits, however, do have a long lead time before translating into construction, and there the data signal a busy summer. 

  Permits for structures with five units or more, surely the most beleaguered housing sector the past few years, rose nearly 50 pc in May. 

  The multi-family sector could use a boost, as May starts sunk to their lowest level - 118,000 at a seasonally adjusted annual rate - since Commerce began measuring the statistics in 1963. 

  The despairing May level of multi-family starts is a level "no econometric model would have predicted," says Richard Peach, deputy chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association. 

  "The permit rise is a hopeful sign that maybe, just maybe, this time we've hit bottom." 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
Faster Non-Inflationary Growth Possible, Seger Says

 

  WASHINGTON -DJ- Former Federal Reserve Governor Martha Seger said it's possible for the economy to grow faster without necessarily sparking a resurgence of inflation. 

  In remarks to the Global Economic Action Committee, Seger noted that financial market participants have become "skittish" about the prospects of an economic recovery because they fear a return to high rates of inflation. 

  "As soon as you mention the word growth, people start throwing bonds out the window because of the inflation concern," Seger said. "But that's not the case." 

  Seger also took note of the 25 pc rise in the dollar against the deustche mark over the past several marks and said it has contributed to a slowdown in export growth in a number of areas.  To a lesser extent, she said, the same thing is happening against the yen. She said it is a major concern and added the Fed has something to do with how the dollar performs. 

  Seger said U.S. businesses have become so competitive that they can't necessarily raise prices or sustain price increases for any length of time.  She also pointed out that growing demand could increase operating efficiency of U.S. plants helping keep costs down and reducing further pressure on prices. 

  Therefore, "even if growth is up, it won't necessarily start inflation," Seger said. 

  Seger was also critical of the Federal Reserve's tendency to overreact to inflation worries, saying the Fed should stop equating growth with inflation. 

  Seger said she didn't know whether the Fed will continue to ease monetary policy, but noted that she has always been a supporter of an easier monetary stance.

text:
Recession More Severe Than Govt Data Indicate, Firm Says

 

  NEW YORK -DJ- Current government measures have underestimated the severity of the recession and the rate of inflation last year and so far this year, according to the economic forecasting firm DRI/McGraw-Hill. 

  "I can guarantee that the Commerce Department will announce that the 1990-91 decline in real Gross National Product was deeper and that inflation was worse," said DRI chief economist Roger Brinner in a press release made available here. 

  "The Department of Commerce now uses 1982 as the base year for splitting business revenues between growth in physical output and changes in prices. In November, they will re-base to 1987 values," he said. 

  Based on the current convention, DRI/McGraw-Hill noted that the government projects a cumulative annual decline in output during the recession of 1.0%, compared with a postwar recession average of 2.6 pc. Re-based to 1987, the current recession will appear somewhat deeper, according to Brinner, with a peak-to-trough decline of 1.3%. But even this understates the downturn, he said. 

  Using 1990 as the base year for calculating real GNP yields more accurate results, Brinner said.  "Measured in 1990 dollars, real growth in the fourth quarter of 1990 and the first quarter of 1991 declined at annualized rates of 5.3% and 1.7%, respectively. This implies a recession characterized by a decline of almost 2.0% in output, nearly double the 1.0% currently reported in 1982 dollars." 

  The inflation picture is also worse than government estimates suggest, Brinner said: "In 1990, the price index for all goods and services rose 4.9%, rather than 4.1%, if the benchmark year for evaluating output is shifted to 1990 from 1982. Similarly, the outlook for inflation this year - using the 1990 benchmark - is currently 4.0 pc, not 3.6%. Such differences are significant, given the Federal Reserve's ambition to cut inflation to 2% to 3% per year." 

  Brinner traces the discrepancy between the 1982, 1987, and 1990 base-year values for GNP and inflation to the disproportionate weight given to the computer and related office products sector in the 1982 base-year calculations. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
N.Y. Stocks Rally On Late Programs; DJIA Up 21.02

 
   By Craig S. Smith 
   Dow Jones Staff Reporter 
 

  NEW YORK -DJ- Computer-guided buy programs prodded the market higher late in today's session after stocks took a midday nap. 

  Share prices started the day higher as investors bought stocks after a key inflation report sent yields falling in the bond market. 

  The Producer Price Index for June fell 0.3%, while excluding the volatile food and energy sectors the index was unchanged for the month. Many economists had expected the index to rise, reflecting growing inflationary pressures as the economy lifts from the recession. 

  But stocks soon settled down as a number of weak earnings reports sapped investor enthusiasm.  The Dow Jones Industrial Average, which hit resistance at about the 2,975 issue in its morning, scraped along the 2,950 level through the middle of the day. 

  Trading activity had begun to wane when the program buy programs snapped stock prices out of their slumber, sending the Dow Jones average to its highs for the day.  The industrials ended off those highs with a 21.02 point gain at 2,980.77. 

  Newton Zinder, technical analyst at Lehman Brothers, said the market may be headed to restest its old highs in the week ahead. 

  "The market was helped by the fact that it didn't collapse during the mid-session selloff," said Zinder.  He also noted that the number of advancing stocks held above the number of declining stocks throughout the day. 

  "The market's breadth has held up very well this week, even when the Dow (Jones average) was down," said Zinder. 

  At the close today, 1,017 stocks had advanced in price, while 496 had fallen.  NYSE volume totalled 173.6 million shares, up from 157.7 million shares. 

  Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index rose 3.28 to 380.25, the New York Stock Exchange Composite Index added 1.62 to 208.16, and the Dow Jones Equity Market Index gained 2.92 to 354.81. 

  While the market may well rise back to the top of its recent trading range at 3,035, there are high hurdles to be cleared before stocks can reach new highs. 

  Interest rates and corporate earnings are regarded as the key levers that could lift, or drop, the market out of the range that has held it spellbound since February. 

  Fears that inflation will resurface as the economy recovers have kept long-term interest rates stubbornly high, while the slow-motion recovery hasn't yet produced the corporate profits that could spur the market higher. 

  Inflation fears subsided somewhat today, sending interest rates slightly lower. The yield on the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond eased to just under 8.44%. 

  But earnings have yet to show any evidence of strength. Edward J. Laux, head of block trading at Kidder Peabody, said the market will have trouble making sustainable gains with profit reports arriving in force next week. 

  The final Dow Jones Industrial average close was 2,980.77, up 21.02.  There were 1,016 issues advancing, 499 declining and 553 unchanged. 

  Volume totaled 173,060,000 shares, compared with 157,680,000 shares yesterday. 

  The NYSE Composite index was 208.17, up 1.63.  The average price per share rose 28 cents. 

  American Stock Exchange volume totaled 9,290,000 shares, compared with 9,560,000 yesterday.  There were 308 issues advancing, 234 declining and 229 unchanged. The average price per share rose 7 cents.

text:
Greenspan Reappointment Signals Steady Stance

 
   By Laurence Bauman and Kevin Donovan 
   Dow Jones Staff Reporter 
 

  NEW YORK -DJ- The reappointment of Alan Greenspan as Federal Reserve chairman has eclipsed the impact of politically motivated demands on the central bank to lower interest rates. 

  The reappointment also appears to ensure that the Fed will maintain the gradualistic approach to monetary policy that has become its hallmark. 

  As the recession deepened throughout the fall and winter, the Fed came under criticism from Congress, economists and bond market participants for not easing monetary rapidly or sharply enough. 

  But with the economy starting to rebound, it is becoming apparent that by easing policy slowly and over a protracted period, the Fed avoided putting itself in the position of having to reverse course and tighten policy, which would choke off the recovery. 

  "The Fed hoped that if they stopped easing quickly enough, they wouldn't have to reverse themselves" and start tightening in the early stages of the recovery, says Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. 

  While the economy is showing clear signs of rebounding, "they won't have to change direction because they didn't overdo it in easing," Johnson adds. 

  "They were cautious about easing," and that has contributed to a moderate recovery that currently isn't threatening to fuel a rebound in inflation, says Gary Schlossberg, economist at Wells Fargo Bank, San Francisco. 

  "They're not stepping on the accelerator," says Schlossberg, who expects the rebound to be "a little weaker than the norm" for a post-recessionary period. 

  Moreover, adds Schlossberg, "the political heat is off the Fed," given the reappointment of Greenspan and the Senate Banking Committee's approval of the nominations of Fed Gov.  David Mullins as vice chairman and Lawrence Lindsey as a member of the Board. 

  The addition of Lindsey to the Fed isn't expected to change the central bank's approach to policy. 

  "It's hard to view him as more dovish than Martha Seger," the recently resigned Fed governor, says Johnson.

text:
Greenspan Says M2 Growth- Zero Inflation May Clash

 

  WASHINGTON -DJ- Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan acknowledged that 6.5% M2 growth is not compatible with achieving zero inflation over time. 

  Greenspan conceded this point at a House Domestic Policy subcommittee hearing at which he announced the Fed's provisional M2 growth target for 1992 at 2.5%-6.5%. 

  Subcommittee chairman Stephen Neal, D-N.C., said that target, particularly the upper end, strikes him as totally incompatible with price stability. 

  Greenspan said Neal is correct over the long run. 

  At some point, Fed Chairman Greenspan said, the Fed will make "a final downward notch, a small one" to create the sort of monetary target ranges consistent with eliminating inflation as a factor in the decisions of businesses. 

  Earlier, the Fed chairman indicated that "inflation of 1%-1.5% would be synonymous with zero inflation." 

  Rep. Neal supports legislation, which the Fed has backed, to erect zero-inflation as the appropriate goal of monetary policy.

text:
Officials Fear Iraqi Famine Even If Sanctions Eased

 

  BAGHDAD -AP- One year after the economic embargo was clamped on Iraq, relief officials say they fear famine will devastate the country even if sanctions are immediately eased to allow the purchase of food. 

  Some believe there could be food riots or mass migration within three months. 

  "People are eating bread, and/or rice, and vegetables.  No meat, or maybe meat once a month," said Douglas Broderick, the representative for Catholic Relief Services in Iraq. 

  In addition to shortages and soaring inflation that puts the price of food out of reach for many Iraqis, officials say there is no seed stock to plant crops next year. 

  "I think that at this point we can take no further risks. We have to give priority to the human aspects of this crisis," Bernt Bernander, the administrator of the United Nations humanitarian reielf program, said in an interview yesterday. 

  Broderick said the food being brought in equals just 30 to 50 days worth, in a country that imported 70% of its food before the invasion of Kuwait. 

  He predicted the real crisis would begin in October or November. 

  "You might have food riots.  You might have massive migration. You might have people breaking into store windows to get some food," Broderick said.  "You have an iceberg, and there's nothing in the world to stop it."

Russia Seeks Republics' Input TO Boost Energy Prices

 

  MOSCOW -AP- The Russian Federation, endowed with more than half the Soviet Union's oil and gas reserves, wants to negotiate with other republics an increase in domestic energy prices, according to news reports. 

  The independent Interfax news agency said Russian President Boris Yeltsin made the announcement yesterday to oil workers in the Tyumen region, part of his weeklong tour of western Siberian oil and gas fields. 

  Yeltsin also granted certain Siberian energy producers the right to sell 25 pc of their resources at market prices beginning Sept. 1, a Russian government spokesman said. 

  Some of the profits, estimated at one billion rubles ($1.7 billion) annually in the Tomsk region alone, would be used to build houses and hospitals and help low-income people, the official Tass news agency reported. 

  Interfax quoted Yeltsin as saying he wants oil price talks to begin with other republics after the signing of a new Union Treaty, which would reconstitute the country as a loose federation. 

  Republics refusing to sign will be charged world prices, Yeltsin said. 

  Members of a new Siberian Agreement Association will be permitted to sell up to one-quarter of their oil and gas at market prices, either domestically or overseas, said Leonid Batalin of the Russian Council of Ministers. 

  Batalin said in an interview the Russian government might set limits on the amount of resources that could be sold abroad, to ensure an adequate energy supply within its own borders.

text:
CBO Increases FY92 Budget Deficit Estimate To $362 Bln

 

  WASHINGTON -DJ- The Congressional Budget Office increased its estimate of the fiscal year 1992 budget deficit to $362 billion from its earlier estimate of $294 billion. 

  For fiscal year 1991, it revised its estimate downward to $279 billion from $309 billion. 

  The revision, as expected, were largely in line with the White House's revised budget deficit figures released last month.  Following the release of the figures, which estimated a $348.3 billion deficit, up from its earlier $280.9 billion figure, CBO Director Robert Reischauer said that he expected the CBO revision to be similar to those released from the White House. 

  The CBO and White House revisions both reflected weaker-than-expected revenue estimates, due to an overestimation of personal income. 

  The CBO projects that the total budget deficit will "drop back sharply in 1993," following the 1991 and 1992 increases. Last year's total deficit was $220 billion. 

  The CBO report said that three factors - spending to resolve bank and thrift failures, cost of Operation Desert Storm, and the 1990-91 recession and pending economic recovery - contribute to the "up and down" pattern of the deficit. Excluding the temporary factors, the underlying deficit is projected to stabilize in the range of $170 billion to $190 billion over the next several years, the report said. It went on to say that in relation to the size of the economy, "such deficits are no better than those of the late 1980s and considerably worse than the average of the 1960s and 1970s." 

  The CBO said that its projections assumed that the economy is in a recovery phase, but will be moderate by historical standards, projecting real gross national product of 3.4% in calendar year 1992 and the average of 2.6% per year between 1993 and 1996.  The CBO also projects that inflation would be lower following the recession and that short term interest rates will rise slightly during the recovery. 

  -0- 

  Even though the CBO now foresees a wider deficit in each of the next five years than it did just five months ago, it argued in a new 112-page report that last year's deficit-reduction law is working. "This deterioration in the budget outlook doesn't reflect an erosion of last year's hard-won savings and would have occurred even if the 1990 . . . bill had not been enacted," the CBO said. "Without the spending cuts and tax increases enacted last year, the situation would be considerably worse." 

  The office attributed the increase in its 1992 deficit estimate to changes in its economic forecast, higher costs in the Medicaid health-care program for the poor, added spending in the near term on deposit insurance and less revenue than anticipated. 

  Two-thirds of the changes in the revenue forecasts for the next few years result from the fact that the office now anticipates slower economic growth and a lower inflation rate. The balance reflects its realization that tax collections so far this year are lower than expected. 

  After the administration reduced its revenue forecasts, critics of last year's budget law seized on the changes as proof that the tax increases it ordered were counterproductive.  But in its new report, the CBO attacked this argument, saying that the lower projections for tax receipts reflect a slowdown in personal-income growth that predates the tax increases. 

  The CBO also said it believes the economy "has now moved out of recession and into recovery, but that the ensuing expansion will be moderate by historical standards." 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires
