text:
Analysts See Bank Of Canada Rate Little Changed Tomorrow

 
   By Rose Tamburri 
   Dow Jones Staff Reporter 
 

  OTTAWA -DJ- Signs of an economic turnaround and some high-profile labor disputes are expected to help keep the Bank of Canada's bank rate little changed tomorrow from its current level of 8.78 pc, money-market analysts said. 

  John McCarthy, chief money-market dealer with Toronto Dominion Bank said encouraging economic data, such as the 0.9-pc gain in June's leading economic indicator, plus lingering inflation pressures have made the Bank of Canada more cautious about lowering short-term rates. 

  The bank rate, the levy the central bank charges on loans to financial institutions, is set weekly at 25 basis points above the average yield on three-month treasury bills at the Thursday auction.  The rate fell only two basis points last week. 

  "With signs of an incipient recovery underway, monetary officials have adopted a more cautious stance as they assess wage and price developments," said Bank of Nova Scotia economists Aron Gampel and David Rosenberg. 

  Labor disputes involving Canadian postal workers and government employees also are likely to cause the central bank to "hold the line on further interest-rate declines," said Ted Carmicheal, senior economist at Burns Fry Ltd. 

  Rotating strikes by Canada's 46,000 postal employees entered the 12th day today with little sign of an agreement being reached between the two sides.  The Public Service Alliance of Canada, the union representing 150,000 Canadian government employees, said it will reveal on Friday the date of the anticipated strike by its members.

text:
Bundesbank's Storch Says Mark Hurt By Domestic Factors

 

  FRANKFURT -DJ- Guenter Storch, a member of the Deutsche Bundesbank's directorate and policy-making Central Bank Council, said that the deutsche mark is being hurt by "homemade" factors which also threaten to boost inflation. 

  "The exchange rate of the mark is also being burdened by homemade influences," Storch said.  "Among these are high budget deficits as well considerable problems of adjustment in Eastern Germany," he added. 

  In addition, Storch pointed to the recent rapid reduction of the German current account surplus, which this year slid into deficit after years of record surpluses, as a factor 

undermining the German currency.   He said that the dollar is being helped by "favorable expectations for economic growth in the U.S." 

  Storch also said the Deutsche mark must remain the anchor of the European monetary system (EMS). 

  This comes at a time when key European finance officials are meeting in Brussels to decide on the conditions for the next step in the process of European monetary union. 

  At the world congress of the International Union of Housing Finance Institutions, Storch said that a confidence-building step in EMU would be to give European central banks greater independence from their governments and to make price stability one of their tenets.  He did not make any specific recommendations about the EMU talks. 

  He also repeated the Bundesbank's stance that the mark's anchor role in the European monetary system means that the it must remain committed to preserving price stability. 

  "A committment to preserve price stability in Germany is therefore not only a national, but also a European task," Storch said.

text:
Fed Cut Seen Easing Pressure On Bundesbank To Boost Rates

 

  FRANKFURT -DJ- The cut in the U.S.  discount rate makes it even less likely than before that the Bundesbank will be forced to raise key German interest rates in coming months, economists say. 

  Fears of a German rate increase were already subsiding before the Federal Reserve cut its discount rate to 5.0 pc from 5.5 pc, the analysts said. 

  Western Germany's feverish economy has already begun to cool, while the region's money-supply growth and inflation appear under control, economists said.  Those developments damped speculation that the German central bank might increase its key 9.25 pc Lombard rate again this year. 

  Expectations of a German interest rate cut "had diminished in the last few days, anyway," said Hermann Remsperger, chief economist at BHF-Bank in Frankfurt. 

  "My feeling is that (German) inflation will wane in the coming months as the German economy slows down," said Nigel Rendell, international economist at James Capel & Co. in London.  "Therefore, the chances of another Bundesbank rate increase in the coming months is very small indeed." 

  The move by the Fed will widen the existing spread between U.S. and German interest rates and thus support the Deutsche mark, a factor that will diminish imported inflation into Germany.

August CPI Seen Up 0.4%; Ex-Food & Energy Seen Up 0.3%

 

  NEW YORK -DJ- The consumer price index is expected to have risen 0.4 pc in August, with CPI excluding food and energy prices - the core rate of inflation - seen as having increased 0.3 pc, according to the average estimate of 18 economists surveyed by Dow Jones Capital Markets Report. 

  The overall CPI was up 0.2 pc in both June and July, with the non-food and energy component posting a 0.4 pc rise in both months. 

  The August CPI will be released by the Labor Department Friday at 8:30 a.m. EDT. 

  "The consumer price index, excluding its food and energy components, has not performed as well as the PPI (producer price index)," writes Marilyn Schaja, money market economist at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. The overall PPI was down 0.2 pc in July and down 0.3 pc in June, with the non-food and energy PPI posting a 0.2 pc increase in July, after being unchanged in June.  The August PPI will be released tomorrow. 

  "So far this year, the core CPI has risen at an annual rate of 4.8 pc," Schaja adds. "We expect it to decelerate to 4 pc" by the end of the year. 

  In 1990, the overall CPI rose 6.1 pc, and was up 5.2 pc if food and energy prices are excluded. 

  "The story with the CPI is apparel prices," says Raymond Stone, managing director of Stone & McCarthy Research Associates.  Stone says that apparel prices tend to post sharp increases as the new fall lines are introduced into stores without any discounts. 

  In July, apparel prices were up 0.9 pc, following a 0.1 pc decline the previous month, when summer items were being discounted.  The August apparel price increase isn't expected to be as sharp as July's. 

  Estimates for the August CPI range from increases of 0.3 pc to 0.5 pc, which was the same range for the projections for the non-food and energy CPI.

  TOKYO -DJ- The Bank of Japan  released its prediction that the broad measure of money supply, M2 plus certificates of deposit, would grow between 2 pc and 3 pc in the October-to-December quarter. 

  The prediction follows growth of 2.8 pc in the July-to-September term and 3.7 pc growth in the quarter before that. Japan's money supply growth has been declining steadily since it peaked at 13.2 pc in April and May of 1990. 

  "There has, on balance, not been a significant tightening of corporate financing" arising from the most recent declines in growth rates, the bank said as it issued the prediction.  It said that companies are fulfilling their need for capital by drawing on their own reserves, issuing bonds, or stepping up borrowing from so-called 'non-bank' lenders. 

  The central bank said it would maintain a "cautious" monetary policy stance centered on price stability.  That echoed statements by Bank of Japan governor Yasushi Mieno earlier today to a securities industry group, in which he added that the central bank can't yet be "optimistic" about recent easing in some price pressures. 

  The central bank said Japanese wholesale prices would likely continue to show stability, reflecting low petroleum prices, and an easing of demand pressure due to the slowing pace of economic growth. 

  Slowing money supply growth in Japan may bottom out in October, a Bank of Japan official said. 

  The official was briefing reporters after the central bank released its prediction on t money supply growth. 

  The official said he believes the predicted level of money supply growth won't trigger a sharp economic slowdown.

British Steel To Raise Price Of Basic Products By 4-5%

 

  LONDON -DJ- British Steel PLC said it intends to cut rebates on its basic products Jan. 1, raising prices by between 4% and 5%. 

  The U.K. steelmaker cited the need to maintain investment. 

  The company said it would reduce rebates on hot-rolled coil, and on the products made from that basic product, by 10 pounds to 15 pounds a metric ton.  With rebates, a ton of hot-rolled coil costs customers just under 200 pounds a ton. 

  Competition among world producers to offer ever more attractive rebates has lowered steel prices by 20% over the past two years, according to British Steel.  At the same time, costs have risen by 15 pc, it said, and can be expected to rise further. 

  A big reason is the dollar's strengt in foreign exchange markets. 

  Crucial products that British Steel imports from abroad, including iron and coal, are priced in dollars.  Forward contracts have protected the company so far from the dollar's 12% rise against the pound since January.  But British Steel should feel the full weight of those changes when the protective contracts run out at the beginning of next year. 

  Meanwhile, British Steel needs to invest several hundred million pounds a year to stay competitive, the company said. In July, British Steel said it made capital investments totalling 459 million pounds during 1990-1991 financial year and expected to make 325 million pounds in investments in the current year.

text:
Fed's Parry Says Recession Over, On Path To Recovery

 

  NEW YORK -DJ- Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said "I think that the recession is over and that we're on the path to recovery." 

  Parry, in a speech at California State University, Fullerton, Calif., said the rise in oil prices and the Gulf War, which he identified as the causes of the recession, "are largely behind us now." 

  In addition, he said the drop in interest rates since July of last year "should add strength to economic activity, especially in housing and consumer durables." 

  Also adding strength to the recovery is the lack of an inventory overhang, he said. 

  "We may be getting a glimpse of some of these effects," he said. 

  "Economic activity was roughly unchanged in the second quarter, an improvement over the decline registered in the prior six months. 

  "Although this isn't conclusive evidence, it appears that the economy expanded at a more robust pace in the third quarter just ended." 

  Parry's comments were contained in a text of the speech made available to reporters. 

  San Francisco Fed President Parry says the recession might not "feel" like it's over because the transition to expansion occurs at the bottom of the business cycle when levels of economic activity are low. 

  Also, the recovery "so far has been concentrated mainly in the industrial sector, rather than in the broad services sector." 

  He says the recovery is likely to be moderate because of cutbacks in government spending, overbuilding in commercial real estate, and less credit extension from financial intermediaries. 

  "Naturally, weak bank and thrift credit helps explain why the Fed's main monetary aggregate, M2, now stands at the lower boundary of its 1991 target range," he said. 

  However, Parry also said: "It's too soon to tell how much the reduction in total credit is affecting the strength of the expansion." 

  Turning to inflation, Parry said the drop in oil prices and the strength of the dollar has helped stem the tide, "although a good deal of this may be temporary." 

  "Factors affecting underlying inflation are far more important for the long term. In this area, the situation is uncertain." 

  He said slack in the labor and product markets should restrain growth in labor compensation before long, but he added that "we haven't seen significant improvement in the data yet." 

  "Overall, however, I wouldn't be surprised to see consumer inflation of around 3 pc both this year and next," he added. 

  The Fed's Parry said he expected the economy to grow much more slowly than in previous recoveries, probably around 3 pc in the first year of the recovery. 

  Meanwhile, he said transition periods from recession to recovery are "especially risky times" for policy makers. "For one thing, they're a time when signals often are quite mixed," he said. "They're also a time when it's natural to be overly pessimistic about the strength of the recovery." 

  "This may explain why there have been too many times when policy has eased well after the trough has passed," he said. And when the Fed has been overly aggressive in its easing of monetary policy, "unsustainable growth and eventually painful struggles with inflation" usually follow, he said. 

  Parry emphasized the Fed's role as an inflation fighter, saying that although the Fed "should facilitate the recovery, (it) cannot lose sight of (its) longer-term goal, which is to control, and ultimately eliminate, inflation." 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
First Hawaiian Sees Record Earns Yr; Growth Slows 2nd Half

 
   By Ralph T. King Jr. 
   Dow Jones Staff Reporter 
 

  HONOLULU -DJ- First Hawaiian Inc.'s profit growth in the second half of 1991 won't match the 20 pc clip set in the first six months, but the bank holding company will still post record earnings for the year in part because the mainland's recession hasn't spread to Hawaii, Chairman Walter Dods told Dow Jones. 

  Analysts expect First Hawaiian to earn between $19 million and $21 million, or 60 cents to 65 cents per share, in the third period ended Sept.  30, versus $18.5 million, or 60 cents per share, in the year-ago quarter.  Dods would not comment on these projections, but he said quarterly results, to be released Oct. 17, would also be a record. 

  He noted that "anything over 60 cents a share is record," adding that the company has 5.1 million more shares outstanding now than at this time last year. For the full year, analysts are looking for $82 million to $85 million, or $2.55 to $2.65 per share, compared with $71.5 million, or $2.45 per share, in 1990. 

  Despite a sharp decline in tourist arrivals during the Gulf War, Hawaii's economy will grow 2 pc this year, Dods said. "In the first quarter, the Japanese stopped coming almost overnight, and that has fully recovered." Still, the number of U.S.  mainland visitors continues to lag.  Through July, arrivals are off 5.5 pc, "but that is catching up each month," he said. 

  Meanwhile, hotel occupancy is down about 10 pc to a current 79.5 pc. Dods attributed the slump to roughly 3,000 luxury hotel rooms built in the past year or so. Giant resorts are suffering the most, he said, but precise figures on this category are not available. 

  In contrast to its mainland brethren, First Hawaiian has few problem real estate loans.  Nonperformers total just 0.62 pc of total loans and leases, up from 0.46 pc last quarter. That is a mere blip compared with the industry average of 5.7 pc, according to Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. 

  The low level of problem loans is the result of lending mainly in its own backyard. On a loan portfolio in excess of $4 billion, First Hawaiian has just $73 million in California real estate loans, $7 million of which is nonperforming. "That helps me sleep," Chairman Dods said. 

  Unlike California, "Hawaii's real estate prices, knock on wood, are still holding. But there is a softening on the luxury home and megaresort side," he said. The reason for this is that Japanese investor interest has cooled and Japanese banks have pulled back from the Hawaiian market. 

  Dods said that First Hawaiian's torrid profit growth will abate in the second half because its net interest margin is under pressure. That's partly because lending rates adjust downwards more quickly than the interest rates banks pay depositors. Further, the bank is trying to increase market share, offering a passbook rate of 5.5 pc, versus the 5 pc rate of its slightly larger chief rival, Bancorp Hawaii. First Hawaiian already has 39 pc of the state's total bank deposits. 

  The wave of intrastate mergers currently sweeping the banking industry are driven by the hope of operating cost savings of 35 pc or more. But Dods thinks this expectation is too optimistic, at least at his bank.  Having recently completed the acquisition of First Interstate of Hawaii Inc., First Hawaiian should realize cost savings of just 25 pc, or $12 million annually by 1993, he said.

text:
FOMC Voted For Steady Policy -2-

 

  Minutes of the Oct. 1 FOMC meeting show that at the time the committee members felt that the economic data at the time "was consistent with a continuing though still sluggish recovery in economic activity and that the prospects remain favorable for a sustained expansion at a moderate pace over the next several quarters." 

  But many committee members felt "that the risks to  the expansion appeared to be tilted at least marginally to the downside." 

  Moreover, several FOMC members indicated that they were "uneasy about the potential implications of the ongoing weakness in the broad measures of money and credit." 

  In the committee discussions of the growth of the monetary aggregates and credit, it was pointed out that there had been "a significant restructuring of household and business balance sheets" and that this restructuring was reflected in the monetary aggregates. 

  "Slow growth in broader money and credit did not necessarily indicate that monetary policy was being too restrictive by damping the expansion of incomes or curtailing demands for goods and services," the minutes state. 

  The minutes also show that the FOMC "continued to view the outlook for inflation as favorable" and that the expected moderate rate of economic expansion would "accommodate further downward adjustments in the underlying rate of inflation." The minutes also show that the relatively slow pace of money growth "would tend to foster lower inflation while providing liquidity sufficient to sustain a moderate rate of economic expansion." 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  November 08, 1991 17:00 ET (22:00 GMT)

text:
Discount Rate Cut Shows Fed's Concern Over Economy

 
   By Laurence Bauman 
   Dow Jones Staff Reporter 
 

  NEW YORK -DJ- The Federal Reserve showed how concerned it is about the health of the economy by easing monetary policy in the most visible means available to it - a reduction in the discount rate. 

  The Fed's move pushed the discount rate to 4.5% from 5%, where it had stood since Sept.  13. 

  The move comes only a week after the Fed eased policy by lowering the Federal Funds rate 25 basis points to 5%, and implies that the Funds rate will be lowered by an additional 25 basis points, analysts say. 

  The move was widely anticipated, although the timing caught market participants by surprise, coming as it did in the middle of a Treasury refunding. 

  "I think it's unprecedented," to cut the discount after the start of a quarterly refunding, says Stephen Slifer, economist at Lehman Government Securities. 

  Nonetheless, "it should have happened, and is a bit overdue," he adds. 

  "This keeps (the Fed) on track toward lower rates, and until there are signs of economic strength, it will continue," says Slifer. 

  "The question is whether we're at 4.75% on Funds," says Henry Engler, economist at Chemical Bank. "My guess is that we are." 

  Almost every policy shift by the Fed under the leadership of Chairman Alan Greenspan has involved a 25-basis-point move in the Funds rate, including last week's move down to 5%. 

  Federal Funds currently are changing hands at 4.75%, after opening the day at 5%, prior to the discount rate cut announcement. 

  The pace at which the Federal Reserve has instituted policy easings has clearly been increased, reflecting the central bank's growing concern about the economy's ability to sustain its faltering recovery from recession. 

  Today's discount rate cut comes only a week after the Fed lowered the Federal Funds target to 5%. Many of the Fed's previous easings had come with intervals of at least a month. 

  If, as is widely expected, the Fed's new Fed Funds rate target is 4.75%, "that gives us 50 basis points in two weeks," says Slifer of Lehman.  "They have speeded up the pace." 

  Since late summer, when the economy showed signs of rebounding, market participants viewed each easing of monetary policy as the last move the Fed would need to make. 

  But that perception has changed, and there is a growing outlook that the easing of policy undertaken today will be followed by other moves toward lower rates. 

  "I think we have more cuts in store," adds Slifer. 

  He contends that as long as the Fed Funds rate is above the rate of inflation, "it is not terribly stimulative." 

  Slifer says the Funds rate could eventually move as low as 3%. 

  "The view that the economic recovery looks a good deal more uncertain is a major contributor" to the perception that the Fed will have to ease further, says Engler of Chemical Bank. 

  But Engler doubts the next move will come imminently. 

  "The Fed will certainly want to adopt a wait-and-see approach" before easing again, Engler says. "They'll want to see how the fourth quarter will shape up." 

  Engler also says there is a potential roadblock to further Fed easing. If "the fourth quarter continues to come in poorly, there will be a tendency (by the Bush Administration) to move toard fiscal stimulus. That may keep the Fed from doing anything more on the policy front," he says. 

  The combination of a tax cut with huge budget deficits and an easier monetary policy is widely seen as a sure-fire means of fueling inflation. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  November 06, 1991 09:34 ET (14:34 GMT)
label: inflation-related

text:
U.K. Oct. Producer Output Prices Rose 5.2% From Yr Ago

 

  LONDON -DJ- British producer output prices rose an unadjusted 5.2 pc in October from a year earlier and 0.2 pc from September, while producer input prices fell 1.7 pc from a year ago but rose 0.6 pc from September, the U.K.  Central Statistical Office said. 

  Market forecasters had expected output prices to rise 5.3 pc from a year ago and 0.3 pc from September.  Input prices were seen fallen 0.2 pc from September. 

  After seasonal adjustment, input prices rose 0.4 pc in October from September and were down 1.8 pc from October 1990.  That compares with September's 0.4 pc monthly fall and 2.9 pc yearly fall and forecasts for a 0.1 pc monthly rise and 2.2 pc year-on-year fall. 

  Output prices, excluding food, tobacco and drink, rose 0.2 pc an unadjusted basis in October from September and were up 4.2 pc from a year earlier. 

  The statistics office noted that the 4.2 pc rise was the lowest since April 1987, when it also rose 4.2 pc.  The year-on-year rate peaked at 6.5 pc in January and February this year. 

  The Treasury welcomed the slowdown in output price inflation, noting that the decline in the year-on-year rate for all manufacturing to 5.2 pc from 5.7 pc in September was the biggest monthly fall observed since March 1986. 

  The Treasury suggested that the sharp fall in output price inflation shows that underlying inflation pressure in Britain is continuing to decline.  It added that this should feed through into further reductions in retail price inflation over the coming months. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  November 12, 1991 07:32 ET (12:32 GMT)
label: inflation-related

text:
Bundesbank - Inflation -2-: Threatens Growth, Employment

 

  FRANKFURT -DJ- In yet another warning to Germany's labor unions, the Deutsche Bundesbank said wage-driven inflation in 1992 could be "hard to combat and demands all the more harsh retaliation." 

  "The few demands for the round of 1992 wage talks that we know about are in the same dimensions as in 1991, although the economic environment - in part because of wage increases - has considerably worsened," the German central bank said in its December monthly report. 

  "With the slowing of growth there isn't as much room to distribute (profits) as in there was in the previous two years," it added. 

  Year-on-year wage growth was around 6.5 pc-7 pc in November, the Bundesbank noted. Consumer prices were up around 4 pc in November. 

  While warning the "wage talk partners" that Western Germany's economic growth has slowed, the Bundesbank said it "wouldn't be correct to speak of recessionary tendencies." 

  Viewed over the long term, production at many Western German companies is going stronger than average, and employment is relatively healthy, the Bundesbank noted. 

  But in a broad context, a wage-price spiral "doesn't just bode risks to price stability; even in the medium-term it dampens prospects for growth and employment as well," it said. 

  The Bundesbank called on employers and unions to avoid the continuation of a wage-price spiral and build a "solid basis for long-term, stress-free economic growth." 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  December 18, 1991 08:18 ET (13:18 GMT)

text:
Morgan Stanley Japan Unit To Co-Lead NTT Domestic Debt Issue

 

  TOKYO -DJ- Nippon Telegraph & Telephone Corp., Japan's telecommunications giant, said it plans to include Morgan Stanley Group Inc.'s Japanese unit as a co-leader of a domestic debt issue. 

  This is apparently the first time that a foreign securities house will co-lead a domestic issue for a major Japanese borrower. 

  Morgan Stanley will help lead the issue with Nomura Securities Co. to help NTT start to price its bonds more in line with the market rather than relying on set prices from securities houses that in turn have to selectively discount the paper to retail it. 

  The new kind of pricing, in use in Europe and the U.S., may help introduce transparency as well into the Japanese corporate bond market to help lure issuers and investors back from the Euromarket. 

  However, efficient pricing and greater participation from investors are necessary to increase the local market's capacity, dealers contend. 

  NTT's offering of domestic bonds is likely this week, John S. Wadsworth Jr., president of Morgan Stanley Japan Ltd., said. 

  The size and maturities of NTT's past domestic issues suggest an offering would be in the range of 50 billion yen approaching 10-years. The floatation would introduce "negotiated fixed-price reoffering" to Japan's domestic corporate straight-bond issue market. 

  Nomura Securities Co. will "run the book," or keep track of the syndication, for NTT's issue. 

  In the U.S. and Europe, underwriters check demand before pricing an issue, then offer the issue at one price to all investors for an initial term. 

  Currently, in Japan the lead manager bids to the issuer for an offering, then places it at varying prices, often selectively discounted. 

  -0- 

  The NTT bond issue is also a coup for Morgan Stanley Group's Morgan Stanley & Co. 

  "Up until now it has been hard for us to determine the appropriate price for our bonds," said Toyoaki Ukita, senior manager for NTT's finance division. "The fixed-price method will make things clear.  If that encourages more investors to buy NTT bonds, it will minimize our long-range capital costs." 

  Morgan Stanley and Nomura will each receive a 30%, or 15 billion yen, share of the offering. Morgan has never had more than a 1% share of a straight Japanese domestic bond issue. 

  The success of the issue will be tested as early as Wednesday, when underwriters are expected to begin selling to investors. But longer-term evaluation will depend on whether the bond is traded among investors in the secondary market. 

  Other managers in the NTT syndicate include Yamaichi Securities Co., Daiwa Securities Co., Nikko Securities Co., Kankaku Securities Co., New Japan Securities Co. and Kokusai Securities Co. The 25 other syndicate members with smaller shares include five other foreign securities houses: Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd., S.G.  Warburg Securities Japan Inc., Goldman Sachs (Japan) Corp., Merrill Lynch Japan Inc.  and Paribas Capital Markets Ltd. 

  Because the companies don't discount the bonds, the 0.65 yen commission that underwriters charge for each 100 yen of face value may actually result in greater commission revenue than Japanese securities houses have usually seen from corporate bond underwriting. 

  Ukita expressed confidence in the proposed offering's success but acknowledged the risk that investors in Japan may not immediately take to the fixed-price system. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  December 09, 1991 09:22 ET (14:22 GMT)
label: non-inflation-related

text:
T. Rowe Price's Boltz Sees Inflation Steady-Lower In '92

 

  NEW YORK -DJ- This year's good news is that inflation is down and next year it should be steady to lower, says Paul Boltz, financial economist at T.  Rowe Price Associates Inc. 

  The inflation decline "is about the only good that comes out of recessions," he says.  Excluding food and energy, in 1990 the consumer inflation rate was 5.2 pc and so far this year it has been 3.9 pc - the decline coming as a result of falling energy prices. Boltz says "unless the economic recovery is much weaker than we anticipate inflation next year should be in the 3 1/2 to 4 pc area." 

  T. Rowe Price expects that real Gross National Product on a fourth quarter-over-fourth quarter basis will be virtually unchanged this year and will grow about 2 3/4 pc in 1992. "This would be roughly half the growth of other post-World War II recoveries", Boltz said. 

  Looking forward, "we believe the sluggish recovery will feel much like a recession through mid-1992. None the less, we think that consumers will gradually emerge from the gloom, as they always do, and the economy will resume more normal growth in the second half of next year," the T. Rowe Price economist said. 

  Boltz added that unless the recession impacts inflation more than expected, the Federal Reserve will return to a modest credit tightening pattern in the second half of 1992. Boltz was speaking at a T. Rowe Price Associates Inc. 1991 Investment/Economic Outlook seminar. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  December 03, 1991 12:07 ET (17:07 GMT)
label: inflation-related

text:
OECD, UK -3-: Sees Improved Prospects For Low Inflation

 

  Since the third quarter, the OECD said the prospects in the U.K. for attaining sustained low inflation have improved as wage settlements dropped to levels below those of the early 1980s, when unemployment was considerably higher. 

  The growth of productivity has also picked up despite falling output, the study said, allowing for a "slight decline" in manufacturing unit labor costs. 

  "The drive by industry to contain costs and moderate wage claims in response to lower inflation seems to represent changes in attitude," the OECD said.  "Such changes are consistent with maintaining sterling's central rate within the EMS and could mean that the output and employment losses associated with achieving low inflation will be significantly smaller than in the past." 

  Meanwhile, the OECD said macroeconomic policy "remains oriented" towards keeping sterling within its exchange rate mechanism bands and to the attainment of "durably low" inflation. 

  The report said the government's March 1991 budget was "broadly neutral" in cyclically adjusted terms, with a projected swing into a small deficit into fiscal year 1991-1992. 

  Meanwhile, the OECD said the government's latest autumn spending statement raised planned expenditure, including privatization proceeds, for the current fiscal year and will increase the share of general government expenditure in GDP by two percentage points over the two years to fiscal year 1992-1993. 

  "Monetary policy remains tight," the report said.  "The drop in base lending rates to 10.5 pc in August 1991 largely reflected coincident falls in inflation." 

  The report went on to note that sterling has remained close to its central 2.95 Deutsche mark rate in the ERM over the past year. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  December 19, 1991 14:55 ET (19:55 GMT)
label: inflation-related

text:
WSJ:Brazilian Currency Slide Is Halted Tues By Rise In Rates

 
  By Peter Fritsch 
  Staff Reporter of The Wall Street Journal 

  SAO PAULO, Brazil -- The worrying slide of Brazil's currency stopped abruptly after the nation's central bank boosted interest rates in an effort to attract investment and discourage a spike in inflation. 

  But the situation remained tense, as thinly traded markets focused their attention on a key congressional vote scheduled for this afternoon and the political implications that higher interest rates could have on an economy already in deep recession. 

  After losing ground early, Brazil's currency, the real, rallied to finish its third day as a free-floating currency at 1.56 reals to the dollar, stronger than Monday's close of 1.59 reals to the dollar. The Brazilian currency has lost 22% of its value against the dollar since the central bank first moved to devalue the real a week ago. The Sao Paulo Stock Exchange's key Bovespa Index closed 267 points, or 3.8%, higher at 7380 in light trading. 

  Stocks have risen thanks in part to bottom fishing by foreign investors as share prices, quoted in dollar terms, traded at deep discounts. Indeed, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co. said it was increasing its Brazil position in its model portfolio by unwinding positions in Chile and Peru. Stocks also rose on anticipation of congressional passage of an important pension-reform bill today. 

  Late Monday, Brazil's monetary policy committee raised the ceiling on benchmark interest rates to 41% from 36%. The central bank immediately backed up that move, lending overnight funds to banks at 32% yesterday, up from 29.8% Monday. Futures markets indicate rates could soon shoot up to 39%, near the 39.75% rate at which the Treasury sold one-year paper yesterday. Brazilian consumers pay annual interest rates of more than 100%. 

  The rate increase made good on Finance Minister Pedro Malan's promise earlier Monday that Brazil would defend its currency with higher rates -- at least for the short term. That action was supported by the International Monetary Fund and encouraged by Brazilian economists who feared President Fernando Henrique Cardoso might try to drop rates precipitously to gain political points with Brazil's badly bruised business establishment. 

  Mr. Malan is expected to elaborate on his policy plans today at a breakfast hosted by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Among the commercial and investment bankers expected to attend are senior executives from Citigroup Inc., Chase Manhattan Corp., J.P. Morgan & Co. and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. 

  Because of a fat budget deficit, Brazil has external borrowing requirements estimated at more than $55 billion this year and needs to maintain rates attractive enough to coax that money from beyond its borders. Yet dollars keep leaving the country, even after the central bank said Friday it would stop spending its own hard currency cache to support the real. 

  Since then, dollar outflows are on a pace to average about $6.5 billion a month -- enough to wipe out Brazil's current dollar reserves by August (not including future disbursements from the remaining $32.5 billion in bailout funds available from the IMF and other lenders). 

  It isn't unusual for a country to raise interest rates following a currency devaluation in order to stem an outflow of hard currency. In Brazil's case, higher rates also represent a badly needed bridge between the shock of a change in exchange-rate policy and the so-far elusive return of investor confidence. Investors say the only way Brazil can shore up confidence is by delivering badly needed fiscal reforms. 

  Yesterday, Brazil's Senate voted as expected to increase and extend a tax on banking transactions -- a cornerstone of budget savings promised the IMF. That measure still needs to be approved in the lower house of Congress, where Mr. Cardoso has faced the most legislative resistance to reform. 

  A far greater test comes today, when Congress is scheduled to vote on a controversial measure to begin taxing retirees to shore up a bankrupt pension system. That measure has failed four times during the past four years, and an administration victory would be worth a lot more than the planned $2.6 billion in budgeted savings this year. 

  "The importance of this vote for investor confidence and the real is hard to overstate," said Mauro Schneider, economist for ING Barings in Sao Paulo. Most analysts believe the government has the votes to pass the measure and will then aim to pass enabling legislation allowing states to reduce their bloated payrolls. 

  With such reforms under his belt, Mr. Cardoso will come under intense political and fiscal pressure to lower interest rates over the medium term. Not only do high rates tighten the stranglehold on the economy, but they also build on the government's massive domestic debt -- two thirds of which is indexed to interest rates. "I think the pressure to lower interest rates will come more from the fiscal end than from the political end," said Jair Ribeiro, managing director of Banco Patrimonio de Investimento SA in Sao Paulo. 

  Officials here have said unofficially they hope to be able to drop overnight rates to below 20% by the end of March. Buttonholed by reporters, Central Bank President Franciso Lopes said the latest rate increase is only meant to be temporary. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  January 19, 1999 20:10 ET (01:10 GMT)
label: inflation-related

text:
NZ Birch Sees Favorable Exchange/Interest Rate Mix Remaining

 

  WELLINGTON (Dow Jones)--New Zealand Treasurer Bill Birch said Tuesday the current mix of the New Zealand dollar exchange rate and interest rates appears likely to remain favorable for "some time" ahead. 

  Birch, in an economic briefing to New Zealand-based law firm Chapman Tripp, said lower interest rates and a lower currency exchange rate are the key factors behind a recovery in the New Zealand economy. 

  "The mix of exchange and interest rates appears favorable for some time ahead. As Treasurer, I am not about to predict the path for either the dollar or mortgages, but the Reserve Bank (of New Zealand) has signaled that monetary conditions will remain easier for some time and the latest consumer price index figure will help this," Birch said. 

  Inflation data for the fourth quarter of 1998 was much lower than economists had expected. The key consumer price index minus credit costs fell 0.1% from the third quarter, whereas economists' median expectation had been for a 0.4% rise. 

  The Reserve Bank of New Zealand had projected in November fourth quarter inflation would be 0.5% and the sharply lower number encourages the market to belief that any tightening in monetary policy can be further deferred. 

  Birch noted the New Zealand dollar versus the U.S. dollar has dropped from a high of over US$0.70 in early 1997, to less than US$0.50 in (August) 1998 to around US$0.54 now. 

  "That makes our goods much cheaper overseas and easier to sell and is why we have seen a huge pick-up in trade," Birch said. 

  He said economic data delivered through December 1998 and in January 1999 confirmed that, while the first half of 1998 was difficult, growth resumed strongly in September with New Zealand now having an excellent foundation for continuing growth. 

 

  (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires

  January 25, 1999 23:30 ET (04:30 GMT)

text:
WRAP/Brazil's/Real -2: Odds On Permanent Free-Float

 
 

  Markets have now turned their attention to what permanent forex system Brazilian authorities will adopt and where the real will finally settle. 

  Finance Minister Pedro Malan, Central Bank President Francisco Lopes and top U.S. and International Monetary Fund authorities will gather in Washington over the weekend to discuss policy options. Although the Central Bank said it would release a communique Monday, there was some speculation an announcement would be made late Sunday to clear the air before markets open. 

  Most economists rule out the possibility of the Central Bank even attempting to return to the sort of rigid system that Brazil had clung to for the past four years. 

  Rather, they say the Central Bank will either stick to the free float or adopt an extremely wide band for the real. 

  'If I had to flip a coin, I'd say they're likely to go to flotation,' said Walter Stoeppelwerth, strategist for Robert Fleming Inc in Sao Paulo. He said arguments in favor of a wide band - which he put in the range of BRR1.35 or BRR1.40 to BRR1.70 - are to help establish expectations for interest rates and inflation. 

  Henry Willmore, senior economist at Barclays Capital in New York, said a free-float had been widely expected and would be well-received. 

  'Actually doing it sooner is a lot better because they haven't used all of their IMF money to defend the currency and can instead use it to manage the aftermath of the float,' Willmore said. 

  Brazil signed an agreement with the IMF in November to receive $41.5 billion in funds from international lenders. 

 

  (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires

  January 15, 1999 10:59 ET (15:59 GMT)
label: inflation-related

text:
Malaysia Petronas/Output -2: Peg Eases Impact Of Low Prices

 
 

  KUALA LUMPUR (Dow Jones)--Malaysian national oil and gas corporation Petroliam Nasional Bhd. (P.PET), or Petronas, has no immediate plans to cut oil production even as it faces the lowest oil prices in 12 years, President and Chief Executive Mohd. Hassan Merican said Wednesday. 

  "At the moment, we're not considering any reduction of (oil) production for the country," Hassan said in a news conference. 

  Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad recently suggested that Malaysia may cut its oil production due to low oil prices. 

  Hassan added that as a small contributor to the world oil market, the company will continue to produce at its current level of around 630,000 barrels per day, of which 400,000 are for export. 

  Hassan noted that in ringgit (MYR) terms, the impact of the low oil prices on Malaysia is cushioned by the country's fixed exchange rate. 

  Capital controls imposed Sept 1., 1998, prohibited offshore trading of ringgit, effectively pegging the Malaysian currency at MYR3.80 to the U.S. dollar. 

  The policy was crafted to allow Malaysia's economic planners to pump more liquidity into the recession-hit economy without undermining the stability of the currency. 

  The ringgit can now only be exchanged on the current account for trade-related purposes.

text:
Greenspan Calls Econ Outstanding But Sees Overheating Risk

 
 
   By Joseph Rebello 
 

  WASHINGTON (Dow Jones)--Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan warned Wednesday the U.S. economy is in danger of overheating despite a global economic slump, suggesting the central bank isn't likely to cut interest rates again this year. 

  In testimony to the House Ways and Means Committee, Greenspan said the U.S. economy produced an 'outstanding' performance in 1998, generating a rare combination of torrid growth and low inflation. But he said it must be cooled a little to ensure continued growth. 

  'Through the end of 1998, the economy continued to grow more rapidly than can be currently accommodated on an ongoing basis,' Greenspan said in prepared remarks. As a result 'some moderation in economic growth...might be required to sustain the expansion.' 

  The U.S. economy is expected to have grown at a 3.75% rate in 1998, resulting in the longest peacetime expansion in U.S. history. That performance, bolstered by three Fed rate cuts, has stirred many Fed policy makers to warn that the growth could stoke inflation. Most economists, as a result, no longer expect the Fed to cut rates again this year. 

  Greenspan's testimony reinforced those expectations. Appearing before a Congressional committee for the first time since September, Greenspan said economic growth has shrunk the supply of U.S. workers willing to work who don't have jobs, a trend that could push labor costs up. Moreover, he said, the rise of U.S. stocks in recent months, which has contributed to economic growth, may be unsustainable. 

  'Everything he said suggested the Fed is going to be on hold for the remainder of the year,' said Josh Feinman, an economist with Bankers Trust in New York. 'The Fed has a pretty even balance of risks going forward: With the economy strong and financial markets stabilizing, the Fed wouldn't dream of easing (interest rates). At the same time, with inflation subdued, a tightening isn't on the table either.' 

 

  (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
U.S. Retail Gas Prices Fall One Penny Per Gallon - Lundberg

 
 

  CAMARILLO, Calif. (AP)--Gasoline prices plunged nearly a penny per gallon over the past two weeks, and they could go lower, says an industry analyst said Sunday. 

  The average price, including all grades and taxes, was $1.0141 per gallon on Friday, down .94 cent from two weeks earlier, according to the Lundberg Survey of 10,000 stations nationwide. 

  When adjusted for inflation, that is the lowest price in the history of the retail gas market and follows months of declines linked to an oversupply of crude and refined oil products, Trilby Lundberg said Sunday. 

  "The bigger picture does not suggest higher prices soon. In fact, the price crash may not be over," she said. 

  The faltering world economy weakened demand, she said. "It had to do especially with the Asian economic crises, followed by those in Russia and parts of Latin America." 

  The winter driving season in the U.S. also had lessened demand. 

  Retailers have responded by cutting their profit margins "in order to chase sales," Ms. Lundberg said, adding that such reductions accounted for about half of the latest decline. 

  While bad news for gas station owners, the drops may help the overall economy, she added. "Low prices may be indirectly encouraging retail sales of goods and services in general by encouraging consumers to drive." 

  Average prices at self-service stations were 95.26 cents per gallon for regular gasoline, $1.0634 for mid-grade and $1.1487 for premium. 

  Full-service prices were $1.4155 for regular, $1.5075 for mid-grade and $1.5799 for premium. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
WSJ: Shareholder Scoreboard: Best- And Worst-Performing Companies: Best 1-Year Performer: Amazon.com Inc.

 
  By George Anders 
  Staff Reporter of The Wall Street Journal 

  Amazon.com Inc.'s headquarters are just above a discount clothing store in a somewhat seedy part of Seattle. The company's chief executive officer works at a makeshift desk assembled from a plywood door and some metal brackets. Losses last year topped $100 million, and top officials warn of more red ink this year. 

  If you think those traits make Amazon a stock-market flop, guess again. Last year Amazon shares surged 966%, the most of any of the 1,000 companies tracked in The Wall Street Journal's Shareholder Scoreboard. An investment of just $1,000 at the end of 1997 would have ballooned to $10,664 12 months later. Along the way, Amazon has become the archetype of an Internet success story: a company willing to post hefty losses while it achieves explosive growth in the brave new world of electronic commerce. 

  By the end of last year, more than six million people had visited Amazon's Web site and purchased books, music or videos. With a few clicks of a computer mouse, they picked out their favorites and then typed in their credit-card numbers as payment. Those orders whizzed into Amazon's warehouses, which then shipped the goods via mail or private shippers. All of a sudden, consumers had a new way to shop, without ever leaving the house or talking to a sales clerk. 

  For Jeffrey Bezos, Amazon's CEO, 1998 was the year his five-year-old way of doing business went from a minor high-tech curiosity to a part of mainstream American culture. "Last year was all about comfort and familiarity," he says. "People realized that shopping online wasn't just a novelty. It was a way of saving time and saving money." 

  Amazon's most explosive growth came just before Christmas, when stressed-out shoppers decided that point-and-click at their home computers was a lot more fun than pushing and elbowing at the mall. "It was a very good period for people to try us for the first time," Mr. Bezos says. Amazon achieved nearly 40% of its 1998 sales in the fourth quarter, as business nearly quadrupled from the year-earlier pace. 

  In most other industries, investor enthusiasm about Amazon's soaring sales would be tempered by severe worries about profitability. Bookselling in general is a low-margin business, as big merchants compete largely by offering customers sizable discounts to list price. Amazon opted to keep its prices low so it could pull in customers. That left little cushion to cover its overhead or massive marketing spending aimed at drawing new customers. 

  As an Internet-commerce play, however, Amazon has enjoyed wide leeway from investors to run up losses in the name of building sales and brand recognition. The opportunities to grab a commanding lead in cyberspace are too big to be passed up in the name of a short-term focus on profits, says Henry Blodget, an analyst at CIBC Oppenheimer Corp. "I don't think {Amazon} will turn profitable until 2001 -- and they're right to do it that way," he says. 

  Skeptics argue that Amazon's losses may have no clear end in sight. Although Amazon was the first online bookstore, it now has dozens of rivals, including heavyweights such as Barnes & Noble Inc. and Wal-Mart Stores Inc. Meanwhile, a relative newcomer, Buy.com Inc., has vowed to undercut Amazon's prices on all titles. 

  So far, Amazon has kept its dominant position in online bookselling while sales have grown rapidly in newer markets such as music, videos and overseas markets. But operating margins in those new sectors are even slimmer than in the domestic book market. Looking ahead, Amazon says it wants to offer customers an even wider range of goods online; it won't say whether it will make acquisitions or merely provide electronic links to other merchants. 

  At the very least, Amazon has bought a lot more time to continue its experiments. In January, the company sold $1.25 billion of convertible bonds at a trifling interest rate of 4.75%. That gives it a formidable cash hoard to cover operating losses, expansions and any acquisitions for years to come. 

  Amazon also may be on the brink of a major efficiency improvement by upgrading its warehouses and distribution, says Steve Horen, an analyst at NationsBanc Montgomery Securities. A highly automated warehouse in Nevada is due to open this summer, he notes. By contrast, Amazon's Seattle warehouse requires employees to find each book ordered and pull it off a shelf. Paring down labor costs could bring Amazon much closer to profitability, Mr. Horen says. 

  What's more, Amazon's ability to do business in cyberspace lets it grow rapidly without tying up much cash. Its chief financial officer, Joy Covey, recently calculated that the company so far has spent just $36 million on physical assets. By contrast, if it were running physical stores, she says, it would have spent $650 million on leases for at least 200 facilities to achieve the same level of sales. 

  As Amazon pursues more growth, it is almost impossible to gauge whether the company has any hope of delivering welcome surprises to shareholders, given how much its stock already has surged. At current prices, Amazon is valued at 24 times annual sales, whereas rival Barnes & Noble sells at just twice its annual sales. 

  In a recent conference call with investors and analysts, Amazon's Mr. Bezos urged investors to make Amazon only a small part of their holdings and to focus on the company's long-term prospects rather than look for a quick killing in the stock. The company's growth so far has created "high expectations," Mr. Bezos says. "Every investment we make won't pay off as strongly as they have historically." 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
Confidence In NZ Real Estate Mkt Reaches New High - ASB Bk

 
 

  WELLINGTON (Dow Jones)--Confidence in New Zealand's real estate market has climbed to a record high in the three months ended Jan. 31, according to a survey by ASB Bank. 

  The ASB housing confidence indicator showed a net 71% of respondents think it is a good time to buy a house, up from 52% with that view in the previous quarter ended Oct. 31. It is the highest level for the indicator in its three-year history. 

  ASB economist Rozanna Wozniak said mortgage interest rates have fallen to 30-year lows, and that has encouraged both confidence and activity in the real estate market. Three-quarters of those who think it is a good time to buy a house said low interest rates were the main reason for their view. 

  House prices rose 1.5% in the fourth quarter of 1998 after falling 5.4% over the preceding three quarters. Respondents to the ASB survey are more optimistic that prices will continue to rise, with 22% expecting increases in the next year, up from 2% from the previous survey. 

  However, Wozniak said, rises won't be significant. She said there are signs from the survey results that economic and financial uncertainty continue to be constraints on demand. Also, mortgage rates will start to rise, she said, though only from the second half of 1999. 

  She said the global economy remains the main factor that has the potential to stall the recovery in the economy and the real estate market, while the national election, which must be held by November this year, is a secondary risk. 

  Other factors slowing the house price advance are: the steady supply of new dwellings, as the trend in dwelling consents improves; the net outflow of migrants; and a likely reluctance of consumers to add to already high debt levels, she added. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

Colombia's Econ Performance Worst Since 1931 -Association

 
 

  BOGOTA (AP)--Colombia's economy failed to grow last year in its worst performance since 1931, an association of banks and financial institutions said Sunday. 

  "No growth, as has been calculated for last year, represents a true economic and social disaster," the National Association of Financial Institutions said in its weekly analysis of the economy. 

  If confirmed by official figures not yet released, it would be the first time the economy has failed to grow since 1931, when it shrank 1.6%, the association said. 

  Government officials had predicted 2% growth for 1998, but the economy nose-dived during the last few months. Economists blame high interest rates, new taxes, guerrilla violence and low oil prices in the oil-producing South American country. 

  The government predicts 1% growth this year, but Armando Montenegro, head of the association, said zero growth is likely again. 

  Unemployment that soared to 15.2% last October is provoking unrest among workers, who have called for a national protest Thursday against government austerity and privatization measures they blame for layoffs at government and state-owned companies.

text:
WSJ OpEd: The Global Crisis of Corporatism

 
 

  By Edmund S. Phelps 

  (Editor's Note: This is an opinion piece from Thursday's Wall Street Journal. Mr. Phelps is a professor of economics at Columbia University). 

 

  NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Meeting last month in Bonn, finance ministers of the Group of Seven countries discussed ways in which greater regulation of international financial flows could ease the plight of nations hard hit by the global economic turmoil. There's a better way to help: Induce the nations in crisis to reform their economies on the capitalist model, drop government involvement in the direction of "development" and establish acceptable standards of information reporting. Such steps would ensure that in the future these nations are less of a danger to themselves and others in the global economy. 

  The G-7's approach and the one I suggest reflect the opposing perspectives of the world's two main surviving economic systems: capitalism, in which every would-be entrepreneur is free to enter the market and compete without favoritism, and corporatism, in which private corporate interests are reconciled and coordinated by the central government. The first is pluralistic, open; the other is cooperative, run by insiders, Today, several economies in East Asia are informally corporatist, Russia and China seem increasingly so, and parts of Europe and Latin America have not wholly shed their corporatist ways. 

  Corporatist leaders have attempted to deflect attention from the recent malfunction of their system by blaming capitalism and calling for its restraint. They impute the series of crises to the system's financial center, which, they say, directs huge movements of capital in and out of the periphery -- Asia, Eastern Europe and Latin America -- at the drop of a hat. A few Western economists and financiers seem to agree, as do Europe's center-left politicians. 

  But attributing the sharp moves in financial flows to the erratic "push" of capital from the center doesn't fit the facts. The push thesis fails to explain why in the 1990s huge capital flows went into east Asia while little went to Latin America and nothing to Africa. The thesis also leaves unexplained why within east Asia the more corporatist economies -- South Korea, Indonesia, Thailand and Malaysia -- were the big takers. (Noncorporatist Taiwan and the Philippines experienced more modest inflows and suffered only from the ensuing financial contagion.) 

  A better explanation for the crisis is the "pull" thesis. According to this view, the crisis had its roots in the big domestic firms' rosy expectations about the future returns on their investments and the future interest rates on their loans -- expectations that would not materialize if everyone acted on them at once. Similarly, domestic banks had unrealistic expectations about the capacity of the government to make good its implicit guarantee on loans that went bad. What followed was domestic asset-price inflation, particularly in the prices of nontradable capital goods, which drove the production of those goods above its equilibrium path -- and the economy's total employment above its equilibrium path. 

  Once these expectations came to be seen as unrealizable, the bubble of inflated asset prices burst. Prices had to drop at least to the path that would have prevailed had the bubble never gotten started -- and employment had to fall similarly. However, the boom created structural imbalances that forced asset prices to sink far below where they were when the bubble began -- and this reversal in turn drove employment into a structural slump. The typical corporatist economy had overinvested in export capacity, thus depressing export prices. It had also invested unwisely, picking too many losers. Its workers, richer from the extra earnings of the boom, would not accept prebubble wage rates absent a slump. Its banks became paralyzed by the overhang of bad loans. And the government's incompetence cost it the confidence of investors, 

  To be sure, capitalist economies, like corporatist ones, can lose their equilibrium -- witness the American bubble of the 1920s. It is in the nature of capitalism that rational lenders and shareholders take chances on less than complete information; they know they cannot tap into an entrepreneur's private knowledge and intentions. It is in the nature of corporatism, though, to get into a large and protracted disequilibrium, resulting in larger and larger structural imbalances. 

  First, the corporatists shielded their bubble from second opinions by denying lenders and share buyers access to extensive and timely information. Bundesbank President Hans Tietmeyer told The Wall Street Journal Americas conference last fall that he had talked to Western bankers who clearly knew nothing about some of the Asian countries in which they were lending. If the actual situation had not been so obscure, new lenders would have been far more cautious, and old loans would have been called in sooner. 

  Second, the corporatist economy is disequilibrium -- prone because it steers capital to industries and firms viewed as prospective winners -- while capitalists bet on diverse and even incompatible visions. And since there are limits to how much economic knowledge the government can muster in making its choices, it tends to narrow the scope of development to a small number of industries. It was characteristic of the booms in the corporatist economies that they were concentrated in real estate, chemicals, steel, cars, microchips and a few other sectors. I suspect that the upward pressure on wage rates as workers became more comfortable over the years also played a part. To keep prosperity going in the face of rising labor costs, the corporatists fueled an investment boom to stimulate the demand for labor. 

  If this is the main story behind the recent turmoil, it constitutes a crisis of corporatism, not a crisis of capitalism. That seems to be the lesson drawn by Singapore, which has said it is opening its doors to more foreign investment and loosening restrictions to attract more overseas firms to locate there. And this suggests that the G-7's concern over financial flows is misplaced. It is national governments, not financial flows, that ought to be monitored, to check that they have reformed themselves along capitalist lines and are enforcing acceptable rules of conduct in their economies. 

  Students look shocked when told advanced capitalist countries have a right to demand of another country that it reform itself in their image. Yet in our business with other parties we demand they behave in a certain way if they want us to be their customer or employee or lender. And, not uncommonly, good guys gang up to require everyone else to meet their standards in order to obtain the general good. 

  Another reform is to start a private agency to gather information of interest to lenders and investors on emerging markets and disseminate it to subscribing Western banks and investment funds. So far neither the International Monetary Fund nor the private credit-rating agencies can be counted on to do this, as they maintain close ties to foreign corporatist governments. Yet the importance -- and the influence -- of such an agency cannot be understated. A large bank would be uncomfortable not subscribing, as it would be a conspicuous failure to exercise diligence in its lending. And an emerging-market economy would think twice about refusing to provide information, since doing so would risk a pullout by Western lenders and investors. 

  What the emerging-market nations need now is more capitalism, not less. The West will be right to demand that the so-called emerging market nations adopt the capitalist model for their own benefit and that of all members of the global economy. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
Ecuador Tries To End Populist Past As Economy Tumbles

 
 

  QUITO, Ecuador (AP)--Ecuador's penchant for eccentric presidents, circus-like politics and populist economics has backfired, and the tiny Andean nation must now pay the price, experts say. 

  In an effort to ease Ecuador's worst economic crisis in decades and soothe fears of a financial meltdown, President Jamil Mahuad announced a package of harsh austerity measures on Thursday that have enraged leftist-led unions. 

  Mahuad, who took office seven months ago, ordered the banks temporarily closed to prevent massive withdrawals, froze many dollar checking accounts for one year, doubled the price of gasoline, proposed prison for tax evaders and promised to accelerate privatizations and slash the bloated bureaucracy. 

  Earlier, he had ended fuel subsidies and frozen public sector wages. 

  Unions, students and Indian groups have called the measures a "bullet in the head" for Ecuadoreans. Vowing to topple Mahuad, they are calling for street protests and bank occupations on Wednesday. Business leaders are furious at having their dollar accounts frozen. 

  But so far, most Ecuadoreans -already among the poorest in Latin America- remain stunned. Violent protests have been limited. 

  With banks scheduled to reopen Monday after being closed for a week, people are anxious to see what the financial future holds. 

  "I pray this signals a turn away from populism and easy solutions," Ecuadorean economist Jose Samaniego said. "Because what we were doing before was the road to self-destruction." 

  Past presidents have shamelessly doled out political patronage and cut deals with parties in Congress in order to pass laws, repeatedly approving deficit budgets and rejecting necessary but unpopular measures. 

  From small shopkeepers to factory owners, few in Ecuador pay taxes and no president had been willing to crack down on evaders. The government estimates that 80 percent of taxes are not paid. 

  As a result, Ecuador's budget deficit has ballooned to $1.2 billion and its national debt stands at $16 billion. 

  "The roots of Ecuador's crisis are political," said former Vice President Blasco Penaherrera. "For more than 20 years, with only a few very brief respites, we have not had serious government." 

   Banana And Oil Export Revenues Collapse 

  While many of its Latin American neighbors privatized their state industries and opened markets to competition years ago, Ecuador has lagged behind, its economy propped up by oil and banana exports. 

  As long as its leaders could spread oil and banana money to the military and political elites, no president dared buck the system, Penaherrera said. 

  But when El Nino-driven floods devastated banana production last year and world oil prices fell, Ecuador entered what Mahuad called its "worst economic crisis in 70 years." 

  With the patronage system disrupted, economists say Mahuad, a political centrist with a master's degree in public administration from Harvard, has a unique opportunity to create a modern, free-market state. 

  But experts fear politics may doom the effort. 

  Many key reforms must be approved by Congress, which can veto presidential legislation. Mahuad's party lacks a majority and the main parties have announced their opposition to the austerity measures. 

  "Mahuad doesn't have the support he needs in Congress to pass the reforms. I doubt that he can do it," Penaherrera said. 

  Among his supporters, there are growing calls for Mahuad to bypass the discredited Congress and rule by decree. 

  Since few presidents have held a majority in Congress, they have been forced to make deals with factions within the legislature to be able to govern. 

  "For years, Congress has prevented effective government and blocked Ecuador's development," Penaherrera said. 

  Congressmen have engaged in fistfights, hurled glass ashtrays and even threatened to urinate on each other during sessions. 

  "We've had the worst politicians in the world," said 24-year-old newspaper vendor Aldo Guzman. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  March 14, 1999 17:26 ET (22:26 GMT)

text:
Nymex Close: Calif. Gasoline Surge Boosts Oil Complex

 
 

  NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--A desperate gasoline supply picture on the U.S. West Coast popped gasoline futures higher at the New York Mercantile Exchange Monday, as East Coast traders worried about gasoline supply heading away from them and to the California market. 

  California Air Resources Board, or CARB, gasoline prices have shot up 45 cents a gallon to 80 cents in Los Angeles in the month since the closure of Tosco Corp.'s Avon refinery. Also in that time, Exxon Corp. and Atlantic Richfield Co. shut down fluid catalytic crackers, which produce gasoline, in Benicia and Carson, Calif. 

  Brokers in the San Francisco Bay Area, where prices traded around 90 cents a gallon Monday, said the region is virtually without supply. 

  April gasoline futures on Nymex settled 178 points higher at 49.42 cents a gallon, after hitting a high of 49.50 cents. April heating oil futures ended 170 points up at 42.39 cents a gallon. April oil, which expired at the end of the session, climbed 26 cents to $15.50 a barrel, while May ended 38 cents higher at $15.74. 

  Supply problems on the West Coast don't typically affect gasoline prices in the New York Harbor, which underlie Nymex gasoline futures. But such an extreme supply pinch coupled with indications that overall U.S. gasoline demand is rising had traders edgy. 

  "There's some fear in the market that we'll see gasoline heading to the West Coast as gasoline demand strengthens on the East Coast," said Jason Chartrand, an energy analyst with GSC Energy in Atlanta. 

  In the week ended March 12, gasoline demand was a strong 8.8 million barrels a day, according to the American Petroleum Institute, at a time of year when gasoline demand is usually soft. At the same time, U.S. gasoline supply fell nearly 7 million barrels to 226.219 million barrels. 

  The refinery closures also had a bullish effect on diesel fuel prices, which sparked buying in heating oil futures. Diesel fuel and heating oil are distillates, and can have an effect on each other, a trader said. 

  Some analysts were skeptical of problems in California affecting the Nymex. And some warned that the market may rethink the gasoline run-up on Tuesday. 

  Surprisingly, the excitement in the products pits occurred on a day when OPEC and production cuts were supposed to be the focus of attention. But little earth-shattering news came from Vienna, where OPEC ministers are gathering ahead of Tuesday's full ministerial meeting, which should see ratification of an output cut of over 2 million barrels a day. 

  OPEC president and Algerian oil minister Youcef Yousfi said Monday that total cuts by OPEC and non-OPEC oil producers will exceed 2.1 million barrels a day. That figure is in line with what most analysts are expecting. 

  Most analysts think the cut agreement has been factored into prices, and the market could be set for a correction once the final headline from Vienna is written. "That'll be a big unknown out of the way, and we can then get back to reality," one said. 

  But, the situation in California is likely to be considered in any sell-off this week. 

  The market shrugged off news Sunday that oil flow had stopped on Iraq-Turkey pipeline due to an explosion on a Turkish part of the line. Monday, the U.N. said oil resumed flowing on the line 

  The incident may have been an act of sabotage by the Turkish Kurdish Workers Party, or PKK, an autonomy-seeking terrorist organization that has attacked sites within Turkey, but officials wouldn't comment on the source of the explosion.

text:
FX Asia: High Oil Price Impact On Exchange Rates Downplayed

 
 
     By Tom Holland 
 

  SINGAPORE (Dow Jones)--Far from being the disaster for Asia that some market players imagine it to be, this month's 27% rise in the price of oil will have no more than a small impact on Asian economies and currencies. 

  As officials and ministers from oil producing countries meet in Vienna on Tuesday to ratify an agreement to cut production by over 2 million barrels a day, some foreign exchange traders in Asia are citing the pact as reason to buy U.S. dollars against Asian currencies, particularly the yen. 

  But although the foreign exchange market may respond to the production cut with its customary kneejerk reaction, according to economists at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, there is little fundamental reason why a higher oil price should translate into a weaker yen. 

  "The notion that Japan is a huge oil importer is an outdated idea," declares Robert Feldman, Morgan Stanley's chief economist in Tokyo. 

  Since 1982, when crude oil imports made up 38% of Japan's total imports, the importance of oil to the Japanese economy has fallen drastically. Today, says Feldman, crude oil accounts for just 8% of Japan's imports, eclipsed by alternative energy sources including nuclear power and liquid natural gas. 

  And although at its current price of $15.50 per barrel, the price of the benchmark West Texas Intermediate blend is up a massive 50% from its 12 year low of $10.35 hit in December, the price has merely regained levels last seen in October. 

 
   Yen Price Of Oil Down By 3% 
 

  Overall, in U.S. dollar terms, the price is just 18% above last year's average. In yen terms, however, the price of the oil imported by Japan has actually fallen. Because of the rise in the value of the Japanese currency in the third quarter of last year, from a Japanese perspective, the oil price has dropped by around 3% from last year's average, argues Feldman. 

  With Japanese oil imports worth around Y3 trillion in 1998, a 3% fall in the oil price represents a saving of about Y90 billion. Put into the context of Japan's Y500 trillion gross domestic product, the impact is negligible. 

  "In short, there is no effect," says Feldman. 

  The impact on other Asian countries and currencies is also likely to be subdued, says Morgan Stanley. 

  According to Tim Condon, the firm's Hong Kong-based Southeast Asian economist, Malaysia and Indonesia, as net oil exporters, will benefit from any sustained rise in the oil price. 

  Each country will see its current account move further into surplus and there will a small boost to GDP in 1999. GDP shrinkage in Indonesia will be limited to around 3.6% compared with previous estimates of 4.0%. Malaysia will grow by around 2.0%, compared with 1.8% in the absence of the oil price rise. 

  Among other regional countries, Singapore, with a roughly balanced oil account, will see little or no net effect. Korea and the Philippines, as oil importers, will see some contraction of their trade surpluses, and slightly slower growth than would have been expected otherwise. 

  Most at risk from any extended oil price rise would be India, which already a running a sizable $15 billion trade deficit. 

  "The extent to which currencies are vulnerable to external shocks such as higher oil prices depends on the size of their current account surpluses or deficits and the extent of over or under-valuation of currencies," wrote Condon in a research paper published on March 16. 

  "The Indian rupee may be vulnerable to pressure from a wider current account deficit. But for the rest of the region, the small narrowing of trade surpluses would be unlikely to result in serious pressure on their currencies." 

  -By Tom Holland; 65 421 4808 tom.holland@cor.dowjones.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  March 22, 1999 23:20 ET (04:20 GMT)
label: non-inflation-related

text:
Ecuador Wins Preliminary Agreement For $900M Loan Package

 

  By Michael M. Phillips 

  WASHINGTON (Dow Jones)--Cash-strapped Ecuador secured preliminary agreement Friday on a $900 million international loan package to help it escape a severe economic and financial crisis. 

  The deal will include $500 million from the World Bank, Inter-American Development Bank and Andean Development Corp. (ADCC) to help the government restructure or close troubled banks. The International Monetary Fund committed to provide its own large 18-month loan, worth an estimated $400 million. 

  In addition, the development banks plan to disburse $500 million this year for ongoing projects in Ecuador, bringing the total flow of aid to $1.4 billion. 

  The heads of the IMF, IDB and World Bank joined Finance Minister Ana Lucia in a display of support obviously intended to calm financial markets and generate political support for reform in Ecuador. 

  "We applaud and admire the government's efforts," IMF Managing Director Michel Camdessus told reporters. 

  The small oil-producing country has been hit by a combination of low oil prices, international and domestic financial turmoil, and political stalemate. President Jamil Mahuad's austerity campaign has generated intense opposition from the legislature, as well as upheaval in the streets. 

  Key to winning IMF support was the fact that the government finally convinced Congress this month to adopt tax increases and spending cuts expected to slash the budget deficit this year to about 4% of Gross Domestic Product from about 8%. In addition, international auditors will begin work Monday trying to assess which of the country's 36 banks should be restructured or closed, a process likely to cost billions of dollars. 

  Stanley Fischer, the IMF's No. 2, is traveling to Quito next week to discuss the need for reforms, and the IMF expects to formalize an agreement by the end of May. With IMF board approval expected in June, Ecuador will be able to meet July 5 with the Paris Club of creditor governments to seek restructuring of some $800 million in debt. 

  Minister Armijos described Friday's announcement as a "show of the international community's immense support for Ecuador's progress." 

  -Michael Phillips (201) 938-5099

text:
Mexico/Pemex/March -2: Nat Gas Prod 4.768 BCF/D

 
 

  MEXICO CITY (Dow Jones)--Mexico's state-owned oil monopoly Petroleos Mexicanos (E.PEM) exported an average of 1.64 million barrels a day of crude oil in March at an average price of $10.79 a barrel. 

  According to statistics released Monday, Pemex crude output in March totaled 3.05 million b/d, up from 3.02 million b/d in February. 

  Heavy Maya crude output averaged 1.659 million b/d, while light Isthmus output averaged 846,000 b/d and super light Olmeca production averaged 548,000 b/d. 

  Of March crude exports, 1.417 million b/d went to the Americas, 121,000 b/d went to Europe and 59,000 b/d went to Asia and other regions. 

  Exports of Maya crude averaged 1.021 million b/d, exports of Isthmus averaged 169,000 b/d and exports of Olmeca averaged 450,000 b/d.
