text:
NZ Economists/Prices -2: Food Prices Affected By Climate

 
 

  The divergence between the 0.1% fall in the CPIX in the last quarter of 1998 and the expected 0.4% rise in the latest quarter was driven to a large extent by one-time factors which pose no monetary policy significance, economists said. 

  "A lot of the latest rise in prices was due to food, which was drought-related," said Robin Clements, Chief Economist at Warburg Dillon Read (NZ) Ltd. 

  The food price index rose 0.8% in January and 1.1% in February. Food makes up around 18% of the total CPIX index. 

  The summer drought in some regions contributed to a significant rise in vegetable and food prices in early 1999, economists said, while hikes in tobacco and alcohol retail prices were related to adjustments to government taxes. 

  The start of the academic year, in which technical institute and university fees rose, also pushed up the general level of prices within the recreation and education subgroup of the CPIX, economists said. 

  Economists agree prices within the housing sector partially recovered after falling a dramatic 0.8% in the last three months of 1998. But views vary on the extent to which a strengthening construction market will have been accurately reflected in first quarter data. 

  ANZ Banking Group (NZ) Ltd. Treasury Economist David Drage said he estimates that prices in the housing group rose 0.6% in the first quarter compared with the fourth quarter. 

  Other economists, however, said they expect prices in the housing group were closer to flat in the latest quarter. 

  Merrill Lynch NZ Ltd. Economist Mark Benseman said central bank officials will be monitoring recent statements by electricity retail companies and local government agencies, indicating their charges will soon rise. 

  Yet, it is unclear at this stage how significant to the general level of prices such individual sector movements will prove to be, he said.

text:
U.S. Retail Gasoline Prices Up In East, Dn In West-Lundberg

 
 

  CAMARILLO, Calif. (AP)--Gasoline prices rose slightly nationwide over the past two weeks, though prices declined somewhat in the West, an industry analyst said. 

  Crude oil price hikes forced pump prices up about 2 cents per gallon in states along the East Coast and the Gulf of Mexico, while prices dropped about 1.5 cents in the West and Midwest, according to the Lundberg Survey of 10,000 stations nationwide. 

  The national weighted average, including all grades and taxes, was $1.2296 per gallon Friday, a 0.15 cent rise from two weeks earlier, analyst Trilby Lundberg said. 

  'Behind that apparent lack of activity there, a lot has been going on,' Ms. Lundberg said. 'There have been price increases in Eastern and Gulf Coast states, which washed out the price cuts.' 

  Explosions and problems in several California refineries caused prices to skyrocket in that state in recent weeks. However, increased supplies of gasoline have helped stabilize the market to knock down prices in the West, she said. 

  'The capacity is not all the way up to what it was, but as the situation normalizes in California, prices in the West will continue to topple,' said Ms. Lundberg. 

  The average prices at self-service stations was $1.1733 per gallon for regular gasoline, $1.2748 for mid-grade and $1.3598 for premium. 

  Full-service prices were $1.5304 for regular, $1.6173 for mid-grade and $1.6905 for premium.

text:
Ecuador Econ Crisis Won't End Anytime Soon - U.S. Analysts

 
 

  By Enza Tedesco 

 

  NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--With Ecuador mired in its worst economic crisis in seven decades, observers are asking themselves whether things can get any worse. 

  The answer is yes, according to several U.S.-based analysts. While Ecuador's government is forecasting economic growth of between 1.5% and 2.0% this year, economists are predicting a contraction of between 2% and 10%. Inflation projections range from 40% to 170%, against the government's estimate of 36%. 

  With gross domestic product expanding a minuscule 0.8% last year as it battled the weather phenomenon El Nino and low commodities prices, analysts say the tiny Andean country is just setting out to solve its fiscal and economic problems. 

  This year a chaotic currency devaluation, a one-week closure of banks, the freezing of almost half of all bank deposits, nationwide strikes and increasing political squabbles between the government and opposition parties have fueled an ongoing deterioration. 

  Vowing to halve the country's ballooning fiscal deficit to 3.5% of GDP, President Jamil Mahuad last Friday forwarded to Congress a raft of tax and cost-cutting measures that lawmakers are expected to start debating next week. That's not enough, according to many economists. 

  "Even if the package is approved by Congress, we believe the 1999 deficit will again overshoot by a significant margin as a result of unplanned currency weakness and a sharp contraction of the economy," says Graham Stock, vice president of international fixed-income research at Chase Securities Inc., which is forecasting a 10% GDP contraction. 

  Many see the pending measures in Congress as only offering short-term economic relief, with the government needing to attack fundamental problems to create medium and long-term stability. 

  "Currently, Ecuador has a credibility problem," says Ramon Aracena, senior Latin American economist at the Institute of International Finance, or IIF, which represents many of the world's largest banks and investment funds. 

  "Once credibility is restored, the pressure on the currency and interest rates will be alleviated," predicts Aracena, who expects GDP to contract 2%, on the optimistic end of economists' forecasts. 

 
   Banks, Political Opposition Are Twin Challenges 
 

  Jose M. Barrionuevo, a global strategist at Lehman Brothers, says the government fiscal program could become the first baby step toward a slow economic recovery, but only "if those reforms are approved with urgency by Congress and if combined with a decisive program of bank restructuring." 

  Barrionuevo is forecasting a GDP contraction of 4% and inflation of 50% "in the most conservative scenario, where the government manages to skip a deteriorating political dispute." 

  According to Chase's Stock, the road to recovery turns tougher since some of the measures seem unrealistic. 

  "Oil prices assumptions are all right today, but they're not guaranteed to stay as high; while the assumed funding from debt renegotiations don't seem viable," he says. 

  But investors' immediate concerns surround the banking sector's frailty, highlighted by this month's collapse of the second-largest bank - Banco del Progreso - and the political gridlock that is sapping any residual support for Mahuad's administration, which assumed power last August. 

  "Banks are in an extremely delicate situation," says IIF's Aracena. "They need some sort of chemotherapy to cure their health and that will take years. But the important thing is for them to start the treatment." 

  Bruised by continuous pressure on the local currency, the government on Feb. 12 decided to abandon the sucre's trading band and let it float freely. While that helped staunch the bleeding of reserves, it prompted a run on bank deposits and introduced extraordinary volatility in the foreign exchange market - most of it downward. 

  The sucre closed Wednesday at a mid rate of 10,250 per dollar, after plunging as far as ECS17,000 in intraday trading March 5 - a 74% depreciation from the end of 1998. U.S. analysts predict the exchange rate will average between ECS10,500/dollar and ECS14,000/dollar in 1999, against a government projection of ECS7,460 before the devaluation. 

  After shooting up to 180% earlier this year, interest rates have fallen since the sucre's devaluation - but were still at 94% Wednesday, keeping pressure on the banking sector. 

  On the legislative front, tax reforms and new laws that will help the administration streamline the public sector and reduce public spending are vigorously opposed by the Social Christians, the country's main opposition party. 

  "The main barriers to sound fiscal policy in Ecuador are the relationship between the executive and Congress, and the difficult process for decision-making in Congress due to the large number of parties, each with its own agenda," says Santiago Millan, Latin American analyst at New York-based research firm I.D.E.A.. Millan expects the Ecuadorean economy to shrink by 5% in 1999. 

 
   IMF Aid No Sure Thing; Debt Default Not Ruled Out 
 

  Earlier in March the government seemed to have reached a pact with opposition parties to scale back gasoline price hikes in return for opposition support of new tax measures. But after two parties threatened to pull out of the accord unless the government cut fuel prices further, the executive has beeen scrambling to build a new alliance. 

  "The subsequent delays in turning to economic matters, presumably in the search of a consensus, that never emerged, mean that the fiscal position is worse than ever, and the ongoing recession has reduced tolerance for economic discipline," says Chase's Stock. 

  Under these circumstances, economists say it's hard to envision a prompt agreement with the International Monetary Fund. An IMF mission has been in Ecuador for several weeks in an effort to hammer out an 18-month, $400-million standby credit facility. 

  "Over the next few months we expect to hear words of encouragement from the Fund for the banking sector reform and fiscal adjustment, but proper negotiations look unlikely before the second half of the year at the earliest," says Stock. 

  A delay in reaching a deal with the IMF would translate into a similar delay in negotiations with the Paris Club, as Ecuador seeks to refinance about $400 million in capital and interest arrears from $1.3 billion in bilateral debt. The country's external debt totals $15.245 billion and its service equals about 41% of the budget. 

  "The country's debt burden takes up considerable space in the budget...this is obviously the unfortunate result of an inefficient process of fiscal policy that through the years led to a large accumulation of foreign debt," says I.D.E.A.'s Millan. 

  Millan pegs Ecuador's current external debt to GDP ratio at 75.3%, more than double the Latin American average of 35%. 

  Faced with a bloated deficit and growing popular discontent, analysts don't rule out the possibility that either this administration or any successor might default on sovereign debt. 

  "One day the finance ministry will be faced with a tough choice between missing another month's salary for nurses and teachers or skipping a coupon payment to foreign investors," says Chase's Stock. "It's a choice I wouldn't want to make, but I think the sympathies of most Ecuadoreans will be very clear." 

-By Enza Tedesco; 201-9382203; enza.tedesco@dowjones.com; 
(Mercedes Alvaro in Quito contributed to this article) 
 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  April 01, 1999 15:05 ET (20:05 GMT)

text:
NZ Bonds Slightly Weaker In Morning But Tone Well Bid

 
 

  WELLINGTON-(Dow Jones)--New Zealand bond prices are lower Wednesday, but the local market has a bid tone with buying seen mainly in the longer-dated maturities, especially the five-year bond. 

  "Bond yields are seen as being near the upper edge of their recent range and some people regard these levels as a good entry point," said a bond trader at a commercial bank. 

  "There has been more of a selloff in U.S. bonds overnight but we haven't gone with it fully," he said. 

  The 7% July 2009 bond yield is unchanged from its opening level of 5.95% Wednesday. However, the July 2009 bond yield is currently 55 basis points above the yield on its U.S. equivalent, having been 57 basis points above the U.S. 10-year yield at Tuesday's close. 

  On the computerized Sycom market, Australian June 10-year bond futures have fallen five basis points from the contract's opening level. 

  Locally, buying was seen overnight from overseas investors in the longer-dated bonds, another bond trader said. 

  However, he noted that local participants were still on the sidelines, likely waiting for Thursday's NZ$350 million bond tender to do any buying.

text:
Australia Curr Acct Deficit Seen At Over 6% Of GDP

 
 

  SYDNEY (Dow Jones)--Australia's first-quarter current account deficit has probably widened to over 6% of first-quarter gross domestic product, and it doesn't look like it will improve much in the second quarter, analysts say. 

  Analysts on average expect the first-quarter current account - due out at 0130 GMT Tuesday - to grow to A$9.10 billion from A$7.97 in the fourth quarter of 1998, which was the largest quarterly deficit on record. Forecasts range between A$8.90 billion and A$9.60 billion. 

  Retail data for April is also due out Tuesday, and analysts on average expect a 1.5% fall in this sector after a 2.3% rise in March sales. Expectations range from a 3.5% fall in sales to a flat outcome. 

  A deficit of A$9.10 billion would take the current account deficit to over 6% of first-quarter GDP, which have come under pressure by lower prices on commodites, making up around 60% of Australian exports, analysts say. 

  Australia's current account deficit averaged 4.1% of GDP in the fiscal year ended June 30, 1998. 

  Ian Macfarlane, the governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, recently said the widening in the current account deficit is "more a reflection of the strength of the Australian economy, rather than its weakness." 

  The deficit is widening because of "differing growth rates between the Australian economy and its trading partners," Macfarlane said. Australia's economy grew 1.1% in the fourth quarter of 1998, or 4.7% of GDP year-on-year. First-quarter GDP data are due out June 2. 

  Given external reasons for the country's large current account deficit, Richard Yetsenga, senior economist with Deutsche Bank in Australia, doesn't expect investors to run away from Australian investments, though the Australian dollar "might wobble a little bit" on Tuesday's data. He expects the current account deficit widened to A$9.1 billion in the first quarter.

text:
Sri Lanka/Ctrl Bk -3: External Trade Suffers Setback

 
 

  Industrial output growth also slowed to 7.6% from 10.3% in 1997, the central bank report said. Building materials, wheat flour, milk products and other related factory products showed improved growth, it added. 

  Agriculture sector growth also slowed down somewhat, falling to 2.5% in 1998 from 3.0% the year before. High yields on rice paddies helped contain a negative effect from other sectors. 

  The report said tea prices, which form nearly 5% of GDP in total export earnings, failed to maintain early momentum and rose by a modest 17% in 1998. 

  The slide in tea prices was triggered by Russia's currency turmoil in August and an oversupply in world markets, the report said. 

  Russia and the Commonwealth of Independent States account for about 30% of direct and indirect imports of Sri Lankan tea. Since the ruble crisis, though, that share has slipped to around 25%. 

  The island nation's external trade also suffered in the period under review, thereby affecting overall economic performance. Exports grew by just 2.0% last year, much lower than the 13% registered the year before, the report said. 

  The report highlighted the difficulties faced by rubber and coconut manufacturers due to the currency depreciations in East Asia. For instance, rubber output declined by 21% in the period under review. The gem and diamond industry posted declines in nominal income of around 5%, the report said.

text:
Australian Salaries Seen Gaining 3.5%-4.25% This Year

 
 

  SYDNEY (Dow Jones)--Australian workers are likely to receive a salary increase of between 3.5% and 4.25% in 1999, according to a survey issued Monday by the Australian Institute of Management. 

  That is down slightly on actual salary increases in 1998 of between 3.8% and 5.4%, according to the survey. 

  If proved correct, such increases are well above Australia's inflation rate, which stood at an underlying rate of 1.7% in the first quarter from a year earlier. 

  On an industry-by-industry basis, the largest salary increases are likely in the electronic and information technology sector and the business and professional services sector, where average increases of 4.8% are expected, according to the survey results. 

  The biggest change in salary increases by industry is expected in the banking, finance and insurance sector, where salaries are forecast to rise by 3.5% in 1999, down from average increases of 5.5% in 1998. 

  Organizations responding to the survey said the most likely common reason for a salary increase during 1999 will be individual performance, followed by increases based on inflation and adjusting salaries for changes in labor market rates.

text:
AWSJ: Indonesia's Election Restores Faith Of Investors

 
  By Jay Solomon 
  Staff Reporter 

  JAKARTA -- Investors are registering a major vote of confidence in Indonesia's freest election in nearly a half century. 

  The stock market rose 12% Tuesday, the International Monetary Fund approved $450 million in aid, and local businessmen talked optimistically of restructuring debt-laden companies in a more-stable political environment. 

  "Political stability is the only chance for companies to survive, and the first major hurdle was cleared" in Monday's parliamentary election, said Indra Widjaja, president-director of PT Bank Internasional Indonesia, one of the largest private banks in the nation. "Interest rates and the currency should stabilize as political risk subsides." 

  Business investments in Indonesia have largely been put on hold in the months heading into the parliamentary vote. The rioting that swept the country last year - and forced former President Suharto's resignation - remained fresh in people's minds, and the assumption was that politics, combined with simmering ethnic and religious tensions, would set off another round of unrest during the campaign. Foreign-investment approvals plunged nearly 90% in the first 10 weeks of 1999, compared with the year earlier. 

  But the euphoric three-week campaign period ended up looking more like a rock concert than a war zone - large-scale unrest never materialized. Monday's voting was calm and orderly. 

  Financial markets responded. Jakarta's key stock index rose 12% Tuesday to a 22-month high, while the nation's currency, the rupiah, has strengthened 5.6% since Friday, trading late Tuesday in Asia at 7,660 rupiah to the dollar. Traders said the market gains were fueled by "panic buying" driven by a perception that the political risks long associated with Indonesia were abating. 

  "It's all about country risk in Indonesia, and with the election over this risk subsides," said the Singapore-based trading chief at a U.S. brokerage house. "People are not overly concerned about who's in charge of the country - only that it's stable." 

  The IMF also placed its stamp of approval on the election by endorsing the $450 million loan late Monday in the U.S. While the fund never explicitly said it was withholding loans to Indonesia until after the election - as the World Bank did - it did delay a meeting that could have seen the funds disbursed earlier. Many observers saw this as the IMF pressing President B.J. Habibie's government for a free and fair vote. 

  Stanley Fischer, the first deputy managing director at the IMF, voiced optimism Monday in Washington over Indonesia's prospects for economic recovery. "With inflation falling and the exchange rate stable, there is room to reduce interest rates further, thus improving prospects for recovery," Mr. Fischer said. The IMF official also said Indonesia's economic growth was likely to become positive by the end of the year, while inflation would fall to single digits. 

  But many financial analysts still are cautious about Indonesia. On the corporate side, they say that many Indonesian companies remain insolvent because of the combination of a weak rupiah and billions of dollars of debt. Although interest rates have been falling - one-month central-bank paper is now yielding 25%, down from 40% earlier in the year - it is still too expensive for most companies to raise financing. 

  The idea that Jakarta's main index, now at 687, is within striking distance of its precrisis high of 740, hit in July 1997, is a portent of an overcooked market, they warn. "The prices can't hold from a fundamental point of view," said economist Neil Saker of SG Securities in Singapore. 

  Some observers warn that there could still be political tension ahead, despite the success of the actual vote. A fractious coalition government could emerge, making implementation of painful economic reforms all the more difficult. 

  But Indonesian businessmen still say the peaceful vote is significantly improving the investment climate. 

  Harun Hajadi, managing director of PT Ciputra, a major Indonesian property firm, said his attempts to restructure the company have been undercut by political risk over the past year. Foreign investors he courted balked because of perceived political and social risks; those who did consider projects demanded exorbitantly high returns. Sales of Ciputra's private homes fell 70% from precrisis levels, to 3,000 units last year, as soaring interest rates killed off consumer demand, Mr. Harun said. 

  But now he sees his business fortunes improving, mainly as a result of falling interest rates. "The peacfulness of the election was a very significant event," he said. 

  Mr. Widjaja of Bank Internasional Indonesia, who is in the process of recapitalizing the bank, also said the calm will help him, too. Indonesian banks have been crushed by negative spreads - which means they pay borrowers higher rates than they earn from deposits. "This situation should improve" as a result of the vote, he said. 

  Perhaps most importantly, the peaceful votes could woo back Indonesia's ethnic-Chinese business class, whose shops and homes bore the brunt of much of last year's violence. Though the memories of last May's rioting remains fresh in their minds, and some continue to keep their families overseas for security reasons, many say they feel the security situation in the country is starting to improve. 

  "During the past year I lost half of all I owned," said Richard Hakim, an ethnic Chinese businessman who owns the toiletries producer PT Kintamolek Masa. "Things can only get better." 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
U.S. DOE Touts $1B USDA Loan Plan To Oil Patch

 
 
     By Campion Walsh 
 

  WASHINGTON (Dow Jones)--The U.S. Department of Energy is seeking to tap in a U.S. Department of Agriculture's $1 billion-a-year rural development loan program in order to help the country's distressed oil and gas producers. 

  Searching for ways to help small, independent domestic oil producers suffering from the 1998 plunge in crude oil prices, DOE officials discovered that Agriculture Department loan guarantees for rural business apply to oil and gas producers, said Peter Lagiovane of DOE's fossil energy division. 

  DOE began promoting the loan program at an April workshop with oil and gas producers in Oklahoma, Lagiovane said. It will discuss the program further at workshops planned in California in June or July, and in Texas in August, he said. 

  Since 1997, the Agriculture Department has had $1 billion in spending authority for the program, which aims to assist non-farm businesses in rural areas, encompassing regional populations of less than 50,000. 

  "The oil industry hasn't been a big user of the loan program," said Dayton J. Watkins, administrator for Agriculture Department's rural business and cooperative division. 

  "We're working at the staff level with the Department of Energy, trying to craft a relationship that's beneficial to (the oil and gas) industry," Watkins said. 

  Lagiovane said almost all of the smaller, independent oil and gas companies can apply for the loan guarantees because the program's rural requirements concern the location of a company's operations, and not its headquarters. 

 
    [New Funding Needed To Ensure Oil Sector Aid] 
 

  Since 1997, the Agriculture Department program has been fully subscribed, and oil companies would face stiff competition from other loan-hungry industries, Watkins said. 

  Given the difficult conditions in the petroleum sector over the past year, oil and gas companies may be able to show a particular need for assistance, but they'll also have to present reasonable credit risk, he said. 

  Earmarking funds for oil and gas producers would require new funding for the program from DOE or Congress, he said. 

  The program guarantees up to 80% of loans from private banks of up to $10 million per company. The average amount of loans has been about $1.5 million, and the default rate has been less than 3%. 

  Meanwhile, Sen. Pete Domenici's, R-N.M., plans to send a bill to the Senate floor later this month that would guarantee up to $500 million in emergency loans specifically for oil and gas producers. 

  On May 25, the Senate Appropriations Committee approved Domenici's bill, along with a similar bill sponsored by Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., to support the U.S. steel industry. 

  Domenici's bill, which was stripped from an emergency supplement spending bill passed last month, would allow oil and gas producers and oil-service companies to take loans of up to $10 million each with guarantees from the federal government. 

  Domenci's proposed emergency loan guarantee program would expire after five years, but loans could remain outstanding for a longer period. The program would cost the federal government $125 million in guarantees and $2.5 million in administrative costs, according to a draft of the bill. 

  The Agriculture Department's rural development program could cut down on administrative costs of Domenici's bill if it passes, according to Watkins. 

  The program has already helped to distribute assistance available to communities affected by military downsizing and the North American Free Trade Agreement, he said. 

  - By Campion Walsh; 202-862-9291; 
campion.walsh@dowjones.com 
 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
WSJ(6/18):Column: Mexico's Telephone Monopoly Hang-Up

 
 

  By Mary Anastasia O'Grady 

  (Editor's Note: This is an opinion piece from Friday's Wall Street Journal. Ms. O'Grady edits the Americas column). 

  NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--"...[T]here has not been significant pro-gress toward the policy goal of increasing the penetration rate to 20 [telephone] lines per 100 persons. As a result, Mexico is even further behind other countries than it was in 1990." 

  - From a draft copy of "Regulatory Reform in Mexico's Telecommunications Industry," Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development, February 1999. 

  The final release of this 57-page OECD report is due out shortly. Unless it is dramatically altered for political correctness, it promises to be an enormous embarrassment to a government that purports to defend the public interest. The stock of Telmex, Mexico's telecom `monopoly', is roaring, but Mexicans - or at least the ones who have been able to obtain telephones - are choking on their bills. 

  While the OECD acknowledges that the country's 1995 telecommunications law is a good one, it finds that "the regulatory authority has inadequate powers to regulate, particularly in regard to regulation of the incumbent in markets where it has substantial market power." 

  Just why the regulator - known by the Spanish acronym Cofetel - has been unable to rein in Telmex and create a competitive market is a subject of much political debate. But the apolitical OECD draft report simply measures the results: Eight years after privatization, Mexican telephony consumers still suffer inordinately high cost structures and poor service, leaving them miserably behind their OECD counterparts. 

  When it comes to private monopolies, there is probably no better symbol in Mexico than giant Telmex. It is Mexico's second largest company and the largest on the Mexican Stock Exchange. When the company was privatized in 1990, the government granted it certain concessionary rights to attract investors. Although the market was officially opened to competition in 1997, Mexico's Competition Commission (CFC) said in March 1998 that Telmex continues to enjoy "dominant status" in five telecom markets. 

  One important problem the OECD report raises is the question of the regulator's political independence since its "rights and obligations" are delegated by the Ministry of Communications and Transportation. When pressed about the need to curtail Telmex's monopoly powers in October 1997, Minister Carlos Ruiz Sacristan said "one has to be very careful not to negatively impact the stock market." In December 1997 a Morgan Stanley Dean Witter research paper commented favorably on Telmex, noting "we continue to see regulators acting in favor of the company's interest, which is a positive." The OECD's report shows how this attitude, together with the "inadequate statutory powers of Cofetel," has left Mexicans in the dark ages of telephony. 

  The report compares Mexico's telecommunications services to other OECD countries. One of the salient points is in the area of access: At the start of 1998, Mexico had less than 10 telephones per 100 inhabitants. Poland, the next worst performer among OECD countries, had 20. In Mexico no new access lines were added in 1996 and 1997. This is particularly scandalous given the fact that Cofetel argues, according to the OECD, that interconnection rates "must be set above long-run incremental cost to encourage network expansion and universal service goals to be met." In other words, Telmex was given the right to charge high access rates to competitors because it was to use the extra income to get more phones to more people. 

  A second problem for consumers is high prices. The report shows Mexican "tariff baskets" for both residential and business service towering over the rest of the OECD. Inflation, the authors note, distorts this picture. But this seems scant justification: According to the publication Telecommunications, local phone service prices, which are still controlled by Telmex, increased 63% in 1997, not a year of raging inflation. Moreover, the report says that following the macroeconomic crisis that began in 1994, Telmex "appreciated in relative value given the decline in the value of the Mexican peso on international markets." 

  In the February issue of the Inter-American Development Bank's magazine IDB America, Paul Constante compares telephone costs for a Mexican producer against those of a U.S. producer competing for business in London. For five calls of four minutes apiece the American pays $5.40 while the Mexican pays $25.20. The picture in local rates is even gloomier. 

  The report points out that Telmex, by concession, "virtually owns all public networks and provides local and interconnection services." It is control over these interconnection services that in practice allows Telmex to control prices. Yet in telecom deregulation, this is the drill, nothing unique to Mexico. The real difficulties, say some analysts, comes from the fact that Cofetel, the ministry and Telmex set the terms for the concession in secrecy. There is no public hearing, no public record and no cost transparency; as far as the public knows, the regulator accepts whatever "costs" Telmex declares. 

  Not only are cost claims cryptic but there has been no public accountability for the failures in network expansion. Says Philip Peters, Vice President of the Lexington Institute in Virginia and a telecom expert, "Cofetel bought the idea that high interconnection charges are needed to cover Telmex's investments in phone network expansion, but the money all went to Telmex general revenues. There was no segregated fund, much less an accounting of expenditures." 

  Some speculate that Telmex is protected because a drop in its share price would be bad for Mexican stability. This theory makes little sense. Policy makers have had ample time during the six-year presidency of Ernesto Zedillo to open up competition for the welfare of all citizens. And nothing would improve Mexico's stability more than productivity improvements derived from competition. 

  The CFC, to its credit, is pushing hard for competition. And Cofetel is now proposing to force Telmex to separate local and long distance pricing in order to end the practice of cross-subsidizing predatory pricing in competitive markets with revenues from local markets where there is almost no competition. Cofetel has also drafted rules that would force Telmex to share costs and data with rivals. 

  As if to demonstrate just how difficult that will be, Telmex sought and won an injunction last week against the CFC's "dominant status" ruling, which is the fulcrum of all Cofetel's reforms. Cofetel has promised to go back to court to argue that these reforms are in the national interest; if that can proven, the judge ruled, the decision can be reversed. 

  The legal wrangling is guaranteed to continue. But with a little political will the government can give Cofetel the power and independence it needs to help foster a competitive market. A good start would be requiring greater transparency in the regulatory process. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

Australia/Leading Index -3: Raising Rates In 1Q 2000

 
 

  Strong gains in the share market, coupled with a rise in the real money supply and the amount of overtime worked also contributed to the strength of the April index. 

  Growth in the leading index is 2.8 percentage points above trend, and "is now even more clearly signaling that growth through 1999 and into 2000 will be well above long-term trend," said Westpac's general manager of economics, Bill Evans. 

  "This evidence casts further doubt on the generally held view that the Australian economy will experience a significant slowdown in the second half of 1999 and into 2000," he said. 

  The coincident index was also buoyed by strong March quarter national accounts. "Nonetheless, the strength of the coincident index appears to have attenuated over the past few months, which was predicted by the leading index earlier. 

  Weak labor market statistics are the "major soft spot" for the coincident index," Evans said. We expect that a near-term recovery in jobs growth, combined with continuing strong retail spending will underpin a strong coincident index in coming months." 

  "Overall, the leading index for Australia continues to signal that Australia's growth will be maintained at a very healthy pace, certainly much faster than predicted by both the government in their recent budget papers, and the Reserve Bank," he said. 

  Evans continued saying that "while interest rates are currently on hold, particularly because the authorities are expecting the economy to cool later this year, we expect the continuing evidence of our robust economic growth will lead the Australian authorities to follow the U.S. by raising interest rates beginning in the first quarter of 2000." 

  The leading index of inflation, which measures inflationary pressures in the economy, moderated to 4.9% in April.

text:
NZ Econ Grp Sees Domestic Recovery; Mixed Export Success

 
 

  WELLINGTON (Dow Jones)--Rising domestic demand will underpin economic activity in New Zealand over the next year or so, but the country's export performance paints a mixed picture, a New Zealand economic research house said Monday. 

  In its Quarterly Predictions, the New Zealand Institute of Economic Research Inc. forecasts the expenditure-based measure of gross domestic product will rise by 2.9% in the year ending March 31, 2000, compared with the year ended March 31, 1999. 

  The economy is forecast then to grow by 3.6% in the year ending March 31, 2001, followed by annual average GDP growth of 4.0% in the following year to March 31, 2002, the NZIER said. 

  Domestic demand is continuing to carry the economy forward, aided by income-tax cuts last year and retail interest rates, which have so far in 1999 sat at, or close to, historically low levels, the NZIER said. 

  "Growth in real expenditure GDP will lift from minus-0.8% in 1998-1999, to +2.9% in 1999-2000. The main factors behind this are a continuing growth in household consumption and a gradual recovery in exporting as the effects of the Asian crisis subside," the NZIER said in a commentary. 

  "Our export situation is still very vulnerable, with some sectors yet to show convincing signs of an improvement. Our overall export performance has been very patchy so far in 1999, and it will remain patchy for some time yet," it said. 

 
    Tourism Has Recovered From Downturn In Asia 
 

  The NZIER said the tourism sector has been the "star performer" recently, recovering strongly from the downturn in Asian markets seen last year. 

  The fall in the value of the New Zealand dollar over the past 18 months or so has fueled strong growth in arrivals from Australia, the U.S. and the U.K., particularly for people arriving to do business, or visit friends or family. 

  The NZIER forecasts total arrivals will continue growing strongly, at a7.0% annualized rate, in the year ending March 31, 2000. 

 
   Manufacturing Sector Is A Cause For Concern 
 

  In contrast, the manufacturing sector appears to be experiencing a "quiet crisis," with no growth in exports, and little sign of improvement on the horizon, the NZIER said. 

  Local manufacturers' key export market, Australia, has become an increasingly competitive market following last year's downturn in key Asian markets. 

  While the New Zealand dollar has eased, it hasn't eased by as much as many Asian currencies, meaning some competitors based in Asia have gained a greater exchange-rate-induced competitive advantage, the NZIER said. 

 
   Agricultural Exports Continue To Falter 
 

  The NZIER said agricultural exports remain weak, with lamb prices falling steadily and wool prices continuing to falter. 

  "At the same time, the legacy of two years of drought will constrain production over the next few seasons. We are forecasting export volumes for meat products to continue falling over the next year. Dairy export volumes will rise, reflecting the recovery in Asia, but prices will remain under pressure. Overall, agricultural exports are in a difficult situation and won't recover quickly," the NZIER said. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  June 20, 1999 09:00 ET (13:00 GMT)

text:
Australia Watch: Benign Inflation May Narrow Bond Spread

 
 
      By Nicki Bourlioufas 
 

  SYDNEY (Dow Jones)--Second quarter data to be released next week are expected to show that inflation pressures remained subdued in Australia, opening the way for a further narrowing in the spread of Australian bond yields relative to U.S. Treasurys. 

  Underlying inflation was running at 1.7% year-on-year in the second quarter, according to the average forecast of analysts surveyed by Dow Jones Newswires. That would be unchanged from the first quarter rate, and within the Reserve Bank of Australia's 2% to 3% target band. 

  'That's still pretty modest inflation given that the economy is growing at plus-4%,' said Grant Fitzner, economist at HSBC Markets. 

  With inflation under control, and little prospect of a rate rise this year, Australian bonds ought to perform better relative to U.S. Treasurys, some analysts say. Though U.S. inflation also appears subdued, there's still some prospect the Federal Reserve will raise rates again in August. 

  'By the end of the month there should be a bit more of a focus on inflation and that should give the local bond market a bit more scope for outperformance,' says Su-Lin Ong, senior economist at RBC DS Global Markets. 

  She says the spread between 10-year Australian government bonds and the equivalent Treasurys issue could narrow to below 20 basis points, just above that level presently. But the extent of any narrowing would depend on where the spread stands before the July 28 inflation data release, given that the spread has come in quite dramatically this year. At the start of 1999, the spread was as high as 51 basis points. 

  Any rise in the spread back to 45 basis points or more would represent a good opportunity to take long positions in Australian bonds, says David Plank, fixed-income strategist at Deutsche Bank for Australia and New Zealand. 

  But some analysts say Australian bonds could struggle to extend their gains. 

  'We need to get good news to keep (bond) prices where they are,' said Paul Brennan, chief Australian economist at Salomon Smith Barney. 

  That suggests to some that Australian bonds will simply follow the direction of U.S. Treasurys, leaving the spread little changed. 

  And there's a greater danger that there will be some inflation surprise in the July 28 data which will trigger a selloff in Australian bonds. 

  'I think we only need to see a slightly higher-than-expected number to see the bond market sell off,' Brennan says. 'The market is pretty susceptible to bad news.' 

  Nevertheless, Brennan acknowledges that the yield spread could still hold at 20 basis points by year end, because of subdued inflation. 

  Craig James, chief economist at Colonial State Bank, said Australia's growing current account deficit is maintaining upward pressure on bond yields and limiting the scope for bond outperformance. Australia's first-quarter current account deficit stood at close to 6.0% of first-quarter gross domestic product. 

  'If we didn't have a current account deficit around 5% to 6% of GDP, clearly Australia should be trading below U.S. bonds,' giving a negative yield spread to Treasurys, said Craig James, chief economist with Colonial State Bank. 

  Australian bonds traded below Treasurys in May and June 1998 based because Australia's economic cycle was lagging the U.S.. But since then, the spread to Treasurys has been in positive territory, reflecting the premium demanded by offshore investors to hold Australian bonds given the growing current account deficit, James says. 

  'If you take all our factors into account, inflation, growth, productivity, wages growth, you would have to say Australia would have to be a magnet for offshore investors. 

  'Clearly Australia bonds are a magnet, but there is some degree of reticence about holding Australian bonds,' James said. 

- By Nicki Bourlioufas; (61 2) 8235 2959; nicki.bourlioufas@dowjones.com 
 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
Treasurys Drop On 2Q Rise In Labor Costs; Dlr Pressured

 
 

  NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Treasurys fell sharply Thursday morning, as investors sifted through several economic numbers and concluded that labor costs and other factors are likely to put upward pressure on rates. 

  The morning's reports included news of a stronger-than-expected 1.1% rise in employment costs in the second quarter, offset by a slowdown in gross domestic product growth to 2.3%. At least early on, the market focused on the employment-costs number. 

  By 9:00 a.m. EDT, the benchmark 30-year Treasury was down 27/32 from late Wednesday, and down 20/32 from before the release, at 89 11/32, to yield 6.08%. At the Chicago Board of Trade, the September bond futures contract was trading at 115-02, down 26/32. 

  The dollar was under pressure, too. For example, currency investors were retesting the euro's Monday high of $1.0724, the U.S. currency was also nearing Y115.00. 

  U.S. employers saw their labor costs rise at the fastest clip in eight years in the second quarter, as the tightest labor market in three decades is intensifying inflationary pressures on the economy. The 1.1% rise was above a forecast of 0.8%. 

  Second-quarter employment costs are up 3.2% from the previous year's quarter. 

  "The number has caused a lot of volatility in the past," said Ken Fan, bond strategist Paribas Capital Markets in New York. 

  The long bond yield spiked to 6.07% immediately after the release of the data, from 6.03% before the release. 

  Yields of shorter-dated notes also rose.

text:
Australia's Westpac Sees GST Adding 2.1 Pct Pts To CPI

 
 

  SYDNEY (Dow Jones)--Australia's Westpac Banking Corp. estimates that the introduction of a 10% goods and services tax will boost the consumer price index by 2.1 percentage points over the long term and cause third-quarter inflation to jump even more. 

  The government plans to introduce a 10% goods and services tax, or GST, in July, 2000, to replace the wide range of sales taxes it currently levies. 

  But to get the legislation through the Senate, where the government lacks a majority, it agreed with the Australian Democrats party late in May to exempt "basic" foods from the GST. 

  To pay for the cost of exempting basic foods from its GST, the government cut back on reductions of some indirect state taxes and reduced diesel fuel subsidies. 

  Warren Hogan, economist at Westpac Banking Corp., estimates those changes to the government's original broad-based tax will, in total, reduce the inflationary impact of the goods and services tax, or GST, by about seven percentage points over the long term. 

  The bank now estimates the GST will add 2.1 percentage points to the country's consumer price index over the long term, down from an original estimate of 2.8 percentage points. Most of the reduction is the result of exempting basic food from the GST, Hogan said in a research paper. 

  The government itself had estimated the original tax plan would add 1.9 percentage points to the CPI over the longer term. New government estimates are expected to be issued in December.

text:
AWSJ: Column/Fischer -2: Issue Awaits Decision From Clinton

 
 

  By Tim Fischer 

  (Editor's Note: This is an opinion piece from Tuesday's Asian Wall Street Journal. Fischer is Australia's deputy prime minister and minister for trade.) 

  HONG KONG (Dow Jones)--For the last nine months the Australian and New Zealand lamb industries have been involved in a difficult fight against calls from the American sheep-meat industry for tariffs and quotas to be placed on our exports to the U.S. The crude nature of the remedy proposals under consideration, combined with the lack of any reasonable case for punishing Australian lamb producers in this way, has turned the lamb issue into a huge test for our bilateral trade relationship, as well as for the United States' credentials as a world leader committed to free and fair trade. 

  On June 22, the United States Senate delivered a principled decision to resist the appeal of protectionism for the steel industry by setting aside a bill to impose quotas on steel imports. The American sheep-meat industry's recommendations, based on findings from the United States International Trade Commission, are now before U.S. President Bill Clinton for a final decision. The president must now show the same level of leadership on the lamb issue. 

  The governments of Australia and New Zealand have been pressing strongly against any decision to impose unjustified trade restraints, arguing this will do nothing to help the U.S. domestic industry, while it will penalize Australia's fairly traded, unsubsidized prime lamb exports and the American consumer. Putting trade barriers in place would be sadly ironic, even more so when done on the mere basis of a 'threat' of injury to U.S. lamb, which is all that the ITC has determined. Furthermore, the ITC found that Australia and New Zealand were not engaged in unfair trading. 

  Indeed, this latest wave of protectionism is not so much a response to pressures from overseas lamb producers. U.S. lamb producers are urging drastic tariff and quota measures in a knee-jerk reaction to difficulties in the domestic market. This is wrong-headed. The difficulties the producers face are not related to imports. They stem from an outmoded marketing approach that has sought to pitch prices for lamb at levels which are well out of line with prices for competing foodstuffs. 

  In Australia and New Zealand, where lamb meat is competitively priced, per capita consumption is 20 times that of the United States. An opportunity for U.S. lamb producers to achieve similar results is going begging. 

  Furthermore, efforts to limit imports can only backfire on U.S. lamb producers themselves. The U.S. industry must realize that keeping products at artificially high prices is no way to grow any market. Far from strengthening their industry, the protection domestic producers seek would only weaken the market for their product, hurting producers in the process. While consumers would be among the first to suffer, in time the lamb industry itself would face the prospect of further contraction as the domestic market became even more marginalized. 

  Recognizing the opportunities that exist both for ourselves and U.S. producers, Australian and New Zealand lamb producers generously offered to commit up to $1.5 million a year over four years toward joint promotion with U.S. industry. Unfortunately, this innovative and forward-looking offer was rejected by the U.S. industry out of hand. 

  Structural change is under way in the U.S. lamb industry. Like any industry, change will occur regardless of any Band-Aid protectionist fix. A more positive approach would be to undertake a realistic adjustment program with cooperation and fair competition from foreign producers. All stand to benefit. Should efforts to restrict foreign lamb imports into the U.S. succeed, however, everyone involved will suffer: those who wish to export lamb to the American market, American consumers and eventually even the American lamb industry itself. 

  Moreover, if President Clinton takes the wrong step on lamb, he will send the wrong signal to agricultural producers and governments in other countries. He will be saying that they can deal with the pressures of change by erecting barriers to trade. 

  With the U.S. set to host the vital WTO Ministerial Meeting in Seattle at the end of this year, it is not only Australia and New Zealand that will be sitting in judgment on how the U.S. administration responds to these unfair calls for import relief. The entire world will be watching. 

  In Auckland, New Zealand last month, trade ministers of the economies of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation met to plan for Seattle and to review the encouraging signs of economic recovery in East Asia. They recognized the remarkable commitment to free trade from economies that have suffered enormously during Asia's financial crisis - a commitment to keep their markets open when domestic pressures to close them have been intense. We and our neighbors have applauded the great contribution the United States has made toward recovery in Asia. 

  Yet history tells us that the pace of trade liberalization depends on the larger economies leading by example, and the success of Seattle will depend in large measure on the leadership of the United States. Such leadership can only be demonstrated if it is clear that the U.S. is committed to the principles of free trade and can resist protectionist pressure at home. 

  The recent outcome on the steel quota bill gives hope that President Clinton's endorsement of a new round of trade negotiations in his State of the Union address this year was meaningful. Australia hopes that this important step will be followed by the right decision in the lamb case. An industry threatened by change is best assisted by domestic adjustment support, not barriers to competition. All our industries hope for is the opportunity for us to work with the U.S. toward an outcome that will provide the basis for real, long-term prosperity for us all. 

  President Clinton now has an opportunity to deliver to the American people a win-win solution on this issue. A win for the forces of free trade, a win for American lamb producers - and above all, a win for American consumers. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  July 05, 1999 19:33 ET (23:33 GMT)

text:
WSJ(7/27): Texaco Net Fell 20% In 2nd Quarter

 
  By Alexei Barrionuevo 
  Staff Reporter of The Wall Street Journal 

  Higher crude-oil prices and lucrative refining margins on the West Coast gave a huge boost to Atlantic Richfield Co. in the second quarter and cushioned a drop in earnings for Texaco Inc. 

  Like their competitors, both companies benefited from crude-oil prices that shot up to nearly $20 a barrel by the quarter's end and from tight gasoline supply in California, which pushed prices -- and profit margins -- well above the national average during the spring. 

  For Texaco, though, higher prices couldn't overcome the effect of weak refining margins overseas. Texaco's net income slid 20% to $273 million, or 50 cents a diluted share, from $342 million, or 61 cents a share, a year earlier. That was slightly above Wall Street's expectations of 49 cents a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. 

  The quarter included $76 million in asset write-downs and $67 million in employee separation costs, but they were largely offset by inventory valuation adjustments, gains on tax issues and gains on asset sales. Before special items, earnings were $286 million, or 52 cents a share. 

  Revenue rose 3% to $8.27 billion from $8.04 billion in 1998. 

  Texaco, based in White Plains, N.Y., said exploration and production earnings, before special items, rose 34% to $216 million, reflecting crude-oil prices that were up about 19% from a year earlier and up about 40% from the first quarter. 

  Texaco's U.S. refining business is part of a joint venture with Shell Oil Co. and Saudi Aramco. The company said improved West Coast refining and marketing margins, due mostly to refinery fires and other outages that caused supply shortages, were partly offset by problems at a Puget Sound refinery and scheduled maintenance at its Los Angeles refinery. Refining earnings overseas, however, fell 61% before unusual items. 

  Texaco Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Peter I. Bijur said the company so far this year has cut per-barrel expenses by 9%, compared with a year earlier. 

  Arco, based in Los Angeles, more than doubled its net income to $313 million, or 95 cents a diluted share, from $154 million, or 47 cents a share, a year earlier. 

  Excluding special items, profit was up 37% to $302 million, or 92 cents a diluted share, compared with $220 million, or 67 cents a share, last year. That beat analysts' estimate of 86 cents a share for the quarter, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. 

  Revenue climbed 21% to $3.22 billion from $2.65 billion in the year-earlier period. 

  Along with oil prices and California refining results, Arco Chairman and CEO Mike R. Bowlin credited the company's cost-cutting, saying that Arco expects to reach its goal of slashing $500 million in expenses by year end, one year ahead of schedule. 

  Arco said its refining and marketing earnings more than doubled to $206 million in the quarter, from $97 million in 1998. 

  Arco did it despite a scheduled shutdown at a Washington refinery that remained down most of June. Arco operates refineries in only five Western states, including California. 

  Oil and natural-gas production rose 10% in the quarter, helping push after-tax exploration and production profit to $174 million, up from $17 million in the yearearlier quarter, after a $75 million writedown of a gas field. 

  Shares of Texaco fell $1.50 to close at $60.875, while those of Arco dropped $1.8125 to close at $87.625, both in New York Stock Exchange composite trading. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  July 26, 1999 21:27 ET (01:27 GMT)

text:
S African Ctrl Bk -2: Won't Be Pushed Into Lower Rates

 
 

  JOHANNESBURG (Dow Jones)--Incoming South African Central Bank Governor Tito Mboweni Saturday reiterated his pledge to carry on the bank's tough monetarists approach, ruling out populist measures like pushing interest rates lower. 

  "Artificial low interest rates - forget it," he told a media briefing. 

  "It's a cost you will have to pay a couple of years down the line" if softer credit is pursed, he said. 

  South African government interest rates, through the securities repurchase rate, has fallen 8.25 percentage points to 13.600% since last October. But the pace of the decline has all but stopped in the past week. 

  Elements within the government are keen for rates to fall further so as to accelerate current anemic economic growth in the country. 

  Mboweni takes the helm of the the South African Reserve Bank Sunday, succeeding Chris Steals, a veteran of 44 years at the central bank, the last 10 years as governor. 

  Mboweni said controlling inflation remained a priority of the central bank and that it is considering setting growth targets in accordance with the government. 

  He said he hadn't talked about the issue with Finance Minister Trevor Manuel, who earlier this week predicted the establishment of a mutually agreeable inflation-target range by the first quarter of 2000. 

  "I hope the process (of setting targets) will be co-managed" with the finance ministry, Mboweni said.

text:
WSJ(8/25): Prices Of Wood Products Plunge

 
  By Jim Carlton 
  Staff Reporter of The Wall Street Journal 

  Wood-products prices have plunged from their record and near-record levels of only a few weeks ago amid an unexpected supply glut that analysts said again illustrates the timber industry's volatility. 

  Analysts cautioned that any slowdown in either the economy or housing market could cut short a resurgence in the timber industry that has been under way for much of the year. More likely, they said, is that markets will stabilize and even rebound as housing and remodeling activity pick up - as long as the Federal Reserve doesn't move to raise interest rates too much. Fed policy makers increased interest rates one-quarter percentage point yesterday. 

  "This industry ebbs and flows according to what the general market does," said Karl Lindberg, president of the Southern Forest Products Association, an industry trade group in Kenner, La. 

  As of Friday, the composite price per 1,000 board feet of framing lumber had fallen to $391 - a 20% drop from the record level of $490 reached in mid-July and the fifth consecutive weekly decrease, according to Random Lengths, an industry newsletter in Eugene, Ore. Prices also have been falling in other forestry products such as structural paneling, which dropped 26% to $333 per 1,000 board feet as of Friday from a high of $453 on July 16, according to officials at Random Lengths who add that these are the most precipitous drops in six years. 

  The price drops come as something of a surprise in the industry, which has watched prices increase for 10 months in a row on demand fueled primarily by a robust U.S. housing market. That trend led to unexpectedly strong earnings reports by many of the timber companies, such as Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Portland, Ore., and Plum Creek Timber Co., Seattle, in the second quarter. 

  Although the housing market remains strong, industry executives say the supply of wood products recently exceeded demand in part because of the unusually hot summer weather in many parts of the country. That led to construction delays that backed up timber products in the distribution pipeline, they say. 

  Timber production, meanwhile, has ramped up rapidly. The amount of timber products made on the West Coast jumped 11% through June from the same period last year, while they rose 7% in the South and 5.6% in the Mountain West over the same time, according to estimates by industry trade groups. 

  "The numbers have been spectacular in terms of production, exceeding everyone's expectation," said Mike O'Halloran, president of the Western Wood Products Association, a trade group based in Portland. 

  Timber manufacturers aren't expressing too much concern over the price drops just yet. While few will predict when prices might bottom out, most people in the industry view the situation as a temporary setback to a recovery they say could last for two or more years. During the second quarter, the industry pulled out of a two-year slump that was prompted by an oversupply of wood products and slackened demand from Asian markets. 

  "You have to remember where prices were when they started coming off," said Keith Matheney, vice president of core businesses at Louisiana-Pacific. "This is in my view a normal correction." 

  Indeed, manufacturers report continued strong demand in the U.S. for lumber and other wood products. 

  "The other thing helping us is that Europe is getting better and is likely to continue improving over the next five years," said Rick Holley, chief executive of Plum Creek. "I think the overall industry is going to have an excellent year." 

  Analysts pointed out, though, that the timber industry remains a highly volatile sector whose fortunes can change overnight. Aside from being prone to the vagaries of economic cycles, analysts said the industry suffers from being fragmented into thousands of producers who frequently manufacture excess quantities. "We are sort of guessing where we go from here," said Burrle Elmore, editor of Random Lengths. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  August 25, 1999 00:41 ET (04:41 GMT)
label: non-inflation-related

text:
Venezuelan Official: Oil-Price Rise May Obviate New Debt

 

  CARACAS (Dow Jones)--Venezuelan Planning Minister Jorge Giordani suggested Tuesday that the country may not issue foreign debt, or simply reduce the amount it originally sought in overseas capital markets this year. 

  The sustained rise in oil prices could mean windfall revenues of up to $1.2 billion, Giordani said in answer to questions on whether Venezuela still plans to raise $1.4 billion to $2 billion abroad. 

  He didn't elaborate. 

  The executive branch is looking to finance a 1999 budget deficit equivalent to 9% of gross domestic product, or about $9 billion. 

  Giordani said the economy is still on course to meet the official 1999 inflation target of 20% to 24%, which is down from the near 30% rise in prices last year. 

  Venezuela's consumer price index rose 1.6% in July, up from the 1.5% rise posted in June but down from the 2.1% increase in July of last year. 

  Inflation for the first seven months of the year amounted to 11.9%, down markedly from 18.2% the year before, the Central Bank of Venezuela announced Monday. 

  Giordani said the executive branch believes the economy will recuperate "soon," and added that the recovery in demand wouldn't fuel inflation. He didn't, however, explain why. 

  But economists point out that the collapse in demand is precisely the reason inflation growth has been moderating. 

  Economists reckon the economy will contract by between 4% and 9% this year. 

  -By Fred Pals; 582 564 1339; fpals@ap.org 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  August 03, 1999 14:36 ET (18:36 GMT)
label: inflation-related

text:
WSJ(8/31): Major Makers Of Cigarettes Raise Prices

 
  By Gordon Fairclough 
  Staff Reporter of The Wall Street Journal 

  NEW YORK -- Philip Morris Cos., maker of Marlboros, raised prices on all of its major cigarette brands by 18 cents a pack, and other tobacco companies immediately followed suit. 

  Discounts offered by the cigarette makers may help soften the blow to smokers in the near term. But David J. Adelman, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York, estimates the retail price of a pack of cigarettes next year will average about $2.65, nearly $1 more than in 1997. 

  The price increase is the second largest in history, after a 45-cent-a-pack boost last November, when tobacco companies agreed to pay $206 billion to 46 states that had sued seeking to recover money spent caring for people with smoking-related diseases. 

  Cigarette makers confirmed the 18-cent-a-pack increase, but declined to comment further. Analysts said the latest jump will cover an increase in the federal excise tax on cigarettes, which goes up by 10 cents a pack starting Jan. 1. Another four cents of the per-pack increase is needed to pay tobacco companies' obligations under various legal settlements, they said. The remaining four cents a pack amounts to a fairly standard annual price rise for the industry. 

  "If they didn't take this price increase, profits would have been under pressure," Mr. Adelman said. 

  Besides Philip Morris, the nation's largest cigarette maker, and R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings Inc., maker of Camels, British American Tobacco PLC's Brown & Williamson unit and Loews Corp.'s Lorillard Tobacco Co. subsidiary also boosted their prices, a move that is likely to widen profit margins through the end of the year, analysts said. 

  In New York Stock Exchange composite trading, Philip Morris shares were up 18.75 cents to $37.75; R.J. Reynolds shares fell 12.5 cents to $28, and Loews shares fell 87.5 cents to $78.625. American depositary shares of British American Tobacco were unchanged at $17.5625 on the American Stock Exchange. 

  The higher prices could further damp demand for cigarettes. But low unemployment and the buoyant economy, which have put more disposable income in the hands of smokers, may blunt any decline, said Martin Feldman, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in New York. 

  The price increase came earlier than expected by wholesalers, preventing them from stocking up on cigarettes at the old, lower prices. "It was a big surprise when we got the telegram last Friday afternoon," said Del Peterson, president of Moreland Wholesale Inc., in Cheyenne, Wyo. Mr. Peterson complained that wholesalers will get pinched, since they have to start paying the new prices before they can raise the prices they charge retailers. 

  The timing of the price rise, well ahead of the tax increase and settlement obligations that will kick in next year, also gives tobacco companies plenty of flexibility to offer discounts to customers, Mr. Feldman said. "Consumers will only gradually feel the price increase," he predicted. 

  After last year's sharp price rise, cigarette makers used aggressive discounts and promotions to keep smokers from abandoning premium brands in favor of lower-cost alternatives. The strategy worked, Mr. Feldman said, preventing serious erosion of the big-name brands' market share. 

  Even so, some cigarette sellers caution that sooner or later, the price increases will turn off smokers. "They're going to drive everybody to lower priced brands and roll-your-own," said Michael P. Washo, owner of Carolina Tobacco Emporium in Enfield, Conn. He said he has seen a sharp increase in sales of loose tobacco and rolling paper to customers who now prefer to make their own cigarettes.

text:
Interview/McDonough-3: "Attentive" To Inflation Pressures

 
 

  Turning to inflation, McDonough, who arrived in South Africa Friday morning, said he hadn't had a chance to digest Friday's batch of U.S. labor data - which analysts said was clearly inflationary. 

  Nevertheless, the Fed deputy chairman said the U.S. central bank had to be "attentive" to a situation where labor costs rise beyond productivity gains. 

  Late this week, the U.S. economy was presented with clear evidence of this, through a series of government data. 

   McDonough refused to be drawn on the monetary policy implications of the most recent figures, but said "by far, the best time to do anything about inflation is early." 

  On Friday, the U.S. Labor Department said employers added 310,000 more workers to their payrolls in July - well above expectations of a rise of 206,000. At the same time, workers' average hourly earnings rose by 0.5%, or six cents, last month, higher than predictions for a 0.3% increase. It was the fastest monthly wage climb in six months. 

  The set of figures followed data showing a softening in productivity improvement. 

  Global markets were spooked Friday by these worse-than- expected numbers and sold off. 

  McDonough offered no view on whether the latest inflationary figures warranted a tightening of U.S. credit. 

  The Fed last raised interest rates in late June, lifting the Federal Funds rate 25 basis points to 5%.

text:
WSJ(9/7): Foreign Exchange: Dollar Regains Some Strength

 
  By Marianne Sullivan 
  Staff Reporter of The Wall Street Journal 

  The dollar seemed back in fashion Friday as investor sentiment did an aboutface, following signs U.S. inflation might be less threatening than feared. 

  "Market sentiment has swung away from expecting a rate hike," said Marc Chandler, currency strategist at Pittsburgh's Mellon Bank. However, Mr. Chandler still expects the dollar to trade lower in the early part of this week, from 108.80 yen to 110.50 yen. He expects the euro to trade in a range of $1.0500 to $1.0700 in the early part of the week. 

  The dollar has tended recently to follow movements in U.S. stocks and bonds, which have been pressured by expectations of tighter monetary policy. Friday, the U.S. currency shared a relief rally with stocks and bonds after the August employment report showed less overheating in the economy than expected. 

  In late-afternoon trading Friday, the dollar was at 109.93 yen, up from 109.13 yen late Thursday. The euro was trading at $1.0613, down from $1.0690. Sterling was at $1.0620, down from $1.0675. 

  The New York exchange markets were closed yesterday to observe Labor Day. 

  With the market living from indicator to indicator and comment to comment, a firm commitment to bid the dollar higher or lower against either currency will be stymied by the anxiety ahead of U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's speech tomorrow in Michigan, Japan's long-awaited gross-domestic-product numbers Thursday and U.S. producer prices Friday. 

  "A lot will depend on the other side of the equation, with rising optimism about the euro zone and Japan, " said Kathy Jones, currency analyst at Prudential Securities in New York. 

  The euro, she said, should be the beneficiary of the uncertainty surrounding both U.S. and Japanese fundamentals. 

  Since the dollar began its decline in mid-July, the euro has moved about 5% higher since bottoming out July 13 at $1.0108. The yen, however, has moved more than 10% higher since its July 8 low of 122.75 yen. Ms. Jones said the euro has more room to move higher. 

  Investors wanting to get out of dollar holdings are reluctant to buy yen due to the currency's potential for a quick decline if Japan intervenes to halt its appreciation or next week's GDP numbers fail to validate Japan's recovery story. 

  The yen, which has been a favorite for investors and hedgers, is considered overbought, Ms. Jones said. 

  Last Wednesday, it posted a seven-and-a-half-month high of 108.73 yen against the dollar. But at these higher levels, she said, the currency is vulnerable and could decline rapidly if the Bank of Japan opts to limit the currency rise or Friday's growth numbers disappoint investors. Mr. Chandler said positioning in preparation for central-bank intervention and Japan's growth numbers should be the driving force behind the dollar's trade this week. 

  Meanwhile, financial problems brewing in emerging markets-debt restructuring in Ecuador, Chile's float of its currency and renewed currency woes in Thailandcould eventually lead spooked international investors back into the dollar. 

  A lingering political wrangle over the Taiwan Strait has already weighed considerably on the yen against the dollar in several Asian sessions this week. 

  Any development interpreted as bringing Beijing and Taipei closer to armed conflict would buoy the dollar. The New Taiwan dollar was at NT$31.750 late Friday, unchanged from Thursday. 

  The U.S. dollar was at 1,191 won, up a bit from 1,190 won. 

  Steven Xu, a treasury economist at the Standard Chartered Bank in Hong Kong, said although developments in corporate sector will continue to drive volatile swings in the dollar-won exchange rate this week, the U.S. currency should remain within a broad 1,180 won to 1,200 won band. 

  But South Korean Friday pledged to defend five Yellow Sea islands after North Korea threatened to use military force to gain control of contested waters around them. If shooting breaks out, the dollar would rise on "flight to safety" buying.

Thai Fin Min: Oil Prices Higher On Global Mkt, Not Baht

 
 

  BANGKOK (Dow Jones)--Thai Finance Minister Tarrin Nimmanhaeminda said Thursday the government shouldn't take immediate action to ease domestic oil prices, because the increases in oil prices are due mostly to global market factors, rather than local or currency factors. 

  Tarrin told reporters after a speech to foreign businessmen and the Thai Customs Department that the government should wait for the results of an upcoming meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries before deciding to take action. 

  Industry Minister Suwat Liptapanlop said earlier Thursday that domestic oil prices were at their highest levels this year, and the government was looking at what it could do to stem further increases. 

  The retail price of unleaded premium gasoline is up 0.30 baht (THB) on last week's levels to THB13.29. 

  Meanwhile, the U.S. dollar had risen to around THB39.70 midday Thursday, from less than THB39 last week. 

  Tarrin said high oil prices shouldn't affect growth prospects this year. The government recently revised its 1999 gross domestic product growth target to 3%, from 1%. 

  But with much of the population still suffering from the effects of a two-year recession, the government has been under pressure to cut taxes on oil as a means of easing the burden of higher prices. 

  Private refining and retailing firms, on the other hand, have been complaining that the state Petroleum Authority of Thailand's, or PTT, retail gas stations have only been able to maintain such low prices because of state subsidies. The private firms have to match PTT to maintain market share, but say they are losing money.

Australia Employment/Analysts -2: Wage Index Due Wed

 
 

  But according to a survey released Tuesday, Australian manufacturers expected the economy will continue to grow strongly in coming months, creating the most positive outlook for employment growth in more than four years. The survey was carried out by the Australian Chamber of Commerce & Industry and Westpac Banking Corp. 

  Cost pressures are expected to rise in the next six months due to a tightening labor market and higher oil prices, the survey said. 

  The Bureau of Statistics will release its wage cost index for the second quarter at 0130 GMT Wednesday. 

  Analysts on average forecast a modest 0.6% rise in the index in the second quarter from the first quarter, down from a 0.9% rise in the first quarter. 

  The index measures movements in underlying wages by calculating the change in the wage and salary cost of a sampling of jobs. 

  Grant Fitzner, an economist at HSBC Market, said annual wage costs are stuck around 3.0%, which is very modest wage inflation and "quite easily affordable." 

  Assuming a consumer price inflation of 2.0%, then productivity growth of only 1.0% is needed to pay for 3.0% wages growth, Fitzner said. 

  The Reserve Bank of Australia previously has said it expects the consumer price index to rise to about 2.0% in the first half of 2000. The consumer price index rose 1.1% on year in the second quarter of 1999.

text:
Vietnam Electricity Price -3: Money Needed For Development

 

  Vietnam's electricity charges are subsidized by the state in order to ensure that customers can afford a steady supply of power for their homes and factories. 

  But the World Bank and other development agencies have long pushed Hanoi to increase its power prices. They say the government must increase the amount it charges end-users in order to raise the funds needed to improve Vietnam's still-basic power supply structure. 

  Power failures are common in Vietnam's major cities, and many rural areas still have no access to electricity other than through the use of local generators. 

  "It is necessary to apply (higher electricity) prices so that the power industry can have more money for development," the pricing committee official said Thursday. 

  According to the new government decree, urban households from October 1 will pay a minimum of 500 dong ($1=VND13,984) a kilowatt hour for the power they use, while rural residents will pay VND360/kwh. Previous residential power prices weren't stated in the decision - a copy of which was obtained by Dow Jones Newswires - but the pricing committee official said Hanoi's new price structure represents an average 6% increase over previous power costs. 

  He said businesses and administrative offices will from next month pay an average of 10% to 12% more for their power than they pay now. 

  The pricing committee will outline different costs for electricity use during the day and during the night, in a bid to help spread demand for power over each 24-hour period and prevent power shortages during peak hours, he added.

  With the Australian economy growing at a rapid pace, economists have brought forward forecasts of interest rate rises ahead of the introduction of an inflationary 10% goods and service tax next July. 

  Many analysts are now predicting a 25-basis-point or 50-basis-point rise in interest rates after the Reserve Bank of Australia meets for its next monthly policy meeting Nov. 2. 

  But Giltrap doesn't expect a sharp rise in interest rates over the next year. The key overnight cash rate now stands at 4.75%. 

  "The unemployment rate has blipped up so we don't have the labor market tightness that they do in the U.S.," which is part of the reason the U.S. Federal Reserve has raised interest rates by 50 basis points since June, she said. Australia's unemployment rate stood at 7.4% in September, compared to 4.2% in the U.S.

  Earlier Tuesday, a report released by HSBC Markets in Australia found that major Australian federal wage agreements reached in the third quarter rose by an annualized average of 3.4%, down from 3.5% in the quarter before.
