text:
WHITE HOUSE WATCH: Spooked By Jittery Stock Market

 
 

  By Alex Keto 

  A Dow Jones Newswires Analysis 

 

  WASHINGTON (Dow Jones)--It took a teetering stock market Friday to get the Clinton administration to drop some of its budget bluster and take the threat of a partial government shutdown off the negotiating table. 

  For the first time, White House officials promised publicly that U.S. President Bill Clinton will sign a new continuing resolution, or temporary spending bill, when the current one expires at the end of next week. 

  "The president is not interested in shutting any of the government down," said White House spokesman Joe Lockhart. 

  Until now, White House officials had repeatedly said maybe Clinton would sign a new CR, or, maybe he wouldn't. The tactic was designed to put maximum pressure on the Republicans in Congress to move forward with passing the spending bills needed to fund the entire federal in fiscal year 2000. 

  However, after remarks by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan and poor inflation outlook figures frightened investors, the White House apparently figured that adding another element of instability to the financial markets was unwise at best. 

  What spooked investors was the combination of Greenspan's cautioning banks they need to set aside reserves for any downdraft in stock prices and the news the producer price index jumped 1.1% in September from the month earlier. 

 

  Treasury Secretary Summers Gives Marching Orders 

 

  With early indications showing the Dow Jones Industrial Average would open sharply lower, the White House mobilized quickly Friday morning to do what little it could to prevent a retreat from becoming a stampede. 

  Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers gave White House officials explicit instructions on what they could say and what the couldn't say to restore a semblance of confidence. 

  "I think it is important to remember the fundamentals of our economy remain strong. While we monitor all economic indicators, we base government policy and economic policy on overall long-term economic trends," Lockhart said parroting Summers' message. 

  Asked if he could comment directly on the prospect for inflation in the economy, Lockhart said he couldn't because remarks along these lines hadn't been cleared by the Treasury secretary. 

  National Economic Council Chairman Gene Sperling was given greater latitude and used it during a brief appearance with the Rev. Jesse Jackson on a separate matter. 

  Speaking to reporters outside the West Wing, Sperling said the administration expects continued growth coupled with low inflation. 

  In a surprise move, Sperling also gave an early indication of what the third quarter gross domestic product will look like to support his forecast. 

  "The third quarter GDP numbers should be quite solid," Sperling said. He didn't elaborate on this prediction, but administration officials rarely if ever offer previews of economic figures. 

 

  Trying To Find A Sanction To Slap On Pakistan 

 

  William Milam, the U.S. Ambassador to Pakistan, met Pakistani Army Chief of Staff Gen. Pervaiz Musharraf for two hours Friday but found the general unwilling to make any commitment to return Pakistan to civilian rule soon. 

  Rebuffed, the White House began a search for an economic sanction to slap on Pakistan but was stymied by the fact that it has already slapped a number of sanctions on Islamabad because of its nuclear weapons tests. 

  "The lawyers are looking at this now....In practical terms, there's already a wide range of sanctions applied against Pakistan," Lockhart said. 

  Likewise, the U.S. will have little success in trying to put pressure on Pakistan by seeking to block the International Monetary Fund from giving Islamabad loans. The IMF has already suspended its loan program to Pakistan anyway. 

  "At this point, it's a bit of a moot point," Lockhart conceded. 

  "If they get to the point where they come into compliance, we'll take a look at whether the behavior of the military government there warrants the United States' looking at blocking further loans," Lockhart said. 

  -By Alex Keto; 202 862 9256; Dow Jones Newswires, alex.keto@dowjones.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
REPEAT:Iraq Al-Anbari Sees $22 As "Reasonable Oil Price"

 
 

  BAGHDAD (AP)--The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries should work towards "a reasonable price" for crude oil in the range of $22 a barrel, Iraq's candidate for OPEC secretary general said Monday. 

  Abdulamir al-Anbari, in a telephone interview from Paris, also dismissed reports that Iraq will drop his nomination in return for political concessions from Saudi Arabia. 

  "$22 is a reasonable price...If prices shoot to $28 or $30 that will be too high," al-Anbari said. 

  The 1999 average of OPEC's basket price is currently $15.49 a barrel. 

  The value of the reference basket of seven crude oils used by the OPEC as a gauge of world oil price levels averaged $22.85 a barrel Friday. 

  Al-Anbari's remarks contradict those by Iraqi parliamentary speaker Saadoun Hammadi Sunday in which he called on OPEC to cut production further to raise oil prices to more than $33 a barrel. 

  They also run contrary to those by President Saddam Hussein who was reported as telling his cabinet last month that the price was still too low and accused the U.S. of manipulating the market. 

  OPEC ministers, who met in Vienna last month, agreed to keep their oil cutbacks in place through the end of March 2000. But they were deadlocked on the issue of selecting a new secretary general with Rilwanu Lukman remaining in place until next March. 

  Al-Anbari now competes with candidates from OPEC's two biggest members - Saudi Arabia's Suleiman Jasir al-Herbish and Iran's Hossein Kazempour Ardebili. 

  "What political concessions my government can expect from Saudi Arabia? Nothing. Regarding sanctions, that is in the hands of America," al-Anbari said. 

  Oil Minister Amer Mohammed Rashid, in a news conference last week, described al-Anbari as "the most qualified" among OPEC's candidates. "The Iraqi candidate," he said, "is the one who will guarantee OPEC's independence...and safeguard it against external influences." 

  Iraq has repeatedly accused Saudi Arabia of producing more crude than what it should in a bid to flood markets and lower prices to serve U.S. strategic interests in the region. 

  Rashid said Iraq had no intention of dropping al-Anbari's nomination. 

  Al-Anbari, however, said he was certain the Saudis and others will block his nomination but added many in OPEC opted for "the most efficient, the most qualified" to take the job. 

  And since OPEC rules require a unanimous decision in appointing a secretary general, al-Anbari suggested the formation of a high-level committee to decide who is better-placed to win the top job among the three candidates. 

  "Many (OPEC) ministers have agreed to this proposal," he said. 

  Iraq nominated al-Anbari just before the OPEC talks last month, a move many saw as a maneuver to block a Saudi or Iranian winning the job following the withdrawal of Algeria's Oil Minister Yousef Yousefi. 

  Oil Ministry officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they had nothing against the qualifications of the Saudi candidate. "He's a good man but our candidate is also of a high caliber," said one. 

  Anbari holds law degrees from Baghdad University and Harvard University and has held many posts in the Iraqi oil industry in the late 1960s through the 1970s. He also served in the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries and was director of the OPEC legal department for more than 25 years ago. 

  He has been Iraq's ambassador to Britain and the U.S. and was Baghdad's U.N. envoy during the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. In 1992, he became Iraq's envoy to UNESCO in Paris and led the Iraqi team in negotiations for the U.N.-approved oil-for-food deal. 

  -By Leon Barkho; +964-1-8866496

text:
Treasurys -2: Rate Uncertainty Main Theme Of Market

 
 

  Despite the recent spike in oil and other commodity prices, investors and brokers have become so impermeable to bad inflation news that the market showed little reaction to a slew of data showing consumer spending remains rampant and the labor market remains tight. 

  The number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits rose an unexpected 10,000 to 312,000 in the week that ended Oct. 2, partly reflecting the lingering effects of flooding caused by Hurricane Floyd. 

  The increase surprised Wall Street, which had expected claims to decline after a big gain in the previous week, yet the market didn't seem to take notice. 

  Meanhwile, job cuts for September increased 7% from August, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas. The firm attributed the monthly rise to ongoing efforts to shut down unprofitable units and reduce staff. 

  At the same time, an analysis of sales at 69 retailers by the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi places September same-store sales 6.7% above year-ago levels, equaling August's gain. 

  This was consistent with a similar survey run by Salomon Smith Barney, whose chain store index was up 6.3% in September from a year ago, also matching August's gain. 

  Yet a third report Thursday showed U.S. consumer credit expanded sharply in August, making for another sign of Americans' willingness to continue spending. 

  The Federal Reserve said Thursday that outstanding consumer credit advanced at a 9.6% annual rate, or by $10.8 billion, in August - the fastest increase in dollar terms since January, which saw a $15.3 billion increase, the Fed said. 

  The number underscores the strength in domestic consumption, which is what worries Federal Reserve officials. The Federal Open Market Committee announced Tuesday it was leaning toward tighter monetary policy ahead, noting that "growth of demand has continued to outpace that of supply." 

  This consumption news will become an irritant factor for the voting members of the FOMC, as this survey suggests consumers have not slowed down their spending spree despite recent monetary policy tightening. 

  Economists surveyed by Dow Jones Newswires and CNBC are calling for an increase of 220,000 in payrolls in September, and for the unemployment rate to remain steady at 4.2%. 

  Yet, despite all of the potentially negative news late, the market didn't react, preferring to mark time ahead of the payroll number. This is because the market has already adequately priced in the potential rate move. 

  For example, Treasury market observers noted that the yield curve has flattened since the Federal Reserve adopted a "tightening bias" Tuesday, with the yields of longer-dated maturities moving closer together with the shorter-dated Treasurys. 

  But even though the market has rebounded off of its lows Thursday, analysts say that investors remain extremely cautious and defensive. 

  "The market is directionless and it's searching for a theme," said David Greenlaw, money market economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co. Inc. in New York. 

  "But it's unlikely it find direction in Friday's number," he added, "as there's a series of data due out between now and Nov. 16 that could potentially steer the Fed one way or another." 

-By Umberto Torresan; Dow Jones Newswires; 
 201-938-2206; umberto.torresan@dowjones.com

text:
Kazakstan Forced To Sell Tengiz Oil Stake - Official

 

  ALMATY, Kazakstan (Dow Jones)--The government of Kazakstan is forced to sell a part of its stake in international oil operating consortium, Tengizchevroil, because of its cash crisis, a top official said Monday. 

  "The general economic situation is forcing" the government to sell a part of its holding in the consortium, which operates the country's biggest oil field, Tengiz, said Kananbek Zhumin, director at state oil company Kazakoil. 

  Like several top Kazak officials, Zhumin said he is against the plan to reduce the government's stake in the company, possibly the state's most valuable asset. The plan, initially announced by the then-Prime Minister Nurlan Balgimbayev, has prompted unusually vocal opposition in Kazakstan's government circles. 

  Analysts say the government needs a massive privatization deal before the end of this year, to plug a budget gap, largely caused by low world oil prices early this year, as well as the financial crisis in neighboring Russia last year. 

  Zhumin said Monday the government has approached 20 major oil companies with an offer that is thought to involve 10% of the operating company. 

  "Officially, I can say there have been such talks, but as far as I know, there has so far been no final decision," Zhumin said. 

  Kazakstan is in the middle of a government crisis after Prime Minister Nurlan Balgimbayev resigned Friday, officially to return to Kazakhoil as the company's president. The country, where the powerful president appoints the ministers, is now run by an acting government. 

  The Kazakoil official Monday declined to name the government's asking price. 

  "It is in the billions," Zhumin said. 

  Press reports have put the asking price between $1.2 billion and $1.6 billion. Last week, Russia's biggest oil company, OAO Lukoil, said it is interested in acquiring the stake but called the Kazak government's asking price "excessive." 

  The other members of the consortium - Chevron (CHV) and Mobil (MOB) - are also thought to be considering the Kazak government's preliminary offer. 

  France's Total Fina S.A. (TOT), which is a stake holder in another Kazakstan-based consortium, the Offshore Kazakstan International Operating Company (OKIOC), has also announced its interest in the stake. 

  Tengizchevroil produces 220,000 barrels oil crude oil a day, with an output of 260,000 b/d targeted by the middle of next year, according to the consortium. 

  Large-scale privatization sales have become the government's recurrent resolution to its wide budget deficits. 

  Late last year Kazakstan helped balance its budget by selling its stake in OKIOC to the U.S.'s Phillips Petroleum and Japan's Inpex. 

  This year, Kazakstan's cash needs will also depend on the government's ability to reach a new loan deal with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. 

  After talks at last week's IMF and World Bank annual meetings in Washington, the loan negotiations are expected to resume later this month. 

  Kazakstan targets an oil output of 28.5 million metric tons this year, compared with 26.0 million tons in 1998, a senior official from the Ministry of Energy, Industry and Trade said, also speaking at the Monday press conference.

Verbatim Text Of The FOMC Decision On Interest Rates

 
 

  NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--The following is the verbatim text of the Federal Reserve Open Market Committee announcement Tuesday afternoon. 

  The Federal Open Market Committee today voted to raise its target for the federal funds rate by 25 basis points to 5 1/2%. In a related action, the Board of Governors approved a 25 basis point increase in the discount rate to 5.0%. 

  Although cost pressures appear generally contained, risks to sustainable growth persist. Despite tentative evidence of a slowing in certain interest-sensitive sectors of the economy and of accelerating productivity, the expansion of activity continues in excess of the economy's growth potential. As a consequence, the pool of available workers willing to take jobs has been drawn down further in recent months, a trend that must eventually be contained if inflationary imbalances are to remain in check and economic expansion continue. 

  Today's increase in the federal funds rate, together with the policy actions in June and August and the firming of conditions more generally in U.S. financial markets over the course of the year, should markedly diminish the risk of inflation going forward. As a consequence, the directive the Federal Open Market Committee adopted is symmetrical with regard to the outlook for policy over the near term. 

  In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved requests submitted by the Boards of Directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Boston, Cleveland, Richmond and Kansas City. The discount rate is the rate charged depository institutions when they borrow short-term adjustment credit from their district Federal Reserve Banks. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
WSJ(11/11): US Oct PPI Declines 0.1%; Core Rate Up 0.3%

 
  By John McKinnon 
  Staff Reporter of The Wall Street Journal 

  WASHINGTON -- Producer prices fell in October for the first time in eight months, but underlying the good news were some potentially troublesome trends. 

  The Labor Department said the producer-price index declined 0.1% last month on a seasonally adjusted basis, helped by big drops in food and energy costs. But the so-called core rate of prices, excluding the volatile food and energy categories, was up by 0.3%, a lot more than the 0.1% economists had projected. 

  That number was affected largely by big one-month increases for autos (1.1%) and prescription drugs (1.2%). Although observers in both industries said the jumps likely were exaggerated by statistical factors, some economists couldn't help but suspect that real-world price pressures also are at work. That could draw the attention of Federal Reserve policy makers, who meet Tuesday to decide whether the hot U.S. economy needs an interest-rate increase to cool off. 

  Of the two widely noted factors in yesterday's numbers, the drug-price increase attracted more attention, because of recent drug-industry merger activity as well as the political heat being generated by the issue. 

  On Tuesday, the House Democratic leadership and first lady Hillary Rodham Clinton held a Capitol Hill rally to tout President Clinton's proposed prescriptiondrug benefit for Medicare, the federal health program for the elderly and the disabled. In addition, some consumer advocates worry about the possible impact of growing concentration in the industry. 

  Several analysts noted that drug companies often implement price increases toward the end of the year, in hopes of affecting orders placed for the new calendar year. In addition, the analysts noted that some new drugs with fewer side effects are being priced at significant premiums. 

  The analysts added that some genericdrug makers have been more aggressive about raising prices in recent years, a trend that could have contributed to the October drug-price jump. The drug categories that saw the largest increases include some with a significant generic-drug presence, including hormones (5.3%), antiarthritics (4.5%), analgesics (2.6%), and dermatologicals (2.5%), said William Snyders, a Labor Department economist. 

  Still, several industry analysts viewed the October drug-price jump as an anomaly. In general, price increases in recent months "are nothing different than what we've seen the last four-five years," said Hemant Shah, pharmaceuticals analyst for HKS & Co. 

  The increase in auto prices appeared to be affected in part by record-breaking demand for cars this year, analysts said. That put more year-2000 models into the sales mix as soon as they were available, said Paul Taylor, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, McLean, Va. 

  From October 1998 to October 1999, prices for new cars are up only 0.3% on a nonseasonally adjusted basis, he said. The producer-price report reflects "an anomaly in the inventory of new cars," Mr. Taylor said. 

  A record total of 16.8 million units (cars and light trucks) are likely to be sold in the U.S. in 1999, Mr. Taylor said. The old record of 16.04 million units was set in 1986. 

  David Littman, chief economist at Comerica Inc. in Detroit, also pointed to the weakening dollar as a key factor, as it makes foreign cars more expensive in the U.S. "Competition remains a restraining factor, but nothing is more powerful than a reversal of the strengthening dollar," he said. 

  But major foreign auto makers insist the fierce pricing battles in the marketplace mean they have little room to pass the effect of a weaker dollar on to consumers. 

  The producer-price report comes in time to influence Tuesday's meeting of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee. Fed officials have said the producerprice numbers don't matter much in their decision-making about interest rates because they are so much narrower than the consumer-price index, which doesn't come out again until Wednesday. Some economists said the PPI number will carry more weight this time. 

  "The greater-than-expected rise in the core PPI has swayed our expectations for a Nov. 16th rate hike," said analysts at Warburg Dillon Read, Stamford, Conn. "We now put a 60-40 probability" on a one-quarter point rate increase. 

  Overall, the October producer-price numbers were a big improvement over September, when the core rate jumped 0.8%. Excluding the increase for autos and light trucks, in fact, the Labor Department said that the core rate would have been in line with expectations. Still, policy makers aren't likely to dismiss the auto- and drug-price increases as mere statistical noise, Warburg analysts said. "We don't believe the Fed is going to play this game,"said Joe Carson, a Warburg economist. 

  Analysts also noted that price pressures seem to be building further back in the producer pipeline. For example, prices for intermediate-stage goods other than food and energy were up 0.4%, said David Orr, chief economist at First Union Corp., Charlotte, N.C. Also, of the more than 60 core intermediate-stage materials, prices of more than two-thirds increased, he said. "I see a continuation of the gradual but consistent upturn in inflationary pressures," Mr. Orr said. 

  Other analysts made much less of the latest report. Over the past 12 months, in fact, producer-price growth remained relatively tame at 2.7%. "This is marginally negative news that shouldn't fundamentally alter inflation expectations," said Jay Feldman, economist with Credit Suisse First Boston. 

  As for any rise in pipeline pressures, he said, that probably will take a backseat to recent statistics showing decelerating wages and accelerating productivity. 

  Adding to the picture of a bustling economy was a new weekly report on unemployment claims. It showed that for the week ended Nov. 6, initial claims were down 6,000 to 285,000 on a seasonally adjusted basis. 

  --- 

  Gregory L. White in Detroit contributed to this article. 

  ---

Finished goods ......... 135.0     2.7 
 Minus food & energy ... 147.5     1.9 
Intermediate goods ..... 125.2     2.4 
Crude goods ............ 104.9     11.6

text:
WSJ(11/30):Column: Economic Freedom Marches On

 
 

  By By Gerald P. O'Driscoll Jr., Kim R. Holmes And Melanie Kirkpatrick 

  (Editor's Note: This is an opinion piece from Tuesday's Wall Street Journal. Mr. O'Driscoll and Mr. Holmes, of the Heritage Foundation, and Ms. Kirkpatrick, of the Journal's editorial page, are co-editors of the "2000 Index of Economic Freedom." 

  NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--At the dawn of a new century and a new millennium, it's good news to learn that economic freedom is on the rise world-wide. 

  That's the principal finding of this year's edition of the Index of Economic Freedom, jointly published by the Heritage Foundation and The Wall Street Journal. Of the 161 countries rated, many more (57) expanded economic freedom during the past year than curtailed it (34). 

  If this trend continues, the world-wide growth in economic freedom will be measured by the increase in prosperity of more and more of the world's people. In future centuries, people may come to marvel over the concept of "poverty" and how some governments relegated their citizens to that awful state when they might instead have lifted them into prosperity. 

  But for now, poverty is still with us. Despite the gains recorded in this year's Index of Economic Freedom, the bad news is that a majority of the world's economies remain unfree. Overall, the economies of 73 countries are rated this year as "free" or "mostly free," while 88 earned ratings of "mostly unfree" or "repressed." The freest economies are concentrated in North America and Europe, while a majority of the repressed economies are in Asia and Africa. Latin America showed the most improvement. 

  The Index of Economic Freedom is now in its sixth edition. Every year we rank the world's economies according to 50 economic variables in 10 broad categories: banking, capital flows and foreign investment, monetary policy, fiscal burden of government, trade policy, wages and prices, government intervention in the economy, property rights, regulation, and black markets. Each year the data point to the same important conclusion: Countries with the most economic freedom also have higher rates of long-term economic growth; their people are better off, at all income levels. 

  Here, region by region, are the principal findings of the 2000 Index of Economic Freedom: 

  North America and Europe 

  This remains the most economically free region in the world, containing five of the 10 freest countries. Nineteen countries achieved better scores than last year, while only five saw their scores worsen. 

  The dominant trend this year is the improvement in monetary-policy scores: 10 of the 43 countries saw their ratings go up. In fact, this region can generally be characterized by its low inflation: half of the countries in Europe and North America have inflation rates below 6%. 

  The reasons for overall progress in economic freedom are threefold: First, some formerly communist countries have enacted policies that have yielded remarkable achievements since they gained their independence. Estonia (No. 22), Hungary (41), and Armenia (84) illustrate the economic success that can come from free-market policies: Armenia's real gross domestic product has averaged 5.7% growth since 1994, while Estonia has grown by 4.2% and Hungary by 3.3%. 

  Second, present-day Europe bears the marks of the 1992 Maastricht Treaty, which set strict monetary and fiscal disciplinary requirements for would-be member states of the European Monetary Union. This commitment to the economic union presented a policy challenge to signatories. Some nations have struggled to meet the Maastricht requirements or have barely tried to adhere to them, while others, such as Luxembourg (No. 4), have seized the opportunity to enact structural reforms. All 11 countries in the EMU rate the highest possible monetary policy score of 1. Nonetheless, many of these countries continue to struggle with a high fiscal burden of government. 

  The third thread evident in Europe and North America this year is the success of the Anglo-American pattern of capitalism in promoting economic freedom. While mainland Europe tends, in broad terms, to adhere to market socialism, the United Kingdom (No. 8), Ireland (7) and other countries with British roots such as the U.S. (4) and Canada (11) follow a more capitalist approach to economic policy. While not the only valid route, Anglo-American capitalism by and large has led to a high level of economic freedom, as this year's index indicates. 

  Latin America and the Caribbean 

  For the second year in a row, this region made the greatest overall progress toward economic freedom. Of the 26 countries graded, 13 improved and only three worsened. The dominant story in this region is the number of countries that are controlling inflation; one-third received better monetary policy scores. 

  Chile and El Salvador (tied at No. 11) are the freest economies in the region, followed by Argentina (17), the Bahamas (22), Trinidad and Tobago (31) and Panama (33). Argentina's improved score reflects the effects of deregulation and remarkably lower inflation rates over the past few years. Brazil's score (No. 110) worsened due to the financial crisis and the government's subsequent policies, which resulted in higher taxes and increased government expenditures. The fate of the Brazilian government's economic reform program, enacted in response to the crisis, is in question, leaving the future of economic freedom in Latin America's largest country in doubt. 

  In Central and South America, economic freedom rose in Chile, El Salvador, Argentina, Barbados (No. 37), Trinidad and Tobago, Jamaica (37), Uruguay (37), Bolivia (44), Belize (53), Costa Rica (58), the Dominican Republic (61), Honduras (99) and Cuba (157). Guatemala (46), Ecuador (84) and Brazil regressed. The rest remained the same. 

  North Africa and the Middle East 

  Economic freedom improved in this region as well. Of the 18 countries graded, seven improved their scores and two worsened. The improvements were largely a result of lower inflation rates and less government intervention in the economy. Bahrain (No. 4) is the economically freest country in the region. Its high score is chiefly the result of a lack of taxation on personal income and corporate profits. Bahrain also has one of the world's lowest levels of inflation, as well as a strong and efficient court system that upholds the rule of law. 

  The United Arab Emirates (No. 19) has the second freest economy, followed by Kuwait (37), Israel (49), Morocco (49), Oman (53), and Jordan (61). Other mostly unfree countries are Tunisia (74), Qatar (81), Lebanon (90), Algeria (108) and Egypt (110). Yemen (134), Syria (139), Iran (134), Iraq (160), and Libya (159) have unfree economies. 

  Sub-Saharan Africa 

  Sub-Saharan Africa remains the least free -- and by far the poorest -- area in the world. Of the 42 countries graded, none received a free rating. Only seven received a rating of mostly free, 28 were rated mostly unfree, and seven were rated repressed. Overall, 13 countries improved their scores this year while 15 nations saw their scores decline. 

  On a per capita basis, many sub-Saharan African countries are among those receiving the highest levels of economic assistance in the world. The index demonstrates that sub-Saharan Africa's poverty isn't the result of insufficient levels of foreign aid; rather, the main cause of poverty is the lack of economic freedom embodied in policies these countries have imposed on themselves, and the rampant corruption systemic there. 

  Asia and the Pacific 

  The Asian financial crisis has had a profound effect on the region. Countries that just a few years ago uniformly prospered now have gone in different directions due to policies pursued in reaction to the crisis. It's fair to say that for analytical purposes Asia as a whole no longer exists as a cohesive entity; it has fractured into subgroups of the economically free and unfree. Three of the four freest economies in the world are in Asia -- but so are eight of the world's 24 repressed economies. 

  Regionwide, five countries earned better scores this year but nine received worse ones, an overall regional decline in economic freedom. The decline was largely due to two factors: more government intervention in the economy and higher inflation. Taiwan (No. 11), Japan (19), South Korea (33), Thailand (46) and Indonesia (110) all declined, still reeling from the after-effects of policies enacted in the wake of the financial crisis. China's score (No. 100) rose due to significant improvement in inflation rates, but it still remains one of the most economically unfree countries in the world. 

  New Zealand (No. 3) and Australia (8), two of the brightest spots, represent the new, divergent Pacific region. Like other former British colonies that have adopted the Anglo-American capitalist model, they have experienced the success that comes from establishing an institutional backdrop for economic freedom -- such as the rule of law. This helped them weather the Asian financial crisis. 

  Hong Kong and Singapore still rank first and second, as they have in every past index. The editors of last year's index warned that Hong Kong might forfeit its top spot because of the government's intervention in the stock market in August 1998, but this year the government announced a plan to sell off its holdings. Singapore, which remains a close second, saw its score decline this year due to an increase in the marginal tax rate paid by the average taxpayer. 

  The fact that Hong Kong and Singapore have long ranked at the top of the index is testimony not only to their overall good policies, but also to the greater policy errors of other governments. Happily for the peoples of the world, more and more governments are adopting policies that promote economic freedom and long-run economic growth. Competition for the top rungs in the index ranking is increasing. 

  We look forward to chronicling this healthy competition to be the world's freest economy as we enter the 21st century. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  November 30, 1999 03:05 ET (08:05 GMT)
label: inflation-related

text:
WSJ(11/15): REPEAT: `Emerging' Bonds Rally Much Sooner Than Expected

 
  By Pamela Druckerman 
  Staff Reporter of The Wall Street Journal 

  NEW YORK -- The rally that was expected to sweep emerging-market bonds early next year has happened ahead of schedule. 

  Several months ago, conventional wisdom on Wall Street was that emergingmarket bonds wouldn't come into favor until 2000, once fears about potential computer glitches had passed. But on Friday, the main emerging-markets index hit its strongest level in 15 months, capping a 6.7% total return since the beginning of October and the index's strongest year-to-date performance in three years. 

  "I think the first-quarter rally is beginning to happen right now," says Joyce Chang, head of global bond research at Chase Securities Inc. 

  The jump reflects a rosier economic outlook for emerging markets and the perception that governments and big companies are reasonably well prepared to stave off year-2000 problems. Developing Asian countries are expected to see about 5.7% growth in gross domestic product this year and next, thanks partly to an economic uptick in Japan and the rebound in global-commodity prices. Russia, whose bonds have seen the sharpest gains this year, appears to be moving toward a long-awaited domestic-debt restructuring and the release of additional money from the International Monetary Fund. 

  And Latin America, whose government bonds comprise the bulk of J.P. Morgan's EMBI+ index, sidestepped the potentially nasty consequences of Brazil's sharp currency devaluation earlier this year. Although the region's major markets should contract slightly in 1999, they are expected to grow as much as 4% in 2000. 

  "Most of the big macroeconomic blowups have already happened," says Peter Petas, chief emerging-markets debt strategist at Deutsche Bank AG. He says debt from weaker-credit countries such as Algeria and Nigeria has already begun to draw interest as overall confidence in emerging markets grows. 

  So far, emerging-market bonds have mostly attracted investors who specialize in the asset class, although traders say they are getting inquiries, and some orders, from nonspecialists drawn to the high yields. However, trading volume remains low. In the third quarter, emerging-market bond trading was 48% below levels of the same period in 1998, according to the Emerging Markets Traders Association, an industry group. Brazil, Argentina and Mexico accounted for more than two-thirds of all trading, EMTA reported. 

  If interest from the generalist investors turns into more than a nibble, the bonds could rally even more. David Sekiguchi, head of Latin American debt strategy at J.P. Morgan & Co., said interest rates on some emerging-market bonds will fall 2.7 percentage points by the end of next year, a sign of improved confidence. When investors assess the markets at year end, he expects them to recognize that developing-country debt outperformed every other major category of bonds, as well as many equity markets. 

  There is also hope that the rally in government bonds will spill into other emerging-market securities. Ms. Chang says Mexican corporate bonds, which yield three to five percentage points more than the country's sovereign debt, could be next in line for a price surge, as investors take more risks in search of higher yields. She is keen on companies with strong trade ties to the U.S., which she says have been overlooked due to general trepidation about the developing world. 

  It could also spread to better-rated countries that have been left behind by the rally, often because their bonds are less liquid. Ms. Chang says debt from smaller countries such as Colombia, Panama and Peru, which are better rated than Argentina and Brazil, should be destinations for "crossover" buyers, although they are inherently limited by the small amount of bonds outstanding. 

  (END) DOW JONES NEWS 11-15-99 

   2 17 AM 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  November 15, 1999 06:22 ET (11:22 GMT)

WSJ(11/15): Romania Faces Tough Decisions Over Economy

 
  By Cristi Cretzan 
  Dow Jones Newswires 

  BUCHAREST -- The Romanian government faces an almost impossible task: balancing mounting protests from workers over the sharp deterioration in living standards with demands for budgetary discipline from international lenders. 

  As the government undertakes increasingly desperate attempts to revive its ailing economy, market observers say the International Monetary Fund should step in to help. 

  "The IMF must do something if they want to maintain relations with this government," said Matthew Vogel, senior economist at Merrill Lynch International Ltd. in London. 

  Social pressures are rising as austerity measures have resulted in a dramatic drop in living standards. 

  In the past week, workers at truckmaker Roman SA stormed a local government building in the city of Brasov, railway workers blocked trains for hours in the capital's main rail station and steelworkers blocked a major road in northeastern Romania. Students took to the streets and declared strikes to demand higher grants. 

  "It is normal to have these protests as the government must do so much in so little time," said Sonja Gibbs, a London-based economist at Nomura International. 

  The IMF has taken a first step toward releasing more funds to Romania by agreeing to ease the requirement that Romania has to raise $470 million from the private sector before a second tranche of a $547 million standby loan is released. 

  Although no new amount was set, National Bank of Romania officials hope a loan of about $100 million, underwritten by foreign banks active in Romania, will be enough to satisfy the IMF board. 

  "We will have details on the loan in a few days and we will have this condition fulfilled," central bank chief economist Valentin Lazea said. 

  The release of the $200 million second tranche would trigger the release of loans worth $500 million from the World Bank and European Union. 

  But budgetary concerns remain for the IMF, particularly after the government of Prime Minister Radu Vasile approved a pay raise for army and police and fuel subsidies for the agricultural sector. 

  The IMF has asked for clarification on the measures, although government officials claim they won't affect this year's budget. The budget deficit is still seen at 3.9% of gross domestic product, as agreed with the IMF. 

  The government has tried to defuse tensions by offering other kinds of compensation than money, although this could trigger more criticism from the IMF. 

  At debt-ridden Roman, the government decided to offset part of the company's government debts by taking delivery of 420 trucks for the army and police. It also exempted Roman from paying duties on imported spare parts in 2000. 

  Romania is scheduled to hold presidential and parliamentary elections in the fall of 2000, and the opposition leftist Social Democracy party, together with ex-President Ion Iliescu, a former communist leader, enjoy a comfortable lead in opinion polls. 

  Merril Lynch's Mr. Vogel argues that the IMF should continue to encourage the government even if it doesn't immediately release the second tranche. 

  "It is necessary to show that they believe in the [government's] program," he said. "They must come back in Bucharest and work on the 2000 budget." 

  However, Mr. Vogel said Romania should qualify for the tranche considering its good work this year. Foreign-exchange reserves at the central bank stood at $1.56 billion at the end of October, after falling below $800 million in June. 

  The current account deficit should be halved this year to $1.5 billion from $3 billion in 1998, helped by the gradual depreciation of the leu. The Romanian currency is expected to depreciate in real terms by 10% to 15% this year. 

  Still, the government will fail to meet its inflation target of 40.6% as agreed to with the IMF. But the central bank's Mr. Lazea said this will have little impact on the IMF's decision. He said Romania will work to keep the year-on-year inflation rate at the end of 1999 at below 50%, meaning a monthly inflation rate of about 2% in the remaining two months of 1999. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  November 15, 1999 03:09 ET (08:09 GMT)
label: inflation-related

text:
WSJ(12/27): McTeer Joined Others In Vote On Fed-Funds Target

 
  By John D. McKinnon 
  Staff Reporter of The Wall Street Journal 

  WASHINGTON -- Evidence of inflation might still be scant, but the risk in November was enough to convince even the most reluctant Federal Reserve policy maker of the need to raise rates. 

  According to minutes of their Nov. 16 meeting -- which were released Thursday after the customary delay -- Robert McTeer, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, voted with all other Fed policy makers to increase the target for federal funds by a quarter point to 5.5%. Mr. McTeer had cast the sole vote against two previous rate increases, in June and August, based on his desire to test the economy's growth limits. 

  This time, according to the minutes, Mr. McTeer joined other policy makers who worried that the red-hot economy's increasing demand for workers could force labor costs to rise, while some of the factors that had held down other costs -- such as low energy prices and low demand overseas -- were turning around. 

  "On balance . . . the unsustainable pace of economic expansion along with the reversal of factors that previously had held down overall price increases suggested a significant risk that inflation would strengthen over time given prevailing financial conditions," the minutes say. 

  Against that background, all the members supported "a slight tightening at this meeting to raise the odds on containing inflation and forestalling the inflationary imbalances that would undercut the very favorable performance of the economy"the minutes say. 

  The officials also expressed "broad agreement" on "tentative recommendations" to change post-meeting statements of the policy-making committee concerning its "bias" on the direction of interest rates, though the minutes don't mention any specific proposals. The Fed has been issuing such statements since May, but critics say they're confusing. Fed policy makers are expected to clarify their procedures regarding the statements before their next meeting in February. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  December 27, 1999 00:13 ET (05:13 GMT)
label: inflation-cause-dominant

text:
WSJ(12/13): US Wholesale Prices Tame In November

 
  By Sarah Lueck 
  Staff Reporter of The Wall Street Journal 

  WASHINGTON -- Wholesale prices rose moderately last month, despite a sharp jump in energy prices, further evidence that inflation pressures remain tame. 

  The producer-price index rose 0.2% in November compared with the previous month, the Labor Department said Friday. But energy prices climbed 1.8%. Food prices, meanwhile, rose just 0.1%. Overall producer prices jumped 2.7% compared with November 1998. 

  The so-called core inflation rate, which excludes the volatile food and energy sectors, was flat for the month. Since the core rate is often what economists examine when trying to predict the scope of price pressures, they took Friday's report as another sign that Federal Reserve policy makers won't raise interest rates when they meet Dec. 21. 

  "It will suggest to officials that although inflation risks are on the high side, we have not seen any stirring yet on that front," said Michael Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc. 

  Even before Friday's report was released, analysts had predicted that Fed officials would be reluctant to raise interest rates this month because of concerns about possible Y2K-related glitches. "The Fed probably prefers to stay on the sidelines," said Jeffrey Palma, economist at Warburg Dillon Read, Stamford, Conn. But Fed officials may switch their so-called bias -- their declaration of which way they are leaning on interest-rate policy -- toward tightening, he said. 

  Mr. Palma also said Fed policy makers will give more weight to upcoming reports on retail sales and consumer prices than to Friday's producer-price data. "So far, consumer and producer prices have been very well behaved," he said. 

  Many finished goods that caused concern in the October report showed smaller increases in November. Prices for passenger cars, for example, rose 0.2% after a 1.1% increase in October. Prescription drugs, light trucks and household furniture all fell in November after rising the previous month. Durable manufacturing materials rose 0.2% last month after a 0.6% increase the previous month. 

  For all the good news, the new report contained some evidence of price pressure. Prices of intermediate goods rose 0.3% for the third month in a row, while crude-goods prices rose 4% after falling 1.6% the previous month. 

  As for energy prices, intermediate energy goods rose 1.8% in November, after increasing just 0.2% in October. Crude energy materials shot up 8.8% last month, after falling 4.8% the previous month. Electric power rose 0.7% and liquefied petroleum gas jumped 2.3%. 

  Even when the more volatile sectors are excluded, producer prices are inching up. The core rate of inflation for finished goods was up 1.9% for the 12 months ended in November, compared with an increase of 1.7% for the 12 months ended in October. Among finished-goods prices, eggs rose 22% last month following a 16.3% drop in October. Passenger-car radial tires rose 3.6% in November after a 2.5% decline the previous month. 

  Mr. Moran sees higher inflation on the horizon. "You're seeing some important changes take place-foreign economies are improving, which will lift demand all over the world," he said. "You could see the inflation rate in the U.S. creep higher." 

  Meanwhile, although consumers remain positive about the economy, their enthusiasm appears to be slipping from recent highs. The University of Michigan's Index of Consumer Sentiment decreased to 104.2 in November from 107.2 the previous month. The mid-December index for consumer expectations declined to 100.2 from 101.0 in November.

 Minus food & energy     147.4     1.8

text:
Politics, Not Econ, May Still Occupy Venezuela's Chavez

 

  By Charles Roth 

  CARACAS (Dow Jones)--Now that Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez is armed with a new constitution that enhances his powers and enables him to serve up to 12 more years, local business leaders hope he'll turn his attention to economics. 

  And while the vast majority in the business community say the new constitution is laden with costly social guarantees and raises the state's already heavy presence in the economy, they're still holding out hope for the drafting of market-friendly laws and amendments. 

  Despite the possibility of a fiscal stimulus package in early 2000 to give at least a temporary boost to the sagging economy, however, politics may continue to dominate Chavez's agenda well into the new year. 

  The new constitution approved Wednesday opens the door to new elections for practically all public offices beginning as early as February. As a result, the president may soon start yet another round of campaigning - not just for the presidency, but for his coalition members who aim to land seats in federal and state legislatures, governorships and municipalities. 

  At the same time, Venezuela's economic problems are severe. Despite a tripling in the price of its oil basket from year lows in the first quarter, some believe the petroleum-rich country's economy will still contract 5% to 7% this year. 

  Unemployment stands at 20%. But the figure actually masks just how dire the country's labor situation really is: Only 36% of Venezuela's labor force is fully employed with benefits, according to Cenda, a labor market research house. 

  "It's not possible to wait any longer to confront such problems," Domingo Maza, a central bank director, told Dow Jones Newswires. 

  Fiscal Faucets Seen Flowing Ahead Of Elections 

  While by no means a long-term solution, a quick-fix may be in the offing. 

  Thanks to oil, and the revenues it generates for the government, analysts reckon the Chavez administration has the resources to stimulate the economy. And with elections ahead, it also has the incentive. 

  Government officials project economic growth of 2.2% next year. Luis Vicente Leon, a director at Datanalisis, an economic and social polling firm, says growth will be higher, perhaps even 4%. 

  Leon is convinced that the government will open the fiscal faucet ahead of the elections to kick-start the economy, so that Chavez and his coalition allies will be able to bank on the improved sentiment that increased cash flow usually produces. 

  But analysts and business leaders alike say an intravenous money line for public works isn't enough to revive the ailing economy. Sustained growth, they argue, can only come if the private sector is permitted to flourish. For that to happen, the laws needed to apply the new constitution will have to provide a solid margin for the private sector to operate, they say. 

  While the private sector had its objections to the new constitution, it now has hopes that future legislators will also promote "the important role of the private sector recognized in the constitution," said Pedro Carmona, vice-president of Fedecamaras, the country's largest business chamber. 

  Fedecamaras and other business chambers are urging the drafting of laws to mitigate articles relating to high severance pay, restrictive labor laws, a stiff tributary regime and a pervasive presence of the state as participant, planner and regulator in a slew of economic sectors. 

  The new constitutional articles relating to social security and education are meanwhile phrased to suggest that the state assumes full and exclusive responsibility, with even non-contributors to social security being guaranteed benefits. 

  Economists point out the state-run social security system is already effectively bankrupt and public health services notoriously poor. They say the added costs of honoring all the social guarantees in the new constitution could rise to 30% of gross domestic product over the next few years - outlays they maintain the government can't begin to afford. 

  Central Bank Hopes For Legally Defined Autonomy 

  Leading proponents of the constitution, including constitutional assembly President Luis Miquilena and Alfredo Pena, the head of the assembly's economic commission, have already said amendments can be made. 

  On Tuesday Chavez told foreign reporters that the constitutional guarantees wouldn't be applied overnight, and that employers and employees would have to join the state in making the new social and labor systems work. 

  Yet hopes for legislative changes aren't limited to the private sector. Maza said the central bank is also hoping for modifications. 

  For instance, while one constitutional article provides for the bank's autonomy, another stipulates that it must coordinate its monetary policy with the Treasury's fiscal policy. The constitution also requires the legislature to approve not only central bank directors but also its budget. 

  "We hope the Central Bank Law, to be drafted within a year, will correct the inappropriate aspects (of the constitution) which could affect the bank's autonomy and monetary policy," said the bank's Maza. 

  That autonomy, he added, "is fundamental in the fight against inflation." 

  Social Program Can't Advance Without Economic Growth 

  But broadly speaking, Maza said he's optimistic that with the vote on the new constitution over, the country's political and economic paralysis should end. 

  "The political panorama is clearing in good measure," he said. "So now the economic action of the government will have priority." 

  He added that upcoming political campaigns will have a "different tonality" than the one preceding the vote on the constitution. "There is now a national consensus as to the necessity to reactivate the economy," he said. 

  In Maza's view, at least, that consensus supercedes the elections. Thus when financial markets reopen Friday after having stayed closed Thursday because of massive flooding in several parts of the country, he expects improved performance in both the bourse and the country's debt. 

  In New York Thursday, Venezuelan Brady bonds had a muted reaction to the passing of the constitution. The country's DCB bonds were up 1/4 to 79 bid in late activity, while bonds maturing in 2027 were off 1/8 to 65 7/16 bid. 

  Fedecamaras' Carmona wouldn't speculate on how local financial markets might react to Wednesday's vote. But most dealers and analysts say Venezuelan asset values should rise in the short term, now that the country's political and institutional framework has been in large part defined. 

  In the long term, however, financial markets will reflect performance in the broader economy. And that will depend, analysts say, on how much of a role the private sector is ultimately allowed to play. 

  Without a vibrant economy, they add, Chavez's "peaceful revolution" could quickly lose steam. 

  -By Charles Roth; Dow Jones Newswires; 582 564 1339; charles.roth@dowjones.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
WSJ(12/14): Unsung Officials Get Credit For Savvy Bond Sales

 
  By Gregory Zuckerman 
  Staff Reporter of The Wall Street Journal 

  At a family gathering this year, Sean Lannan was asked by his wife's cousin what he did for a living. Mr. Lannan, who works for telecommunications giant Lucent Technologies Inc., answered with pride: "I'm the director of capital markets at Lucent." 

  Uncomfortable silence. Blank stares. The conversation quickly shifted to the weather. "People always think the title sounds important, but they don't know what I actually do," says Mr. Lannan. 

  Mr. Lannan and other executives who decide when companies should sell bonds to investors, and how much they should sell, will never be the life of the party in the real world. But in corporate America, and to an extent on Wall Street, they're increasingly getting respect. 

  That's because the bond market has been as tough on the nerves as a fourth cup of coffee, and executives who guessed right and sold a ton of bonds at just the right time saved their companies hundreds of millions of dollars. 

  Consider AT&T Corp.'s decision in March to sell $8 billion of bonds, shattering the record for the biggest bond deal on record. Some on Wall Street questioned the wisdom of raising so much money then, after interest rates had already moved higher. But rates have continued to climb, and the move now looks like a savvy one: If AT&T were to sell the same amount of bonds today it would have to pay $86 million a year more in interest payments over the next 30 years, a whopping $680 million in today's dollars. 

  Lucent itself sold $1.4 billion of bonds at a yield of 6.50% in March, after Mr. Lannan's team, together with Chief Financial Officer Don Pederson, determined that the economy would keep growing, forcing the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to keep inflation at bay. 

  The Fed proceeded to raise interest rates three times this year, and bond investors have gone through periods in which they fled from all kinds of bonds, including Lucent's. In fact, to get the same deal done today, the company would have to pay investors a yield of about 7.20% on its bonds, meaning Lucent saved about $11 million a year for the next 30 years, or about $138 million in today's dollars. 

  Treasurers, directors of capital markets and even chief financial officers often make these gutsy bets and can save their companies piles of money. But while chief executive officers get lots of credit for savvy strategic decisions, and many are even household names - think Michael Eisner, Bill Gates and John Welch - finance executives are often only recognized within their own households. 

  "It's not as bad as being a proctologist, but it's right up there," says Mr. Pederson of Lucent. Capital-raising is "taken for granted if it's done well, but if we screw up everyone knows about it." 

  To be sure, a growing number of chief financial officers have made a name for themselves and gone on to high-profile jobs heading or helping to run companies. Douglas Ivester was the CFO of Coca-Cola Co. before eventually becoming chief executive. Jerome York was the chief financial officer of Chrysler Corp. and International Business Machines Corp. before leaving to become vice chairman of Kirk Kerkorian's Tracinda Corp. 

  And thanks in part to savvy financing moves, Daniel E. Somers, AT&T's chief financial officer at the time of its bond deal, last week was named president and chief executive of AT&T Broadband & Internet Services, which manages the company's cable initiatives. Some even see him as a possible successor of AT&T Chairman Michael Armstrong. 

  To executives charged with running capital-raising efforts, the stakes are high. "I live and die on these decisions," Mr. Somers said in an interview earlier this year, noting that his boss, Mr. Armstrong, encouraged AT&T's decision to jump into the bond market. 

  Roy Guthrie, chief financial officer at Associates First Capital Corp., says: "In my chair, you sweat" having to decide when to issue bonds and how much to sell. 

  Mr. Guthrie should know. He says some investment bankers second-guessed Associates' decision to sell $7.3 billion of fixed-rate bonds between October 1998 and June of this year. But the company has saved $77 million a year over 20 years, $383 million in today's dollars, by acting before rates jumped and investors turned lukewarm to corporate bonds. 

  "Many companies got caught by paying up for financing in the third quarter but we didn't have to," he says. 

  Companies with heavy financing needs that go to the bond market regularly don't have the luxury of timing the bond market. They usually pay Wall Street firms to swap their interest-rate payments for floating-rate payments that move with interest rates. But companies without pressing needs can be choosier. Finance executives like Mr. Lannan gather intelligence on the future of rates, polling investors, Wall Street traders and analysts, with the goal of getting to the bond market when bonds are selling like hotcakes, and yields are low, rather than hot potatoes. 

  "We're involved in various parts of the economy so we have a view" of the future of interest rates, says Scott McCarthy, senior vice president of capital markets at Associates. 

  The task is crucial, Wall Street analysts say. The stock market tends to focus on high-profile acquisitions and new-product announcements, says Blake Bath of Lehman Brothers, "but AT&T can save hundreds of millions of dollars over the life of its bond issue and people don't appreciate that." 

  So what should companies eager to raise money do now? Head for the bond market, say top financing executives. The economy shows few signs of slowing and the Fed may have to raise rates several times next year to keep inflation under wraps. Unless you can wait until the economy slows, perhaps during the second half of the year, sell your bonds now. 

  "Rates are heading higher and we see several more Fed [rate increases] in the cards," says Mr. Lannan of Lucent. "There's good demand from investors right now" so companies should sell bonds now, rather than later. 

  Adds Mr. Guthrie of Associates: "Pricing power will manifest itself in inflationary biases" in the next year, forcing the Fed to raise interest rates and the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond above 6.50%. 

  Associates is set to follow its own advice. "We're going to be pretty aggressive out of the gate in year 2000 about raising money," says Mr. Guthrie. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  December 14, 1999 00:25 ET (05:25 GMT)

WSJ(1/18): Defying West, OPEC Cuts Output 5.6%

 
  By Bhushan Bahree and Thaddeus Herrick 
  Staff Reporters of The Wall Street Journal 

  VIENNA -- The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries moved to cut oil output by 1.5 million barrels a day, or 5.6%, after a last-minute move by some members seeking a bigger reduction failed. 

  Coming after four successive output increases in the span of a year, the cut underscores OPEC's determination to keep oil prices high, even at the risk of pushing the slowing U.S. economy closer to recession. 

  OPEC undertook what is widely seen as a sizable cut despite pleas for restraint from the U.S. and the European Union. Libya, Iraq and Iran, all price hawks on production matters, mounted a short-lived campaign for a cut of 1.7 million barrels a day. But Saudi Arabia, which accounts for nearly a third of OPEC output, prevailed. 

  Lower production quotas are intended to keep oil prices at about $30 a barrel for the U.S. benchmark, West Texas intermediate crude. But uncertainties in global oil markets, including how much oil Iraq actually exports in the next few months, mean OPEC's action is probably just the first of several output adjustments it will make this year. "We may have to do more, or we may have to do less," said Ali Naimi, Saudi Arabia's oil minister. 

  Mr. Naimi and other OPEC ministers contend that the slowing U.S. economy, coupled with a downturn in demand that accompanies the end of the northern winter, will lead to a drop in demand by as much as three million barrels a day. That could mean another cut when OPEC meets here again on March 16. "We were forced to cut at this meeting in order to avoid a price crash in the second quarter," said Ali Rodriguez, OPEC's secretary-general and a former Venezuelan oil minister. "And we will cut by one million barrels a day in March if prices continue to fall." 

  With the latest cut, OPEC output, excluding Iraq, will decline to 25.2 million barrels a day. Oil futures fell yesterday on the news of the cut. West Texas intermediate crude dropped 69 cents to $29.60 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. 

  Analysts say yesterday's meeting illustrates OPEC's willingness to make risky decisions to prevent a price collapse. "If OPEC is going to take risks, it's going to take them on the upside rather than the downside," said Raad Alkadiri, an analyst at Washington-based Petroleum Finance Co. 

  OPEC's success in managing markets hinges heavily on Iraqi oil exports, which have been disrupted since the beginning of December. Iraqi officials say their country will resume exports of as much as 2.4 million barrels a day by the end of January. In the meantime, the intermittent nature of Iraqi exports since December -- because of spats over sales terms with buyers and the United Nations, which regulates Iraqi oil exports -- has made it difficult to ascertain just how much oil Baghdad is pumping. 

  But many in the industry figure Iraq has been exporting fewer than 500,000 barrels a day on average. When Iraq resumes its full exports, it alone will more than offset the reduction that OPEC agreed to yesterday. 

  Should Iraq resume exports, the U.S. economy continue to slow and seasonal demand drop as expected, OPEC may in fact see a glut. Industry experts expect non-OPEC oil output -- the North Sea, the U.S., Latin America and elsewhere -- to meet demand growth this year. That would mean OPEC, which added 3.7 million barrels of oil a day in the past year, would almost certainly have to keep cutting production to keep prices up. 

  OPEC oil ministers say they won't allow prices to drop just to give a boost to the U.S. economy. In fact, OPEC ministers say higher oil prices are not contributing to the slowdown, even while industry experts argue the opposite. 

  "Economies go up and down," said Obaid bin Saif Al-Nasseri, oil minister for the United Arab Emirates. "I don't think oil is responsible." 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
Cargill Halts Production At Corn Processing Plant

 
 

  FARGO, N.D. (AP)-Cargill Inc. (X.CRG) has stopped production temporarily at the ProGold corn processing plant north of Wahpeton, citing high natural gas prices and a seasonal drop in demand for corn sweeteners. 

  Plant general manager Richard "Red" Geurts said production would be shut down indefinitely until conditions improve. 

  Cargill's 126 ProGold employees will report to work on maintenance and training during the plant's idle period, Geurts said. He said processing could resume by spring, when bottlers produce more soft drinks and use more corn sweetener. 

  "We'll know more in a few weeks," he said. 

  The plant stopped receiving corn Tuesday. It will take about six days for workers to process the corn already there, and the plant will keep delivering corn sweetener from its inventory to some customers, "maybe even for the duration of the idle," Geurts said. 

  Cargill will continue to make lease payments to the plant's owners - Golden Growers Cooperative of Fargo, Wahpeton's Minn-Dak Farmers Cooperative and Moorhead, Minn.-based American Crystal Sugar Co. 

  The $261 million plant had a rocky start, opening in 1996 just as market prices for its high-fructose corn syrup dropped sharply. A 10-year lease signed with Cargill the next year brought stability to ProGold's operation and allowed Golden Growers to post profits for the last two years. 

  Letters were mailed Tuesday to Golden Growers shareholders informing them of the decision to idle the plant, said Mark Dillon, executive vice president of the co-op. 

  Dillon said the decision to idle production would not affect income for Golden Growers and the plant's other owners. But that may not be the case for co-op members, who are committed to sell to the ProGold plant 49% of the corn it processes. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
Syria State Bk: Hard Currency Buys Up After Rate Loosened

 
 

  DAMASCUS (AP)--Days after Syria loosened its exchange rate, the state-run Commercial Bank of Syria said Saturday that purchases of hard currency had doubled. 

  "Purchases of foreign currencies, which in the past have stood at $60,000 a day, have become $130,000 a day during the past three days," the bank's director general, Mahmoud Mithqal, said. 

  Mithqal predicted that the figure will soon be three to four times the old daily quantity. 

  Syria started issuing daily exchange rates Monday, basing them on the current rates in Lebanon, Jordan and other neighboring countries. Previously, the government had set the U.S. dollar rate at 46 pounds (SYP) for buying and SYP46.5 for selling. 

  Mithqal said for the time being, the bank wouldn't sell dollars and other hard currencies at market prices to finance commercial dealings. However, it would make foreign currency available for personal needs such as paying for air tickets, medical treatment abroad and Muslim pilgrimages to Saudi Arabia. 

  Bureaus of change are banned in Syria, but clandestine moneychangers do exist and there is a black market. 

  Mithqal said change bureaus would be legalized, but he didn't give a date. 

  He said the government is keeping an eye on the black market and the official rate would vary so that citizens get a valid price. 

  He added the government would keep its rate of SYP46  to the dollar as this figure has been used in the budget. 

  He said the government aims to create a better climate for investment in Syria. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  January 27, 2001 15:09 ET (20:09 GMT)

text:
Treasurys Rally Amid Falling Stocks, Bets On Lower Rates

 
 

  NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Treasurys rallied Friday as investors continued to fret about a slowing economy, falling stocks and the state of credit. 

  The broad-based buying in the government bond market benefited shorter-dated securities the most. It drove the two-year note's yield to its lowest level since the beginning of January, 1999. 

  Traders reported the across-the-board buying also steepened the slope of the yield curve. The spread between the two-year note and the 30-year bond stood at around 83 basis points by early afternoon, versus Thursday's closing spread of 67 basis points. 

  Bond prices are increasingly moving to price in much lower interest rates ahead, even after the Federal Reserve's surprise half-point cut in its overnight interest rate target to 6% earlier in the week, participants said. They are increasingly expecting the Fed to cut rates another half point when it meets in a two-day policy meeting ending on Jan. 31. 

  At 1:45 p.m. EST, the 10-year Treasury note stood at 105 31/32, up 18/32 to yield 4.96%. The 30-year Treasury rose 3/32 to 111 29/32, yielding 5.43%. 

  The five-year soared 20/32 to a 4.68% yield, while the two-year was up 10/32 to yield 4.61%. 

  "The bond market is doing very well today" as participants move the market to price for big interest rate cuts ahead, said Richard Gilhooly, market strategist with Paribas in New York. "The theme is more of the same: equity market implosion and concern over the California power situation" - and the chance that difficulties there will spill over into the rest of the economy, he said.

text:
WSJ(2/8): California Sheds Light On Regulation

 
  By David Wessel 

  MAYBE PEOPLE THINK better in the dark. When the lights went out in California, a lot more people understood that how electric utilities are regulated matters to how we live, work and play. 

  In the darkness, however, some people rushed to familiar ideological corners. 

  One corner says that only if prices go high enough for long enough will consumers use less electricity and investors build more power plants. Painfully high prices now, this argument goes, will allow California to live happily ever after as demand and supply meet at a lower price in the future, however distant. 

  The other corner says the California mess proves that the market doesn't work. Never mind that California hardly let market forces act unfettered. This camp looks longingly for restored government control. 

  Believing firmly in one or the other school can blind you to workable solutions. Two examples: 

  First, should the federal government set ceilings on wholesale electric rates in the West? The market camp says, "No!" Backed by the Bush administration, it argues that temporary controls inevitably become permanent and that controls always discourage new supply. All good arguments, but not the right answer in a half-regulated, half-unregulated market for electricity. 

  "If the price goes to $100,000 a megawatt, is that going to increase the speed with which they build a new power plant in California?" asks Paul Joskow, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology energy economist. Not likely. 

  Second, should customers have to pay more for electricity at those moments when it costs more to make or buy it? The reregulate camp says, "No!" Yet experience in other states shows that answer is wrong. 

  What happens in California will shape the way the rest of the U.S. approaches electricity regulation. If California gets much messier, any remaining political support for deregulating elsewhere will vanish. 

 

  THE CASE FOR MARKETS is strong: They are better than bureaucrats at getting goods to those who will make the best use of them because they are willing to pay the most. That insight may finally dawn on Sacramento politicians as they wrestle with the fundamental issue: California is short of power. 

  Electricity is hard to store; it is produced as needed. Customers want it instantly and without restriction; no busy signals allowed. And utilities need generating capacity to meet demand at the one moment of peak usage, the summer afternoon when everyone turns up his air conditioner. Utilities save the least-efficient plants for those peaks. 

  For more than 25 years, clever economists and clearheaded regulators have been urging utilities to charge lots more during peak hours so big business customers shift demand to other periods, when power is cheaper than average. The lower the peak, the less need for new power plants. 

  "It's pretty much in everyone's interest," says Severin Borenstein, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley. He is pushing California to adopt this "real-time pricing" technique and sees a pinprick of light in the darkness. 

  Although the technology is available, few U.S. utilities have moved aggressively to real-time pricing. California has been especially reluctant. "Under the old regulatory regime," Mr. Borenstein says, "the more real-time pricing and reduction of demand on peak, the fewer generation facilities you got to build." And utilities existed to build plants. 

 

  THAT DAY IS GONE. And the success of pioneering utilities is instructive. At 4 p.m. this afternoon, Southern Co.'s Georgia Power Co. will send 1,600 big customers 24 separate prices for each hour tomorrow. For very big, and very flexible, customers, it offers a new price every hour; at 10 a.m., it tells them what power will cost between 11 a.m. and noon. At crunch time, prices can be as much as 50 times normal. 

  "At first, many customers say, `There's nothing I can do to change my consumption,' " says Michael O'Sheasy, the utility's project-design manager. "But after a while, the creativity is amazing." 

  An insulation maker shifted production to a Wednesday-Sunday schedule. Grocers turned their freezers on extra cold before a peak period, and turned them off when power was pricey. A factory built inventory in anticipation of a price peak so it could turn off an energy-greedy machine during the expensive hours. Others used their own generators when Georgia Power's electricity was expensive. Georgia Power routinely sheds 800 megawatts of demand when prices get high -- a big deal for a utility with a 15,000-megawatt peak. 

  In the same spirit, Exelon Corp.'s ComEd unit pays big Chicago customers to voluntarily turn off the power at peak periods, much as airlines offer bribes to surrender seats on overbooked flights. The payment is linked to the price of power on the spot market. Other utilities have similar programs but don't offer big enough bribes or do enough marketing to lure substantial numbers of customers. When necessary, ComEd can shed 1,200 megawatts of demand, the output of a big nuclear plant. 

  While electricity was cheap, few top executives were interested in experimenting. New energy retailers were more interested in market share than managing demand. Old utilities were worried about the thinner profit margins that come with shifting risk from supplier to customer. 

  California changes everything. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  February 07, 2001 23:01 ET (04:01 GMT)
label: inflation-related

text:
Turkey's Lira Crisis Could Empty The Shops Of Intl Goods

 

  By Selim Atalay 

  Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 

  ISTANBUL (Dow Jones)--The rapid devaluation of the Turkish lira since its float Thursday is threatening to empty the shops. 

  Just two working days after its free float, the lira has lost 36% against the dollar, and many international companies have stopped supplying goods to local retailers until the currency stabilizes, and they can plan a sensible pricing policy. 

  "We stopped shipping to the local chains," said the Istanbul executive of a major multinational fast-moving consumer goods company, who declined to be named. "Supplying in this environment doesn't make sense." Many international suppliers typically spend dollars on imports and are then paid in lira by local retailers 90 to 120 days after shipment. 

  "There's too much risk of selling below cost and remaining exposed to the currency," said the executive, who predicted that the existing stocks in the supermarkets would last about two weeks. 

  On Saturday, famous retail chains at a mall in Istanbul were offering 30% to 50% discounts for cash purchasers. 

  "We need to revise our pricing policy; maybe we'll issue monthly prices," another leading international company retail executive added. "We did the same in Mexico during their crisis...But first the dust needs to settle before we can see ahead." He also declined to be named. 

  The dust is far from settling. The Turkish government still has to come up with a plan to support the currency. Sunday, Tunca Toskay, state minister in charge of foreign trade, predicted a "fair" exchange rate of TRL850,000 to a dollar, but that view isn't shared by the markets, even with the International Monetary Fund in town to help the government. Interbank rates Friday were around TRL1,250,000. 

  So far the casualties of the crisis have been restricted to monetary officials and Central Bank governor Gazi Ercel, who has already resigned. The markets are waiting to see if there will be political scalps, too. 

  Oil companies, which don't want to shoulder the political risk of locking the country out with a fuel shortage, have been extending credit to retailers, however. 

  "We are continuing to supply fuel to the stations," said an executive of an oil major, who also asked for anonymity. "We're selling at the pre-crisis prices." 

  Another food retail executive said: "Next week is crucial, as it will give us a sense on how things may develop." 

  From March 2 through March 12, Turkey enjoys a long religious holiday. The government is expected to use that period to try and restore stability while the markets are closed. 

  -By Selim Atalay, Dow Jones Newswires; +90 212 231 3355; selim.atalay@dowjones.com
