text:
Ghana Raises Fuel Prices; 60% Hike In Gasoline

 
 

  ACCRA, Ghana (Dow Jones)--Ghana's government announced a 60% hike in gasoline prices in a bid to keep its debt-ridden national refinery from collapse. 

  Gasoline, which formerly sold for GHC6,400 a gallon, will now sell at GHC10,500 ($1=GHC7,000), Energy Minister Albert Kan-Dapaah said Friday. 

  Diesel fuel, which is commonly used throughout the country, will sell at GHC8,800, up from GHC6,000 a gallon, the minister said. 

  The increases took effect Friday. 

  Since taking office in January, President John Agyekum Kufuor has stated the need to raise fuel prices to save the Tema Oil refinery, which processes all of Ghana's crude oil imports. The refinery has accumulated nearly $350 million in debts, Finance Minister Yaw Osafo-Maafo said recently. 

  Despite the increase, fuel prices in Ghana remain the lowest in West Africa and the government is still subsidizing the cost of fuel, Kan-Dapaah said. Earlier this month Kufuor told parliament that the previous government spent GHC6 billion a day subsidizing petrol. 

  Ghana's economy has deteriorated badly over the past 18 months, as increases in world prices of oil, its main import, coincide with a sharp fall in international cocoa and gold prices, its two main exports. 

  The government alleges former President Jerry Rawlings delayed increasing fuel prices in order to win votes for his party in December elections. 

  Last week, Kufuor led a team to Abuja, Nigeria, to negotiate for fuel imports under a 90-day repayment agreement. 

  The country's main trade union body, the Trade Union Congress, warned Thursday that any price increases in fuel should be done gradually and should be accompanied by a raise in workers' salaries.

text:
Charting Europe: April IPE Brent Crude Capped At $29

 
 
   By Axel Rudolph, MSTA 
   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  LONDON (Dow Jones)--The charts are pointing to at least a short-term consolidation for the Brent crude price on the International Petroleum Exchange. 

  Currently trading at around $27.65, April Brent has been coming off its recent relative high at $29.15 and is probably going to retrace towards at least $26.50 within the next few days. 

  The combination of a loss in momentum, a bearish crossover in the highly overbought modified stochastic and a "Bearish Engulfing" pattern in a high probability trend-reversal time zone all indicate lower prices to come. 

  Following the rally from $22.90, Brent Crude came close to the 61.8% Fibonacci retracement at $29.42, taken from the all time high to December low. The fact that it only briefly traded above $29 without reaching the Fibonacci level and then closed below the $29 mark points to a spike reversal having formed. 

  Furthermore the "Bearish Engulfing" pattern on the daily Japanese Candlestick chart Friday, formed a day after the spike to $29.15, is a potential trend-reversal pattern. 

  For the time being no reversal of the medium-term trend is anticipated. 

  A correction towards the 38.2% Fibonacci retracements of last year's October to December decline as well as of the current advance, at $26.92 and $26.76 respectively, are likely, however. 

  This price zone also encompasses the Dec. 11 and Dec. 12 highs, adding further support and making it a target on the chart. 

  Since Brent is still within its December and January uptrend channels, technical analysis favors the trend to continue and the market to simply correct to the lower boundaries of these channels. 

  They currently come in around $26.00 and $25.50. Only a daily close below the $25.50 major support zone, at $25.00 or lower, would reverse the current uptrend. 

  A consolidation is probable though, as the recent high has been made at a critical juncture in time from where at least short-term corrections to a trend have occurred in the past. 

  This time zone is where the duraction of the November to December 2000 bear move has been multiplied by 1.618 to provide the next possible high. 

  In the case of April Brent crude, the November to December decline lasted for 23 days. The recent high was formed after 37 days (1.618*23), taken from the Dec. 20 closing low. This time level coincides perfectly with the Feb. 8 high. 

  Furthermore the daily momentum has slowed over the past few days after having reached extreme levels from where recent corrections or trend-reversals have been made. 

  Also the %K and %D lines of the modified stochastic have just crossed in the highly overbought 80% zone and are now pointing down, further adding to a probable consolidation. 

  All relative highs since June 2000 have been made from the 75%-90% overbought zone in the modified stochastic. Therefore, the probability of another relative high having just taken place above $29 is high and a correction is in the making.

text:
US Beef Prices Soar After Tough Winter, Drought

 
 

  WASHINGTON (AP)--Retail beef prices are soaring -reaching a record $3.21 a pound for USDA-choice cuts in January -because of a harsh Plains winter that has been tough on cattle. 

  Prices are likely to dip by the summer, but then rebound because of tight cattle supplies. Producers are only starting to rebuild herds that they thinned because of drought and low prices in the late 1990s. 

  The winter has been so cold and damp that cattle are taking several months longer than usual to fatten up. In bad weather, cattle in feedlots don't eat as much and use up energy staying warm. 

  "We have basically had one of the harshest winters that we have seen in a very long time," said Chuck Levitt, a meat analyst with Chicago-based Alaron Trading Corp. "The last time we had a winter this severe across the major cattle feeding areas was in 1993." 

  The previous record for retail prices was in September, at $3.13 a pound. In the late 1990s, they were averaging about $2.80. 

  Live cattle are selling for 82 cents a pound, up from 78 cents last month and about 68 cents in February 2000. 

  "We've definitely seen the beef prices go up big time," said Rickey Figueroa, executive chef of Atlanta's Chops Steakhouse. 

  The price the upscale restaurant is paying for beef tenderloin has gone from $15 to $20 a pound in recent weeks. So far, the restaurant isn't changing its menu prices, in hopes of negotiating better deals with another supplier, Figueroa said. 

  Americans have rediscovered a taste for beef at the same time that U.S. meat exports are up and many producers have been sending all of their calves to slaughter, rather than holding females back for breeding. 

  Experts say it's too early to assess the impact on U.S. prices and supplies from outbreaks of mad-cow and foot-and-mouth diseases in Europe. 

  Beef sales plummeted in the European Union after an upsurge of mad cow cases in several countries last year. Since October, beef prices in Europe have fallen by about 27%. 

  The European Union doesn't buy most U.S. beef because the cattle are treated with growth hormones. 

  In the United States, "The prices are up because the stock of cattle in the country is way down," said Mark McLaughlin, who ranches near Sweetwater, Texas, in a region that has been through several years of drought. "I bet in this area of Texas we've gotten down to 30%" of normal herd sizes. 

  McLaughlin sent 450 calves to feedlots this winter so they could be fattened for slaughter. That's about half the cattle he was selling a few years ago when his herds were larger. Last fall, however, he kept some female calves so he could start rebuilding his herd over the next two years to take advantage of the higher prices. 

  U.S. cattle supplies are down 1% this year and 6% from a peak in 1996. 

  Beef consumption, meanwhile, reached 99.5 pounds per person last year, up from 98.7 per person the year before and 95.6 pounds in 1997. U.S. beef sales to Japan and other export markets rose 11% in 1999 and another 4% last year. 

  "Demand is holding up very strongly," said Agriculture Department analyst Ron Gustafson. 

  Retail prices will likely moderate as the weather warms and more cattle head to slaughter, but then cattle supplies will tighten over the next two years as ranchers retain their female calves, rather than send them for slaughter, he said. 

  On the Net: USDA's Economic Research Service: http://www.ers.usda.gov 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
Calif Assembly OKs Investigating Power Plant Outages

 
 

  SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP)--The California Assembly took several steps Thursday to cope with California's energy crisis, passing bills that would regulate power plant outages and expand utility programs that cut rates for big power users who turn off electricity when needed. 

  A measure by Assemblywoman Carole Migden would give the overseer of the state power grid authority to coordinate plant outages to prevent too many from going off line for maintenance at any one time. 

  If a power plant seemed to have too many outages or was shut down for a suspicious length of time, the grid manager, the Independent System Operator, could investigate and the state Electricity Oversight Board could order fines. 

  "We have suspected that in some instances these generators have shut down and this has not been in the public interest," said Migden, D-San Francisco, adding that she was not accusing anyone of wrongdoing. "What we're trying to do is create an audit and accountability system." 

  The bill largely puts into state law an executive order issued last month by Gov. Gray Davis and goes further by giving the Electricity Oversight Board the power to issue fines. The fines would be based on the cost of power the ISO had to buy as a result of a plant's shutdown. 

  Senate leader John Burton on Wednesday announced a Senate committee will investigate whether electricity wholesalers illegally withheld power to drive up prices. 

  He cited plant outages for scheduled and unscheduled maintenance that have contributed to supply shortfalls, forcing the ISO to scramble for power at premium prices to meet demand. 

  Duke Energy (DUK), Dynegy Inc. (DYN), Mirant Corp. (MIR) and Reliant Energy (REI) will be among major providers included in the Senate inquiry, said Committee Chairman Joe Dunn. 

  Jan Smutny-Jones, executive director of the Independent Energy Producers industry group, said wholesalers will cooperate, but warned that if it becomes a "witch hunt" it could discourage them from building plants in California. 

  A similar Assembly panel has been formed to look into natural gas prices. The probes could lead to action by the state attorney general. 

  The Federal Regulatory Energy Commission on Wednesday ordered Williams Cos. (WMB) unit Williams Energy Marketing & Trading and AES Corp. (AES) unit AES Southland to show why they should not be forced to refund $10.8 million to California utilities for taking generating units in Long Beach and Huntington Beach off line last April and May. 

  That follows a FERC order last week directing wholesalers to refund $69 million in California electricity charges or demonstrate why the charges were justified. FERC, a strong supporter of deregulation, has given the companies until March 23 to appeal that decision. 

  The Assembly approved Migden's plant outage bill 57-5 and sent it to the Senate. 

  The Assembly also sent the Senate two measures on investor-owned utilities' interruptible-service programs, which give non-residential utility customers discounted rates if they agree to shut down during periods of tight power supplies. Both votes were 67-0. 

  The programs are considered key tools for avoiding rolling blackouts this summer, when air conditioning and other power use is expected to further strap the state's electricity supply. 

  The Assembly approved a bill by Assemblyman Rod Wright, D-Los Angeles, that would extend the programs until the end of 2002 and require investor-owned utilities to offer customers more ways to participate. 

  It also passed a measure by Assemblywoman Lynn Daucher, R-Brea, that would let those in such programs for at least a year that have been barred by the state Public Utilities Commission from getting out of them opt out without penalty. 

  Customers of Edison International (EIX) unit Southern California Edison and PG&E Corp. (PCG) unit Pacific Gas and Electric Co. customers found themselves shut down frequently in January. Several schools and businesses asked to be let out of the programs, saying they couldn't function due to the frequent outages. 

  The PUC on Thursday was expected to discuss a new plan for interruptible-service programs. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
WSJE: ECB Keeps Rates Steady On Concern About Inflation

 
  By G. Thomas Sims 
  Staff Reporter 

  FRANKFURT -- Unfazed by falling stock markets, the European Central Bank, as expected, left interest rates steady because the bank still detects some inflation risks. 

  The ECB didn't explain the decision taken at a regular policy meeting, but recent comments from officials indicate the ECB still fears workers may demand higher wages that could stoke inflation. The trickle-down effect on consumer prices from last year's oil-price increase and a weaker euro still concerns the ECB, as does increased government spending. 

  Unlike in the U.S., dramatic falls in European share prices have little bearing on the broader economy here. European firms don't rely as heavily on stock markets for financing. Stock market capitalization in Europe is only 66% of ouput, half the level of the U.S., according to ECB figures. 

  European households don't have that much money invested in the stock market either. German households' equity holdings, as a percentage of disposable income, are five times less than for U.S. households, a working paper for the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development says. A 20% fall in share prices would only knock 0.1 of a percentage point off output in Germany, France, and Italy - eight times less than the effect of such a stock fall in the U.S. 

  "The macroeconomic impact of movements in the stock exchanges is much more limited indeed than in the U.S.," Wim Duisenberg, the ECB president, said last week. 

  The ECB has been the only major central bank in the world not to ease borrowing costs, with growth slowing nearly everywhere. Over the past two months, however, the ECB has admitted that inflation risks are deteriorating, but some caution is necessary and justifies a wait-and-see policy. This has caused economists to expect the ECB to cut interest rates in the second quarter of this year. 

  Inflation reports from France, Germany and Spain earlier this week suggest annual inflation quickened in February after a two-month slowdown to perhaps as much as 2.6%, well above the 2% maximum rate the ECB permits. The European Union issues the report Friday. Oil, meat and tobacco were behind the price increases in those countries. 

  Unlike the U.S. and Japan, the euro-zone economy is showing only moderate signs of slowing. The ECB expects growth to slow to just under 3% this year from about 3.4% last year. 

  Confirming views of a slowdown, Italian industrial production in January fell a seasonally adjusted 1.8% from December, according to government report Thursday. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
Calif To OK 20% Rate Hike For Utils -Commissioners

 
 

  (This article was originally published Saturday) 

 
   By Jason Leopold 
   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  LOS ANGELES (Dow Jones)--The California Public Utilities Commission will likely approve a 20% rate increase for two of the state's largest utilities Tuesday,  ending a three-year-old retail rate freeze, two PUC commissioners told Dow Jones Newswires Saturday. 

  The rate hike would let the state recoup money it spent buying power since January, said the commissioners, who asked not to be named. The increase also would let utilities start paying small independent power producers on a forward basis for electricity sold directly to the utilities, the commissioners said. 

  PUC also may approve a trigger mechanism. The move would allow utilities PG&E Corp. (PCG) unit Pacific Gas & Electric and Edison International (EIX) unit Southern California Edison additional rate increases of 5%, if needed, to cover future power costs. Rates could go down if the future price of power stabilizes, the commissioners said. 

  A PUC administrative law judge is expected to issue a proposed order that does not support the rate increase and end to the rate freeze. As a result, PUC Commission President Loretta Lynch is expected to issue an alternate proposal that will call for a rate increase of about 20%, the commissioners said. 

  Both proposed orders are expected to be issued Sunday afternoon. 

  "There is just no way we can extract 10 cents from a nickel," said one Democratic commissioner, who asked not to be named. "Unfortunately, we are going to have to grant the utilities an increase." 

 

  SoCal Ed To Present Rate Arguments Monday 

 

  The commission is expected to hear oral arguments Monday by SoCal Ed executives regarding the company's rate stabilization plan. When first presented to the commission in November, the plan called for a 10% rate increase. PG&E also filed a rate stabilization plan at the time asking for a similar increase. 

  Both utilities argued last November that their costs exceeded their revenues because wholesale power prices spiked during the summer. The utilities' customers' rates were frozen, but wholesale prices continued to soar, surpassing the roughly 5.5 cents per kilowatt hour and 6.5 cents/KWh rate the utilities were legally allowed to charge their customers. 

  In December, PG&E and SoCal Ed revised their rate stabilization plan, requesting rate increases of as much as 30% because wholesale power prices failed to stabilize and the utilities were getting deeper into debt. The commission denied the request in January and approved a temporary rate increase of 9% for residential consumers and 14% for large industrial customers. 

  PG&E and SoCal Ed are now more than $13 billion in debt, have seen their ratings downgraded to junk-status by Wall Street credit agencies and have defaulted on billions of dollars in dividend payments, power bills and bank loans. 

  Gov. Gray Davis was in Palm Springs over the weekend for a fundraiser, and his staff was unavailable for comment. Representatives for PG&E and SoCal Ed were also unavailable for comment. 

  Earlier this month, Davis told Wall Street analysts that he would not allow a rate increase because he feared a ballot initiative by consumer advocates in the state, who would call for an end to the state's deregulation law. 

  "Believe me, if I wanted to raise rates I could have solved this problem in 20 minutes," Davis said at a March news conference. 

 

  Group Pledges 'Ratepayer Revolt' If Prices Rise 

 

  Harvey Rosenfield, executive director of consumer advocacy group The Foundation of Taxpayer and Consumer Rights, promised a "ratepayer revolt" and 2002 ballot initiative if electricity rates are increased. Consumer advocates are also expected to testify at Monday's hearing about why the utilities should not be permitted to raise consumer electricity rates. 

  Legislative sources said the rate increase is needed so the state Department of Water Resources, which in January started purchasing power for the cash-strapped utilities, can be repaid. Moreover, the utilities can begin paying the state's so-called qualifying facilities for electricity. PG&E and SoCal Ed have not paid the QFs in full since January, and the companies owe the generators about $1 billion. 

  In hindsight, one key Democratic state senator said, if the state allowed the utilities to raise rates in January, the DWR would not have had to spend nearly $4 billion from the general fund buying power. Further, said the senator, who asked not to be named, the state would not have had to negotiate a deal to buy the utilities' power lines in an effort to restore the companies to financial stability. 

  "Think about it. PG&E and Edison could have regained access to loans and would have been able to restore their credit," the senator said. "We ultimately spent more than $5 billion than we should have if a rate increase is approved. That's not counting, the billions of dollars more we spent and are going to spend on long-term contracts, transmission assets and revenue bonds. People are going to want answers and I don't know what we're going to tell them." 

  -By Jason Leopold, Dow Jones Newswires; 323-658-3874; jason.leopold@dowjones.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  March 26, 2001 08:15 ET (13:15 GMT)

text:
FERC Considers Cap On Calif Pwr Prices During Top Alerts

 
 

  WASHINGTON (AP)--Federal energy regulators are reviewing a proposal to restrict wholesale electricity prices in California during the severe power shortages expected this summer. 

  The proposal, which is to be taken up at a Federal Energy Regulatory Commission meeting Wednesday, also would require producers to sell power for California's grid during power emergencies. 

  The commission has faced growing political pressure to find new ways to address allegations of price gouging in the Western power markets, where wholesale costs have been ten times what they were a year ago, and likely will go higher in the coming months. 

  The agency, reflecting the views of its Republican chairman, Curtis Hebert, has refused repeated requests by West Coast officials to impose price caps on wholesale electricity sales in the West. 

  The staff proposal aims to avoid the term "price caps" and views the plan as limited "price mitigation" that would seek to blunt severe price increases but not threaten supplies, according to a staff summary. 

  The proposal "recognizes that (power) scarcity ... will exist for the near term and that, during such periods, some extraordinary measures must be considered," said the summary provided to commissioners. 

  It proposes that price restrictions be limited to California and only at times of so-called Stage 3 emergencies, when electricity reserve margins virtually disappear, raising the prospects of rolling blackouts. 

  At the same time, the commission is expected to discuss a proposal to officially endorse plans where industrial power users curtail or close facilities and sell back electricity during severe shortages. 

  The commission has reviewed thousands of wholesale power transactions during the first three months of this year and has singled out $124.5 million in alleged overcharges. California officials say many times that amount should be recovered in refunds because of price gouging. A recent California report put alleged overcharges during the past year at more than $6.2 billion. 

  The new "price mitigation" plan is aimed at preventing the most severe price run-ups ahead of time, instead of having to seek refunds later, according to several of the commissioners. 

  But the staff proposal is short of what even some members of the commission have wanted, since it limits price intervention to only the most severe emergency periods. It also does not address escalating prices elsewhere in the West, particularly Washington and Oregon, where prices at times have been higher than in California. 

  While Hebert, the Republican commission chairman, has stood firm in his opposition to price controls, he has indicated he might go along with some very limited form of price mitigation if it can be shown not to inhibit producers from expanding power supplies. 

  At the same time, Linda Breathitt, one of two Democratic commissioners, has indicated in recent weeks that she is increasingly leaning toward some price intervention. 

  It is "important that we place all options on the table for serious consideration," including some "price mitigation plans," she said during a recent FERC meeting with state utility regulators from Western states. 

  The third commissioner, William Massey, also a Democrat, has all along argued for across-the-board price caps, based on cost of production, and said they should apply to all 11 states in the Western power grid. 

  The FERC has been operating with three commissioners and two vacant seats. President Bush has announced two nominees to fill the vacancies, but both still await Senate confirmation and are not likely to be on board before the summer's power crunch hits. 

  When the two nominees - Pat Wood of Texas and Nora Brownell of Pennsylvania, both state utility regulators - come up for confirmation, they are expected to be questioned sharply by Senate Democrats about their views on price controls and the free market. 

  Last week, Democratic Sens. Joe Lieberman of Connecticut and Jean Carnahan of Missouri asked the General Accounting Office to investigate whether FERC has complied with its duties under the Federal Power Act to ensure that wholesale electricity prices in the West are fair and reasonable. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
Meat Byproduct Shortages Hit Array Of Goods In Europe

 
 

  FRANKFURT (AP)--Fruit chews pulled from store shelves in Poland. Price hikes for Italian shoes and French handbags. Animal fat abandoned by global makers of face cream and soap. 

  Europe's effort to rein in its bout of livestock disease isn't just hammering world supplies of lamb chops and prime rib. It's starting to hit the 40% of a cow, pig or sheep that never makes it to a store refrigerator shelf. 

  Consumers around the world may soon develop a newfound appreciation for these uneaten animal parts, which are skinned, ground up or melted down into ingredients used every day in a dizzying array of goods. 

  With fewer animals slaughtered in Europe due to fears of eating meat, hide prices are soaring. Shoppers could pay more for this summer's lineup of items like leather furniture, high-end car seats, clothing and shoes. 

  Costs also are rising for tallow, or animal fat, which is used in candles, soap and beauty products - though consumer prices appear unaffected for now as manufacturers absorb higher costs or use substitute ingredients. 

  European suppliers of meat byproducts, meanwhile, face millions of dollars in losses. 

  "Our byproduct industry has taken a hammering," said Martin Grantley-Smith at Britain's Meat and Livestock Commission. "In straight exports, Britain will be losing millions of dollars a year in terms of byproducts." 

  British slaughterhouses used to get GBP5 per ton of byproduct material from companies eager to turn it into tallow, leather or bone meal. But with a host of new restrictions against using those parts, slaughterhouses are now having to pay up to GBP90.50 a ton to have it hauled away. 

  Bans imposed by nations around the world because of mad-cow and foot-and-mouth diseases have halted 94% of the European Union's beef exports and 73% of its pork exports. They also have slowed Europe's weekly livestock slaughter from a half million head to just 350,000 head, according to Hidenet.com, an Internet market report. 

  Restraints on using nonedible beef byproducts have been around since the mad-cow outbreak in the mid-1990s. But a mad-cow scare that peaked in the fall and the current food-and-mouth crisis have led countries to fortify or extend those laws. 

  Europe is trying to halt the spread of foot-and-mouth disease, which unlike mad-cow poses no human health threat, by incinerating the animals, hides, hooves, bones, fat and all. 

  Europe's mass culls have torpedoed the local supply of leather, by as much as 75% in Britain, and have lifted the price of local leather by about 20%. Worldwide, the supply squeeze has pushed up cowhide prices 15% in the last two months, Hidenet.com reported. 

  The market claimed its first U.S. victim last month when Irving Tanning Co., a small 390-employee firm in Hartland, Maine, filed for bankruptcy protection. 

  Irving Tanning doesn't buy European hides, but vice president Paul Larochelle said the company was pinched by a blitz of overseas demand for U.S. skins that pushed stateside prices up 66%. 

  "You can only absorb so much before you have to turn around and say, 'Enough is enough,"' Larochelle said. 

  To counteract tight demand, the European Footwear Confederation has petitioned the E.U. to order member countries to remove pelts and skins before animals are destroyed. 

  But what's a crisis to one region is often an opportunity to another. 

  Increased European demand for leather is fueling a mini-boom in Brazil, where ranchers are boosting their 2001 export forecast to 1.83 billion reals ($1=BRL2.14) from an earlier prediction of BRL1.61 billion, says Jose Roberto Scarabel, president of the Brazilian Tannery Industries Center. 

  U.S. hide exports shot up 25% to $2 billion last year after the mad-cow scare struck, according to Leather Industries of America, another trade group. And January exports were 12% ahead of last January's. 

  In other byproduct markets, the impact is less direct. 

  About 12% of an animal is usually ground down and melted to make tallow. The animal fat is widely used in consumer and industrial goods despite a shift to substitutes in the mid-1990s by makers of cosmetics and other products seeking to address health concerns raised in earlier mad-cow scares. 

  But the current outbreak has forced countries such as Japan to institute full-fledged bans against animal products in such consumer goods. 

  That has ramifications in Europe for companies like Cognis, a Netherlands-based chemical company that makes raw ingredients for body care products as well as industrial lubricants. 

  Just a few years ago, it used animal tallow in nearly half of its cosmetics. Today, virtually none of its health care line uses animal products, although tallow still accounts for 20% of its industrial chemicals. 

  Cognis calculates it costs 10% more to make vegetable-based products. But the shift may be paying off, because tallow prices have spiked in the last month as European restrictions crimp supplies. 

  "If foot-and-mouth disease lasts for one or two years, we could see a possible increase. But right now, it's really just a short-term phenomenon," said Albert Strube, one of the Cognis' top chemists. 

  At the same time, German cosmetics giant Welle AG, maker of Ultrasheen hair care products, has tripled its research budget to find plant-based alternatives to tallow - in part because consumers scrutinize ingredients more carefully than they used to. 

  Gelatin, derived from ground bone and cartilage, is a common ingredient in yogurt, soft cheese, medicine capsules and jelly. It's also used in candy, which it makes soft and chewy. Recently, the German makers of the Mamba fruit chew pulled them off supermarket shelves in Poland when customs officials said they posed a possible health risk. 

  British candy maker Cadbury hopes to avoid a similar fate by importing its gelatin from South America, where the mad-cow risk is lower. Kurt Bohlen, general manager of Leiner Davis Gelatin, Latin America's largest gelatin producer, expects Brazilian exports to jump 10% this year. 

  Meanwhile, German candy giant Haribo, inventor of the gummi bear, is taking a different tact. Just last month, it rolled out its first batch of gelatin-free gummi candies, a new product that gets around similar beef bans in countries like Malaysia and Singapore. 

  The situation could ease as foot-and-mouth disease comes under control. As the continent slowly turns the tide against the outbreak, E.U. agriculture ministers met this past week to discuss broadening limited immunization programs already authorized in the worst hit areas of Britain and the Netherlands. 

  A turn for the worse could be foot-and-mouth disease finally hitting U.S. shores. The last U.S. outbreak occurred in 1929, and the leather industry says it could prove disastrous for the nation's 98 million head of cattle. 

  "If we get it here, heaven forbid, there's no telling where prices could settle," said Charles Myers, president of Leather Industries of America. "I just hope and pray it doesn't come this way." 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

WSJ(4/3): Commodities: Crude-Oil Futures Slip To Yr Low Mon

 By Marie C. Sanchez 
  Dow Jones Newswires 

  NEW YORK -- Crude-oil futures started off the second quarter at the lowest price of the year. 

  May crude futures skidded 70 cents to $25.59 a barrel at the New York Mercantile Exchange. A flurry of late selling briefly sent the contract to its lowest level since May 2000. 

  "There's a general oversupply of crude right now," said Ed Silliere, vice president of risk management at Energy Merchant, an energy-marketing firm. "It's just the posture of the cash market. You call out for buyers, you get one or two. You call out for sellers, you get three or four." 

  The steep decline in prices was a nod to conventional wisdom: The usual seasonal decline in oil demand during the second quarter is likely to be exaggerated by the slowing economy, causing a glut and sending oil prices crashing. 

  Crude-oil inventories have been climbing steadily during the past three weeks and added more than 11 million barrels during the latest week reported, according to a report last week by the Department of Energy. 

  Yesterday's retreat in the stock market also frayed nerves over the state of the economy. 

  Chris Schachte of brokerage firm GSC Energy said there is a general sense of an economic slowdown: "In that environment, demand is going to ease. 

  "We're waiting to see if the stock-market problems will affect the economy," he said. "There are worries that demand will fall off the table if the economy gets bad." 

  Yesterday's weak performance in crude oil sets the stage for further losses, perhaps to $24 a barrel, Mr. Schachte said. 

  Although refined-products futures plunged, with heating oil losing three cents and gasoline sliding two cents, it was crude oil that pressured the petroleum complex lower, analysts said. 

  "This is the tail wagging the dog," Mr. Silliere said. 

  Analysts also said an article in The Wall Street Journal contributed to the pessimism with a report that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries isn't likely to live up to its promises to cut output. 

  OPEC has cut production quotas twice this year - by 1.5 million barrels a day in January and one million barrels last month - in an effort to keep the group's reference price basket of crudes near its target of $25 a barrel. 

  The latest output cut went into effect Sunday. However, OPEC was overproducing by 500,000 barrels a day in February, The Wall Street Journal reported, and analysts said it won't be long before OPEC members are cheating in earnest. 

  The OPEC basket price slipped to $22.79 a barrel Friday. To avert a price plunge in the second quarter, OPEC members have agreed informally to reduce production quotas by an added 500,000 barrels a day if the price basket stays below $22 a barrel for 10 consecutive trading days. 

  "Even if OPEC production dropped by one million barrels a day over the weekend as previously announced, the market can still be confident of a supply surplus of roughly 1.5 million barrels a day [during the second quarter]," said Tim Evans, analyst at IFR Pegasus, a research firm. 

  "It's not going to hold the price here or move it higher," Mr. Evans said. 

  In other commodity markets: 

 

  HOGS: Prices soared on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, fueled by the U.S. Department of Agriculture's hogs-and-pigs report. The June contract rose by its two-cent limit to 71 cents a pound. The report, released after 4 p.m. Friday, showed that at 58.8 million head, the number of hogs and pigs in the U.S. on March 1 was up 2% from last year's figures, but 1% below Dec. 1, 2000. 

 

  GOLD: Futures fell at the Comex division of Nymex on the strength of the dollar, a weakening of the lease rates charged for lending gold and reduced demand for physical gold. The June contract fell $2.60 to $256.60 a troy ounce. Dollar strength is "taking away physical demand" and may be encouraging selling from producers in Australia and South Africa, whose currencies are way down, said Dave Meger, senior metals analyst at Chicago-based Alaron Trading Corp.

WSJ(4/13): WEEKEND JOURNAL: Travel: Takeoffs & Landings

 
  By Michelle Higgins and Rafer Guzman 

  Mileage Marathons 

 

  HERE'S ONE corporate-travel cutback you can still salvage: your frequent-flier account. 

  The slowing economy is forcing business fliers to fly less or even switch to cheaper flights on carriers that don't boost their frequent-flier accounts. But travelers looking to keep upping their miles should consider so-called cash-for-clicks programs, such as FreeAirMiles.com or MyPoints.com, which reward users for purchases as well as for looking at online sites and their advertising. One site, WebMiles.com, offers fliers universal "WebMiles" that can be swapped for travel on any airline with no blackout dates or seat restrictions. 

  But that doesn't do much to help your stranded miles. "Most online shopping and other ventures will only give you one or two miles per dollar spent," says frequent-flier expert Randy Petersen. "You would have to spend a lot of money clicking and shopping." He says "mileage runs," where travelers take a quick trip solely to accumulate miles, are becoming the best way to cure a mileage deficiency. Indeed, FlyerTalk.com has a Mileage Run forum where frequent-flier fanatics share secrets to add the most miles and other tricks of the trade. 

 

  Back to Bell 

 

  LOOKING FOR CHEAP deals on the Web? Try picking up the phone. 

  "A lot of suppliers don't want to post a discounted fare where all their competitors will see it and match," says Sam Galeotos, president of Cheap Tickets Inc., which sometimes offers deals only through its call centers. For example, a round-trip fare from Richmond, Va., to Oakland, Calif., costs $376 via the call center, but $438 if you book online. That's 16% less. 

  Online discounters have long boasted that they had the cheapest deals around. While the Internet drives down prices by making it easier for consumers to shop for the best bargain, it also lets online merchants monitor and match each others' prices without overtly colluding. 

  Other online Web sites like Expedia and Travelocity insist their Web deals are still the lowest. "Expedia prides itself on getting the best rates online," says a spokeswoman. "The low fares are the online fares." 

 

  Good News 

  Behind the Wheel 

 

  HAS ANY PART of traveling actually gotten better? 

  Yes -- rental-car companies have improved their customer service and car quality, according to a new J.D. Power & Associates survey. In a poll of 2,900 customers, business travelers gave Avis and National top marks, while Enterprise ranked highest among leisure travelers. 

  Wait times haven't improved from last year: Business renters reported average waits of 10.5 minutes for shuttle buses and 5.5 minutes for returns. Leisure travelers waited a little longer: 11 minutes for a bus and seven minutes to return cars. But customers forgave long waits when customer service was good, says Michael Taylor, director of travel services for J.D. Power. For business customers, Avis didn't score highest in speed, but compensated by having cars at the ready with their trunks open. 

  On the leisure side, Enterprise led the way on both speed and service. Overall, customers were happier with the cars themselves, with only 22% reporting problems such as engine failure or unclean cars. That's down from 33% last year. 

  Improvements have been "trending upward" for the last five years, Mr. Taylor says. That's "opposite what we've seen in the rest of the industry." 

 

  Odds & Ends 

 

  MIND YOUR MANNERS: Miami's Doral Golf Resort & Spa offers drink coupons to guests who are "mindful of golf etiquette." Rangers are posted to watch for good deeds such as replacing divots, raking sand traps and keeping up with the speed of play. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

WSJ(5/2): Column: The Recession That Wasn't

 By Thomas J. Bray 
 

  (Editor's Note: This is an opinion piece from Wednesday's Wall Street Journal. Mr. Bray is a staff columnist at the Detroit News. He writes a column every Tuesday for OpinionJournal.com, where this article first appeared.) 

 

  DETROIT -- It's possible, of course, that the preliminary figures showing 2% economic growth in the first quarter are just plain wrong. But out here in the industrial Midwest, some of us are wondering if this will be the recession that never happened. 

  While the high-tech "new economy" may indeed be suffering from an acute inventory overhang, the "old economy" appears to be adjusting rapidly -- in part thanks to inventory controls made possible by the new economy. A large backlog of unsold cars, for example, has been quickly whittled down. Vehicle production is now rising at double-digit rates. 

  Consumers also are showing a certain amount of exuberance. Durable-goods sales were up 3% in March, while single-home sales rose 4.8%. Pressure on profits remain intense, and highly visible layoffs are still taking place. But there are still profits to be made, and the employment picture remains relatively strong. 

  Maybe it's a false dawn. The stock market, perhaps the best single indicator of economic expectations, has recovered some of its losses but still bounces around uncertainly, well below its 1999-2000 highs. Classified advertising at most newspapers has fallen sharply. As higher energy prices feed through the economy -- the result mainly of a lack of generating and refining capacity -- it's hard to imagine a quick return to the florid growth of prior years. 

  But if the growth number holds up, it will nonetheless present the Bush administration with the best of political scenarios: a slowdown that won't seriously threaten its rising popularity but will leave the Federal Reserve chastened by the threat of deflation and Congress focused on the need for serious tax and regulatory relief. 

  The Democrats, eager to exploit economic fears, have launched an advertising blitz designed to show Mr. Bush as little more than a pawn of corporate interests bent on protecting obscene profits, poisoning America and jeopardizing health benefits to give huge tax cuts to the very rich. 

  But the mere prospect of tax and regulatory relief may have helped stabilize the economic picture somewhat by persuading Americans that the slowdown wouldn't get out of hand. 

  Yes, consumer confidence is down, but as The Wall Street Journal revealed Monday, a clear majority of investors now think they will earn substantial returns in the coming 12 months. Indeed, the Bush team may now be in a position to argue that the stock-market collapse and brief slowdown represented little more than a return to reality after the Clinton years. 

  Mr. Bush has succeeded in establishing his presidential credentials, which may have lifted a big psychological weight from the economy. Mr. Bush has made some compromises, but the Democrats have made bigger ones -- going from opposition to any tax cut to yesterday reaching tentative agreement with congressional Republicans on a $1.35 trillion deal. 

  In so doing, they also concede Mr. Bush is not an accidental, much less an illegitimate, president. After all, he is a man who seems to know what he is doing. The malaise of the contested election has largely passed, and with it the uncertainty that the country might find itself consumed by a political firestorm, which would make it difficult to deal with unexpected crises. 

  In 1993, Bill Clinton's response to a perceived slowdown was to raise taxes and invoke the need for government "investments." Republicans lost some of their credibility with scare talk about how the tax increase would lead straight to economic disaster, when in fact they should have argued more prudently that the tax hike would retard recovery -- as indeed it did. 

  But in his first 100 days, President Bush resoundingly won the big economic argument -- that growth comes from improved incentives in the private sector, not more redistribution of income. Not even the far left is arguing for a reprise of the Clinton economic strategy. 

  With the economy apparently still growing, Mr. Bush can continue to move forward with his aggressive agenda. If Democrats persist in their increasingly frazzled attempts to paint Republicans as nothing more than corrupt interlopers, they risk looking just as blindly partisan as Republicans ever did. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

WSJE: WEEKEND JOURNAL: Collecting: Tracking The Art Markets: Next Stop, Basel

 By Margaret Studer 

  Some 262 galleries from Europe, the Americas and Asia will show this year around 5,000 works from 1,000 artists at Art 32 Basel ( June 13-June 18), the world's leading fair for 20th century and contemporary art. And if your body revolts at the thought of tramping around an art citadel of that mass, the fair does offer the services of a Wellness Center for the first time in its 32-year-old history. Visitors can have a massage for two Swiss francs (1.30 euros) a minute to "recover from fair-induced physical stress," notes the fair's arm-breaking 652-page catalogue. And paying tribute to the growing number of young collectors, the fair also has installed for the first time a kindergarten, thus relieving parents for an undisturbed art hunt in the jungle of stands. This younger group has become increasingly important as "involvement with cultural assets enjoys a rising popularity," says Dresdner Bank art analyst Wolfgang Wilke in the bank's latest issue of "Trends." What's more, there is a new gourmet restaurant in the VIP collectors' club manned by the city's star chefs: Pierre Buess of Restaurant Bruderholz (2 Michelin stars) and Evelyne and Werner Martin of Restaurant Martin in Flueh (1 Michelin star). Indeed, there's nothing like a good lunch to open a collector's wallet. 

  For six days each year, this Swiss town on the Rhine, becomes the commercial center of the global contemporary and modern art world. "No other fair comes close to Basel. Dealers actually keep back works for the Basel fair," says Cheyenne Westphal, head of contemporary art at Sotheby's Europe. From the around 900 galleries that apply, only a third are chosen by the fair's selection committee. And they are a careful mix of galleries offering classical modern pieces that are priced in the millions of dollars and young art that is sold for a few thousand dollars or less. In this year's vast so-called "Art Unlimited" hall will be the trendy young Atelier van Lieshout's compost toilet in the form of  a fisherman's house, offered by Amsterdam's Galerie Fons Welters, for around $20,000 (23,100 euros) or the equally trendy team of Markus Muntean and Adi Rosenblum with "Untitled" (2000), an installation with two lost figures standing uncertainly beside a large bed priced at around $30,000 at Galerie Susanna Kulli in St. Gallen. 

  Coming after last week's round of benchmark contemporary-art auctions in New York but before London's big contemporary-art sales in the last week of June, the fair is the next major sales event on the art circuit. And whereas auction results are what reveal the state of the market for most of the year, Basel is the galleries' showcase where they become the barometer of the market's health. Among the trends illustrated at the New York sales is a growing interest in cutting edge, figurative art such as portraits by Karen Kilimnik and John Currin. In New York last week, a standing nude portrait of a woman by Currin was estimated by Christie's at up to $200,000 and went for $336,000. There's also a return to craftsmanship through painting, drawing and watercolors, says Sotheby's Ms. Westphal. And while the prices of stars such as Jeff Koons are nearing those of Andy Warhol, buying is very selective, she adds. For example, at Sotheby's last week Koons's "Michael Jackson and Bubbles" (1988) sold for a record $5.6 million, but at Phillips auction Koons's stainless-steel flower sculpture failed to sell. Demand for photo art continues, led by stars including Cindy Sherman, Andreas Gursky and Thomas Struth, notes Ms. Westphal. At Christie's in New York, a work by Gursky "N.Y. Mercantile Exchange" (2000) was estimated at up to $180,000 and sold for $292,000. But on the other hand there were works by Gursky at last week's auctions that didn't sell. 

  A look through the Basel fair's catalogue shows all these trends and more. "It will be a real mix with a lot of photography," says Mr. Vetsch. 

 

  Chelsea Fair 

 

  Although ArtLondon founder Ralph Ward-Jackson admits that his event with 50 exhibitors of 20th century and contemporary art is modest in comparison with Basel, he asserts the event is hard to beat for charm. The London fair takes place between June 6 and June 10 in an outdoor marquee on the King's Road, with lots of champagne on tap. Mr. Ward-Jackson encourages one-man shows. "You tend to go gaga in Basel with all those artists. I have to take a rest," he says. To be included in this year's one-man shows is one devoted to British artist L.S. Lowry at the John Martin Gallery. In the same week, Christie's will auction nine Lowry paintings from the Frederick Forsyth collection at King Street on June 8. The paintings are expected to fetch a total of more than GBP 1 million (1,648,396 euros). 

  Prices generally range between GBP 500 and GBP 500,000. Although the fair's strongest contingent is British with top names such as Terry Frost, David Hockney, Bridget Riley, Graham Sutherland, Christopher Wood, Roger Hilton and Ivon Hitchens, collectors can also pick up top non-U.K. artists. The Coskun Fine Art Gallery will offer Andy Warhol's "Playboy Bunnie" (1985) for $55,000. And there will be a strong representation of Asian art. "On the contemporary front, Asian art seems to be very strong in London at the moment," says Mr. Ward-Jackson. Asia Contemporary Art will offer political pop artist Wang Guang Yi's painting entitled "Great Criticism - Elle" (1997) for GBP 15,000. 

  Nevertheless, in a British election week, attention is likely to go to a set of 15 papier-mache dogs decorated in the currency of the 15 members of the European Union by Britain's Justine Smith. The Rebecca Hossack Gallery will ask GBP 1,000 per dog plus the face value of the notes on the dog's surface.

NEW YORK STOCKS: 
 

  Major market averages stumbled in thin trading Friday, after government data released Friday renewed concerns about the pace of the economy's recovery. 

  Shares of several home builders struggled in the session with Pulte declining US$2.07 to US$40.09, while Centex lost 69 cents to 37.78, and Toll Brothers retreated 1.02 to 30.97. 

  The decline followed a Commerce Department report that showed existing home sales fell more sharply than economists had anticipated, which itself trailed a surprisingly weak new home sales report Thursday. 

  Other data released Friday, including a look at durable goods orders last month and a revision to the estimate of gross domestic product last quarter, also showed weaker-than-expected conditions in the economy, suggesting that the economy's response to the recent cycle of interest-rate reductions has been sluggish. 

  Meanwhile, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, in a speech in New York late Thursday, indicated that the economy's slowdown hasn't abated, which would suggest more rate hikes would be in the offing, something that, had the data Friday been more favorable, might have been taken a bit more constructively. 

  "Fed Chairman Greenspan's speech last night signaled more easing ahead," Maury Harris, an economist at UBS Warburg, said in a report Friday, "but didn't answer 'how much more?' or 'when?"' 

  Shares of capital-goods makers, which tend to weaken in response to sluggish economic conditions, declined, with United Technologies off 98 cents to 83.25, while Boeing lost 1.87 to 63.33. 

  Retailers also faded on concerns that consumer spending, which has been weak, won't tick up until the economy begins to flourish again. Shares of Wal-Mart Stores lost 1.69 to 51.20, while Home Depot fell 1.17 to 52.28. 

  The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 117.05 points lower, a decline of 1.05%, to 11005.37. The Nasdaq Composite fell 31.01, or 1.35%, to close at 2251.01. 

  Some market watchers argued that the economic data, and Greenspan's speech, which, at least arguably holds the promise of more stock-friendly rate cuts, had less to do with the outcome of Friday's trading than did the casual nature of pre-holiday trading, especially given the market's big gains coming into the session. 

  Share volume fell markedly, with 818 million shares trading on the New York Stock Exchange, compared with 1.1 billion Thursday, which itself wasn't an especially busy session. 

  "As we ease into this holiday weekend, the stock market is acting very normal," Don Hays, of Hays Research, said in a report Friday. "Stocks that broke out of consolidation or bottoming formations have been spending the last couple of days consolidating back to those break-out patterns." 

  On the New York Stock Exchange, there were 1,389 issues advancing, 1,637 declining and 218 unchanged. 

  NYSE volume totaled 816,082,120 shares, compared with 1,098,168,430 Thursday. 

  The NYSE Composite Index was 647.13, down 5.85. The average price per share fell 35 cents. 

 
 
NEW YORK PRECIOUS METALS: 
 

  Precious metals were trading mixed late Friday, with gold futures giving back another chunk of their gains on long liquidation by funds and other speculative players, yet bouncing back from lows, participants said. 

  "It was long liquidation, end of week. A lot of people have had decent P&L (profit and loss)," said a bullion dealer at a major investment bank in New York. "Open interest is still up, so the funds are not completely out of their (long) positions."

  Open interest in the June contract fell by 10,132 contracts on Thursday, while August open interest swelled by 13,671 contracts. 

  "The only thing I read into it was the rollover, which isn't a surprise. That's going to be normal," said Dave Meger, senior metals analyst at Alaron Trading Corp. in Chicago. "I assume they're longs in the market rolling. The shorts are under no pressure to do so." 

  June gold on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange finished trading US$1.20 lower at US$278.20 a troy ounce. 

  He cited an abundance of fund selling Friday, but emphasized that people had been looking too hard for reasons behind the collapse of the rally, when funds are motivated mainly by technical considerations. 

  "You get weak longs buying up near US$290 (an ounce) and you (drop to) US$280, you're going to see long liquidation. There's no big reason behind it," he explained. 

  Everyone was now focusing on the US$275 level, which he imagined would be taken out if only because sell-stops were accumulating under there and they were likely to be targeted next week. 

  The bulls still might have a chance at extending the rallying back up again if they managed to wash out the weak longs and prepare to advance again, he noted. 

  While it was clear to him that the absence of producer selling due to reduced returns for selling forward had been a key factor in the rally, he doubted the market coud count on them remaining sidelined for a prolonged time span. 

  The bullion dealer predicted more volatility next week, potentially leading to prices covering much the same range seen this week. He said a US$5 move to either side of the curent price was probable. 

  Comex July silver fell back, ending 3.7 cents lower at US$4.583 an ounce, after testing and failing again at the 200-day moving average of US$4.62 an ounce. 

  The 5.0% drop in durable goods orders for April, released Friday morning, hurt silver because it boded badly for industrial demand, the bullion dealer said. 

  Silver hasn't been as vulnerable as gold to liquidation of speculative long positions, said Alaron's Meger, but he had little confidence it could sustain itself above US$4.55 support or even the earlier high of US$4.515 an ounce. It was stil trading on the back of gold, he added. 

  Commission house buying pushed Nymex July platinum into buy-stop territory above US$623, a floor trader said, but the market came off to finish at US$622, up US$3 from Thursday. While he saw the gains as likely to attract more buying from funds, they are already quite long. 

  June palladium rose US$5.00 to US$660 an ounce, looking stronger and possibly preparing to head back toward US$680-$700 after the long holiday weekend, another trader said. 

 
 
NYMEX: 
 

  Refined products futures retreated Friday at the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders locked in profits ahead of Memorial Day weekend, but rose from the day's lows at the close. 

  Crude futures closed as they had opened, trading on either side of unchanged. 

  Nymex closed at 1 p.m. EDT (1700 GMT) Friday, and will be closed Monday for Memorial Day. 

  The decline in refined products contracts extended a sell-off that was sparked by gasoline futures Thursday. The sell-off came after what traders called "panicked" short covering Wednesday exhausted itself early Thursday, ending a sizzling rally in which futures rose 17% in a week. 

  "That took the pressure out of the market," a floor trader said. "We had a good move Thursday. We aren't getting much of a bounce. That sets the tone for the next two sessions." 

  Crude futures could lose US$1 next week, traders said, barring refinery problems and other fundamentally bullish news. 

  Crude is being driven by declining gasoline futures and pressured by its own weak technicals and the weight of continued builds in crude stockpiles on surging imports. The nearby July crude oil contract has fallen US$2.50 from its high Wednesday. 

  Nearby gasoline futures trimmed most losses on short covering and bargain hunting at the close. June gasoline futures are 6 cents off their high from Thursday: an all-time record of US$1.1750 a gallon. The contract is seen expiring May 31 near US$1.065. Deferred gasoline contracts retreated sharply. 

  Booksquaring ahead of Memorial Day was the dominant feature of trading Friday. Volume was thin and many players were absent. 

  Concerns over thin supplies and regional shortages just ahead of the traditional Memorial Day kickoff to the summer driving season, coupled with refinery problems and a drop in reformulated summer gasoline stocks, may continue to support the petroleum complex. Tightness in the supply situation is making traders wary of aggressively selling the market short. 

  "One refinery glitch and prices could pop 4 cents," an analyst said. "Especially over a long holiday weekend." 

  A draw in key summertime inventories triggered the latest leg up. Stocks of reformulated gasoline fell 1.4 million barrels to 39.9 million barrels in the week ended May 18, the Department of Energy's Energy Information Administration reported Wednesday. That substantiated an earlier report by the American Petroleum Institute.

text:
Survey: Teachers' Salaries Don't Keep Pace With Inflation

 

  WASHINGTON (AP)--Teacher salaries have risen slightly in the past several years, but have failed to keep up with inflation, according to surveys released Thursday by teachers' unions. 

  The American Federation of Teachers said the average teacher salary in the 1999-2000 school year was $41,820, up 3.2% from the previous year but just short of the 3.4 inflation rate. AFT said the rise in salary was among the smallest in 40 years. 

  "The teacher shortage plaguing school districts nationwide will not abate unless salaries improve," AFT President Sandra Feldman said. "Better wages aren't the only way to retain and recruit teachers, but they sure make a difference." 

  The National Education Association's survey found that, adjusting for inflation, teacher salaries in half of the states dropped in the last decade. 

  The NEA said teachers in West Virginia, Arkansas and Alabama saw the largest drops in real earnings, from 12 to 16%, since 1989. 

  The surveys used data from state departments of education. The unions had slightly different calculations on state-by-state salaries, but both said Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Michigan and Pennsylvania paid teachers the most, between $48,300 and $52,400 on average. 

  Montana, Mississippi, Oklahoma, North Dakota and South Dakota were at the bottom of both lists, paying teachers, on average, about $30,000. South Dakota, at $29,072, paid the lowest average teacher salary in both lists. 

  AFT said the average salary increase for new teachers was actually lower in 1999 than in 1998. New teachers last year earned, on average, $27,989, up 4.2% from the previous year. In 1998, their salaries jumped 4.4%, AFT said. 

  The NEA report said that, between 1989 and 2000, average salaries rose by less than 1%, adjusted for inflation. It also said spending on K-12 education increased but didn't keep pace with the nation's economic growth. 

  While education revenue per student increased 3.6% from the 1998 to 1999, NEA said, total personal income in the United States grew 5.9%. 

  "It's inexcusable that during a decade of unprecedented economic growth in this country, students were left behind. What does that say about the real value we place on education?" said NEA President Bob Chase. 

  New teachers' salaries also lost ground to starting wages in other white-collar professions, the NEA said. 

  While a new teacher could expect to earn about $27,989, college graduates could expect an average starting salary of $47,112 for engineering jobs, $46,495 for computer science jobs and $40,242 for jobs in business. 

  "I don't think there's anybody who doesn't wish teachers could be paid more, said Bruce Hunter, director of public policy for the American Association of School Administrators. "It really gets down to, 'Can you?"' 

  Hunter said many states are watching good teachers leave for states that pay higher salaries. 

  "In some places the taxpayers have been very generous, and in some places they haven't," he said.

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

WSJ(5/30): Brazil Proposal To Boost Thermal Power Comes Late

 By Jonathan Karp 
  Staff Reporter of The Wall Street Journal 

  SAO PAULO, Brazil -- The government is poised to remove a key obstacle to the construction of thermoelectric-power plants in a move that foreign investors said is welcome but two years too late to avert the country's energy crisis. 

  Brazil urgently needs thermal power to reduce its almost-exclusive dependence on hydroelectricity. But many foreign investors have balked because of the high foreign-exchange risk involved in paying dollars for natural gas, used to fuel the plants, but being able to sell the electricity at prices set in Brazil's currency. Under a new plan, the government will set natural-gas prices annually and state-owned oil company Petroleo Brasileiro SA, or Petrobras, which will supply most of the gas, will absorb foreign-exchange variations. 

  "This is one step forward. Gas is 50% of a power plant's cost," said Luiz David Travesso, head of AES Corp.'s Brazil unit. The Arlington, Va., utility, one of the largest U.S. investors in Brazil, suspended $2 billion in planned power projects earlier this month in a warning to the government to clarify investment and regulatory rules. 

  Mr. Travesso said it is too early to resume talks over the plants because there are other issues to be resolved, such as long-term financing and provisions for electricity distributors to raise consumer rates in line with rising energy prices. 

  Drought and rising demand have drained Brazil's reservoirs. The country is to begin rationing energy this week in an attempt to reduce consumption by 20% and prevent blackouts. The crisis has revived efforts to accelerate the construction of power plants fired by plentiful natural gas from Brazil, Bolivia and Argentina. 

  A two-year-old government plan envisioned 49 new thermal-power plants, but just nine are under construction, said Paulo Feldmann, head of Ernst & Young's energy practice in Sao Paulo. "It's a pity. If the government had resolved the gas issue a year-and-a-half ago, these thermal plants would be operating," he said. 

  The new natural-gas scheme won't satisfy all 49 planned projects, because Petrobras managed to cap its supply so as to reduce its financial exposure. 

  Separately, the Brazilian unit of Canada's Alcan Inc. said it is preparing to cut aluminum production in the next six months by almost 25% because of power rationing. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
WSJ(6/29): Column: Argentina's Econ Measures Are Pro-Growth

 
  By Domingo F. Cavallo 
 

  (Editor's Note: Mr. Cavallo is Argentina's economy minister.) 

 

  Two weeks ago the Argentine government launched a new package of measures aimed at improving fiscal solvency, enhancing competitiveness, and reigniting domestic demand and economic growth. 

  No economic recovery can take place without an improvement in Argentina's macroeconomic fundamentals. This is why our earlier policy changes, announced over the past couple of months, have focused on this objective. New tax measures and cuts in public spending were designed to consolidate fiscal matters. A successful debt exchange, carried out last month, will create a substantial reduction in financing needs over the next five years. Competitiveness plans focus on reducing tax pressure on domestic producers so as to encourage investment, employment and growth. 

  Now we have moved to strengthen these policies. On the fiscal side we are declaring an all-out war against tax evasion and privatizing the collection of tax arrears. In terms of competitiveness, we are moving to protect domestic producers from adverse external shocks and boosting domestic demand through additional measures aimed at encouraging consumption and investment. 

  This government is committed to building a tax system with only two taxes: the value-added tax (VAT) and the income tax. This new tax system will require mechanisms to reduce the current levels of tax evasion. To tackle these objectives the government is establishing a uniform payroll tax of 16%. If this new rate increases an individual's tax burden, the difference may be credited toward his or her VAT. Only those who were previously evading income tax will pay more. We are also changing the VAT payment regime to a cash basis -- from an accrual basis -- in order in order to facilitate taxpayers' financial management and also compliance control. 

  The new measures also include the implementation of a privately managed system to collect tax arrears. The private manager will establish a trust fund, which will be made up of unpaid taxes as its assets and tax credits owed as its liabilities. The liabilities will be securitized as bonds and given to corporations that are due the credits. This will convert tax credits, previously immobilized on balance sheets, into liquid instruments. It is expected that a private manager will collect tax arrears more efficiently than the government. And collection improvements will reduce the incentive for tax evasion. 

  To enhance competitiveness and encourage exports the government is implementing a comprehensive set of trade-policy instruments that we call the "convergence factor." Exports will be rewarded with an adjustable reimbursement equal to the difference between the present exchange rate -- one U.S. dollar -- and the rate under the enhanced convertibility law, which is a simple average of the dollar and the euro. At the present time that difference is approximately 7 cents. 

  Similarly, imports will pay a tariff, also adjustable, and of the same magnitude. In order to compensate for the short-run price effects associated with the convergence factor, the maximum import tariff on consumer goods and the maximum reimbursement on exports are reduced 7 percentage points. 

  It is worth noting that the new mechanism has nothing to do with old-fashioned dual exchange-rate regimes. It preserves dollar convertibility in its present form for peso holders, fully respecting their property rights, and does not imply a modification of the exchange system of the Argentine peso. The payments will be done through current trade-policy practices with no participation whatsoever of the Central Bank or monetary authorities, which will continue to exchange one peso for one dollar as required by the convertibility law. Reserves of the Central Bank play no role in the scheme, which in no way is related to currency transactions. 

  The convergence factor fluctuates on the basis of the dollar-euro exchange rate and, to the extent that these currencies approach parity, it would converge to zero. When dollar-euro parity is reached, the new dollar-euro method of valuing the peso will take effect, and therefore the need for the convergence factor will disappear. 

  The new mechanism also generates resources for the government. Since fuels will be excluded, and our trade has a significant surplus in this area, income will be larger than payments. The elimination of reimbursements adds to the fiscal savings of the measure. In all the government expects to collect almost $600 million from these trade-related measures. 

  The strengthened competitiveness of the tradable sector is a key element for sustaining long-run economic growth. However, the government recognizes that an economic recovery requires domestic demand. In order to boost domestic demand (consumption and investment) the government has designed two measures. First, to underpin recovery of domestic consumption, we have implemented an income-tax cut for families with medium and low incomes. The cut increases disposable income by about $500 million. Second, to strengthen the infrastructure plan, and to enhance its execution capacity, a Road Network Fund will be created, financed by a modification of the toll system and fuel taxes. The fuel-tax adjustment will sharply reduce gasoline prices, putting another $500 million in consumers' pockets. This will be financed by an increase in diesel taxes that can be counted as prepayment against the VAT. 

  The fiscal impact of these measures is estimated to be above $600 million, yet improving fiscal balance is not the main purpose of the latest policy changes. The focus is improving competitiveness and reducing tax evasion, thus increasing fairness and making it possible to lower rates for everyone. 

  In this sense, we address not only social concerns but also market concerns: to improve the fight against tax evasion, to consolidate fiscal resources, and to shield the economy from additional appreciation of the dollar. This completes our short-run economic policy measures, which were made in installments because of the constraints produced by the need for congressional approval of specific legislation. 

  We will now move to long-run structural measures such as social-security reform, the improvement of the health-care system, and even stronger trade liberalization. Friday's decision to set up a single trade negotiator for Mercosur is a good starting point. This negotiator will be given the task of working to open the markets of the European Union and the U.S. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

WSJ(6/25): US Faces Fight For "Smart" Sanctions Against Iraq

 
  By Neil King Jr. and Bhushan Bahree 
  Staff Reporters of The Wall Street Journal 

  WASHINGTON -- Bush administration officials enter a week of tough diplomacy at the United Nations today on fears that international opposition could thwart efforts to build a new "smart" sanctions system for Iraq. 

  Facing deep resistance among Iraq's neighbors and its allies Russia and China, the U.S. and Britain say they will continue to push for a Security Council vote on a new Iraq resolution before a July 3 deadline. But senior U.S. officials concede that many forces are stacked against them and that a vote is likely to be put off for a month or longer - and could be scrapped altogether. 

  Iraq hasn't exported any oil under the U.N. oil-for-food program for three weeks in protest over the sanctions initiative, depriving the world market of an average flow of about 2.1 million barrels a day. Further delays at the U.N. could keep that oil off the market for months, although Baghdad's punitive move has so far done little to affect prices or squeeze supplies. 

  Defeat at the U.N. would be a sharp blow to Secretary of State Colin Powell, who plunged into Iraq diplomacy in his first weeks in office in a bid to rebuild an international consensus to contain Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. Failure would also leave the current sanctions system in a shambles and give weight to those within the administration who favor launching a U.S.-backed armed insurgency to topple the Iraqi government. 

  The U.S. and British plan, now into its third draft resolution, aims to allow a free flow of goods into Iraq except for a core list of items whose import would need U.N. approval. The administration also has promised to find ways to crack down on the import of illegal military goods into Iraq and to cut off the smuggling of Iraqi oil, an effort that has largely run aground due to opposition among neighboring states like Jordan and Syria. 

  Much of the diplomatic skirmishing still swirls around a list of dual-use items that would require U.N. approval before Iraq could buy them. Russia and China want a much leaner list to allow Iraq easy access to telecommunications and other equipment that they argue pose no military threat. 

  France and Russia, who like Security Council member China can veto any resolution, also want to open the way for some foreign investment, particularly in Iraq's decrepit oil industry. The U.S. says it will oppose any provision that could end up enriching Saddam Hussein. 

  U.S. officials admit they underestimated the difficulty of squeezing so many clashing interests and proposals into a three- or four-page resolution that would then win the support of all 15 Security Council members. But other developments have gone against them since the effort began. The fighting between Palestinians and Israelis got bloodier, spreading anger through the Arab world. And Iraqi threats to cut off the flow of cheap oil to its neighbors made countries like Jordan and Syria less than keen to sign onto a new sanctions system. 

  U.S. officials, though, say their largest obstacle now is Russia. Moscow would prefer to get rid of the 11-year-old sanctions on Iraq altogether and views the latest round of U.S. diplomacy as little more than a stalling tactic. Still, one U.S. official said the administration still hopes to win Russia over, though it remains unclear what concessions the U.S. might offer to get Moscow's support. 

  Russia successfully pushed for an open debate on Iraq within the Security Council for tomorrow afternoon in what many predict could be a lively session. U.S. diplomats have criticized the debate as a time-consuming distraction, but say they hope to use the forum to sway skeptics. 

  On the oil side, the market has largely been calmed by repeated pledges from Saudi Arabia that the kingdom will raise output if the loss of crude from Iraq begins to squeeze the world market. The Saudis have said they would boost exports if necessary in a coordinated move with others in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. OPEC's ministers have called a ministerial meeting for July 3 in Vienna, less than a month after they last met following the Iraqi shutdown and decided to hold output steady. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  June 24, 2001 19:30 ET (23:30 GMT)
