DATA SNAP: Brazil Inflation Slows On Easing Food Prices

 
 
IPCA Consumer Price Index: 
              May       Apr      Mar      Feb      Jan 
Forecast     +0.41%   +0.55%   +0.36%   +0.29%   +0.48% 
Actual       +0.41%   +0.58%   +0.38%   +0.46%   +0.57% 
 
    By Anthony Dovkants 
    Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  SAO PAULO (Dow Jones)--Meeting market expectations, Brazil's key consumer price index slowed in May thanks to an easing in food inflation. 

  But the deceleration was partly offset by a pickup in transportation costs. 

  The government-run IBGE statistics institute Tuesday said the IPCA Broad Consumer Price Index advanced 0.41% in May, compared with a 0.58% increase in April. 

  According to a Dow Jones Newswires' survey of 15 economists, the average forecast pointed to a 0.41% rise in the IPCA Broad Consumer Price Index in May. Projections ranged from increases of between 0.21% to 0.45%. 

  The May figure put the 12-month inflation rate at 7.04% and the year-to-date increase at 2.42%. 

  The easing in food price inflation is on the back of the arrival of crops on the market following harvest, combined with a drop in beef prices on the market following a series of outbreaks of foot-and-mouth disease in the southern prime cattle-raising state of Rio Grande do Sul. 

  IBGE said food prices in May rose 0.58%, compared with an increase of 1.80% in April. The turnaround in food price inflation comes after months of pressure from the category on the overall index. 

  The slowdown in the May rate, though, was partly offset by the city of Sao Paulo boosting bus fares by 22% last month, the IBGE said. 

  Despite the easing in the pace of inflation, the matter continues to be a big concern as Latin America's biggest nation now deals with a six-month electricity rationing plan that is likely to cut into economic growth and push prices higher. The rationing program, which started June 1, requires industry, commerce and retail users to cut electricity use by an average 20% a month. 

  The slowdown in May comes ahead of electricity distributors raising fees between June and July and that this factor, combined with high international oil prices and the sharp depreciation of the local currency, is expected to drive inflation higher in coming months. The weak real, which has lost some 19% of its value since the start of the year, so far has mainly affected prices on the wholesale level. 

  The falling currency is also making Brazilian oil imports more expensive and the energy crunch could also send housing costs higher, as the government plans to levy a surcharge on those consumers that fail to meet their energy-saving targets. 

  Opinion is divided among analysts over whether the central bank, which has a 4% IPCA target for this year, will further hike interest rates to keep inflation in check. The goal has a two-percentage-point leeway either side and central bank governor Arminio Fraga recently said inflation could reach 5.5% this year. 

  While some advocate more hikes as inflation remains a threat, others believe that more monetary tightening this year would be useless as the moves would only affect 2002 prices. Inflationary concerns led the central bank to raise the country's benchmark interest rate by 150 basis points to 16.75% between March and May. That reversed a two-year policy of monetary easing. 

  The hikes and the energy crisis are expected to shave between one to two percentage points of the initially forecast 4% to 4.5% growth rate for 2001, while also slowing growth next year. 

 

  -By Anthony Dovkants, Dow Jones Newswires; 55-11 3145-1478; anthony.dovkants@dowjones.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
BoE Watch: Growing Imbalances May Cause Econ To Wobble

 
 
   By Gonzalo Vina 
   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 

  (This story was originally published Friday) 

  LONDON (Dow Jones)--The Bank of England are becoming increasingly concerned that different parts of the British economy are moving at varying speeds. 

  As trade figures indicated only too clearly earlier this week, exports are being hurt by the strength of the pound and the global economic downturn while imports are soaring to meet the insatiable appetites of British consumers. 

  The central bank has also been confronted with trying to insulate the U.K. from the effects of a global economic downturn by cutting interest rates, at a time when the housing market, retail sales and consumer borrowing could do with the opposite. 

  And if that weren't enough, the big public spending increases pledged by the government will pump extra money into the economy over the next few years. 

  During his annual Mansion House speech, the governor of the Bank of England Eddie George, warned that these imbalances can't go on forever and the "elastic is likely to break - possibly through an exchange rate adjustment". 

  And having recently deliberately stimulated domestic demand to offset the effects of the global downturn, that demand will have to be reined back, even though the momentum could prove hard to stop, he added. 

  While the governor also said that this moment is not yet here, it explains the rate stetting Monetary Policy Committee's reluctance to drop rates more sharply in recent months. 

  For Danny Gabay, an economist at JP Morgan in London, George's comments are a clear signal that interest rates will stay on hold at 5.75%. 

  "His (George's) key theme was the twin-speed economy: external weakness and domestic strength - the latter partly deliberately engineered by the MPC to offset the former. However, in an emphatic statement of rates on hold, he noted that this policy could do little to offset external weakness, but ran the risk of exacerbating the growing imbalances within the economy," said Gabay. 

  The central bank's deputy governor also did much to highlight these imbalances during a lecture in Cardiff and, while mentioning that he was keeping an eye on creeping inflation, he did much to play down any worries attributing the recent rises to seasonal food and gasoline price rises. 

  The central bank is in tight spot. It faces rising inflation and an overactive consumer sector which it can do little to curb because of uncertainty still surrounding the U.S. and now euro-zone economies. 

  Furthermore, the political necessities of the current government could also make these imbalances worsen. The Labour Party was voted in for a second term with what Prime Minister Tony Blair regards as a clear mandate to improve public services above all. 

  Geoffrey Dicks, an economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland believes that government spending pledges will add fuel to an already roaring fire. 

  He looks back to 1987, the last time a Chancellor loosened the country's' purse strings at a time when consumer demand was strong. 

  "The parallels with 1987, when a reelected government found itself having to deliver on election promises, will worry those on the MPC with long memories," he said. 

  Dicks notes how the Conservative Chancellor of the day, Nigel Lawson, was reelected on the promise of further tax cuts. Lawson thought the public sector surplus was structural and expected consumer spending to slow. In the event, neither proved true. 

  Dicks says that with public accounts in similar shape but, like the '80s, the economic resources aren't there. 

  "The economy is operating at, or close to, full employment; consumer spending is booming on the back of Budget tax cuts and lower interest rates, though once again the Treasury is pinning its colors on deceleration which as far as retail sales are concerned are nowhere in sight," he said. 

  For him, the MPC has run out of room for maneuver. "At some stage they will have to rein the consumer back in - earlier if sterling falls or later if the euro weakness persists". 

  -By Gonzalo Vina, Dow Jones Newswires; 44 20 7842 9497; gonzalo.vina@dowjones.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  June 25, 2001 02:00 ET (06:00 GMT)

text:
Saudi Arabia Expected To Achieve 2001 Budget Surplus

 
 

  By Abdulla Fardan 

  OF DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 

  MANAMA, Bahrain (Dow Jones)--Saudi Arabia looks set to achieve another budget surplus this year because of firmer-than-forecast oil prices, regional analysts say. 

  In December the government had estimated a balanced budget of $57.30 billion for the current year, having run its first surplus for 18 years of $12 billion in 2000 on the back of higher oil prices and petroleum production. 

  Based on these figures, analysts predicted the kingdom had factored in a conservative price for Saudi oil of $21-$22 a barrel for 2001. 

  In the event, the country's oil sold for an average $26/bbl in 2000 (about 45% above expectations) and has averaged close to this level so far this year. 

  But analysts cautioned that with another six months to go, the picture could change unexpectedly and that, in any case, they don't expect last year's huge surplus to be repeated. 

  "The Saudi economy is benefiting from firm oil prices now, but if something (unfavorable) were to happen in the oil market, the outlook will change..." said Sa'id Al-Shaikh, chief economist at the Saudi National Commercial Bank in Jeddah. 

  He added that the government is currently earning at least $3/bbl above what it estimated for its 2001 budget. 

  "I would expect that if they are disciplined on expenditure, there will be a small surplus - not as much as last year, but there will be a surplus," Al-Shaikh said. 

  Brad Bourland, chief economist at the Saudi American Bank in Riyadh, said if oil prices stay the same, the government could run a surplus of "several billion riyals." But on average, they are expected to be lower than in 2000, he added. 

  Last month, the country's Finance Minister, Ibrahim Al-Assaf, said the government had already achieved its budget target for the first half of 2001, factoring in expected revenues from June oil contracts. 

  Last year, Saudi Arabia increased its oil output by more than one million barrels a day, in line with increases by other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. 

  So far this year, OPEC has cut production by 2.5 million b/d, with Saudi Arabia's share of this just above 800,000 b/d. 

  However OPEC is widely expected to increase output in the third quarter, which will impact both on global oil prices and Saudi revenues. 

  Oil receipts account for about 75% of total Saudi government revenue. 

 
           Real 2001 GDP Seen At Around 2.5% 
 

  Al-Assaf recently said he expects economic growth this year to be no less than in 2000, at a real rate of 4.5%. 

  But local economists predict that real GDP this year will be closer to 2.5% because of expected lower oil prices and production. The oil sector makes up about 40% of total GDP. 

  Other parts of the economy are expected to achieve good growth this year on the back of healthy oil prices. 

  The Saudi government owns around 70% of the domestic petrochemical industry, the largest in the Middle East. The construction sector, whose performance has traditionally tracked the price of oil, has shown consistent growth since the third quarter of last year. 

 

  By Abdulla Fardan, Dow Jones Newswires; (973) 530758; abdullah.fardan@dowjones.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

MARKET TALK/AU-EQ: Bond Futures Drop On CPI

 
 

  [Contact Us: Sydney 61-2-8235-2950; djnews.sydney@dowjones.com] 

 

  1144 [Dow Jones] September government bond futures down sharply in wake of stronger-than-expected 0.8% rise in 2Q CPI from 1Q, which all but wipes out chances of further RBA easing in current cycle; September 90-day bank bills now at 94.980, indicating no expectation cash rate will be eased from current 5.0% in 3Q. NY Precious Metals Mostly Dn Late, Gold Ignores Firm Euro

 
 

  NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Precious metals were trading mostly lower late Wednesday, with gold futures slipping on fund and trade selling, turning their back on the euro's gains, participants said. 

  Initial pressure came from funds choosing to liquidate some of their stagnant long positions in August gold rather than rolling them forward into later months, a trader at an international bank in New York said. 

  Later, "gold got sold down by the trade into some sell-stops below $268 (an ounce)," said broker John Fimat at Fimat in New York. "When stops are discovered to be someplace, the market will usually go to them." 

       (Prices in Dollars a Troy Ounce) 
       Wednesday   Chng On     Leading         Nymex 
       1515 ET     Late NY     Nymex           Range 
Gold   267.95      -2.10       267.80  (Aug)   267.30-270.20 
Silver   4.245     -0.015        4.232 (Sep)     4.225-4.26 
Plat   510.00     +14.00       507.60  (Oct)   498.10-513.00

  Stops accumulated under $268 because it had been a support level. 

  Trading was seen as extremely quiet in Europe and Asia, with a typhoon Tuesday continuing to keep Hong Kong traders from their desks. 

  With just three more active days remaining for the August contract, more long liquidation - and further easing in gold prices - is likely, Geneva-based MKS Finance SA said in its daily report. 

  Precious metals strategist Kevin Crisp at CSFB in London saw the stronger euro sustaining European consumer buying - especially by jewelry fabricators in Italy. But even though the euro was trading near $0.88, gold prices came off. 

  The $265-$270 range remains intact, however, due to physical demand, and MKS Finance expected the more robust euro to lead gold higher again once the rollover has finished.

text:
Dollar Has A Bad Week Vs Majors; Future Cloudy Vs Euro

 
 
   By John Hardy 
   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--The dollar is used to having its own way in the currency markets, particularly against the euro, but this past week told a very different story. 

  Against the dollar, the euro is up 2.4% for the week, the yen is 1.4% firmer and the Swiss franc, the biggest mover of all, is up 2.9%. Even the pound has gained 2%. 

  The last time the dollar slipped on this scale against the euro was back in early April, when the single currency rose by more than 3% in a week and bounced above 90 cents. 

  That euro rally proved to be a fake-out and the single currency promptly fell into a tailspin which culminated earlier this month with a new low for the year at $0.8350, little more than a cent about its all-time bottom at $0.8230 last October. 

  This time, the euro may be able to sustain a recovery as the market's tone has definitely changed. 

  "The euro is now shrugging off every piece of bad news it gets - just like the dollar used to, " said Greg Salvaggio, trading manager at Tempus Consulting in Washington. 

  However, the foreign exchange market is still split on whether this latest euro rally is a real indication that the currency's dog days are over. 

  "I think the euro is going to crash again," said Laurie Cameron, currency strategist in the private bank at J.P. Morgan in New York, voting for the euro-bear approach. 

  On the other hand, the euro is winning some supporters. In his weekly forecasting outlook, Jim O'Neill, chief economist of Goldman Sachs in London, sees the euro rising to 88 cents in the near term and then breaking above $1.00 by the end of the year. The last time the euro was at parity with the dollar was in January 2000. 

  In New York afternoon trading, the euro was at $0.8723, above $0.8715 in London and $0.8710 in New York late Thursday. The dollar was at Y122.95, down from Y123.31 in London and down from Y123.24 late Thursday. 

  Three key factors seem to have been at the root of the dollar's problems this week and they bode ill for the U.S. currency in the future. 

  First, the U.S. economy is no longer the clear winner in the international growth stakes. On Wednesday, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan gave a downbeat assessment of the economy, in his closely-watched Congressional testimony, stating that risks in the coming months remain clearly to the downside. 

  Second, the euro zone is definitely doing a little better and its economic numbers are no longer as damaging as they once were. This week, French industrial production for May increased 0.3%, compared with a 0.4% decline in April. 

  Inflation, which has been seen as limiting the European Central Bank's ability to cut interest rates, seems to be abating. Euro-zone consumer prices for June came in at an increase of 0.1% for the month and 3.0% for the year, better than expected. 

  Third, and perhaps most worrying, is a lessening of the dollar's domestic and international stature. 

  Currency markets have become increasingly confused by the widely publicized debate over the U.S. strong dollar policy. 

  There are frequent and vociferous calls for a more exporter-friendly dollar policy and Gordon Richard, economist for the National Association of Manufacturers, sees the currency's strength as "a speculative bubble that refuses to burst and needs to be deflated." 

  Both President George Bush and Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill have attempted to still the debate in recent days but without success. The Bush Administration has made it clear, however, it has no intention of altering U.S. sollar policy. 

  But doubts about the strong dollar's future are now haunting the U.S. currency's performance aheaqd of this weekend's Group of Seven leading nations' meeting in Genoa, Italy. 

  "The market seems to have caught the bug that the G7 is going to successfully badger the U.S. into abandoning its strong dollar policy," said Salvaggio. "Some major players honestly believe that some modification of policy may be coming - people have been very jittery," he added. 

  Finally, the dollar's international standing has been hurt in recent weeks by the market's dollar-negative reaction to the ongoing crisis in Argentina and its implications for other emerging markets in Latin America and elsewhere. 

  The dollar was sold as rumors of a financial crisis multiplied and the euro may have benefited by association with the Swiss franc. 

  "The reason the European currencies are strong is that the Swiss franc is a safe haven against (problems in) Argentina," said Cameron. 

  This issue could easily cloud the dollar's future. "I am still fearful that we haven't seen the end of the problems in Argentina," she said and added that Mexico could be hurt also. 

  -By John Hardy, Dow Jones Newswires; 201-938-2122; john.hardy@dowjones.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
Venezuela's Oil Sector Badly Hurt By 1H '01 Oil Cuts

 
 

  (This article was originally published Thursday) 

    By Fred Pals 
    Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  CARACAS (Dow Jones)--Two consecutive oil production cuts required by agreements with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had a major impact on Venezuela's oil sector in the first half. 

  President Hugo Chavez revealed Thursday that the  sector contracted 3% from January to June. 

  Despite that contraction, gross domestic product expanded 3.4% in the first half thanks to a strong performance in the non-oil economy. 

   "As you know, we follow a strategy to defend oil prices and keep them in the price band," Chavez said. 

  OPEC has adopted a price range requiring members to cut production when its reference oil basket slips beneath $22 or increase it when the basket exceeds $28 for a set number of days. 

  Once a notorious quota buster, Venezuela has turned into an upstanding member of OPEC under the Chavez administration. Including a third reduction in output effective Sept. 1, the country will have removed some 416,000 barrels a day from the market so far this year in compliance with its OPEC obligations. 

  Venezuela's new quota will stand at 2.67 million b/d, a level not seen since early 1998. The country's current quota stands at 2.79 million b/d. 

  In Venezuela's $100 billion economy, oil accounts for half of government revenue and 80% of its export earnings. It represents about a third of gross domestic product. 

 
   Incipient Criticism After Disappointing Figures 
 

  But Venezuela's hawkish position within OPEC is likely to come under fire again with the release of the latest numbers. 

  According to Hugo Hernandez Rafalli, the president of the local Petroleum Chamber, Venezuela could end up losing on both market share and oil income if the price-over-production strategy continues without adjustment. 

  Industry analysts see enough output from non-OPEC producers coming onstream next year to threaten OPEC's pricing strategy. 

  Slowing U.S. and global economies coupled with growing non-OPEC production have combined to put downward pressure on prices, prompting OPEC to cut its aggregate production. 

  The 2001 running average of Venezuela's basket of crude oil and refined products stands at $21.90/bbl, down from $25.91/bbl last year. 

  Alan Viergutz, a local oil analyst, said OPEC's  strategy to keep prices at the midlevel of the $22 to $28 a barrel range will lead to the worst-case scenario: low prices, low production and much idle output capacity. 

  Analysts suggest that at OPEC's target price range, many non-OPEC producers are profitable, and that their production has been coming on stream. 

  But the price-over-supply policy is built into Venezuela's budget: the 2001 budget is based on a basket price of $20 a barrel. Officials say a high price nets the country more foreign exchange than increased output. Hence the interest in cutting output to support prices. 

  Still, several government officials have already suggested that a lower average target for 2002 would be prudent. 

  Rafalli said it would be healthy to lower OPEC's target price to prevent more cutting. "Lowering the $22 to $28 range is an issue for OPEC to discuss at their next meeting in September," Rafalli said. 

  However, there are some bright spots ahead. Given an expected increase in seasonal demand, OPEC is unlikely to cut its oil production a fourth time this year. Also, state-owned oil monopoly Petroleos de Venezuela S.A. usually starts spending most of its budget during the second half of the year on maintenance works. 

  That should spur economic activity among the sector's ancillary goods and services businesses, which have been directly affected by the country's oil cuts. 

  -By Fred Pals, Dow Jones Newswires; 58-212-5641339; fred.pals@dowjones.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
AWSJ: Toshiba Plans To Cut 20,000 Jobs In Japan

 
  By Peter Landers 
  Staff Reporter 

  TOKYO -- Toshiba Corp. announced it will cut 20,000 jobs in Japan, adding its name to a growing list of Japanese electronic manufacturers that are trimming their work forces as part of corporate overhauls. But Toshiba also followed the pack by insisting that its myriad business units are more valuable together than apart. 

  The company's move was sparked by a plunge in world-wide semiconductor prices. Toshiba expects a 94 billion yen ($782.9 million) operating loss in semiconductors in the year ending March 31, 2002, almost all of it from memory chips. Toshiba's revised outlook for the year calls for a group net loss of 115 billion yen, compared with a 96 billion yen net profit in the year ended March 31, 2001. Sales are expected to fall 3.4% to 5.75 trillion yen. 

  The specifics of the job cuts remain unclear, but no one is being fired or laid off. Toshiba said it expects attrition to account for about half of the 20,000-job reduction, while the other half would come from restructuring some of its units, and voluntary early retirement. However, the cuts, which amount to nearly 14% of the company's jobs in Japan, won't be completed until March 2004. Toshiba said it expects its domestic work force to total around 127,000 then, compared with 144,000 now, because it also plans to hire several thousand people in the meantime. 

  Investors welcomed the news, bidding Toshiba's stock price up 5.6% to 604 yen a share, outpacing a 1% gain on the benchmark Nikkei 225 Stock Average. 

  President Tadashi Okamura declined to comment on what is expected to be the biggest of the restructuring moves - a merger of Toshiba's memory-chip business with either Infineon Technologies AG of Germany or South Korea's Samsung Electronics Co. People familiar with the situation said over the weekend that Toshiba is discussing a deal with the two companies but Mr. Okamura refused to confirm the talks. 

  Despite the cuts, Mr. Okamura insisted that Toshiba will remain a comprehensive electronics maker - known as sogo denki - amid the growing challenge of controlling an unwieldy array of business units. Toshiba's products include electronics parts such as semiconductors; consumer electronics such as TV sets, personal computers and mobile telephones; and heavy industrial equipment. 

  "The biggest feature of Toshiba is that we produce synergy effects" from the various businesses, said Mr. Okamura. He said he plans to transfer more power to the heads of company units, while at the same time encouraging those unit leaders to work more closely with each other. 

  Fujitsu Ltd., which announced 16,400 job cuts last week, also said it has no plans to abandon the sogo denki model. Fujitsu's president, Naoyuki Akikusa, acknowledged that American companies such as Intel Corp. have been successful by focusing on a single product area, but added, "We don't think that is the ideal for our industry." 

  The problem with the sogo denki model is the failure of Japanese electronics companies to produce consistent profits. Most made only modest amounts of money even during the information-technology bubble that gripped the U.S. last year. Recently, ratings agencies have downgraded the credit ratings of many of the major companies. 

  Monday, Standard & Poor's Corp. warned that it might downgrade Sony Corp.'s debt rating. S&P questioned whether Sony can meet its profit targets "given the persistent downturn in demand in the electronics market."

text:
BOJ Watch -2: Markets Listen To Govt, Not Hayami, Now

 
 

  Not only did the BOJ change policy, it broke its own taboo on expanding its JGB purchases - something it has long fretted could open the door to unlimited government spending. 

  Indeed, one BOJ source said policymaking this week was haphazard. 

  The easing was hastily arranged and, if the economy worsens sharply further, the BOJ will just have to improvise again, the source said. 

  In predicting the next step, said Merrill Lynch fixed income strategist Masuhisa Kobayashi, "The market will pay closer attention now to remarks from Finance Minister Masajuro Shiokawa or Economy Minister Heizo Takenaka than from the BOJ governor." 

  Takenaka lauded the BOJ as a "deflation-fighter" after Tuesday's easing and Shiokawa praised the move, but both ministers clearly want more. 

  Particularly, they want the BOJ to set a positive inflation target to obligate the central bank to actively stimulate prices. The central bank promised in March to maintain its loose policy until consumer prices - which have slid unabated for two years - clearly stop falling. 

  But the BOJ hasn't bound itself specifically to making prices turn around, only to waiting until the consumer price index stabilizes at zero or above year-on-year. 

  Hayami again this week insisted he's not considering inflation targets. The bank has long argued that targets have worked in bringing down high inflation but that setting an inflation goal for a deflationary economy would damage the bank's credibility since there are no convincing ways to achieve the target. 

  "The BOJ governor is now against inflation targeting but it won't be surprising if he reverses that view," Kobayashi said. "He used to be against buying JGBs too." 

  How could the BOJ create inflation? 

  "Buy more mid- and long-term JGBs and increase the reserve target by around Y10 trillion," said dovish former BOJ official Mitsuhiro Fukao. He thinks the BOJ should target CPI rises of 2% to 8% over three years. 

  The BOJ now limits the size of JGBs it can hold to the outstanding amount of banknotes issued. 

  "The BOJ should get rid of that limit and flood the banking system," said Fukao, a Keio University professor. 

  If that doesn't work after a year, he says, the BOJ ought to go for broke and buy other assets such as certain stock indexes or real estate investment trusts. 

  "I think the time is near when the BOJ should go ahead with these drastic measures," Fukao said. 

  BOJ officials, in fact, aren't saying never. 

  "If the (BOJ and the market) can agree that the situation is so critical that taking such a reckless step is necessary, then we can go ahead and by stocks or land," one BOJ official said. 

  "We wouldn't take such a step unless the economy paints an ultra-bleak picture" said another. "But nonetheless, it is an option." 

  That might just happen. 

  The economy continues to head south and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's promised structural reforms - curbing government debt and cleaning up the wobbly banks - will only hurt demand and inflame deflation in the short run. 

  "As long as the government is shrinking fiscal spending, there will always be pressure on the BOJ to ease," said economist Masaaki Kanno at JP Morgan Chase Asia. 

  Market watchers generally don't expect the BOJ's next move right away. 

  But, then again, they didn't expect the policy board to budge Tuesday, either. 

 
   -By Yukiko Tsuba, Dow Jones Newswires; 813-5255-2929; yukiko.tsuba@dowjones.com 
   (Michiyo Seki contributed to this report.) 
 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
Mueller Upbeat On German Econ Prospects - Handelsblatt

 
 

  DUESSELDORF (Handelsblatt)--In an interview with Handelsblatt, German Economics Minister Werner Mueller painted a relatively upbeat picture of the prospects for Europe's largest economy. 

  "We are seeing a turnaround in the fortunes of both the Dax-30 leading-share index and the euro, and inflation is likely to fall below 2% by the end of the year," he said, noting that a decline in inflation is needed to spur consumer spending and give leverage to the country's tax reform. Germany's inflation rate in July was 2.6%, down from 3.1% in June. 

  Mueller said the real problem is that signs of an economic upturn are not being properly heeded. "The signals cannot be heard or seen if people have closed their eyes and ears," he said. 

  As examples of positive developments whose significance is being underestimated Mueller pointed to the situation in the construction industry. After two years of dramatic decline, the industry has now clearly seen the worst, he said. 

  And where, as at present, company's stocks are running down to the point where they need to be replenished, this is surely a clear sign that production is set to take off again, Mueller added. On top of that, there are industries, such as car assembly, that continue to boom. 

  "There's sufficient dynamism there for real growth in gross domestic product of up to 3% in the first half of 2002," Mueller said. For this year, he forecast growth of 1.5%. 

  "Essentially, we are seeing a repeat of the situation we had in 1999/2000," Mueller summed up. The full-year GDP growth for 1999 came out at 1.4%, short of expectations, but then the growth started to accelerate. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
AWSJ(9/7) WEEKEND JOURNAL: Mortgage Web Sites Can Take The Pain Out Of HomeLoans

 By Eric Bellman 
  Staff Reporter 

  Last year it took Lili Teo and her husband three weeks going from bank to bank to find the best mortgage rate. "It was a waste of time," recalls the Singapore department-store administrator, who was forced to wait in long lines and often had to return more than once because she didn't have all the right documents. Last May they found a better rate in three minutes by using an Internet site, saving them $6,300 in the first five years. 

  Yes, even after the dot-com crash and in the middle of a global slowdown, there's still a way to make money off the Internet: refinance your home. As interest rates tumble, opportunities for refinancing abound. And banks are working harder than ever to woo the average homeowner to compensate for a dwindling number of corporate clients. In Hong Kong, competition has become so intense that banks have lowered mortgage rates faster than the central bank has dropped its key rate. Average long-term floating mortgage rates there were around 1 percentage point above the prime rate three years ago; now, banks are giving home loans at close to 3% percentage points below prime. 

  "Banks are shaving their (rates) quite quickly to keep their customers from walking down the street," to another bank, says Alistair Scarff, regional banking analyst at Merrill Lynch in Hong Kong. That's where Web sites come in. 

  The last time rates were this low few people were using the Internet. Then, someone searching for the lowest rate for a new home mortgage had to do it the old-fashioned way, by comparing newspaper ads and television commercials in order to calculate the savings. 

  Many Web sites allow you to compare the rates on offer from the banks in your area. Some sites even have tools to help you calculate savings. A few will even let you join forces with other borrowers to get better terms. 

  The Singapore-based dollarDEX.com Pte. Ltd. (www.dollardex.com) for example, posts refinancing rates from more than 20 banks covering Hong Kong, Singapore and Taiwan. In Hong Kong, the range goes from 2.75% to 4.00% for the first year of a refinancing loan. That translates to savings of as much as $12,500 on that year's payments on a $1 million loan. 

  Of course, refinancing is more complicated than the rate for the first year. You have to consider the rate of your current loan as well as any fees or penalties you might incur if you cancel it. You also have to look at how the rates and restrictions on a new loan will change in the future. The better mortgage sites help you break down all these factors to find the best loan package without having to waste a weekend calculating what your monthly payments might be five years from now. 

  With online refinancing calculators you just plug in the rate you are paying now, the amount you want to borrow and the fees you expect to pay and they tell you how much money you would save, if any, by refinancing. Five minutes with the calculator on the Singapore site Propbuzz.com.sg Pte. Ltd. will show how you can save more than $500 a year for the next five years if you refinance a three-year-old loan for $200,000. 

  The better Web sites will also list special promotions from each bank so you can compare them. Lenders are giving out freebies these days like premium credit cards and fire insurance as well as waiving legal fees and other costs of applying for a new home loan. 

  With property prices slipping in Asia, it's important to refinance your loan as soon as possible. Richard Lai, director at dollarDEX.com, says the number of applications coming through his site has surged in the past two months on concerns about falling prices. If the value of a home falls to below the amount of money owed on the mortgage, any refinancing requires the homeowner to put up more money. 

  "Those who are refinancing want to do it quickly, otherwise they won't be able to," Mr. Lai says. 

  Still, you have to be careful about the sites you use. Most property sites are little more than online real-estate ads and many have outdated information and old loan rates. We found a few with information and functions useful to anyone looking into refinancing. 

  --- 

  Send comments to eric.bellman@awsj.com 

  --- 

                      Online Finance 
 
  www.redas.com 
  What clicks: The site's comprehensive calculator lets you put in all the terms of your current loan (other sites only let you put in one interest rate). 
  It's full of news, data and analysis from the Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore, which maintains the site. 
  What doesn't: It only has refinancing rates from four lenders. 
  It's only for the Singapore market. 
 
  www.e-finance.com.hk 
  What clicks: Shows rates from nine banks. Lets you apply to as many as four banks at a time for a loan. Allows you to post the rate you want to borrow at so banks can come to you with offers. 
  What doesn't: You have to open up a separate window for each loan offer, so it is hard to compare them. It doesn't have a refinancing calculator. 
 
  www.propbuzz.com 
  What clicks: The refinancing calculator includes legal and cancellation fees. The site provides tables of all the rates and conditions, making comparisons between loans easy. 
  What doesn't: It is only for Singapore. It has offers from only five banks. 
 
  www.dollardex.com 
  What clicks: It has rates and calculators for Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore. It has rates from more than 20 lenders. The loan rates are more recent than most other sites. It lets borrowers join together with others looking for refinancing loans so they can pool their purchasing power for better rates. 
  What doesn't: Its refinancing calculator is hard to find and doesn't ask for enough details. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
WSJ(9/24) Latin America May Suffer Most From Slowdown

 
  By Wall Street Journal staff reporters David Luhnow in Mexico City, Matt Moffett in Rio de Janeiro and Pamela Druckerman in Buenos Aires 

  Empty beaches in Cuba; thousands of pink slips at Brazilian airlines; idle assembly lines in Mexico's border boomtowns. Welcome to Latin America. 

  Perhaps no other region in the world will suffer more from the economic shock waves of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. A U.S. economic recession would practically halt growth throughout the region, especially in Mexico, which sells nearly 90% of its exports to the U.S. Uncertainty caused by the attacks will also make it harder for Latin companies and governments to borrow the money they need to pay off existing debt and to invest. And with fewer foreign visitors, tourism will be stung everywhere from Baja California to Buenos Aires. 

  Like Wall Street, Latin America's financial markets have taken a beating since the attacks. Brazil's real is at record lows, and Argentina's stock market is at its lowest level in a decade. "We're suffering contagion from the U.S. crisis," says Guillermo Ortiz, the head of Mexico's central bank. Latin America may have exported plenty of financial crises of its own in the past, including Mexico's "tequila crisis" from the 1994-95 peso devaluation. But this time, the financial earthquake is coming from an unexpected quarter: the world's bedrock economy. 

  Following the attacks, the Inter-American Development Bank cut its forecast for regional economic growth this year by half, to a paltry 1%. Most economists expect Latin American economies to rebound only after the U.S. stages its own recovery, expected next year. Even before the attack, a slowing U.S. economy had stopped Mexico in its tracks after 7% growth in gross domestic product last year. Factories assembling TV sets and automotive parts for the U.S. market have laid off 100,000 workers in Ciudad Juarez alone this year, economists say. 

  The attacks came as Argentina's often turbulent debt crisis had reached a period of relative calm. Indeed, the region's governments have already raised the bulk of the estimated $13 billion in debt this year that they needed to refinance. Some Argentine officials even suggest the U.S. woes could make places like faraway Buenos Aires look safer. "As a whole, I would think that local uncertainty is less than global uncertainty," says Mario Blejer, vice president of Argentina's central bank. 

  But borrowing next year could be difficult if the crisis drags on and investors run for cover. Since the attacks, the difference in average interest rates on Argentine and Brazilian government debt compared with those on U.S. debt -- a common measure of country risk -- has widened by about a percentage point. Acknowledging the powerlessness of policy makers in the current global environment, Brazilian Central Bank Governor Arminio Fraga said he has "no rabbit to pull out of the hat." 

  Companies expected to borrow in the coming months must wait, including anticipated deals like Mexican cement giant Cemex's $300 million offering of five-year debt. And companies with short-term debt could face trouble. The first warning shot came when Mexican auto-parts maker Corporacion San Luis SA skipped payment of $9.8 million on $200 million in debt. 

  Reducing perceptions of risk seems a priority. Mexico's top policy makers have agreed to push harder on a series of stalled reforms to the country's tax system and energy sector. Mexico's message to U.S. companies: "Why go to a riskier country in a place like Asia when you can go next door to Mexico?" says Mr. Ortiz. Even if Mexico manages to pass a tax reform to give the government more money, however, an upgrade of Mexico's debt rating by Standard and Poor's may not follow. 

  Tourism will suffer, too. Mexico takes in some $8 billion a year from visitors, and Cuba nearly $2 billion, more than half its foreign-exchange income. Taxis idling in wait for customers outside Havana's hotels are a bad harbinger for the island's communist regime, which has struggled to boost the economy since the collapse of the Soviet Union. Latin American airlines from Mexicana to Varig are shedding workers. 

  Oil is a wild card for regional players like Venezuela, where oil exports represent 40% of its total economy. Weaker demand in the U.S. and Europe could hurt oil receipts unless a Middle Eastern crisis cuts off key Persian Gulf supplies. Indeed, oil prices are already dropping from the panicky spike that followed the attack. Benchmark prices are now below their pre-attack levels. 

  --- 

  Marc Lifsher in Caracas, Venezuela, and Joel Millman in San Diego contributed to this article. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  September 23, 2001 19:42 ET (23:42 GMT)

text:
Rivlin: US Fed Risks Exhausting Ability To Boost Economy

 
 

  By Joseph Rebello 

  Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 

 

  WASHINGTON (Dow Jones)--A former top Federal Reserve official warned Wednesday that the U.S. central bank risks running out of ammunition in its fight to boost economic growth if it cuts interest rates too rapidly. 

  Alice Rivlin, a Fed vice chairman for three years until June 1999, said she would favor a cut in the federal funds rate of just a quarter-percentage point when the Fed's top policymakers next meet Oct. 2. Most economists predict a half-point cut in the central bank's key interest rate, which would leave the rate at 2.5%, the lowest level since the early 1960s. 

  "The Fed has to begin worrying about how fast it wants to move the fed funds rate down, because it wants to preserve the ability to keep doing (interest-rate cuts) longer," Rivlin said. She spoke at a panel discussion on the country's need for additional economic stimulus in the wake of devastating terrorist attacks on New York and the Pentagon on Sept. 11. 

  The Fed has cut the funds rate eight times this year, lowering it by 3.5 percentage points in what has been its fastest campaign of rate cuts in decades. The cuts have had little visible effect on the economy, which stalled in the spring and may have been tipped into a recession by the attacks. 

  The Fed, as a result, has said it is inclined to cut keep cutting rates. In addition, it has pumped unprecedented sums of money into the banking system. 

  Rivlin predicted the Fed will continue to cut interest rates. But she said the central bank now may need to avoid large cuts. "The Fed doesn't want to get into the situation of the Bank of Japan, where interest rates are zero and there's nothing more they can do," Rivlin told reporters after the discussion. She said that if she were a Fed policymaker debating interest-cuts next week, "I think I might do a quarter"-percentage-point cut. 

  Congress and the Bush administration are right to consider additional ways to boost the economy, through a combination of tax cuts and spending increases, Rivlin said. But she said the government should carefully consider the nature of tax cuts or spending increases it makes. 

  "The major rule is not to make this moment an excuse for everybody's tax or spending program," she said. "If we have a good case for additional tax cuts, especially at the lower end, and additional spending, then we ought to do it." 

  She said that Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan's estimate that the country may need an economic-stimulus package  worth about $100 billion - including $40 billion in funds to rebuild Wall Street and the Pentagon - was reasonable. "A hundred billion is a nice, round number," Rivlin said. "It's certainly a good place to start." But she said that it will be hard to know how much money will be enough until more information is available about the damage caused by the attacks. 

  The stimulus, Rivlin said, is unlikely to cause the economy to overheat anytime in the near future. The depth of the U.S. economic slump, the rising unemployment rate and the decline in energy prices, she said, have defused any risk of inflation. "I think we're in a non-inflationary situation for the foreseeable future," Rivlin said. 

  -By Joseph Rebello, Dow Jones Newswires; 202-862-9279; joseph.rebello@dowjones.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  September 26, 2001 12:58 ET (16:58 GMT)

text:
AWSJ(9/24)Japanese Govt Starts Crackdown On Bad-Debt Problem

 
  By Peter Landers 
  Staff Reporter 

  TOKYO -- The terror in the U.S. has delivered a big shock to Japan, the world's weakest economic giant. But events last week suggest that Japanese leaders are beginning to see it also as an excuse to make tough decisions that will help the nation break out of its funk. 

  The government on Friday announced a new crackdown on banks' bad loans, which are at the heart of Japan's decade-long economic woes. The policy calls for tighter inspections of banks and more attention to "market signals" - a veiled reference to plunging stock prices and credit ratings of troubled borrowers such as supermarket chain Daiei Inc. 

  "We will greatly tighten our assessment of assets," said Economy Minister Heizo Takenaka, who is Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's point man for economic reform. Mr. Takenaka quoted Mr. Koizumi as telling a meeting of ministers, "We are in the process of achieving what was thought to be unachievable." 

  Such promises, of course, have been made before. In the past decade Japanese banks have consistently played down their bad loans, putting aside only minimal reserves even for loans to companies that were clearly on their last legs. Past governments, fearing higher unemployment and temporary economic pain, have encouraged or winked at this tactic. But it has left the economy overloaded with crippled companies too weak to do anything except go ever deeper into debt. 

  Mr. Koizumi might have an easier path than his predecessors, because he has made clear many times that his reforms will be painful and he still retains strong public support. The bankruptcy of retailer Mycal Corp. on Sept. 14, the second-largest nonfinancial bankruptcy in Japan's history, received favorable market reaction and little of the teeth-gnashing in the Japanese press that accompanied earlier big failures. 

  "Barring strong public opposition, a bad-loan resolution looks more realistic than at any time in the past decade," Richard Jerram, an economist at ING Baring Securities (Japan) Ltd., wrote in a note to clients. 

  Still, it's too early to say whether Mr. Koizumi can succeed, because many details remain unclear. The most important is how to use public funds to prop up the banking system. If banks conduct stricter assessments of their loans, many would have to record huge losses. Analysts say some banks could become insolvent as a result and most others will be undercapitalized. 

  Daiei, the supermarket operator, and some troubled construction companies are likely to be test cases of how sensitive the government is to "market signals." Daiei's share price fell 12% Friday, closing near a record low after it lowered its sales and profit forecasts. Daiei has more than two trillion yen ($17.23 billion) in interest-bearing debt and virtually no operating profit to repay its loans. Moody's Investors Service downgraded the company's credit rating Friday to Caa1, which means Daiei's bonds are in "poor standing" and in danger of default. 

  By the twisted logic of Japanese politics, Mr. Koizumi will have a better chance the worse the crisis gets. History has shown that Japan responds best when under severe duress - the most recent example coming in October 1998, when parliament passed a bank bailout to stave off a near-meltdown in the financial system. 

  The terror attacks in the U.S. may have also handed the Bank of Japan an excuse to wriggle out of a policy that was drawing intense criticism. The central bank has long resisted radical measures to eliminate deflation but is now beginning to adopt some steps advocated by critics because of the deteriorating global economy. 

  Several times last week the Bank of Japan conducted what is known as "unsterilized intervention" in currency markets as it sold yen for dollars. Normally when the bank sells yen it "sterilizes" the transaction by removing an equal amount of yen from circulation. In effect, unsterilized intervention means dumping a batch of new yen notes into circulation, the sort of monetary easing that proponents hope will create inflationary expectations among Japanese consumers. 

  The central bank's governor, Masaru Hayami, is a staunch foe of easing but his position appears to have weakened, in part due to attacks from a vocal group of ruling party legislators. "The last 10 years of monetary policy by the BOJ have been a total failure," says Yoichi Masuzoe, a former politics professor who was asked by Mr. Koizumi to run for parliament in July elections and won easily. 

  --- 

  Journal Link: What do you think Japan should do to boost its flagging economy? Join a discussion in the online Journal at WSJ.com/JournalLinks. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
WRAP: Goodman Appoints New CEO, FY01 Profit Falls 4.4%

 
   By Ambereen Choudhury 
   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  SYDNEY (Dow Jones)--Goodman Fielder Ltd.'s (A.GMF) appointment of a new chief executive Friday eclipsed news of a 4.4% slump in 2000-01 net profit before one-time items for Australia's largest food ingredients company. 

  The company named former Southcorp Ltd. (A.SBG) Chief Executive Tom Park as its new head, effective mid-October. 

  This came as Goodman said profit before significant nonrecurring items for the year ended June 30 slipped to A$118 million, pressured by increased wheat and petroleum costs. 

  Including one-time items, Goodman recorded a A$78.3 million net loss due to a A$196.3 million restructuring charge as it looked to focus on its retail branded food businesses. 

  However, the profit before one-time items was within market expectations. Sales for the period gained 1.1% to A$3.22 billion. 

  Investment bank ABN AMRO upgraded Goodman Fielder to Add from Reduce following the appointment of Park. The investment bank believes his appointment will "see an acceleration of business improvement. We were impressed with the improvements Tom Park made at Southcorp wines in the year he was there." 

  Existing CEO David Hearn said earlier in 2001 he would depart before his five-year contract ended in 2003. Under Hearn's leadership, Goodman Fielder has whittled its operations to a core portfolio of branded businesses. 

  "I love the food business, I'm thrilled to death to be back in it," Park told reporters. 

  Shares in the company ended up 1.8 cents, or 1.4%, at A$1.32. 

 
              Company Expects Better FY02 
 

  Turning to the latest earnings, Hearn said, "The performance of our milling & baking business in both Australia and New Zealand was adversely affected by rising input costs, including higher wheat and petroleum prices." 

  Still, Chairman Jon Peterson said the company is confident of improving its performance in the next 12 months. 

  "At this early stage of the year, the business is trading satisfactorily, which gives us confidence that we will improve performance in 2002," Peterson said. 

  The company also said it expects to make A$90 million of cost savings in fiscal 2001-02. 

  In June, Goodman Fielder detailed a profit warning and, anticipating the market's negative reaction, said it would look for a new chief executive and accelerate restructuring plans to clean up before 2001-02. 

  The previously detailed sale of the company's Leiner Davis Gelatin business is moving through a regulatory process in the U.S., while the sale of the Germantown specialty ingredients business is expected to take place in the first quarter of fiscal 2002. 

  Goodman's Hearn reiterated that the company is keen to conduct a A$200 million share buyback, but that is mainly contingent on U.S. approval of the gelatin division sale. 

  One Sydney-based analyst said a delay in a much-expected share buyback is a minor disappointment. 

  In addition to the Leiner Davis and Germantown disposals, Goodman Fielder's restructuring plan included the integration in New Zealand of GF Milling and Baking, Bluebird and Meadow Lee into a single national food business. This was followed in Australia by the combining of Uncle Tobys and Meadow Lea into a "billion dollar" grocery business. 

  Goodman will pay an unchanged total dividend of 7.5 cents a share. 

  -By Ambereen Choudhury, Dow Jones Newswires; 

  61-2-8235-2965; ambereen.choudhury@dowjones.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  September 07, 2001 02:35 ET (06:35 GMT)

text:
Schroeder: EU Economic Support Plan May Be Needed In 4Q

 
   (This item was originally published Thursday.) 
 

  BERLIN (Dow Jones)--German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder held out the prospect of a European Union initiative to boost the economy even as he emphasized the need for budget discipline across the 15-member bloc. 

  At a press conference in Quedlinburg with Spanish Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar, Schroeder indicated the effects of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the U.S. could justify E.U. economic-support measures. 

  "The task in the current situation is to observe the markets very closely, to see how the U.S., Japanese and European markets after Sept. 11 develop," Schroeder said. "Then we'll see during the course of the last quarter of the year whether it's necessary to undertake something." 

  Schroeder said any unilateral German economic-support measure would be pointless. "We live in a globalized world, in global markets and so there's no sense in talking about any national programs," he said. 

  The comments follow the announcement this week of a U.S. government economic-stimulus proposal of up to $75 billion, in the form of tax cuts and new spending. 

  But the remarks also come amid relatively tight budget constraints on E.U. governments. E.U. members are committed under their 1997 Stability and Growth Pact to aim for budgets in balance or surplus in the medium term, and to ensure deficits don't exceed 3.0% of gross domestic product in any one year. 

 
   Budget Discipline Seen Key 
 

  Schroeder said Germany and its E.U. partners must heed the Stability and Growth Pact. 

  "The agreed budget consolidation course in Europe must be continued," he said. 

  Those remarks come nearly two months after German Finance Minister Hans Eichel cast doubt on the E.U. budget pact, saying it didn't give states enough leeway to overshoot annual public-sector deficit targets during an economic slowdown. 

  Eichel, the architect of a budget-austerity program to tackle Germany's debt mountain, has since insisted he didn't intend to spark a debate about loosening the budget accord. 

  In any case, Schroeder appeared to rule out any imminent E.U. economic-support measures, in part because they could alarm the European Central Bank, which runs monetary policy in the 12-member euro zone. 

  "In the current situation, I would advise against hasty announcements," he said. "Hasty announcements could have negative consequences for the actors responsible for monetary policy." 

  A German Finance Ministry official said the government remained committed to its austerity plan, which seeks to balance the federal budget by 2006 through steady cuts in new borrowing. 

  The official reiterated a ministry claim that new tax cuts and large spending programs couldn't be justified and downplayed the likelihood of any other economic-stimulus measures. 

  That said, the official didn't rule out the possibility of a modest E.U. economic-support initiative before the end of the year. 

  Many economists expect German real gross domestic product growth to slow to 1.0% or below this year, from 3.0% in 2000. The slowdown would result mainly from global economic weakness, particularly in the U.S., and recent high energy and food prices. 

  The Sept. 11 attacks in the U.S. have diminished the chances of a German economic rebound later this year, and arguably have clouded the outlook for early 2002.

  WELLINGTON (Dow Jones)--New Zealand's third-quarter consumer price index rose an expected 0.6% from the second quarter, bringing annual inflation back under 3%, and giving the country's central bank the latitude to cut interest rates in November. 

  As expected, higher food prices were the biggest contributor to the quarterly CPI increase, making up over half the rise in the index. 

  Higher international agricultural commodity prices have pushed up domestic fruit, meat, vegetable and dairy product prices. 

  The food increase, plus rises in the prices of household construction, appliances and services, alcohol, and local authority rates, were partially offset by a fall in transportation costs due to airfare reductions and lower gasoline prices. 

  Annual inflation fell to 2.4% from 3.2% in the second quarter, which brings the CPI back within the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's official zero-to-3% target range. 

  The market was expecting a quarterly CPI rise of 0.6% and an annual increase of 2.4%, according to a Dow Jones Newswires poll of economists.

text:
Japan Govt Bonds End A Tad Up On Gloomy Econ Outlook

 

  TOKYO (Dow Jones)--Japanese government bonds prices ended slightly higher Monday, thanks to small-lot buys prompted by further evidence of an increasingly gloomy outlook for the economy, traders said. 

  But as the fragility of the economy is already abundantly clear, gains were slim and most players stayed on the sidelines before an auction of five-year bonds Tuesday, traders said. 

  JGBs remained in positive territory throughout the session, following the release of miserable industrial production data before the start of trade, showing a worse-than-expected decline in September of 2.9% from a month earlier. 

  Further gains were limited after the Bank of Japan slashed its forecasts for economic growth and prices late in the session, predicting the battered economy may not crawl out of its present slump until 2003. 

  The BOJ's policy board cut its forecast for gross domestic product for the current year to March to a contraction of between 0.9% and 1.2%, down sharply from their April forecast of growth ranging from 0.3% to 0.8%. 

  Players said the downgrades weren't serious enough to encourage them to chase the market sharply higher ahead of a five-year JGB auction Tuesday, adding they were reluctant to risk seeing a 0.4% coupon, compared with the previous 0.5%, by pushing the five-year yield lower, traders said. 

  The lead December 10-year JGB futures contract ended only 0.03 higher at 140.60, after moving in a very narrow 14-sen range. The yield on the newest 10-year JGBs ended 0.5 basis point lower at 1.33%. Bond yields move inversely to prices.

text:
Canada Sept CPI Seen Mild, Clears Way For Rate Cut

 
 
    By Paul Evans 
    Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  TORONTO (Dow Jones)--Canadian headline and core inflation rates are both expected to have continued moderating in September, removing the last obstacle to an anticipated half-percentage-point cut in interest rates at next Tuesday's Bank of Canada rate announcement. 

  When Statistics Canada releases the September consumer price index data early Thursday, monthly all-items inflation  is expected to have risen slightly to 0.1% over August's flat reading, according to consensus forecasts compiled by Standard and Poors MMS in Toronto. 

  But the year-on-year gain for headline inflation is expected to ease to 2.5% from 2.8% the previous month, while the yearly CPIX measure - the Bank of Canada's preferred measure of core inflation - is forecast to have fallen slightly to 2.2% from 2.3% in August. 

  In the current climate of global uncertainties and concern about the likelihood and timing of a North American economic recovery, inflationary worries have all but vanished from the radar screens of Canadian markets and economists, leading most to believe the September data will be a non-event. 

  Since rising energy prices caused headline inflation rates to spike to a nine-year high 3.9% in May, headline and core rates have drifted gently downward on a path that the central bank and private analysts alike believe will lead the all-inclusive and core rates to converge by the end of 2001 around the 2% midpoint of the Bank of Canada 1%-3% inflation target band. 

  Analysts said that despite another upward jump in gasoline prices in September, the broadly-based subsidence of price pressures in the energy component of the CPI should still exert a noticeable downward influence on total CPI in September. 

  'We're still seeing headline inflation coming down very rapidly because of the unwinding in energy prices,' said senior economist Adrienne Warren of the Bank of Nova Scotia in Toronto. 'And core inflation really isn't doing anything right now - it's moving sideways, but I expect it will begin to drop lower in the next few months and into next year as the economy continues to slow down.' 

  Other analysts predict that another contributor to lower inflation rates in coming CPI data will likely be aggressive Christmas season discounting by retailers eager to boost fragile consumer confidence in the wake of the September 11 terrorist attacks and the unfolding U.S. anthrax scare. 

 
   BOC, Economists' CPI Forecasts Point To Lower Rates 
 

  All told, neither September's CPI data nor CPI reports in coming months are likely to deter the Bank of Canada from easing interest rates further to cope with the fallout from September 11 on an already faltering economy. 

  When it eased interest rates at the end of August, the central bank said it expected 'reduced pressures on production capacity and inflation through the rest of this year and into 2002,' and Bank officials have stuck to this view in subsequent statements. 

  On Tuesday, Bank of Canada senior deputy governor Malcolm Knight said in Toronto that the more pronounced economic weakening that has taken place since September 11 will keep inflation on a downward trajectory. 

  'World petroleum prices have recently been volatile, but assuming that on average they remain around current levels, overall CPI inflation should continue its recent downward trend,' he said. 

  Most economists have no trouble in subscribing to this view, along with its implication that inflation will be no impediment to continued Bank of Canada rate easing on Tuesday, and likely at the central bank's last rate announcement of the year on November 27. 

  Senior economist Marc Levesque of Toronto-Dominion Bank said that the September CPI data should be 'little more than a blip on the radar screen, given current economic conditions.' 

  'In any event, core inflation will remain close to the mid-point of the Bank of Canada's 1%-3% target band - leaving the Bank with all the necessary leeway to continue to cut interest rates,' Levesque noted in a recent commentary. 

  - By Paul Evans, Dow Jones Newswires; (416) 306-2022

text:
AWSJ(10/22) Convention Business Is Battered In Asia

 
  By Cris Prystay 
  Staff Reporter 

  First, it was the British car dealers, then the European pharmacists. The bankers from Hong Kong were next. 

  About 80% of conferences booked at Hyatt International Corp.'s Bali Hyatt in November have been canceled in recent weeks, and general manager Brad Kirk is bracing for more. He is on tenterhooks waiting to hear back from 450 computer techies scheduled for a date early next year. 

  "Absolutely nobody is confirming for the first quarter," he says. "It's a pretty serious situation." 

  Asia's multibillion dollar conference and exhibition business, already wobbly from the slowing global economy, is getting battered by America's war on terror. In Singapore, 24,000 hotel-room nights were left empty after the Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication, or Swift, called off a five-day industry exhibition just one week before the start date. Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc.'s Sheraton Nusa Indah Resort in Bali lost half a million dollars in revenue when the World Bridge Championship pulled the plug, leaving a gaping hole of 2,700 room nights. The industry itself isn't immune: This week, the Association of Corporate Travel Executives called off its industry seminar in Kuala Lumpur on recession-proof travel management. 

  Corporate events are big business for hotels and other organizers in Asia. 

  Only four cities in the world played host to more international meetings in 2000 than Singapore, according to the Union of International Associations. Meetings, conventions and exhibitions contributed 1.13 billion Singapore dollars (US$624.3 million) to that economy last year. 

  In Bali, conferences account for 25% of Mr. Kirk's business, and 40% at the nearby Sheraton Nusa Indah Resort, which manages the Bali International Convention Centre. 

  The scratching of the Swift convention, which was slated to draw more than 6,000 bankers and finance professionals, has made the biggest splash so far. "In 38 years of being in the business, I've never seen this large an event canceled just (a few) days out," says Robert Guy, managing director of Pacific World Destination Management Pte. Ltd., which coordinated the event in Singapore. 

  The board of Belgium-based Swift met after the Sept. 11 attacks, but opted to go ahead. Once bombs started falling on Afghanistan, the board changed its mind. "It was the announcement that more (terrorism) was to come, anywhere, at any time, that did it. If something did happen, an important part of the world's payments community would be far away from where they needed to be," said Leonard Schrank, Swift's chief executive officer. Many financial institutions have slapped a ban on corporate travel, which would prevent delegates from reaching Singapore anyway. 

  A group of 15 hotels are now negotiating with Swift for compensation. "We're trying to come up with an amicable solution, and we recognize our obligations," said Patrik Neutjens, director of the Swift International Banking Operational Seminar. Mr. Schrank estimates Swift's total loss, including the hotel settlement, refunded fees and lost preproduction costs, will come to about $10 million. 

  After Swift withdrew, Nat Wong scrambled to keep his own client from opting out. Mr. Wong, the CEO of Meeting Planners International Pte. Ltd., hired an emergency team of telemarketers to tell the 18,000 people who had registered for the International Textile Machinery Exhibition that despite the start of bombing raids in Afghanistan, it was safe to come ahead. 

  But that crisis was quickly overtaken by another: On Oct. 11, the Singapore government imposed new visa restrictions on travelers from five countries, including Pakistan, Iran and Egypt -- home to some 2,500 of the exhibition's delegates. After a meeting with government officials, Mr. Wong obtained approval the following Saturday morning for a visa waiver for his delegates -- just two days before the five-day event was to begin.  "I was sitting in bed, on my handphone at 3 a.m. both Saturday and Sunday night," he says. "It was absolutely crazy." In the end, about 14,000 people, from 67 countries, turned up for the convention last week. 

  Conventions and exhibitions aren't the only casualty in the function business. In Malaysia, the inaugural Le Mans auto racing Series Race of Champions was postponed for "international security concerns." U.S. promoter Don King canceled a world heavyweight boxing title match scheduled for Beijing next month after broadcaster HBO, citing U.S. State Department advisories, expressed concerns about sending employees to China. 

  Even government conferences aren't unaffected. The Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting scheduled for Brisbane, Australia, from Oct. 6 to Oct. 9, was postponed after a large number of government leaders indicated they might not be able to come. Only 29 of 56 tourism ministers from Organization of Islamic Conference, or OIC, states turned up at a ministerial meeting in Kuala Lumpur on Oct. 12. 

  Event organizers are scrambling to cut deals with airlines and hotels to keep some of this business from drying up. The Sheraton Nusa Indah Resort is now offering 40% off for any group of 10 or more. Singapore-based Pacific World, which served as organizer for the now-scotched Swift exhibition, managed to win a 200-person convention that had canceled in Dubai after it wrung an extra 20% discount on pre-Sept. 11 prices from airlines and Singapore hotels. Singapore Exhibition Services Pte. Ltd., meanwhile, is pledging extra services, such as company visits and tailored seminars. 

  Another survival tactic is to target Asia-based customers, who have proved far more resilient than those outside the region. "We're going to look at markets closer to home," said Mr. Guy, at Pacific World, which traditionally specialized on the long-haul corporate travel and convention market. 

  Singapore Exhibition Services, for instance, managed to draw a record 8,500 people to a three-day annual franchise exhibition that kicked off Sept. 19, just days after terrorists struck New York and Washington. Only 14% of that crowd came from outside Singapore. 

  In Bali, the handful of conventions that have kept their bookings have all come from within Asia, says Raymond Tait, director of sales and marketing for the Bali International Convention Centre. "The long-haul market won't be as prevalent next year because people just don't want to go the distance," he says. 

  --- 

  Zach Coleman contributed to this article. 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  October 21, 2001 17:01 ET (21:01 GMT)

text:
DJ Oil Stocks -2: Shares Rebound After Morning Losses >BHI

 
 
   By Lingling Wei 
   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 
 
  NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Shares of oil drillers and service companies rebounded 
from morning losses Friday after the price outlook for crude oil was further 
muddled by Russia's refusal to acquiesce to the bigger output cut called for by 
the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. 
 
  Russia, the second-largest oil exporter after OPEC, agreed to reduce its 
exports by 50,000 barrels a day for the rest of the year, a move which fell 
below OPEC's expectations. 
 
  The cartel ministers, who met in Vienna last week in hope of shoring up oil 
prices, have decided to put off planned production cuts until Russia, Norway 
and other non-OPEC countries join in. 
 
  Without a joint agreement, some analysts speculated that crude prices, having 
dropped 30% since mid-September, could fall to $15 per barrel over the next few 
months, while others projected a price level around $20 a barrel. 
 
  George Gaspar, an analyst with Robert W. Baird & Co., said a larger 
production-cut agreement between Russia and OPEC remains possible in the next 
two to three weeks. 
 
  But even if that happens, Gaspar said, "what the market is failing to 
recognize is that there is a considerable buildup (of oil production) among 
non-OPEC members," including Norway, Angola and Brazil. The capacity buildup 
could still result in a crude glut given the sagging oil demand amid the 
economic slowdown worldwide. 
 
  Gaspar estimated that non-OPEC members will produce nearly 2% more oil a day 
next year, further diminishing the cartel's grip on world oil prices. 
 
  Falling crude prices tend to discourage exploration and production companies 
from committing to long-term projects. "Spending is going to be skinny in the 
first half of next year," Gaspar said, as compared with the projected 18% 
growth in overall capital expenditures by oil explorers and producers this 
year. 
 
  Kevin Simpson, an oil service analyst with Merrill Lynch & Co., wrote in a 
morning note that "we assume that upstream capital expenditure will fall 7.5% 
in 2002, with the U.S. down 20% and overseas relatively flat." 
 
  Simpson reduced his 2002 earnings estimates for 10 oil service companies, 
including Baker Hughes Inc. (BHI), Halliburton Co. (HAL), Schlumberger Ltd. 
(SLB), BJ Services Co. (BJS), Cooper Cameron Corp. (CAM) and Transocean Sedco 
Forex Inc. (RIG). 
 
  But Simpson said the lowered earnings forecasts are already priced into the 
companies' stocks. "Investors are beginning to look past the near-term earnings 
trough to potential second-half cyclical recovery in assessing the oil service 
group." 
 
  In recent market activity, many oil stocks rebounded from initial losses, 
with Transocean - earlier the biggest percentage loser in the sector - trading 
up 1.2%, or 33 cents, to $28.84, and Schlumberger up 0.6%, or 27 cents, to 
$47.48. 
 
  Industry leader Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM) tacked on 1.5%, or 56 cents, to 
$38.44. 
 
  -Lingling Wei, Dow Jones Newswires; 201-938-2089; Lingling.Wei@dowjones.com

text:
DJ Georgia Has Cheapest US Gasoline Heading Into Holiday

 
 
 
  TUCKER, Ga. (AP)--Fred Lutz found a deal at his local gas pump Tuesday -a 
full tank of gas for his Cadillac at 88 cents per gallon. 
 
  "I haven't seen that in a long time," the retired airline employee said. 
"It's astounding." 
 
  Just in time for the Thanksgiving travel rush, Georgia is home to the 
nation's cheapest gas, with pumps statewide selling for less than a dollar a 
gallon and some suburban Atlanta stations offering prices as low as 79 cents. 
 
  That's made driving more attractive than flying for those making their 
holiday travel plans. 
 
  AAA Auto Club estimates 87% of those who travel this holiday will drive, the 
highest percentage ever. In the South, that means 8.7 million travelers are 
expected to drive 50 miles or more this week, slightly more than last November. 
 
  The average retail price of gasoline, including all grades and taxes, was 
about $1.23 per gallon Friday, according to the two-week Lundberg Survey of 
nearly 8,000 stations nationwide. Gas prices have plunged 32 cents since Sept. 
7. 
 
  A steep drop in Americans' travel and a supply glut have depressed oil 
prices, with producers reluctant to cut back, at least temporarily, experts 
said. 
 
  Georgia's break on gas prices stems from a variety of factors. It's excise 
tax on gas -7.5 cents per gallon -is the nation's lowest. Montana, at 27 cents 
per gallon, is highest. 
 
  Georgians also benefit from their proximity to a major pipeline that carries 
petroleum through Atlanta, said Dale Shuirman, motor fuel tax administrator at 
Georgia's Department of Revenue. 
 
  "The longer you have to haul the product, the more transport costs you get in 
there," said Shuirman, who plans to "buy as much fuel in Georgia as I can" for 
his 750-mile round trip this week to Raleigh, N.C., to visit his son. 
 
  For many of those who couldn't drive, flying was a slightly fearsome 
proposition, according to a handful of travelers interviewed at Hartsfield 
Atlanta International Airport, the nation's busiest air hub. 
 
 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
DJ Fed's Poole Says Cannot Tell When Recession Will Trough

 
  (This article was originally published Tuesday) 
 
  ST. LOUIS, Missouri (Dow Jones)--Although noting that the U.S. economy is 
currently in recession, William Poole, President of the Federal Reserve Bank of 
St. Louis, said he was "optimistic" about the "great strengths" of its 
monetary, fiscal and banking situation. 
 
  He was talking to a business audience in St Louis, Tuesday in prepared 
remarks, entitled "Financial System Robustness." 
 
  Recalling that the National Bureau of Economic Research had announced Monday 
that a recession is under way and that economic activity peaked last March, 
Poole said, "There is no way to tell now when the recession trough will occur." 
 
  He said, "We face many uncertainties, including the possibility of further 
terrorist attacks", which, if they were to occur, would "obviously be negative 
for the economic outlook." 
 
  On the other hand, the U.S.-led military campaign in Afghanistan "seems to be 
going well," he said, while investigations into the anthrax attacks in the U.S. 
may also  yield results, in which case, "success on those fronts would help to 
clear the air and would be positive for the economy." 
 
  He cited strengths in the economy, including that banks are well capitalized, 
that "inflation is low and expected to remain low," and that the federal 
government's budgetary  resources are adequate to meet new security needs 
following  the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. He also noted that the Federal 
Reserve was already in rate-cutting mode before that  date. 
 
  "There is no way to provide a reliable forecast of how quickly these 
fundamental strengths will show themselves in a clear revival of economic 
growth," Poole said. "But they  will, within a matter of a few months or few 
calendar quarters," he said. "Of that, I'm confident." 
 
  Speaking earlier Tuesday, Federal Reserve Governor Laurence Meyer had said 
that "once the economy shows signs of moving to a rate of growth above trend, 
the Fed will have  to reassess the appropriate degree of stimulus and, at some 
point, begin the return to a more neutral policy." 
 
  In Poole's case, much of his prepared remarks Tuesday focused on steps the 
Fed took in the period immediately following the September terrorist atrocities 
as temporary measures to provide ample liquidity to the banking system. Banks' 
capital ratios "remain substantially higher than during the last period of 
major problems in the banking industry, in the late 1980s and early 1990s," he 
said. 
 
  He also said that, despite the huge insured losses expected from the 
destruction caused by September's attacks,  to his "knowledge no insurance 
companies face the risk of insolvency from these losses." 
 
  Poole is a voting member of the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee. 
 
 
   -By John Parry; Dow Jones Newswires; john.parry@dowjones.com; 201-938-2096
