text:
DJ Intl Finance Unites Vs Terrorism Amid Bleak Econ Outlook

 
 
   By Don Curren and Mike Esterl 
   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 
 
  OTTAWA (Dow Jones)--A united attack on terrorist funding networks was the 
focal point of global financial talks here this weekend, suggesting that a 
tentative but potentially powerful consensus has emerged in the wake of Sept. 
11 attacks on the U.S. that have pushed the world economy to the brink of 
recession. 
 
  Finance ministers and central bankers gathered in Canada's capital agreed to 
pursue a coordinated attack on terrorist financing, and asked countries to put 
detection policies in place by Feb. 1. 
 
  "These meetings made it clear that the international community will not be 
cowed by the events of the 11th of September," Canadian Finance Paul Martin, 
chairman of the Group of 20, said Sunday after three days of meetings involving 
the International Monetary Fund, World Bank and G20 countries. 
 
  Nonetheless, the IMF presented a sobering report on growth prospects in the 
wake of the attacks, slashing its global economic forecast for 2002 to 2.4% 
from 3.5% a month earlier. 
 
  Finance ministers, some of whom dubbed the IMF forecasts overly pessimistic, 
warned that developing countries are particularly susceptible to the slowdown 
as commodity prices fall, export markets shrink and investors become more 
risk-averse. 
 
  The G20 issued a resolution to pursue the possibility of debt standstill 
mechanisms for sovereign countries to avoid the ad hoc, often messy 
negotiations that have accompanied defaults and restructurings in the past. 
 
  Martin was among those recommending the creation of an international 
bankruptcy protection model similar to the Chapter 11 mechanism U.S. companies 
enjoy. The plan has opponents, though, including Brazilian Finance Minister 
Pedro Malan, and IMF Managing Director Horst Koehler recommended a cautious 
approach. 
 
  The IMF did say it stands ready to provide additional financial assistance to 
developing countries during the current economic downturn. 
 
  But there was no indication that Argentina, teetering on the edge of default, 
would be getting any more bailouts from the official sector anytime soon. 
Instead, the recession-wracked country was encouraged to continue seeking a 
debt restructuring accord with private sector creditors, who hold $95 billion 
in bonds. 
 
  The three-day gathering drew a small but sometimes raucous group of 
antiglobalization protesters. The protests were not nearly as violent or 
disruptive as those at other global meetings, however, and had no impact on the 
proceedings. 
 
  G20 and IMF leaders emphasized the pledge to crack down on terrorist 
financing as a key development from the session, one that mobilized the 
resources of all of the world's largest economies and some pivotal developing 
countries. 
 
  "It would have been understandable, at a time like this, (for countries) to 
have turned inwards and focus on their domestic concerns. But I believe today's 
meeting has been a reaffirmation of the importance of global cooperation," said 
Gordon Brown, chancellor of the exchequer for Britain and chairman of the IMF's 
 International Monetary and Financial Committee. 
 
  The plans ask member nations to ratify the U.N. resolutions dealing with 
terrorist financing and adopt such measures as creating "financial intelligence 
units" to monitor suspicious transactions and share information with other 
nations. 
 
  Although the G20 and IMFC plans both require member countries to provide 
technical and even financial assistance to other countries that need it, none 
of the officials were willing to attach a cost to the initiatives. 
 
  The IMF/World Bank meetings were originally scheduled for Washington in 
September. The G20 session was moved from India because of security concerns in 
the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks.

  From The Wall Street Journal 
 
  HOLIDAY SALES ROSE to better-than-expected levels at Wal-Mart, the country's 
biggest retailer, and at its rival Target, helped by a surge in last-minute 
shopping over the weekend. But for conventional department stores and specialty 
shops, especially apparel sellers, the sales spike came amid big markdowns that 
may spell trouble for fourth-quarter profits. An 11th-hour shopping spree also 
boosted European retail sales, early indications showed. 
 
  --- 
 
  UBS PaineWebber has begun imposing penalties on brokers whose clients buy IPO 
shares at the offering price, then sell them before the stock has moved up or 
down 10% during the first 40 days. 
 
  --- 
 
  Argentina's government signaled its intention to ease limits on bank 
withdrawals as part of several measures to revive the economy. The limits were 
one of the factors that sparked last week's riots. 
 
  --- 
 
  U.S. textile firms say they are in their worst crisis since the Depression. 
They face more competition in three years when they lose quota protections from 
China. 
 
  --- 
 
  Stocks rose on weak volume, boosted by expectations for a January rally as 
well as upbeat holiday-shopping news. The industrials ended up 52.80 at 
10088.14. 
 
  --- 
 
  South Carolina moved to suspend Liberty Life's license and to impose 
penalties for allegedly charging higher insurance premiums for blacks than for 
whites. 
 
  --- 
 
  Yahoo said holiday sales volume on its shopping site jumped more than 86% 
from the year-earlier period, boosting its shares and those of other online 
retailers. 
 
  --- 
 
  Apple Computer said it plans about $200 million in capital expenditures for 
fiscal 2002 in an effort to increase its retail presence and boost market 
share. 
 
  --- 
 
  Crude-oil prices rose to more than $21 a barrel as OPEC officials repeated 
that the group will announce an output cut when it meets tomorrow in Cairo. 
 
  --- 
 
  Nasdaq short interest increased this month due in part to tax-related 
selling. In general, the higher the short interest, the more people expect a 
stock downturn. 
 
  --- 
 
  Nasdaq said it is returning temporarily to its headquarters across from the 
World Trade Center site but still plans to eventually move to midtown 
Manhattan. 
 
  --- 
 
  Goldman Sachs is set to become the top-ranked investment bank for merger 
business in 2001 with a market share of 34.2%, well above No. 2 Merrill Lynch. 
 
  --- 
 
  Nestle agreed to pay General Mills $641 million for the 50% stake it doesn't 
already own in Ice Cream Partners USA, a venture that includes the Haagen-Dazs 
brand. 
 
  --- 
 
  Adam Barsky quit as head of New York City's public pension-fund system to 
take a job at Millbrook, a hedge fund.

text:
DJ Taiwan CPC, Formosa Petchem Mkt Shr To Fall On Oil Dereg

 
 
 
  By Xu Yihe and J.R. Wu 
 
  Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 
 
  SINGAPORE (Dow Jones)--Taiwan's oil market deregulation, which went into 
effect Wednesday, will hit the island's only two oil refiners, eroding their 
market shares next year, analysts say, but new players to the oil import 
business will benefit from being able to import cheaper feedstocks. 
 
  Sales of oil products by Chinese Petroleum Corp. (Q.CPC) and Formosa 
Petrochemical Corp., which currently monopolize Taiwan's oil market, will fall 
20% next year as abundant supply amid dented demand and prices further prompt 
price wars in the business, analysts say. 
 
  But deregulation should give a boost to the bottom lines of companies ready 
to venture into the oil import business, such as normal paraffin maker Ho Tung 
Chemical Corp. (Q.HOC) and oil container and warehouse operator Pan Overseas 
Corp. (Q.PO). 
 
  Ho Tung's earnings per share could rise to NT$2 next year from around NT$1.40 
this year as it imports cheaper kerosene, an upstream raw material for use in 
producing normal paraffin, a detergent chemical. That means in the first half 
of 2002, Ho Tung's share price could climb to NT$25, from Wednesday's close of 
NT$19.50, said Julian Chen, an analyst at National Securities in Taipei. 
 
  In anticipation of more oil imports into Taiwan, Pan Overseas could enjoy 
increased business as foreign oil importers need somewhere to store their 
products, analysts note. The company's stock, which ended Wednesday's session 
at NT$9.10, has an upside of nearly NT$11, Chen said. 
 
  According to the Petroleum Management Law passed by the Legislative Yuan in 
September, the government will allow non-oil companies with storage facilities 
able to store oil for consumption for 60 days, or registered oil sales of 
50,000 kiloliters in the last 12 months, to engage in the oil import business 
beginning Jan. 1 next year. 
 
  The deregulation of oil product imports is partly aimed at increasing 
competition in the mostly state-dominated domestic oil market. Taiwan began 
allowing non-state oil companies to import fuels other than gasoline and diesel 
in January 1999. 
 
  An official from the Ministry of Economic Affairs said the government doesn't 
expect the new law to spur a building spree of oil storage facilities in the 
short term, because investment in such an area is subject to approval from 
local governments regarding land use and environmental protection concerns. 
 
  "Building such facilities involves complicated approval procedures," he said. 
 
 
       CPC Won't Reduce Refinery Runs 
 
 
  Still, the likelihood of reduced sales of oil products on the heels of 
deregulation doesn't mean Taiwan's largest oil refiner CPC will reduce 
operations or cut its oil throughput next year. 
 
  "We will maintain our operation at 80-90% next year and there are no plans to 
reduce production," a CPC spokesman said, adding that the company is 
considering exporting oil to China. 
 
  With Taiwan's economy expected to show a mild recovery in 2002 from an 
expected first-ever annual contraction this year, analysts say demand for oil 
products will likely underpace supply. 
 
  Indeed, the domestic supply of diesel already outstrips demand by around 
20-30%, said Chen at National Securities. 
 
  He pointed out that the 2,000 or so gas station outlets dotting Taiwan now 
should shrink by one-fourth in two years as price wars force closures. 
 
  In the next six to 12 months, foreign oil imports are expected to seize about 
10%-15% of the domestic oil market share, said Michael Wang, an analyst at 
Polaris Investment Advisory Co. in Taipei. 
 
  The CPC spokesman said the oil refiner is seeking to export part of the 
surplus across the Taiwan Strait to the mainland, starting next year, as one 
way to ease pressure on sales as a result of competition from independent 
players. But such cross-strait trade is subject to government approval, he 
added. 
 
  CPC currently has about 70% of the domestic market share while Formosa 
Petrochemical, Taiwan's only private oil refiner, has the other 30%. Formosa 
Petrochemical will see its market share cut by about 5% after deregulation, 
Wang said. 
 
  Taiwan consumes about 10 million kiloliters of gasoline and 6 million 
kiloliters of diesel a year. The consumption rate has been growing at an annual 
average 3%, according to an official with Taiwan's Energy Commission. 
 
          New Market Players 
 
 
  Among the expected gainers post-deregulation are Ho Tung Chemical and Pan 
Overseas, which both meet the government standard for importing oil. 
 
  The two companies are expected to take a combined 20% of market share next 
year following deregulation, the official with Taiwan's Energy Commission said. 
 
  Ho Tung also owns oil storage tanks with capacity of 220,000 kiloliters in 
Taichung, central Taiwan. 
 
  Pan Overseas, which owns 30% in Taiwan Esso Petroleum Global Co., has 
invested NT$1.4 billion to build seven oil tanks in Taichung with total 
capacity of 215,000 kiloliters. The company has completed construction on five 
of the seven oil tanks. 
 
  Gas station chain operator National Petroleum Co. (Q.NPU), meanwhile, may 
have also a chance to import cheaper oil products, though it already is in a 
strategic alliance with Formosa Petrochemical, said National Securities' Chen. 
 
  However, the Energy Commission official said the Taiwan government hasn't 
received any applications from the two companies for oil import licenses. 
 
  -By Xu Yihe, Dow Jones Newswires; 65-415-4068; yi-he.xu@dowjones.com 
 
 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
BARRON'S: Current Yield

 
  Fed Ready To Ease Again, Even Absent Enron Fallout 
  By Jennifer Ablan 
 
  The swan dive by Enron, the fallen-angel energy trader, will likely continue 
to reverberate through the credit markets this week and next, increasing the 
likelihood that the Federal Open Market Committee will cut short-term rates for 
the 11th time when it meets December 11. 
 
  The December federal-funds contract implied a 93% chance that the FOMC would 
trim its federal-funds target, currently at a 40-year low of 2%, by 25 basis 
points (one-quarter of a percentage point) and a 46% likelihood of a 
50-basis-point reduction -- twice the odds the futures market was giving a week 
earlier. 
 
  Comments that two voting FOMC members made prior to the Enron collapse made 
clear that another easing is on the table. On Tuesday, Fed board member 
Laurence Meyer said the central bank shouldn't be deterred from further rate 
cuts simply because rates have already been pushed to such low levels. The same 
day William Poole, president of the St. Louis Fed, added that "the only 
stopping place is zero, and if going to zero is constructive, then we ought to 
do it." The remarks came on the heels of Monday's confirmation by the National 
Bureau of Economic Research that the U.S. economy entered a recession in March. 
 
  While the financial markets discounted the official recession designation as 
old news, the statements by Meyer and Poole helped spur a sharp rally in 
Treasuries at midweek. Adding to the surge was news Thursday of a 
sharper-than-expected jump in the latest week's unemployment claims. The yield 
on the benchmark 10-year note plunged to 4.764% from Wednesday's close of 
4.948% -- the biggest daily decline since January, according to Salomon Smith 
Barney. "I've never seen intraday volatility like this," notes Michael 
Schumacher, head of interest-rate product strategy at that firm.The 10-year 
note closed the week at a yield of 4.73% Friday, down from 5% a week earlier. 
 
  The November employment data, slated to be released Friday, should confirm 
that the labor market continues to deteriorate, he says. The consensus forecast 
calls for a 200,000 decline in nonfarm payrolls and a rise in the jobless rate 
to 5.6% from 5.4% in October. 
 
  Schumacher also notes that the two-year Treasury, the maturity most sensitive 
to Fed moves, has seen its yield soar to 2.83% from its bottom of 2.30%, "and 
yet the economy hasn't shown any signs of bouncing back yet." The equity 
market, for its part, points to a recovery with an 18% jump in the S&P 500 from 
its September 21 low. 
 
  "I think this would be more important" [than the collapse of Long-Term 
Capital Management three years ago], Larry Jeddeloh, chief investment officer 
of the TIS Group, which produces the Market Intelligence Report, says of the 
Enron fiasco. 
 
  "That is likely why a bankruptcy filing is being delayed, and why there will 
be a ripple effect," he writes. "The world over, a credit implosion is 
unfolding, in slow motion. Sabena Group, Swiss Air, two Japanese companies on 
Wednesday, Bethlehem Steel, Polaroid and now Enron have all folded or are 
folding in just the last 90 days. This matters." 
 
  Tom Gallagher, political economist at the ISI Group, adds: "There's certainly 
no systemic risk that would call for Fed intervention. But having said that, 
the discount window must be available for banks that have loans to Enron." 
Moreover, the Fed is furiously pumping liquidity into the financial system. The 
ISI Group points out that the surge in money supply is looking a lot like a 
"Y2K liquidity repeat." 
 
  Credit conditions haven't entirely deteriorated. Ratings of six U.S. banks -- 
including Citigroup, FleetBoston and Union Planters -- have been upgraded since 
the start of the fourth quarter, according to Moody's Investors Service. "Core 
earnings have thus far remained strong enough to offset an increase in problem 
loans," it says. 
 
  But total U.S. rating downgrades thus far in the quarter have topped upgrades 
by 85 to 40. Among financial institutions, however, 14 upgrades have 
comfortably exceeded three downgrades, only one of which was linked to 
asset-quality deterioration. 
 
  Nonetheless, the Enron issue has made the markets nervous because of the lack 
of transparency about credits. 
 
  "There could be something out there that certain people know because they 
were over the wall . . . bankers or companies," says Glenn Reynolds, chief 
executive officer at CreditSights. 
 
  "We don't know the scope of the counterparty-risk issues and what exactly are 
the legal structures on those counterparty exposures, things like swaps and 
forex and plain vanilla," he continues. "But what else is going on with the 
creative structured deals that they have not fully disclosed, such as the 
derivative issues?" 
 
  With $13 billion in debt and, according to The Wall Street Journal, up to $17 
billion in derivatives contracts, says Reynolds, "we clearly haven't seen the 
last of the Enron hits taken by the banking sector and by energy traders." 
 
  Already, the hits have been crushing. Enron's 6 3/4% unsecured debt due 2004 
was quoted at 20 bid, 24 asked Thursday, down from bid 47 on Monday. The debt 
was quoted 83-85 on November 9, when Dynegy announced its merger agreement with 
Enron, then rated high-quality investment grade before falling to high-yield 
"junk" status on Wednesday. 
 
  Enron's bank debt has been spiraling in similar fashion. Its unsecured bank 
debt, ranked on par with the bonds, is quoted at 19-19 1/2, while the secured 
bank debt is not trading actively. "It's almost impossible to find a fall like 
this for a leading industry benchmark like Enron," Reynolds says. 
 
  So-called vulture investors, which specialize in buying distressed debt, have 
been flocking to the debt of Enron. If a company undergoes restructuring or 
bankruptcy, holders of the bank debt or the claims stemming from the bank loans 
that finance the company get paid first on whatever money the company has. If 
there's any money left after that, holders of the company's bonds are next in 
line. Equity holders stand at the end of the queue. 
 
  Vulture investors buy big stakes in the debt of bankrupt or ailing companies, 
which gives them leverage during a reorganization. Their debt securities may be 
converted to equity, which can yield juicy profits when a restructured company 
emerges from bankruptcy. 
 
  In the past year, many companies have seen prices on their bonds plunge long 
before bankruptcy or default seemed imminent. That's created a ballooning 
supply of distressed debt, generally defined as bonds with yields 1,000 basis 
points or more above comparable Treasuries. 
 
  CreditSights estimates the distressed-debt universe at about $250 billion, 
which includes bonds in default plus bonds trading with a yield-to-maturity of 
greater than 20%. "You are going to see a lot of investors involved in Enron 
and they will retain counsel looking at legal structure; looking at 
residual-value estimates; evaluate time to clear bankruptcy, what the legal 
rights to different classes of creditors are," says Reynolds. "This is the 
mother of all vulture research projects." 
 
  The risk-reward symmetry -- what the assets of Enron are worth versus how 
much capital vultures will pay -- is compelling enough to attract vultures, and 
"this is what they live for," he adds. 
 
  Third Avenue Funds' Marty Whitman, one the biggest vulture investors in the 
market, says at some point he will buy the debt of Enron. "I don't have to 
understand too much if I am a secured lender, but there doesn't seem to be much 
anywhere around here," he says. "I don't think we will have that much of a 
problem appraising the assets, but getting our arms around what the liabilities 
are, all of this off-balance-sheet stuff, will be difficult." 
 
  The financial markets certainly seem to agree. 
 
  --- 
 
  E-mail: jennifer.ablan@barrons.com. 
 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  December 01, 2001 00:15 ET (05:15 GMT)

DJ Welteke: Productivity, Not CPI, Key For Wage Talks -Press

 
 
 
  FRANKFURT (Dow Jones)--Negotiators in Germany's coming round of wage talks 
should take productivity as a guidepost but shouldn't consider inflation 
compensation, as the European Central Bank will keep prices stable, Bundesbank 
President Ernst Welteke told Sueddeutsche Zeitung. 
 
  "Wage negotiators can be certain that (the European Central Bank) will keep 
prices stable," said Welteke, who is a member of the ECB's governing council. 
"Therefore, (wage negotiators) would be well advised to come to agreements 
around productivity and not to push for an inflation compensation." 
 
  An advance copy of the interview, to be published Saturday, was available 
Friday. 
 
  In addition, the paper quoted Welteke saying that "wage agreements should be 
designed so as to help unemployed people become people with jobs." 
 
  IG Metall, the labor union that represents 3.6 million workers in Germany's 
metals and electronics industries, will announce Monday its recommendations for 
the regional wage talks. The industry's wage agreement expires end-February. 
 
  IG Metall Vice President Juergen Peters and several regional union 
representatives have already said they will ask for wage rises of 5%-7%. This 
accounts for productivity gains, price rises and also includes a component for 
higher profit distribution. 
 
  Peters said earlier this week that, taken together, productivity gains and 
price rises comprise 4%-4.5% of the union's wage increase demand. 
 
 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
DJ Poll Shows Argentines Back Dollar Peg;Also Expect Default

 
 
 
  BUENOS AIRES (AP)--As debate heats up on whether recession-plagued Argentina 
should adopt the mighty dollar, devalue its peso or try both measures, a poll 
published Sunday showed more than three-quarters of Argentines want the peso 
kept at parity with the dollar. 
 
  But as the government signaled it was leaning toward dollarizing South 
America's second-largest economy, an increasing number of influential 
economists want the peso to float freely. 
 
  Local polling firm Ibope said 75.6% of Argentines wanted to keep the 
one-to-one rate between the peso and the dollar that brought price stability 
since it was introduced in 1991. 
 
  Only 17.4% disagreed with maintaining the one-to-one rate. 
 
  According to Ibope, 59.2% of 1,200 people polled in 56 localities across the 
country believed it was "probable or very probable" that Argentina would 
ultimately default on its $132 billion debt. About 38% said Argentina would 
honor its payments. 
 
  No margin of error was reported. 
 
  Four years into a crippling recession, Argentina is being forced to consider 
alternative monetary policies. 
 
  The dollar peg has brought stability, but it has also helped make Argentine 
goods more expensive than goods from neighboring Brazil, which has a floating 
currency. 
 
  Anxious not to fall back into the years of hyperinflationary chaos that 
preceded the peg, Argentines and the peg's inventor, Economy Minister Domingo 
Cavallo, are reluctant to ditch it. 
 
  But after the International Monetary Fund cut Argentina off from bailout 
funds last week, officials are starting to mull a change. They could dollarize 
the economy, devalue the peso or introduce a combination of the two. 
 
  All major newspapers carried opinions laying out the various options over the 
weekend. The leading newspaper Clarin ran a front-page headline: "Government 
advances with idea of dollarization." 
 
  But inside, analyst Ismael Bermudez wrote "dollarization won't resolve the 
basic problems" of price competitively and expensive loans. 
 
  In any case, he wrote that the Central Bank's current $9.2 billion dollar 
reserves wouldn't cover the 11 billion pesos currently in circulation, meaning 
the government would have to devalue the peso before dollarizing. 
 
  In La Nacion, another respected daily, former Central Bank Governor Javier 
Gonzalez Fraga wrote that government inaction meant the financial system was 
bleeding $1 billion a week, despite a Dec. 1 partial banking freeze that only 
allows Argentines to withdraw $1,000 a month from accounts. 
 
  "We must float the peso now!" he wrote. Parity, "like all drugs, isn't easy 
to kick once the positive effects have worn off." 
 
 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
DJ After A Long Wait, Taiwan Joins The WTO

 
  GENEVA (AP)--Taiwan formally joined the World Trade Organization on Tuesday, 
ending years of negotiations that were as often political as they were 
economic. 
 
  The island becomes the 144th member of the body that sets rules on 
international trade, less than a month after its huge neighbor China joined. 
 
  The Jan. 1 date was chosen by the Taiwanese deliberately  to make 
implementation of new laws and regulations easier. To become a member of the 
body that sets rules on international trade, Taiwan had to agree to amend 
legislation, lower import tariffs in some areas and improve access to its 
markets for foreign companies. In return, Taiwanese companies hope for 
increased opportunities abroad and consumers hope for lower prices. 
 
  Taiwan's membership was long held up because of an understanding reached in 
1992 that China would join first. 
 
  Beijing claims that Taiwan is part of Chinese territory,  and at first 
objected to Taiwan's joining at all. It was finally agreed that Taiwan could 
join because it is a separate customs territory with different rules on 
importing  goods. It will not be regarded as a country in its own right. 
 
  Completion of the agreement on Chinese membership took more than 15 years. 
China and Taiwan were both finally approved for membership in a blaze of 
publicity during the WTO's meeting of trade ministers in Doha, Qatar, in 
November  but, even then, Taiwan was approved a day after China. 
 
  China and Taiwan split amid civil war in 1949, and Beijing considers the 
island to be a breakaway province to be reunited with the mainland, by force if 
necessary. 
 
  Taiwan held the China seat at the United Nations until 1971, when the U.N. 
General Assembly voted to oust the Taiwan government and replace it with the 
mainland People's Republic. 
 
  China's opposition to Taiwan's status as a country in its own right has 
blocked its membership of the United Nations and other international bodies, 
but Beijing has made  exceptions for bodies that deal exclusively with economic 
issues. 
 
 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

Many investors are seen waiting for the central bank's interest rate decision next week before taking new positions. 

  The zloty weakened against both the euro and the dollar Thursday, despite a strong start to the session by the Polish currency. Late Thursday, the euro was trading at PLN3.8995, from PLN3.8870 late Wednesday. The dollar was at PLN3.0050, from PLN2.9910. Trading was quiet, with most investors apparently done for the week ahead of the rate decision, which will be accompanied by the first commentary from the bank's new Governor Slawomir Skrzypek. 

 

  THE HUNGARIAN FORINT: Dresdner Kleinwort sees the Hungarian central bank cutting interest rates later in 2007, but says that risk is on the side of hikes before then. While the prospect of rates remaining higher for longer should ultimately prove forint-supportive, there is a risk of forint weakness in the near term, the bank says. 

  The forint weakened against the euro Thursday, despite a firm start. A trader said that Fitch's rating of Hungary's eurobond helped to support the forint early in the day. Rating agency Fitch late Wednesday assigned Hungary's EUR1 billion, 10-year eurobond a 'BBB+' rating. Late Thursday, the euro was trading at HUF254.85, from HUF253.35 early Thursday and from HUF254.30 late Wednesday. The euro came close to breaking through resistance at HUF255 Wednesday. 

 

  THE CZECH KORUNA: Traders see the euro continuing to rebound against the region's currencies Friday, following losses earlier in the week. 

  The koruna weakened a tad against the euro Thursday, in line with currencies across the region. There was little reaction to the Czech National Bank monetary policy board's decision Thursday to leave interest rate unchanged, in line with market expectations. Analysts expected the bank to keep its monetary policy on hold amid tame inflationary pressure.    In December, the country's annual inflation rate was 1.7%, up from 1.5% in November. The central bank's key two-week repurchase rate stands at 2.50%. Late Thursday, the euro was trading at CZK28.160, from CZK28.110 late Wednesday. 

 
FIXED INCOME

Bond prices strengthened early in the day, boosted by a firmer zloty and by weaker-than-expected German Ifo data. German business confidence fell unexpectedly in January, with companies' assessment of their current environment less positive than in December, the Munich-based Ifo research institute said.

TVN ended down 5.6%, while Prokom was down 4.8%, Bioton down 3.4%, BZWBK down 2.9% and BRE down 3.8%. Bucking the trend, KGHM ended up 2.2% in a rebound from recent losses. 

 

  IN BUDAPEST: Traders are downbeat about the Hungarian pharmaceutical sector after drugmaker Egis issued a profit warning Thursday. Egis blamed slack sales in Russia and the Commonwealth of Independent States for lower-than-forecast first-quarter profit. 

  Fellow Hungarian drugmaker Richter said Thursday that it sees no need to adjust its earnings projections for this year. 

  But Raiffeisen trader Akos Herczenik says: "Bad news is coming from Russia and the CIS, exactly where Richter expects its largest growth potential to come from." 

  The strengthening forint will also bite into Richter's financial results, he adds. 

  A second trader called the profit warning "very brutal" and said there was "raging pessimism" regarding pharmaceuticals in the wake of the warning. Another trader said that the selling pressure could persist for days as both pharmaceutical stocks are rather illiquid. 

  The BUX index ended down 0.6% at 24066.03 Thursday as Egis and Richter fell in the wake of the warning. Volumes were high. "The Egis announcement was the only negative news today but it set the tone for the entire market," the trader said. Egis ended down 2.4%, while Richter was down 2.6%. At this price, Egis shares are attractive, says Wood & Co. MOL weathered the day well, ending up 1.4% on the back of rebounding oil prices. 

  One trader said he expects the BUX index to continue falling Friday as "MOL alone won't be able to turn the entire market around," with further heavy selling possible over the next two weeks. OTP ended down 2.3% as weakening regional currencies put pressure on the banking sector. 

 

  IN PRAGUE: With no significant scheduled domestic news Friday, the PX index is expected to track movements on core international stock exchanges. A correction is possible Friday, if U.S. stock markets weaken, traders say. 

  The PX index ended up 0.9% at 1675.4 Thursday. CEZ was the most heavily-traded gainer, ending up 1.1%. Among other gainers, CETV ended up 1.3%, Erste Bank up 1.3% and Telefonica up 2.1%. Gains were driven by a steady bullish mood, a trader said. Zentiva was the most heavily-traded faller, ending down 0.6%, as investors sold the region's drug stocks amid Egis-prompted concerns about slowing sales growth of generic drugs in Russia, where most regional drug makers used to enjoy solid gains. Other losers included Komercni Banka, down 0.6%, and Philip Morris, down 3.2%. ECM and Pegas, the index's newest members, both ended lower, down 0.9% and 0.5%, respectively, in very thin trade.

DATA VIEW: Korean Current Acct Surplus Falls, Outlook Gloomy

 
       By Jung-Ah Lee 
       Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  SEOUL (Dow Jones)--South Korea's current-account surplus narrowed sharply in December and in 2006 as higher prices for oil and other commodities pushed up the value of imports and as more Koreans traveled overseas. 

  The Bank of Korea said it expects the current account to deteriorate further in 2007 to its weakest point in 10 years. 

  Economists say the deteriorating performance adds to other recent weak economic indicators, which will encourage the central bank to keep policy steady and not tighten despite its concern about a property sector bubble. Indeed, housing prices seem to be stabilizing in the wake of the government's recent measures to cool the property sector. 

  The current account surplus narrowed sharply to a seasonally adjusted $600.5 million in December from $2.46 billion in November. That meant that the surplus for 2006 totaled just $6.09 billion, less than half the revised $14.98 billion surplus in 2005, the central bank said Wednesday. 

  In unadjusted terms, the surplus fell to $146.7 million from $4.24 billion in November. 

  The Bank of Korea predicts the current account surplus will narrow further to just $2 billion in 2007 as the service account deficit is likely to widen. The service account includes foreign travel, shipping costs and companies' overseas businesses. 

  Economists agree with the central bank's forecast. 

  "Export (growth) is likely to decrease to a single-digit this year, while the service account deficit won't likely improve in one or two years time as the stronger local currency will further encourage Koreans to travel overseas," said Lee Sung-Kwon, an economist at Goodmorning Shinhan Securities. 

  Lee expects that the dollar will continue to weaken against the won, exacerbating these trends. He forecasts the dollar will average KRW938 in 2007 after averaging KRW955.1 last year. At 0230 GMT, the dollar was quoted at KRW942.05. 

  Korean financial markets weren't much moved by the data, which was in line with expectations. 

  The dollar was only down slightly from KRW942.50 Tuesday, while the yield on benchmark five-year treasury bonds was last at 5.01% compared with 5.05% yesterday. 

  "The (sharply lower) current account balance could have a psychological effect, but its impact should be only marginal as such a deterioration has been widely anticipated" due to the nation's already widening service deficit, said a trader at a local bank. 

  The service account deficit widened to $18.76 billion last year - the biggest services deficit ever recorded - from $13.66 billion the previous year largely due to a rise in shipment costs and an increased number of Koreans traveling overseas. In December, the service account deficit widened to $1.88 billion from a revised $1.43 billion shortfall in November. 

  Despite a double-digit growth in exports, the goods trade surplus narrowed to $29.21 billion in 2006 from $32.68 billion in 2005, due to higher prices for raw materials, including oil. 

  Exports rose 14.5% to $325.7 billion last year. In December, exports climbed to $28.87 billion from $25.63 billion a year earlier. 

  Exports were largely led by strong demand for petroleum, machinery, steel and ships. 

  Imports increased 18.4% to $309.3 billion in 2006. In December, they rose to $27.50 billion from $24.19 billion a year earlier. 

  The income account deficit narrowed to $538.6 million last year, from a $1.56 billion deficit in 2005, due to an increased returns of overseas interest payments, the central bank said. The income account surplus widened slightly to $285.0 million last month from $236.3 million in November. 

  South Korea also saw $18.62 billion of capital flowing into the country in 2006, compared with a $4.76 billion capital inflow in 2005. 

  The capital account surplus for December rose sharply to $5.46 billion from $436 million in November. 

 

  -By Jung-Ah Lee, Dow Jones Newswires; 822-732-2165; jung-ah.lee@dowjones.com 

  -Edited by Iain McDonald 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
SURVEY: Brazil Seen Cutting Key Interest Rate 25bp Wed

 
Selic rate history (annual percent): 
 Nov     Oct     Aug    July     May     Apr    Mar  Jan/06 
13.25   13.75   14.25   14.75   15.25   15.75  16.50  17.25 
 

  Gerald Jeffris 

  Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 

 

  BRASILIA (Dow Jones)--Amid concerns over a creeping acceleration of inflation and signs of a warming economy, Brazil's central bank is expected to slow the pace of interest rate easing at its monetary policy meeting Wednesday, a Dow Jones Newswires survey showed. 

  Among forecasts from analysts at 18 financial institutions, 12 said the bank would cut the reference Selic rate a quarter percentage point, while six saw a half-point rate cut. 

  "Even though there's a general perception that inflation will remain under target this year, price pressure in the first quarter favors a more moderate stance by the central bank," noted Newton Rosa, economist at SulAmerica Investimentos in Sao Paulo. 

  With a cut, the Selic would reach its lowest level since the bank established its Copom monetary policy committee in June 1996. 

  The bank has reduced the rate by 6.5 percentage points since September 2005 to a current 13.25% annually, with 10 half-point cuts and two cuts of three-quarters of a point each. 

  Speculation over a shift to a slower pace of easing gained strength in November, however, after the central bank's rate policy committee split in its decision, with three of eight members voting to cut the Selic rate by only a quarter point. 

  Since that time, further indicators have suggested continued cause for caution. 

  While Brazil easily met its inflation target in 2006, posting an annual rate of 3.14%, monthly IPCA consumer price inflation rose to 0.48% in December from 0.31% the previous month, coming in slightly ahead of market estimates. Additionally, core inflation rose during the month to about 0.4% from around 0.25% the previous month. 

  Rising domestic food, fuels, and transportation costs were seen as responsible for the price pressure, which some observers see possibly spilling into further data going forward. 

  The short-term increase, meanwhile, caused analysts to revise inflation projections upward for the coming 12 months. 

  According to the central bank's latest market surveys, the IPCA index is seen rising in 2007 to 4.07%. The government has set targets for IPCA consumer price inflation at 4.5% this year and next. 

  Additionally, Brazil's industrial production rose by 0.8% in November, far surpassing market expectations and suggesting the economy could be seeing the first signs of heating due the central bank's long string of interest rate cuts. 

  Beyond those indicators, some analysts have also cited other domestic factors that could be taken into consideration at the rate meeting, including a wide ranging economic stimulus package that is scheduled for release this week. 

  "The rate committee will likely reduce the rhythm of rate cuts now to evaluate during the coming month what impact the package will have on the economy," said Walter Machado, President of Brazilian Institute of Financial Executives in Sao Paulo. 

  Still, for other observers it remains unclear to what point the central bank will allow concerns over recent inflation to influence its rate decision amid pressure for accelerated economic growth and favorable factors on other fronts, including falling international oil prices. 

  "With expectations of declining inflation, low sovereign risk, low oil prices, low GDP growth, high investment growth and a higher interest rate than the international financial arbitrage rate, it is difficult to justify a smaller reduction of the Selic at the Copom meeting," argued Jose Marcio Camargo analyst at the Sao Paulo based Tendencias consultancy in a recent research note. 

  Following his re-election to a second four-year term in office in October, Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva called for a target to increase Brazil's economic growth by 5% annually. 

  Brazil posted annual economic growth of 3.2% in the third quarter of 2006. 

  Meanwhile, according to the central bank's latest market surveys, economic growth likely ended 2006 around 2.7% and is seen expanding to 3.50% in 2007. 

   The same surveys show the Selic rate falling to about 11.75% annually by the end of 2007. 

  -By Gerald Jeffris, Dow Jones Newswires; (5561) 4501-7143, geraldjeffrisdowjones.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

RATE FUTURES REPORT: Expectations Steady As Data Awaited

 
    By Jesse Thomas 
    Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  CHICAGO (Dow Jones)--For the first time in more than a week, interest rate futures prices Tuesday didn't settle lower, breaking a trend of the market reducing its expectations for the Federal Reserve to cut its benchmark rate this year. 

  However, despite a weak data report released Tuesday, Eurodollar futures prices settled mostly flat, a signal that market participants are showing little conviction in pushing prices higher ahead of inflation data reports and speeches from Fed officials due later in the week. 

  "The market, right now, has no interest in rallying," said Howard Gussis, an independent Eurodollar floor broker. 

  A report from the New York Federal Reserve on the area's manufacturing activity provided support throughout Tuesday's session to Eurodollar futures, which had settled lower on Friday for the sixth-straight session. 

  The New York Fed's Manufacturing Index dropped to a reading of 9.13 in January, compared with a revised 22.19 in December. The consensus among 11 economists surveyed by Dow Jones Newswires was for a January reading of 20.00. 

  Immediately following the report, Eurodollar futures prices climbed, indicating increased market expectations for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates this year. Yet, prices struggled to post gains by the end of the session. 

  "There's just not a strong conviction that this market's going to go higher," said a market source in the Eurodollar options pit, adding that when prices do move up, "traders are quick to take profits," which sends prices lower. 

  "The bigger question is the inflation numbers starting tomorrow," he said. 

  The Labor Department is due to release the December producer price index at 8:30 a.m. EST (1330 GMT) on Wednesday, followed by the December consumer price index at 8:30 a.m. EST on Thursday. 

  Both reports are watched closely by the Federal Reserve and seen as key measures of inflation. Market participants agree that the two reports - known as PPI and CPI - could sway the market, in either direction, with more authority than was seen Tuesday. 

  Also Thursday, Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke will testify on the fiscal and economic outlook before the Senate Budget Committee in Washington. 

  Gussis put it simply, saying, "Bernanke's always big." 

  The downward price trend throughout last week in Eurodollar futures was a result of comments from Federal Reserve officials who cited inflation as their primary concern, along with data reports that suggested economic strength. 

  At Tuesday's close, the June Eurodollar contract priced in a 48% chance that the Federal Open Market Committee reduces its key target rate from 5.25% to 5% in the second quarter. Those odds are unchanged from Friday; markets were closed Monday. 

  For the third quarter, the September Eurodollar contract at Tuesday's close showed a 92% probability for a 5% rate, also unchanged from Friday. The market fully expects 5% by year's end, along with a 40% odds for 4.75%. The FOMC has held the rate at 5.25% at its last four policy-setting meetings. 

  Eurodollar futures, traded at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, are commonly used by traders to bet on short-term U.S. interest rate expectations, although they are actually linked to three-month projections for the London Interbank Offered Rate, or Libor. 

  For longer-dated contracts, Treasury futures tied to longer-maturity bonds at the Chicago Board of Trade saw moderate price gains in Tuesday's session as contracts lifted off their 2-1/2 month lows seen at Friday's close.

WSJA(1/2) China's Oil Hunt Heats Up Abroad

   (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL ASIA) 
   By Shai Oster 

  BEIJING -- China's private entrepreneurs are joining its big companies in striking abroad to search for oil to satisfy their nation's insatiable thirst, in the latest sign of how the world's fastest-growing major economy is roiling energy markets. 

  Perhaps the most successful of this new breed of wealthy Chinese wildcatter is Ni Zhaoxing, a 50-year-old businessman who has spent the last year prospecting for oil in western Canada after amassing a fortune in China's real-estate market. Mr. Ni's ZhongRong Group has struck oil in its Saskatchewan field, a find that eventually could bring in hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue a year, based on his projections. 

  China has been encouraging its big state oil companies to go abroad for years, aware that domestic oil fields don't have enough supply to meet growing demand in China. Government-run companies including China National Petroleum Corp. and Cnooc Ltd. have bought oil and gas fields in Central Asia, Africa and the Americas. 

  That push -- often into countries such as Sudan or Iran that have troubled ties with the U.S. -- coupled with China's stated aim of improving its ability to use armed force abroad to protect its global interests, has raised alarms in Washington and other capitals. Western politicians and oil executives worry that Asia's state-owned oil companies are trying to lock up the world's resources in a bid to boost their nations' energy security. Some analysts counter that Chinese oil companies are actually spending only a fraction of what their western peers are in acquiring overseas oil fields. 

  Mr. Ni's efforts are incidental by the standards of those giants and their foreign Big Oil counterparts. But even in its early stages, the emergence of private-sector oil developers in China's state-dominated industry illustrates both the country's growing obsession with energy and the rise of its entrepreneurial class. It also shows how, amid today's high oil prices and tight supplies around the world, even small-time players with no experience or expertise believe the search for oil can be lucrative. 

  China has become more dependent on energy exports amid rapid industrialization and the rise of a middle class snapping up cars, as well as flat-lining production from its domestic oil fields. Its demand for oil is expected to reach 7.4 million barrels a day in 2007, up from 7 million barrels in 2006 and 35% ahead of the 5.5 million barrels in 2003. But its domestic supply this year is expected to be just 3.7 million barrels a day, only slightly more than the 3.4 million barrels a day it pumped out in 2003. 

  Private Chinese companies are looking well beyond Canada to fill the gap, to places such as Indonesia and Ecuador. In April, 40 such companies traveled to Pakistan and signed deals to develop oil fields, refineries, pipelines and coal mines worth a total of more than 10 billion yuan ($1.28 billion), according to the All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce. 

  The highest profile member of that delegation was Gong Jialong, chairman of Great United Petroleum Holding Co., a consortium of several dozen private Chinese companies involved in small-scale oil production and refining. One of Great United's biggest shareholders is Guangcai 49 Holding Co., whose directors include Charles Zhang, chief executive of Nasdaq-listed Sohu.com Inc., one of China's biggest Internet companies. Mr. Zhang couldn't be reached for comment. 

  Mr. Gong also heads China's Chamber of Commerce for Petroleum Industry, a group of about 1,000 private oil companies that is lobbying for fewer government restrictions in China's heavily regulated domestic oil market. Mr. Gong's future was thrown into question by his detention last month on suspicion of unspecified economic crimes. His detention was disclosed by Tianfa Petroleum Co., a listed company he controls. 

  Another Chinese oil entrepreneur is Cui Xinsheng, chairman of the China International Petroleum Investment Union, a group that includes investors from China as well as Indonesia, Saudi Arabia, Kazakhstan and Singapore. The group has paid about $400 million for rights to four fields in Indonesia and two in the Middle East. It hopes to sell the rights to China's big state-owned companies, Mr. Cui says. 

  Mr. Ni started off running a small village-owned construction-materials factory near the eastern Chinese city of Hangzhou in 1980. After early success with the factory, he moved to the southern Chinese city of Shenzhen, then an emerging economic hothouse where China's leaders were testing capitalism. Mr. Ni says he was repeatedly swindled by business partners in Shenzhen, losing almost all his money. 

  He persevered, though, setting his sights on the rough-and-tumble real-estate market with the founding of ZhongRong in 1992 -- just as China's property market was getting ready to take off. ZhongRong blossomed, too. Among its current projects are a 43-story building in Shanghai's financial district and a collection of 78 neoclassical villas in the mountains west of Beijing, called in a promotional brochure a "royal Xanadu." 

  Mr. Ni now has a net worth estimated at $190 million. He says the assets controlled by ZhongRong, which he and his wife own, are valued at around $770 million. 

  Mr. Ni says he first got the idea to invest in energy during his early-morning newspaper reading. "I saw there was a need," he says in an interview at ZhongRong's Beijing office, a restored former bank in the city's prerevolutionary diplomatic quarter. "We have a responsibility to increase the world's resources, either by conserving energy or finding more," he says. 

  Despite China's obvious need for more oil, regulators at first balked at granting ZhongRong the permission necessary to convert the $30 million needed for its investment in Canada from Chinese yuan. ZhongRong eventually prevailed, and in 2005 began buying Saskatchewan tracts that eventually totaled 15,000 hectares. 

  Trevor Dark, assistant deputy minister of petroleum and natural gas at Saskatchewan Industry and Resources, says ZhongRong's subsidiary has licenses to drill six wells over a 12-month period in the Weyburn region. Canada Capital Energy Corp., the ZhongRong subsidiary set up for the project, says it has found oil in two wells so far, but has not said how much they are producing. The company says its goal is to reach a production rate of 20,000 barrels a day in five years. That would be valued at about $438 million a year at today's prices. 

  China's big oil companies haven't always been welcomed overseas. State-run Cnooc's bid to buy California-based Unocal in 2005 was defeated in part because of fears China was trying to lock up oil resources at America's expense, a charge Cnooc denied. 

  Mr. Ni's reception has been better. "We're very pleased," says Mr. Dark. "We're absolutely happy for more firms from China to invest in Saskatchewan." 

  Mr. Ni says China's growing oil demand has fueled the soaring prices that attracted him to the business. But he says his investment has nothing to do with China's political agenda, or an effort to secure resources for the motherland. "I'm an investor," he says. "Not just a Chinese investor. I'll sell the oil where I find it. 

  --- 

  Zhou Yang in Beijing and Norval Scott in Calgary contributed to this article. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  January 01, 2007 16:30 ET (21:30 GMT)
label: non-inflation-related

text:
WSJA(2/12) Insurers Target Developing World

   (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL ASIA) 
   By Ian McDonald, Liam Pleven and Eric Bellman 

  JHALAWAR, India -- Last year, global insurance giant American International Group Inc. opened a garage-size office in this dusty town of about 50,000. Coming up soon here: a policy that insures a cow for a $10 annual premium. 

  Seeking potential sources of future growth, AIG and its international rivals are racing to sell insurance in the developing world, from sprawling markets like India and China to smaller ones like Romania and Nicaragua. In remote areas, insurers must teach the concept of insurance to populations who have never bought any. Sometimes, as in parts of northern Uganda, the local language doesn't even have a word for it. 

  To penetrate these markets, insurers are devising unusual policies, charging as little as 50 cents to insure everything from television sets to burial costs. They are forgoing conventional documentation requirements, sometimes selling life insurance to people who don't know when they were born. 

  Instead of relying entirely on agents, AIG and many others are partnering in some markets with nonprofit microloan programs, operations that lend small amounts of money to the poor. Many microlenders sell a form of life insurance that will pay off the loan and sometimes also compensate survivors if the debtor dies. AIG has roughly 2.25 million life-insurance policies on microloan recipients, mostly in Uganda, Mexico, India and Brazil. 

  Microlenders say selling insurance benefits borrowers by teaching them greater financial sophistication. It is a "natural extension of our role," says Scott Graham, senior manager of strategic alliances for Washington-based Finca International, a nonprofit group that operates microlending programs in 21 countries. 

  Microlending won Bangladeshi banker Muhammad Yunus the Nobel Peace Prize last year. And just as big banks are being drawn to that business, big insurers are increasingly lured by what they call "microinsurance." It is a way for insurers to wedge themselves into new markets -- markets they see as crucial to the future of the industry, which in 2005 collected $3.4 trillion in premiums. 

  That year, insurance premiums world-wide edged up 2.5% from the year before, according to Swiss Reinsurance Co., the world's largest reinsurer. That is because half the total market is driven by the U.S. and Japan, where insurance is ubiquitous and growth opportunities can be limited. 

  In that same year, insurance premiums in emerging markets rose nearly 7% after inflation, more than three times the growth rates of developed markets, according to Swiss Re. Increasing car and home ownership in those countries are boosting demand, as is rapid economic growth. 

  "The premiums are not very high, but selling these policies allows you to build up relationships with these customers as their markets develop, and that's going to be important," says James Schiro, chief executive officer of Zurich Financial Services AG, which sells microinsurance in four Latin American countries today and is launching a pilot program in South Africa sometime this year. 

  Ugandan Fred Adriko, 20 years old, didn't know his mother had insurance until she was killed in a car accident in 2005. She had taken out a microloan from Finca to develop a business selling produce and purchased a policy at the same time. 

  Because of the policy, Mr. Adriko received a payment of about $650, which he can use to take care of his family, he said in an interview through a Finca-provided translator. 

  AIG knows the benefits of getting in early. Former AIG Chief Executive Maurice R. "Hank" Greenberg, hewing to the style and approach of his mentor Cornelius Vander Starr, started building relationships with government and business leaders in China more than a quarter century ago, before the government allowed foreign insurers to sell policies there. 

  Today, AIG is the only foreign insurer allowed to have a wholly owned unit sell life insurance in China, a right it won in 1992. Other foreign insurers are piling into the China market, but they typically need to work with a locally based partner. 

  Emerging markets can present logistical and cultural hurdles as well as daunting local bureaucracies. What is more, since the premiums collected are small by Western standards, the revenue generated by the microinsurance sector also is tiny. While developing markets are profitable for a few companies, insurance executives say they remain unprofitable for many others. 

  AIG, which does business in about 130 countries, says its microinsurance business is profitable, but total premiums from life insurance sold to microloan recipients in developing markets add up to only about $45 million a year. That is just 0.15% of the $29.4 billion in life insurance premiums AIG took in world-wide in 2005. 

  Some insurers are sitting out the global rush. Northwestern Mutual, a Milwaukee, Wisconsin, company that is among the U.S.'s largest life insurers, doesn't sell insurance abroad. The company relies on agents who aim to establish long-term relationships with customers, explains CEO Ed Zore, and "I don't think we could" build such a sales force in another country. Mr. Zore says the company may expand to other countries in the future. 

  The insurance race is particularly heated in India, which opened its market to foreign insurers in 2000. Not only does the country boast a young population and a British-influenced legal system, but it also is relatively virgin territory. The country's 1.1 billion people spend $21 billion on premiums, a little more than what 13 million Illinois residents paid for property-casualty coverage in 2005, according to the Insurance Information Institute, a New York trade group. 

  A number of the world's biggest insurers, including AIG and Aviva PLC, Britain's largest insurer, expanded into India in the past seven years. Allianz SE, a German insurance giant, says it has 180,000 full and part-time agents in India and is hiring 10,000 more every month. Britain's Prudential PLC, India's leading foreign life insurer in 2005, arrived even before the market opened to establish local ties. 

  India also presents some obstacles. As in China, local players are dominant. The Life Insurance Corp. of India boasts more than one million agents and collected well more than 90% of the country's life-insurance premiums in 2005, according to the Insurance Information Institute. 

  Under India's laws, all foreign companies must partner with locally based companies to sell insurance. India also requires that companies generate some of their business from the countryside, preventing insurers from focusing solely on the affluent urban customers they are often most interested in. 

  India stipulates that 5% of foreign insurers' premiums for property-casualty coverage must be generated by rural customers. Rural customers must represent 7% of all life insurance policies in the insurer's first year, a number that rises to 18% in its fifth year. 

  In rural India, in addition to using their own agents, both AIG and Aviva typically sell basic life-insurance policies through local women's groups and microlending agencies. This lowers distribution costs because the person processing the loan also sells and processes the insurance policy on the loan. 

  Finca, which works with AIG in many places but not India, says its local offices keep as much as 25% to 50% of the premiums left over after claims and expenses in some areas. In others, Finca's local offices get nothing. 

  Some companies working in India say married women are often their best representatives because they tend to stay in their community and know it well. That knowledge is helpful given how much insurers have relaxed traditional standards, accepting thumb prints on policy applications and eliminating death-certificate requirements, since few rural clients die in hospitals. In India, AIG says it accepts the signatures of a village elder or groundskeeper at cremation facilities. 

  Without local expertise "we would be too scared to go into this market," says Sriram Gopal, head of the rural, nonlife insurance business for the Tata AIG Life Insurance Co., which is AIG's local joint venture with Tata Group, an Indian conglomerate. 

  To market its brand in rural areas, Aviva representatives tour villages and stage festivals in a promotional van festooned with a big loudspeaker. 

  In Nandurdi village -- a few brick and mud homes amid sugar-cane and grape fields five hours' drive from Mumbai -- roughly 200 villagers gathered recently to spin a giant wheel in hopes of winning key chains and pens. As they handed out the prizes, Aviva agents talked to the crowd about the value of life insurance. 

  The reps told the crowd that Aviva is the world's fifth-largest insurer and assured them that insurance isn't just for the rich. They asked villagers who would take care of their family if they died. 

  "Who here has insurance?" asked Aviva representative Sushil Gaykawad, and only about six hands went up. "Who plans to get insurance now?" he followed up. All hands went up. 

  To reach its core urban audience, Aviva plasters its logo on the clocks that count down to green lights at traffic stops in Delhi. It advertises during televised cricket matches, and, in 2005, Aviva paid for more than 2,000 airings of TV advertisements for the Bollywood family drama, "Viruddh." The movie ads ended with the India megastar, Amitabh Bachchan, saying the Aviva slogan: "Kal Par Control," or "Control Your Future." 

  After four years in India, Aviva covers more than one million lives and operates 113 branches, says Vivek Khanna, head of Aviva's Indian operations. 

  Rival AIG has already written policies covering the lives of about 15,000 cattle. While local insurers pioneered cow coverage years earlier, those policies became problematic because of fraudulent claims. To avoid bovine fraud, AIG employs retired veterinarians who, armed with digital cameras, visit farms to verify a cow's death. The policy typically pays more than $200 when the animal dies. 

  (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires

  February 11, 2007 16:30 ET (21:30 GMT)

text:
UPDATE: Euro-Zone Jan Services PMI 57.9 Vs 57.2 In Dec

  (This updates an item that ran at 0900 GMT with new sourcing, additional detail and analysts' comments) 

  LONDON (Dow Jones)--The euro zone's services sector grew at the most rapid pace in six months in January, while private sector companies raised their prices more aggressively than at any time since November 2000, a survey of purchasing managers conducted by NTC Research showed Monday. 

  The headline measure of activity in the services sector - the purchasing managers index - rose to 57.9 in January from 57.2 in December.    The rise in the PMI was unexpected. Economists surveyed by Dow Jones Newswires last week had forecast the PMI would decline to 56.7. A reading above 50.0 indicates a period of expansion for the sector, while a reading below 50.0 indicates a contraction. 

  The pickup in the services sector was broad-based, with activity strengthening in Germany, France and Italy. 

  However, a similar survey of purchasing managers published Thursday showed manufacturing activity slowed in January as exports were hit by the strong euro, so the composite PMI fell to 56.6 from 57.5. That indicates  the euro-zone economy continued to grow at a strong, but slightly slower pace as 2007 began. 

  The strength of the services sector relative to manufacturing also suggests that the composition of growth in the euro zone may be changing, with expansion becoming less reliant on exports and more reliant on domestic - including consumer - demand. 

  "The euro's strength against the US dollar appears to have hit manufacturing exports, but this has been offset by faster growth in the service sector," said Ken Gaynor, head of economics at the Royal Bank of Scotland Group, which sponsors the survey. "This suggests that 2007 may see a changing growth dynamic from that seen in 2006, away from exports towards improved domestic demand in the euro area's main national economies, particularly Germany." 

  Strengthening domestic demand makes the recovery less vulnerable to developments elsewhere in the global economy, for example a housing-led slowdown in the U.S. 

  But it may also mean that manufacturers and service providers feel more confident that they can raise prices without losing customers. 

  In January, private sector companies raised the prices they charge at the fastest rate since November 2000, when NTC first began compiling data on that component of the PMI. Although partly the result of an increase in Germany's sales tax rate, that is likely to cause concern at the European Central Bank, and increases the likelihood that the central bank will raise interest rates again in March, and possibly once more before the end of June. 

  "The ECB will be concerned by the sharp rise in both the input prices and prices charged indices for the euro-zone service sector in January," said Howard Archer, an economist at Global Insight. "Reports of improved pricing power among service providers and higher wages will be particularly worrying for the ECB." 

  Private sector companies reported that they continued to hire new workers for the seventeenth straight month, a development that suggests the pickup in domestic demand should continue. 

  -By Paul Hannon; Dow Jones Newswires; 44-20-7842 9491; paul.hannon@dowjones.com

text:
G7 Aims To Curb Carry Trades, Stressing Risk Of Yen Gains

 

  (This article was originally published Saturday) 

 

  By Paul Hannon 

  Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 

 

  ESSEN, Germany (Dow Jones)--Finance ministers and central bankers from Europe and Japan Saturday launched a concerted effort to curb the growth of carry trades, which European officials believe have been a key factor in pushing the euro to record highs against the Japanese yen on the foreign exchange markets. 

  Carry trades refer to investments in assets denominated in high-yielding currencies that are funded by low-yielding currencies. With the Bank of Japan's key interest rate set at 0.25%, borrowed Japanese yen are nowa popularsource of cheap funding for those investments. 

  European expressions of concern about the yen's recent weakness and the role carry trades have played in pushing the euro higher against the Japanese currency fueled speculation in the foreign exchange markets that action would be taken at a meeting of finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven leading economies here. 

  The G7's final communique made no reference to the yen, but noted that Japan's recovery is "on track and is expected to continue." G7 members said they "are confident that the implications of these developments will be recognized by market participants and will be incorporated in their assessments of risks." 

  According to G7 officials briefing later, those statements were intended to draw investors' attention to the possibility that the yen will strengthen  and Japanese interest rates will rise as the recovery continues. That would threaten carry trades, since an appreciation of the Japanese currency would cut investors' profits. 

  In press briefings after their joint statement, some G7 finance ministers and central bankers highlighted those statements with coordinated language that made clear the yen-funded carry trade was their primary target. 

  "We want markets to be aware of the risks in one-way bets in general," said European Central Bank President Jean-Claude Trichet. "We, in particular, think of carry trades, but not only carry trades." 

  At exactly the same time, but in a different room, Germany's finance minister delivered a nearly-identical warning. 

  "We want to strictly stick to one language," Peer Steinbrueck said. "It's the common view of finance ministers and central bankers that markets should be aware of risks stemming from one-sided bets, particularly on foreign exchange markets. This addresses the problem linked in particular to carry trades." 

  Japanese Minister of Finance Koji Omi added his voice to the chorus. 

  "Market participants ought to be aware that acting in one direction could bring a risk," he said, referring to some traders view that yen weakness is a sure bet. 

  Despite Steinbrueck's claim that all G7 members had signed up to the common phrasing, U.S. officials didn't speak about the danger of one-sided bets in general or carry trades in particular.  U.S. Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson told reporters that as a general rule he doesn't believe he should ever comment on the value of freely-floating currencies or evaluate particular trading strategies. 

  The success of efforts to curb the growth of carry trades may depend on how consistently officials stick to the agreed message. European officials felt that their Japanese counterparts departed from an agreed position shortly after the last G7 meeting in Singapore in September, undermining their initial success in talking the yen higher. 

  An official at a European G7 delegation insisted the lesson from that experience has been learned. 

  "Believe me, everyone will stick to the current wording, all parties concerned are fully aware of the risks, notably the Bank of Japan," he said. 

  The mix of an oblique reference in the communique and more direct comments in press briefings may reflect the G7's desire to avoid an overly dramatic reaction in foreign exchange markets. A more direct statement on the yen's value or Japanese interest rates - unlikely in the face of Japanese opposition and U.S. disinterest - could have risked a rapid unwinding of carry trades, sending assets prices into a spin. 

  Despite the immediate focus on the yen in response to European concerns about a loss of competitiveness in markets in which Japanese exporters compete with their European counterparts, the Chinese yuan remained an ongoing concern for G7 members. 

  In their communique, they said that "in emerging economies with large and growing current account surpluses, especially China, it is desirable that their effective exchange rates move so that necessary adjustments will occur." 

  The G7 had previously called on China to allow the yuan greater flexibility to move in response to market forces. The more direct reference to movement in the exchange rate represents a departure from previous statements. 

  The G7 said it welcomed "China's commitment to rebalance growth." 

  China's strong record of economic growth in recent years has been driven by an investment boom and exports, while G7 members want the government to encourage stronger consumer demand as part of a shared effort to reduce trade imbalances. 

  U.S. Treasury Undersecretary for International Affairs Tim Adams described the change in language as a "technical fix." U.S. officials say their message to China hasn't changed, and they continue to believe China should allow the yuan to appreciate in the short term, and move to a freely-floating currency regime in the longer run. 

  However, European officials pointed out that while the yuan appreciated by 3.4% against the dollar last year, that was partly the result of the greenback's weakness. But the euro is now stronger relative to the yuan than it was when China ended its peg with the U.S. dollar in 2005, and linked its currency to a basket of currencies. In their view, the new stress on the "effective exchange rate" reflects the need for the yuan to strengthen against currencies other than the dollar. 

  The G7 sounded a generally upbeat note about the outlook for the world economy, noting that growth is more balanced. 

  "The US economy is experiencing solid activity, while adjusting to a more sustainable growth path," the communique said. "Canada and the UK remain on a strong and balanced growth path. The euro area is experiencing an increasingly broad-based upswing." 

  They noted that with energy prices falling, inflationary pressures are "moderating," although G7 central bankers said they said they will "remain vigilant." 

  -Paul Hannon, Dow Jones Newswires, +44 20 7842 9491, paul.hannon@dowjones.com 

  (Monica Houston-Waesch, Elizabeth Price, Geraldine Amiel, Andrea Thomas, Natsuo Nishio and Dennis McMahon contributed to this report) 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
Signs Mount Of End Game For Zimbabwe's Robert Mugabe

  JOHANNESBURG (AP)--Signs are mounting that Zimbabwe is finally reaching the end game, witnessing the last, desperate throes of a regime that has destroyed one of Africa's few successful economies, forced a third of its people into the diaspora and the rest into poverty that is killing hundreds of thousands. 

  It may not happen Saturday, when President Robert Mugabe celebrates his 83rd birthday with bubbly and cake at a $1.2 million party while hundreds of thousands of Zimbabweans struggle to survive on bread and water. 

  And it probably won't happen in the weeks leading up to April 18, the 27th anniversary of an end to racist white rule and Mugabe's ascension to power. 

  But years of abuse and neglect are culminating in untenable crises. 

  "People's anger is mounting," said Zimbabwean political scientist John Makumbe. "They're no longer afraid to go into the streets and I think the government is growing very afraid of what may happen." 

  Hyperinflation that brings shortages of food, fuel, medication, electricity, is spiraling out of control. Opposition from within his ruling party, which is divided over the timing of his succession and his successor, is mounting. 

  "Each and every individual on the upper echelons" is jockeying for his position, Mugabe complained in an interview on his actual birthday, Wednesday, broadcast over the country's sole and state-owned television station. 

  But, he announced categorically: "There are no vacancies because I am still there." 

  Mugabe blames sanctions, drought and former colonizer the U.K. for the collapse of an economy based on exports of a wealth of agricultural and mineral products. 

  Others blame land grabs in which Mugabe encouraged blacks to violently force out most of the 5,000 white commercial farmers who owned 40% of all agricultural land and produced 75% of agricultural output. White farmers had employed the country's largest work force and their ejection led to the displacement of 300,000 families. 

  Today, the farms, most given to Mugabe relatives, allies and cronies, lie fallow and Zimbabwe doesn't have the foreign currency to import food. 

  On Mugabe's birthday, police announced a three-month ban on protests, following weekend clashes in which they fired tear gas and turned water cannon on opposition rallies. 

  The National Constitutional Assembly, a coalition of human rights, church and grass-roots organizations, in a statement Friday said: "It's not a crime to defend oneself from an unlawful attack, and if need be (people) should protect themselves from a partisan, violent police force that aims at perpetuating dictatorship and increasing the suffering of the ordinary masses." 

  Mugabe is "at war" with the people, opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai declared this week. 

  Opposition supporters wanted to protest the high cost of living and Mugabe's plan to extend his term of office to 2010. 

  A rate of hyperinflation - running at near 1,600% - that economists say soon will be represented by an upright line on a graph has the country in revolt. The number of Zimbabwe dollars that bought a three-bedroom house with a swimming pool and tennis court in 1990 today will buy one sole brick. 

  A lifetime public worker's monthly pension can't buy a loaf of bread. Charities have reported depression, suicide and malnutrition among retirees - including a type of vitamin deficiency affecting gums, bones and hair loss. 

  Doctors and nurses have been on strike since December and the rest of the civil service is threatening to join them. 

  The list of deserters on the walls of army barracks grows ever longer despite a 300% pay raise in January. The military want a 1,000% increase. The police chief in the capital, Harare, has said in a confidential memo that he fears his constables will riot. 

  A hairdresser paid the minimum monthly wage of $30,000 said her bus fare to work cost more but she went anyway to get the tips from clients that keep her and a daughter alive. 

  Political scientist Makumbe said a 16-year-old who broke his collar bone falling out of a tree has lain at home in pain for days because his widowed mother doesn't have the million Zimbabwe dollars needed to have the bone set. 

  Makumbe said an estimated 70,000 people have died this year not because of the doctor's strike but because there are no drugs and because medical equipment like dialysis machines doesn't work any more. 

  Bread disappeared off the shelves this week after the government increased the price of grain sold to millers by 10,000% but didn't increase the controlled price for bread. 

  Water shortages have brought a cholera epidemic that is killing people. 

  Children are among the first to suffer, with one in four Zimbabwean children orphaned and more than 2 million vulnerable to starvation, the U.N. Children's Fund says. 

  The government tries to control inflation by printing money and setting the exchange rate. Last year, when half a dozen eggs cost more than a million Zimbabwe dollars and the poorest Zimbabweans were millionaires, the government simply knocked three zeros off the currency. The minimum monthly salary for a house cleaner went from $15 million to $15,000. The official exchange rate is set at 250 to the U.S. dollar, but the real trading rate is 5,000 to the dollar. 

  Some Zimbabweans are getting rich off the misery. Party and government officials with access to foreign currency buy it at the official rate and sell it at the real rate. 

  The World Bank estimates it would take more than 20 years for Zimbabwe's economy to return to 1980 levels. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires
