text:
UPDATE:CEA:China Yuan Policy May Not Change Its Export Prices

 

  (Updates with further detail.) 

 
   By Henry J. Pulizzi and Elizabeth Price 
   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  WASHINGTON (Dow Jones)--China's policy of depressing the value of its currency pushes domestic inflation higher, and leaves the relative price of goods the country trades unchanged, the White House said Monday. 

  "Chinese intervention does not systematically change the relative real prices between the United States and China," the Council of Economic Advisers said in its annual economic report of the president. 

  China has been under heavy pressure from Congress and manufacturers to ease its tight grip on the yuan, which critics say undervalues the currency and gives Chinese products an unfair advantage in global markets. China's central bank buys dollars on foreign exchange markets each month to control the value of the yuan, also known as the renminbi. 

  According to Monday's report, the increase in China's inflation rate, spurred by the intervention, offsets any price declines resulting from the exchange rate movements. That conclusion suggests the intervention may have little impact on the U.S. trade balance with China, and raises the question of why the U.S. Treasury is devoting so much of its time and energy to persuading Beijing to allow the yuan to appreciate. 

  "Fixing the nominal exchange rate does not tend to move countries away from purchasing power parity," the idea that identical goods and services should cost the same in different countries, CEA said. "The only effect is that domestic goods prices have to do all of the adjustment since the exchange rate is fixed." 

  CEA said there is no "clear preference" between conducting monetary policy with a fixed exchange rate or through short-term interest rates. 

  "In the end, central banks that choose to fix the value of their exchange rate relative to another currency and central banks that choose to set a short-term interest rate are each choosing a different tool to conduct monetary policy," CEA said. 

  Though the panel said economic theory doesn't dictate a preference between the two systems, it said interest-rate targeting is the preferred tool because no major industrialized nation's central bank uses a fixed exchange rate. CEA Chairman Edward Lazear said the panel is "agnostic" on the issue. 

  "Our goal in this chapter was simply to explain the effects of a variety of different strategies, and that's why we said we don't want to take a position on one over the other," Lazear said. 

  In July 2005, China officially ended its policy of pegging its currency to the dollar, moving to a system of managing the yuan against an unpublished basket of currencies. 

  Though the yuan has appreciated more than 6% since July 2005, U.S. exporters, lawmakers and the Bush administration believe it needs to rise further against the dollar. The Treasury Department is pushing China to let the yuan appreciate in the short term, and move to a freely floating currency regime in the longer run. The disagreement between Washington and Beijing is over the pace of reform. 

  Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson, the White House's point man on the issue, told lawmakers last month that Beijing needs to take four steps toward floating the yuan. It must widen the currency's trading band, lower central-bank purchases of dollars, develop a bond market and create central bank policy targets to avoid inflation and boost confidence in the yuan. 

  "China does not yet have the currency policy we want it to have and that it needs," Paulson told the Senate Banking Committee. "China's cautious approach to exchange rate reform exacerbates distortions in its domestic economy and impedes the adjustment of international imbalances." 

  Finance ministers from the Group of Seven leading industrialized countries, meeting over the weekend in Germany, urged China to focus on the trade-weighted value of the yuan. "In emerging economies with large and growing current account surpluses, especially China, it is desirable that their effective exchange rates move so that necessary adjustments will occur," the finance ministers said. 

  Earlier Monday, the Chinese government said the country's trade surplus jumped 67% last month from a year earlier to $15.88 billion. 

 

  -By Henry J. Pulizzi and Elizabeth Price, Dow Jones Newswires; 202-862-9256; henry.pulizzi@dowjones.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
WSJ(3/16) Currency Trading: Swiss Gift

   (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL) 
   By Joellen Perry 

  FRANKFURT -- Historically, Switzerland's currency has been the strong, silent type: The tiny nation's steady economy and peaceful geopolitics have long lured investors to the Swiss franc in times of global economic turmoil. 

  But lately the Swiss franc has started behaving more like the Japanese yen -- a darling of currency speculators who use it to fund risky investments across the globe. 

  The reason: Switzerland's extremely low interest rates of 2.25%. 

  Currency traders are borrowing massive amounts of Swiss francs, then investing that money in countries like Iceland, where the money earns higher interest rates of 14.25% -- a maneuver known as the carry trade. 

  Switzerland's low interest rates are also luring individual home buyers across Eastern Europe and as far away as Greece to take out Swiss-franc denominated mortgages. 

  All this has Swiss National Bank officials worried. If interest rates and investor sentiment changes, these often-complex carry trades could sour quickly and roil the economy of Switzerland and perhaps elsewhere. Last year when Japan indicated it might raise its superlow rates, the announcement rattled global markets as traders tried to adjust their strategies. 

  Yesterday, the SNB raised its base interest rate by a quarter-point to 2.25%. The SNB targets a range for the three-month franc London interbank offered rate, and aims for the midpoint of the range, now 1.75% to 2.75%. 

  Low Borrowing Costs 

  Still, Swiss borrowing costs remain the second-lowest in the industrialized world, after Japan's 0.5% rate. 

  The low Swiss interest rates, according to the bank, are still stoking growth in the domestic economy, where annual inflation in February was zero. But the carry trade raises concerns that local inflation could start galloping higher. 

  That is because one byproduct of the carry trade is to weaken the Swiss franc compared with other currencies. A weaker currency means Swiss companies and consumers must shell out more francs for imported goods. (The carry trade weakens the Swiss currency because essentially, speculators are selling it in order to buy, say, Icelandic kronur; all that selling pushes down the franc's value.) 

  Indeed, the franc is hovering near eight-year lows against the euro. It has also fallen nearly 10% against the dollar since 2005, putting the value of one Swiss franc at about 82 cents. A weak franc is good news for Swiss exporters, because it makes their products more affordable to buyers in other countries. 

  There are also concerns that the currency speculation could destabilize economies in Eastern Europe, where the sale of franc-denominated mortgages is booming. The risk is that any rise in the value of the franc would increase the debt burdens and mortgage payments for people whose earnings are in, say, the Hungarian currency, the forint. 

  "We've tried to say, don't assume it's always going to be this way," says Philipp Hildebrand, a member of the Swiss central bank's board. 

  In addition, Swiss-franc loans often offer floating interest rates, which means debt burdens will spike if Swiss interest rates do. Mr. Hildebrand noted that the franc recently bounced back a bit against major currencies as worried global investors unwound some of their currency bets -- a small warning of what can happen. 

  Market estimates of the yen carry trade typically start around $200 billion, and increase from there. Though experts say the franc trade is smaller, in part because Swiss interest rates are higher, few doubt that hedge funds and currency traders could lose billions of dollars if the yen or Swiss franc suddenly rose in value. 

  Pain of Franc Spike 

  A spike in the franc also could break many ordinary borrowers' backs. With interest rates in the euro zone and many Eastern European countries outpacing Switzerland's, banks outside the country increasingly offer loans in Swiss francs. 

  "It's like a carry trade for the household," says Michael Saunders, a Citigroup economist in London. He warns that typical carry-trade investors are steeped in the complexities of currency risk, and far more likely to protect themselves when engaging in currency bets than ordinary borrowers. 

  According to the Bank for International Settlements, which collects data from 40 central banks, the value of Swiss loans granted to companies or individuals outside Switzerland rose to $138 billion in the third quarter last year, from $61 billion in the same period of 2002. Economists suspect much of that increase was accounted for by these so-called household carry trades. 

  Austrians, who have been borrowing in Swiss franc since the mid-1990s, held 34 billion euros ($45 billion) of foreign-currency loans last December. Several banks in Greece started offering Swiss-franc mortgages last fall. Both Austria and Greece belong to the euro zone, where interest rates hit 3.75% last week and are likely to rise to at least 4% this year. 

  Eastern Europeans with historically volatile currencies have also recently embraced the franc. Hungarian households held about 6.6 billion euros of Swiss-franc debt last December, a jump of 87% from 2005. 

  Much as Switzerland's central bankers might like to raise interest rates further to make the carry trade less attractive, they are limited in what they can do. The bank targets a medium-term inflation rate of 2%, and inflation is at zero. 

  The bank's most recent forecasts, released yesterday, show inflation nearing the 2% target again in 2009, and markets expect another rate increase to 2.50% at the bank's next meeting in June. But with interest rates in many major economies high or rising as well, the Swiss franc looks unlikely to lose its allure for foreign borrowers anytime soon. 

  --- 

  Dollar Rises Against Yen 

  In Bumpy but Tight Trade 

 

  Meanwhile, in New York trading, the dollar was higher against the yen in a bumpy but range-bound session that shadowed U.S. equities and paid little attention to a spate of mixed, second-tier data. 

  But investors, nervous over U.S. subprime mortgage weakness and the U.S. economy in general, failed to make any big moves. 

  "There was limited participation as the choppy moves of the last couple days discouraged people from being overactive in currencies," said Sophia Drossos, currency strategist at Morgan Stanley. 

  Late in New York, the dollar was changing hands at 117.56 yen versus 117.07 yen late Wednesday, while the euro stood at $1.3237, up slightly from $1.3229. The euro traded at 155.59 yen versus 154.63 yen. The dollar was at 1.2179 Swiss francs versus 1.2158 francs, while sterling was at $1.9369, up from $1.9362. 

  --- 

  Dan Molinski 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  March 15, 2007 19:35 ET (23:35 GMT)

text:
Reserve Bank Of NZ Raises Cash Rate To 7.50%, Stays Hawkish

 

  WELLINGTON (Dow Jones)--The Reserve Bank of New Zealand on Thursday raised the Official Cash Rate to 7.50%, as widely expected, and left the door partly ajar for another hike as recent economic indicators show a clear pick-up in domestic demand. 

  "Domestic inflation is projected to remain at high levels over the medium-term and is subject to considerable upside risk," RBNZ Governor Alan Bollard said in the March Monetary Policy Statement. 

  The central bank expects the headline consumer price index to "rise rapidly" in 2008 to the upper part of its 1%-3% target band. 

  Notably, Bollard said that depending on the persistance of the current domestic upturn, "further tightening may be required." 

  New Zealand's Official Cash Rate had been at 7.25% - the highest in the  industrialized world behind Iceland - since December 2005. 

  Bollard said the current policy tightening was aimed at reducing the risk of an unsustainable rebound in domestic activity - at the expense of a rebalancing of the local economy that has been underway since late 2005. 

  "Our concern is that the recent pick-up in housing and domestic demand may gain momentum, giving rise to a cyclical upturn at a time when resources are already very stretched," Bollard said. 

  He added that such an upturn would increase the prospect of a "more costly correction" in the country's current account deficit. 

  Thursday's decision was in line with economists' and market forecasts. Fifteen of 16 economists polled by Dow Jones Newswires had expected the RBNZ to raise rates by 25 basis points, while the Overnight Index Swap market had priced in an 86% chance of a hike. 

  The RBNZ raised interest rates nine times and by a total of 225 basis points between January 2004 and December 2005 to cool pricing pressures brought on by five years of robust economic growth. 

  While the pace of growth in New Zealand has been slowing since mid-2005, recent data have sent mixed signals on the health of the economy, with near-term inflation pressures abating, but housing and labor markets remaining stubbornly tight, retail spending resilient, and business confidence at multiyear highs. 

  New Zealand's on-year inflation eased to 2.6% in the fourth quarter from 3.5% in the third quarter to fall back within the RBNZ's 1%-3% target band. But domestic inflation, which excludes import prices, remains at an uncomfortably high 3.8%. 

  House price growth, a major concern for policymakers, moderated to 9% on year in January but failed to provide the clear slowdown sought by the central bank. 

  The RBNZ revised lower its short-term CPI forecasts to 1.9% for the first half of 2007 from its December forecast of 2.4%, and to 1.6% in the second half from 2.3%, due mainly to a higher New Zealand dollar exchange rate and lower gasoline prices. 

  However, inflation is expected to accelerate in 2008, hitting a peak of 2.7% in the first half of 2009. 

  "A return to a moderating trend in housing and domestic demand will be essential if we are to see a reduction in medium-term inflation pressures," Bollard said. 

  He noted the central bank continues to assess alternative measures to support the official cash rate, such as a tightening of tax rules on housing investment and changes to bank capital requirements to moderate the "amplifying effect of credit on the housing cycle."

DATA SNAP: Colombia Feb CPI +1.17% Vs +0.90% Consensus

 
     Consumer Price Index: (percentage increases, month-on-month) 
          Feb    Jan     Dec    Nov    Oct     Feb/06 
Forecast +0.90%  +0.65%  +0.17% +0.24%  +0.20%  +0.77% 
Actual   +1.17%  +0.77%  +0.23% +0.14%  -0.14%  +0.66% 
 

  By Diana Delgado 

  Of Dow Jones Newswires 

  BOGOTA (Dow Jones)--Colombian consumer prices advanced a higher-than-expected in February owing to a sharp hike in education costs and due to a strong increase in the food sector as dry and cold weather damaged crops, the national statistics department, known as DANE, said late Thursday. 

  The statistics department said consumer price index rose 1.17% in February, while a Dow Jones Newswires survey of nine economists had produced a median estimate of a 0.90% increase of the index. 

  Colombian consumer prices were up 5.25% in the 12-month period to February. 

  The sharpest advance in February came from the educational sector which accounts for 4.8% of the CPI measurement. With the start of the school year leading to higher tuition expenditure and books costs, prices in the sector surged 3.94%. 

  The closely watched food sector, which has a 30% weighting in the CPI, increased 2.11%, as prices of vegetables and fruits climbed sharply in February. 

  El Nino warm current in the Pacific Ocean has caused drought in several parts of the country and night frost in the region around Bogota over the past two months. 

  "The data is madness," said Cesar Tovar, analyst at the local unit of Stanford Group. "The market was an expecting a maximum of 1%," he added. 

  Tovar expects yields on peso-denominated debt to increase Friday as a result of the higher-than-expected inflation figure. 

  He added that the data could comprise this year's central bank's target range of 3.5%-4.5%. 

  The central bank may be inclined to keep increasing rates at a faster pace as a result of the data, Tovar added. 

  On Friday, the monetary authority decided to hike its benchmark interest rate to 8% from 7.75% to tame rising inflation pressures. That was the eighth time the central bank has raised its benchmark rate since last April, when it stood at 6%. 

  Alberto Ramos, senior economist at Goldman Sachs, said in a report Friday that if the Colombian economy doesn't show signs of cooling off, the bank could increase rates to as high as 9%. 

  Colombian inflation rose 4.48% in 2006, in line with last year's target range of 4% to 5%.

text:
CHINA WATCH: Rate Hike Shows Beijing Favoring Market Tactics

 
   By Rick Carew 
 
   A Dow Jones Newswires Column 
 

  BEIJING (Dow Jones)--China's efforts to tame resurgent lending and investment won't stop at Saturday's interest rate hike and the central bank could soon back up its tightening with a second rate increase in coming months, economists said. 

  By raising interest rates, the central bank has put market-based tools back at the forefront of its battle against economic overheating. Most economists expect inflation, investment and other data in coming months to show economic growth momentum remains strong, encouraging further tightening. 

  Still, the People's Bank of China is unlikely to let up on other tightening measures, including bill sales, higher bank reserves requirements and administrative steps aimed at soaking up excess liquidity. The broad package of measures won't likely include a formal widening of the yuan's daily trading band against the U.S. dollar although the Chinese currency's appreciation trend could accelerate, economists said. 

  China's monetary policy, said Goldman Sachs analyst Hong Liang, is still "far from where the neutral policy stance should be" and the yuan's rise so far, including initial revaluation, isn't enough for China to regain monetary policy independence. 

  She expects another 27 basis-point rate rise in June or July, and a 7% rise in the yuan against the U.S. dollar over the next 12 months. 

  "The symmetric hike suggests the PBOC no longer considers it necessary to protect banks' margins," said ING, adding it regards rate hikes as "data-driven, especially data on loan growth."   "We forecast another 27-basis-point hike in lending and deposit rates in 4Q 2007 and one 50 basis-point hike in the reserve requirement every quarter for the next couple of years." 

  The central bank increased banks' reserves requirements twice so far this year, hiking the ratio by 50 basis points each time. 

  The stock market initially took a hit opening sharply lower. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index opened down 2.3% at 2864.26 and the Shenzhen Composite Index opened down 2.8% at 753.08. But within the hour the indexes turned around, rising steadily with large capitalization banks leading the path. The Shanghai index was up 2.5% at 3003.98 by midday and the Shenzhen index was up 1.1% at 782.88. 

  The U.S. dollar fell to CNY7.7350 midday on the over-the-counter market versus CNY7.7360 on Friday after the yuan was set at its strongest-ever level versus the dollar, CNY7.7351, in the central bank's central parity. China's bond prices also edged lower, and could continue to fall in coming weeks. The government bond index on the Shanghai exchange was at 111.71 at midday, down from Friday's close of  111.83, but also up from a morning low of 111.50. 

  Saturday's well-flagged rate increase announcement came after a string of strong data in recent weeks, with the most recent showing capital investment continued to increase strongly. China's urban fixed-asset investment in January and February rose 23.4% from the same period last year, faster than the average 21.8% forecast of seven economists surveyed by Dow Jones Newswires and is an acceleration from December's FAI growth rate of 13.8%. 

  Although inflation remains within the central bank's under-3% target, PBOC Governor Zhou Xiaochuan reportedly said Monday that he's more concerned about the trend. 

  China's consumer price index rose 2.7% in February from a year earlier, picking up from the 2.2% rise in January. In the first two months of the year, CPI rose 2.4% from the same period last year. 

  Economists expect rate hikes and a faster pace of yuan appreciation this year to overshadow stricter investment approval and control measures that have dominated the past tightening cycle. 

  The primary reason: China's huge and widening trade surplus. The gap between exports and imports rose 74% to $177.5 billion last year. The most recent data shows that hasn't eased as February's surplus hit US$23.76 billion widely outdoing the expected $8.3 billion surplus. 

  "It should have become clear by now for Chinese policy makers that each time domestic investment got hit hard by policy tightening, China's trade surplus would surge," said Goldman Sachs in a note. 

  That could mean that China's other major economic planning agency, the National Development and Reform Commission, may play a smaller role in this round of tightening as Beijing fears tightening investment will depress the imports it wants to increase to close the trade gap. 

  The shift would also allow policy makers to test the ability of China's deepening financial markets' ability to respond to market-based controls. 

  China's economic planning agency may have also played a larger role last year as it was the start of a five-year planning period, where local governments set investment targets and start new major outlays.

PREVIEW:Indonesia Mar Inflation Milder; Feb Trade Surplus Up

 

  By I Made Sentana 

  OF DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 

 

  JAKARTA (Dow Jones)--Indonesia's inflation rate likely decelerated this month as the government managed to tame basic food prices, while stronger global commodity prices probably supported a trade surplus last month, analysts said. 

  Market-watchers will scrutinize the inflation and trade data more closely than usual as the central bank is seen as being at a crossroads on its rate policy. The Central Statistics Bureau is due to issue both sets of data around 0630 GMT Monday. 

  The average forecast of a Dow Jones Newswires survey of regional economists is for the Consumer Price Index to have risen 0.23% on month in March and 6.46% on year. Those projections compare with a rise of 0.62% on month and 6.30% on year in February. 

  The expected higher on-year inflation rate is due to a low base. 

  "We expect to see a moderate level of inflation in March...as the prices of rice and sugar have been stable with a slight decline (in) the last week of the month," said Anton Gunawan, an economist with Citigroup in Jakarta. 

  On the trade front, the country's performance likely continued to be robust on the back of high prices and strong demand for oil, gas and commodities exports, analysts said. 

  Still, the trade surplus is projected to have edged up only slightly to $3.13 billion from $3.11 billion in January, the survey showed. 

  Exports are expected to have increased 13.05% on year in February, while imports are forecast to have risen 15.34%. In January, Indonesia's exports were $8.35 billion and imports $5.24 billion. 

  Given the likely inflation and trade data, four economists called for a 25-basis point cut in Bank Indonesia's policy rate when the central bank meets next. If Bank Indonesia keeps the rate unchanged, it will mark the second such pause since monetary policy easing began in May last year. 

  Bank Indonesia's Board of Governors will decide on possible adjustments to the benchmark rate, now at 9.00%, on April 5.

Barron's(4/9) Other Voices: Golden Rules For Growing Economies

   (From BARRON'S) 
   By Jack White and Doug Ramsey 

  How can we explain the economic miracles of the last 40 years? Why have some nations prospered and others not? 

  India was positioned for the new world of outsourcing because so many Indians inherited the language of Shakespeare from the British Raj. 

  Japan's vertical, soup-to-nuts zaibatsu, or conglomerates, were well equipped to compete in export markets. 

  South Korea's early years of benevolent but undemocratic rule allowed the country to invest heavily inhigh-tech industries that would have foundered in a less-ordered economy. 

  Ireland turned its relative poverty into a prime asset, since it could be the European Community's low-wage magnet for international manufacturers. 

  These widely accepted explanations of economic success are mostly accidents of geography or history. 

  If speaking English were a guarantee of economic success, many former British colonies -- such as Malawi and Tanzania -- would not currently rank among the poorest nations in the world. 

  Greece succeeded Ireland as the poor man of today's European Union, but a flood of investment never materialized there. 

  If government intervention could ensure economic success, most Third World nations would no longer need to be international beggars to stay afloat. 

  And if democracy were the acid test of financial bounty, communist China would not be today's greatest economic turnaround story. 

  Economic miracles depend on three old-fashioned rules that also apply to career and business success. 

 

  -- Do it differently and do it better. 

 

  Whether companies are looking to gain market share or nations are aiming to boost gross domestic product, they need strategies that are both different and better. 

  Take South Korea. Through the 1980s, the country successfully modeled its economy on that of another resource-poor neighbor, Japan. With its cheaper labor, Korea slowly took heavy industries away from Japan-shipbuilding and steel, for example. 

  But Korea's greatest success dates back to the early 1990s, when the country finally stopped mimicking Japan and decided that it had the wherewithal to leap ahead of its neighbor and, indeed, most of the world. 

  With a combination of moral persuasion as well as judicious doses of government investment, Korea Inc. made a bold bid to become one of the world's first knowledge economies. 

  Understanding the importance of connectivity in an R&D-based economy, Korea resolved to make high-speed Internet access available to all Koreans, becoming the world leader in broadband penetration within five years. The country is doing the same with wireless broadband. 

  In retrospect, an important milestone was Korea's decision to adopt a little-known digital wireless technology called code-division multiple access, developed by a then-small San Diego company called Qualcomm. CDMA is a spread-spectrum technology that uses digital coding to allow many more wireless-phone calls to share the same bandwidth -- greatly increasing capacity and reducing costs. 

  By focusing on a new wireless standard rather than the entrenched system used primarily in Europe, Korean manufacturers could address their own market, and obtain a pole position in the U.S. cellular market. If you use a Samsung or LG phone today, it is because of a decision to do it differently and do it better made in Korea nearly 20 years ago. 

 

  -- Accept change, don't reject it. 

 

  Volumes have been written about how to master change, and about companies that have failed to do so. To its peril, Lucent was slow to make the transition from analog to digital technology. Many U.S. manufacturers failed to wake up to the fact of globalization until it was too late. 

  The Internet and broadband wireless are revolutionizing the information infrastructure and the way products are distributed and sold, and any company that fails to adapt to the new realities is likely to be left behind. 

  So what happens when it is an entire country that must accept change? 

  Recognizing that its economy was stymied by the failures of socialism, China opted for a different path. It instigated a parallel, free-market economy that would gradually become untethered from the political apparatus of the communist state. 

  The reforms began in 1979, a full decade before the fall of the Soviet Union. The ensuing boom proved that a 5,000-year-old country could turn on a dime if its mandarins largely stayed out of the market's way. 

  Within the global economy, China used its economies of scale to capture entire industries where its cheap labor gave it an advantage, while rotating its earnings into high-end technology industries that could compete head-on with the best in the West. 

  Of course, acceptance of change is, of itself, no guarantee of success. Unlike China, Russia embraced wholesale political as well as economic change almost overnight, but the ensuing free-for-all made a mockery of both democracy and free markets. A few "oligarchs" prospered, but the Russian economy took a decade to recover from the shock to its system. 

  Today's seeming health of the Russian economy stems from one of those accidents of geography: plentiful oil reserves. But as oil prices decline, so will Russia's economy. So it's not just accepting change, but how nations embrace change that makes the difference. 

 

  -- Educate your citizens. 

 

  Like the old adage about the importance of location in retailing, education is of paramount importance to every economy. Japan, Korea, Singapore -- indeed all the so-called 'tiger' economies of Asia --  stressed the importance of literacy and invested heavily in education long before their economies took off. 

  The rapid ascent of India and China in recent years, in large measure, is due to their ability to bring masses of literate, numerate workers into high-tech industries that depend increasingly on research and development for growth. 

  China and the U.S. awarded roughly the same number of undergraduate engineering degrees in 1986; since then, U.S. degrees have steeply declined, to 60,000 a year -- and many of these are awarded to foreign-born students -- while China is producing more than 250,000 a year. As part of its plan to become a developed nation by 2015, India has plans to educate more than 4 million engineers annually. 

  Increasingly, the call-center jobs for U.S. consumer-products companies outsourced to Bangalore are making opportunities for research and development jobs. 

  High-tech multinationals recognize that innovation can happen anywhere, as long as the workforce is highly trained and has good incentives. This comes as no surprise to the Indians, or Chinese, or Japanese, who watched the great clusters of innovation in the United States grow up in Silicon Valley, San Diego, Chicago, Boston, Research Triangle, Seattle and other places, always with good access to major universities. 

  Even in labor-intensive sectors where R&D is not as big a factor, skilled workers can play a critical role in devising new quality-of-service methods and improvements in manufacturing. A culture of education permeates societies where economic miracles have occurred. 

  Economic miracles do happen, but there is nothing miraculous about them. Countries from China to Chile, India to Ireland, went back to basics and followed a few golden rules to succeed. They now welcome change and count on knowledge workers and innovation to keep their economies growing. 

  The United States can and must do the same. 

  --- 

  Jack White was a pioneer in the discount stock-brokerage industry, and Doug Ramsey is director of communications for the California Institute for Telecommunications and Information Technology at UC/San Diego.

WSJ(4/28) Abreast Of The Market: Microsoft, GE, 3M Rise Fri

   (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL) 
   By Karen Talley 

  As the Dow Jones Industrial Average extended its record run to a third straight session Friday, the might was provided by Microsoft, General Electric and 3M. 

  The Dow industrials rose 15.44 points to 13120.94, passing Thursday's record of 13105.5. The Dow got as high as 13148 during the session, exceeding the record intraday peak of 13132.8 it put in the day before. 

  The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 2.75 to 2557.21. While the Dow is delivering all-time highs, the Nasdaq Composite remains well off its record peak of 5048.62, hit seven years ago. 

  The Nasdaq did, however, slip past the 50%-there mark Tuesday, by closing at 2524.54. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index shed 1.18 to 1494.07. 

  For the week, both the Dow and Nasdaq gained 1.2%; the S&P 500 gained 0.7%. 

  Microsoft (Nasdaq) rose $1.02, or 3.5%, to $30.12, the Dow's best percentage gainer. The software titan posted a 65% jump in fiscal third-quarter earnings and issued an upbeat forecast for the next year, reaping dividends from the broad rollout of its long-delayed Windows Vista operating system. For the week, Microsoft advanced 3.8%. 

  GE gained 1, or 2.8%, to 36.84. Citigroup called on the conglomerate to spin off three units, saying the company's size and complexity are working against investor interest in the stock and has eroded value. 

  3M rose 1.10, or 1.4%, to 81.55, adding to Thursday's 4.5% advance when the maker of Post-It Notes and Scotch tape reported a 52% surge in first-quarter earnings. For the week, 3M advanced 4.9%. 

  International Business Machines added 27 cents to 101.17, remaining above the 100 level it topped earlier in the week after boosting its stock-buyback plan by as much as $15 billion and approving a 33% quarterly dividend increase. For the week, IBM rose 7%. 

  Cummins leapt 10.15, or 12%, to 96.14. The industrial manufacturer posted a 6% increase in first-quarter earnings and increased full-year guidance well beyond Wall Street's expectations. Friday's advance was the latest in a run that has raised the stock 63% this year. 

  UAL (Nasdaq) fell 2.91, or 8%, to 34.04; American Airlines parent AMR lost 1.34, or 4.8%, to 26.35; and Continental Airlines dropped 2.53, or 6.5%, to 36.25. Air carriers struggled as the price of oil surged by 2.2% a barrel and J.P. Morgan Securities cut ratings for six airline stocks. 

  Omnicare lost 6.42, or 16%, to 34.90, the NYSE's biggest percentage decliner. The nursing-home pharmacy company reported a 19% drop in first-quarter profit, hurt by lower prices on generic drugs, and cut its forecast for 2007 earnings. 

  Varian Semiconductor Equipment Associates jumped 13, or 23%, to 70, the second best Nasdaq percentage gainer. Fiscal second-quarter net income more than doubled to $38.4 million, or 69 cents a share, and the chip-equipment producer said revenue increased 42% to $241.8 million. 

  Baidu.com's American depositary receipts rose 15.20, or 14%, to 124.57 on the Nasdaq. China's Internet-search leader posted first-quarter net earnings of $11.1 million, or 32 cents a share, vastly up from a year earlier. 

  Burger King gained 73 cents, or 3.2%, to 23.45, benefiting from restaurant expansion and a lower tax rate, reversed a year-earlier loss and posted better-than-expected fiscal third-quarter earnings.

INTERVIEW: Ex-MOF Sakakibara: G7 Unlikely To Focus On Yen

 
   By Takashi Nakamichi 
   OF DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  TOKYO (Dow Jones)--The yen is "abnormally" weak against other major currencies, but Group of Seven finance chiefs aren't likely to focus on the yen when they meet in Washington later this month, a former top Japanese currency official said Tuesday. 

  That is because the yen's weakness is due to Japan's monetary policy settings and G7 officials don't usually discuss a country's domestic policy, he said. 

  "The cause of the yen's weakness is clear - that is, Japan's low interest rates," Eisuke Sakakibara told Dow Jones Newswires in an interview. "It isn't a matter of foreign exchange. It is an issue of monetary policy. Meddling in each other's monetary policy is usually avoided (by G7 officials). In that sense, (the yen) probably won't become an openly debated topic." 

  Sakakibara served as vice finance minister for international affairs between 1997-1999 and was known as Mr Yen for his ability to move the exchange rate of the currency with his comments. He currently is director of Waseda University's Indian economic studies institute. 

  His comments are in line with currency traders' expectations that the Japanese currency will take a back seat to other issues at the coming G7 talks because the dollar and the euro have slowed their pace of appreciation versus the yen after a global stock market selloff and temporary yen surges in late February and early March. 

  Still, G7 officials don't all agree with Sakakibara. 

  Japanese Finance Minister Koji Omi said earlier Tuesday that he doubts G7 officials will discuss the yen, but his Canadian counterpart, Jim Flaherty, said Monday that he "wouldn't be surprised if (the yen's exchange rate) was the subject of some discussion." 

  Finance ministers and central bank chiefs from the U.S., Japan, Germany, England, France, Italy and Canada will meet in Washington, D.C. on April 13. 

  G7 May Warn Vs Yen-Carry Trades Again 

  Sakakibara said that while G7 representatives may skirt around the yen's value, they will likely repeat their warning made in February about yen-carry trades, a risky investment strategy that many analysts blame for the yen's persistent weakness. 

  "The markets are continuing carry trades," he said. "There's no question that the yen is abnormally weak." 

  For example, the euro's "fair value" against the yen is Y110.00 to Y115.00 based on Japan's trade competitiveness and other factors, said Sakakibara. That is well below the common European currency's current level of Y158.34. 

  As for the dollar-yen exchange rate, he said that given Japan's international competitiveness, the country's manufacturers "can easily live with rates of around Y100.00 to Y110.00." 

  "For the time being", however, the greenback will hug a range of Y115.00 to Y120.00, underpinned by Japanese investors' appetite for overseas assets that pay higher returns than those at home, he said. 

  At 1000 GMT Tuesday, the dollar was quoted at Y118.60. 

 
   Bank of Japan May Raise Interest Rates Next Month 
 

  Turning to Japan's monetary policy, Sakakibara said the Bank of Japan may increase interest rates in May because the country's economy is in its "best condition", growing at a price-adjusted annual pace of around 2.5% while prices are stable. 

  "I think a May rate hike is possible," he said. 

  "To be sure, things would evolve differently if the (Japanese) economy slipped into a downtrend or stock prices make a nosedive," he said. "But as long as the current economic conditions are maintained, a May hike would be nothing strange." 

  Sakakibara's prediction is at odds with consensus that the central bank will stand pat until after parliamentary elections in July. 

  "The markets have been wrong recently," forecasting a rate hike in January, when the bank stayed put, while anticipating no tightening in February, when the bank lifted rates by a quarter percentage point to 0.50%, he said. "It may be wise not to put your faith on the markets." 

  Sakakibara himself urged the BOJ to "normalize" Japan's "unusually low interest rates" and stop fueling yen-carry trades by pumping money into the world's money markets. 

  "There're various opinions (on what levels constitute normal policy rates in Japan), but ... they may be around 2.0%," he said. The U.S. policy rate is 5.25%, while the rate in Europe is 3.75%, "but growth rates of the U.S. economy and the European economy are almost the same as Japan's." 

  He played down Japan's lack of inflation, which he attributed to slow wage growth and fierce business competition in Japan - developments that are "positive things" for the economy. 

  "It doesn't make sense for Japanese real interest rates to stay near zero." 

 
   -By Takashi Nakamichi, Dow Jones Newswires; 813-5255-2929; takashi.nakamichi@dowjones.com

3rd UPDATE: Kimberly Clark 1Q Net Up 64% On Higher Sales

 

  (Adds comments from a conference call and other details.) 

 
   By Anjali Cordeiro 
   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Kimberly-Clark Corp. (KMB) reported a 64% increase in its first-quarter profit, propelled by growth in its North American personal care business, strength in emerging markets and higher prices for some of its products. 

  The company, which sells brands like Kleenex tissues and Huggies diapers, continues to face inflationary pressures due to an escalation in fiber costs. Kimberly Clark's first-quarter earnings exceeded analysts' expectations, but the company left its forecast for the year unchanged due to commodity cost pressures. The lower end of the company's guidance range for the year is below Wall Street's average estimate. The stock was recently down $1.04, or 1.4%, to $70.90. 

  Like most other consumer-product companies Kimberly-Clark has been grappling with higher commodity prices and has been forced to prune costs in order to keep increasing profits. In July 2005, the company announced a cost reduction plan that would streamline its manufacturing and administrative operations. The company said it continues to execute this plan and is in a good position to meet or exceed its target to save $75 million to $100 million for the first year. 

  The Irving, Texas, maker of personal-care and health-care products earned $452 million, or 98 cents a share, compared with $275.1 million, or 60 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. 

  Excluding items related to the company's ongoing restructuring, earnings rose to $1.03 a share from 93 cents a share a year earlier. 

  Sales for the first quarter totaled $4.39 billion, up from $4.07 billion a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial, on average, expected the company to earn $1.01 a share in the latest period on revenue of $4.27 billion. 

  "Overall I think they are making small steps in the right direction," said A.G. Edwards analyst Jason Gere. The company's personal-care business is doing extremely well, he said. 

  Still, Gere said he found Kimberly-Clark's guidance for the full year somewhat conservative. "I don't blame them - fiber costs are still going up," said Gere. 

  JPMorgan analyst John Faucher wrote that sales volumes  in the company's consumer tissue segment - which were down 2% - came in below his expectations. 

  In developing and emerging markets, sales increased 16%. Kimberly-Clark said sales growth was particularly strong in Latin America, China and Russia. 

  Sales of personal-care products, which also include Kotex feminine care items, increased 11% in the quarter to $1.8 billion. Sales of Huggies diapers, baby wipes and Pull-Ups training pants were strong. 

  Sales of consumer tissue products, such as Kleenex and Scott bathroom tissue, grew 6.4% to $1.59 billion. 

  Kimberly-Clark had recently said it expects first-quarter adjusted earnings to be at or slightly above the high end of its previous guidance of 99 cents to $1.01 a share. 

  Kimberly-Clark expects adjusted earnings for the second quarter of $1.01 to $1.03 a share. For 2007, the company projects adjusted earnings of $4.10 to $4.20 a share. On average, Wall Street is expecting second-quarter earnings of $1.02 a share and full-year earnings of $4.20 a share. 

  "We also remain focused on cutting costs although the industry experts are predicting that fiber costs will come down later this year," Chief Executive Thomas Falk said in a conference call. "We'll continue to monitor input costs and the competitive environment carefully to see if any other actions are required." 

  Kimberly-Clark was a client of A.G. Edwards and JP Morgan in the past 12 months.

Romania Ctrl Bk Cuts 2007 CPI Forecast To 3.7%-Mediafax -2-

 

  The bank is sticking to its previous forecast of an acceleration in annual inflation to 4.2% in 2008, he told a news conference. Inflation was 4.87% in 2006. 

  Romanian inflation slowed to 3.66% on the year in March from 3.87% in February, the lowest annual rate since records began in 1990 after the fall of the Communist regime. 

  The latest data showed the country's consumer price index rose 0.31% in the quarter, down considerably from the 1.48% increase in the first three months of 2006. 

  "In the first quarter of the year, the disinflation process continued at a higher pace than our expectations," Isarescu said. 

  The slowdown in inflation was driven by an appreciation of the Romanian currency, a drop in price of fuel and some other items, such as eggs and fruit, and the elimination of customs taxes with European Union countries, he said. 

  The central bank has set an inflation target of 3% to 5% percent in 2007 and 2.8% to 4.8% in 2008.

text:
WSJ(5/16) Milk Prices Pressure Food Firms

   (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL) 
   By Anjali Cordeiro 

  An ethanol-fueled rally and strong global demand for corn have pushed milk prices higher, creating another pressure on already hamstrung food companies. 

  Companies that churn out chocolates, yogurt, ice cream and cheese have begun to feel the heat, prompting them to warn Wall Street of lower earnings and ponder price increases. 

  Hershey Co. last week tempered its guidance for the year because of higher costs for milk. Dean Foods Co., which makes ice cream, Horizon organic milk and yogurt, earlier this month warned it would only meet the lower end of a previous forecast. 

  Dean Foods' stock price is off 25% so far this year, while Hershey's stock is up 5%. 

  "We are increasingly concerned about rapidly rising raw-milk prices and industry estimates for continued increases through the balance of the year," Dean Foods Chief Executive Gregg Engles told analysts and investors in a conference call in early May. 

  A confluence of factors are propelling dairy prices higher. Prices for corn, which is used in the production of ethanol, have been rising because of a surge in demand for biofuel. The higher prices for corn, coupled with higher costs for soybeans and hay, have been making livestock feed more expensive. 

  There also are other forces in play. According to Chris Galen, spokesman for the National Milk Producers Federation, a number of food companies have been looking to buy milk produced without the use of the artificial bovine growth hormones known as RVST. While use of those hormones can help increase productivity, a drop in usage crimps supply, he said. 

  At the same time, demand for dairy products has been strong internationally because of a weaker dollar, strong demand from fast-growing Asian economies and a slowdown in the dairy industries of Australia and New Zealand, Mr. Galen said. 

  "Demand is going to be very strong globally and that is going to push market prices higher this year," said Kenneth Bailey, associate professor for agricultural economics at Pennsylvania State University. 

  Class III milk futures, which represent milk used in cheddar cheese, have risen roughly 32% on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange so far this year. Class IV milk futures, which represent milk used to make butter and nonfat dry milk, are up about 26%. 

  Food companies have been grappling with a variety of inflationary pressures. Energy prices are off last year's peak, but oil remains above $60 a barrel. Most food companies have to raise prices for their products in order to fight the cost pressures. Prices for grains like wheat have increased in tandem with corn. 

  Kraft Foods Inc. said it increased prices earlier this year on some of its dairy-based products because of rising commodity costs. The company -- whose stable of brands includes Philadelphia cream cheese and Kraft singles -- said it continues to monitor the market, and will adjust its prices accordingly. 

  Raising prices can be a difficult decision for food companies like Kraft, which are facing competition from cheaper private-label, or store, brands, said Morningstar analyst Greggory Warren. Still, he added that the rise in a commodity such as milk tends to be felt by private-label producers too. 

  "If everyone is feeling pinched, it's easier to get pricing," Mr. Warren said. "In this case it is probably likely everyone will be able to take some incremental pricing." 

  Food companies sometimes try hedging techniques to protect themselves against higher commodity prices. But commodity prices can be volatile and the hedging process complicated. 

  "We did a very small hedging operation with regard to dairy about 18 months ago, but we couldn't get sufficient interest from a counterparty [for it] to be significant for us," said Starbucks Corp. Chief Financial Officer Michael Casey on a conference call this month. The coffee chain has felt the impact of higher dairy costs, and has said its outlook for the year takes those pressures into consideration.

text:
Zimbabwe Pres Tells African Trade Bloc Seek Econ Independence

  NAIROBI (AP)--Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe, whose country is in a financial tailspin, told Africa's largest trading bloc Wednesday that the continent will achieve true economic independence by producing finished goods for sale to the rest of the world. 

  Mugabe spoke during the final day of a summit by the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa, which is trying to make it cheaper and easier to do business on an impoverished continent that is struggling to lure foreign investment. 

  "Because we are producers of primary products, the commodities we produce are not priced by us," Mugabe told leaders of the 20-nation bloc, known as COMESA. "They go to markets where they are priced for us." 

  Zimbabwe is struggling through its worst economic crisis since independence in 1980, with an inflation rate in the thousands. The problems have been blamed on corruption, mismanagement and the often-violent seizures of thousands of white-owned commercial farms ordered by Mugabe beginning in 2000 that disrupted the agriculture-based economy. 

  On Tuesday, COMESA endorsed a standard customs tax as part of a deal designed to make doing business in Africa more attractive to investors. The agreement is set to go into effect in 2008. 

  The deal calls for charging 10% tax on semi-processed products and 25% on finished goods being imported into most of COMESA's member countries - lower than the taxes in place in many African nations. But not all COMESA's 20 members were prepared to join quickly, despite endorsing the deal, and some may never take part. 

  Still, COMESA's outgoing chairman, President Ismael Omar Guelleh of Djibouti, said the union would lead to more foreign investment and "deeper integration into the world economy." 

  Established 12 years ago, COMESA represents about 390 million people and has an estimated gross domestic product of $200 billion. The value of trade within COMESA countries rose to $6.3 billion in 2005, from $4.5 billion in 2004, according to the Kenyan Trade and Industry Ministry. 

  COMESA has been a free trade area since 2000 but only 13 of its 20 members have signed on to the free trade area agreement. Other trade blocs, such as the five-nation East African Community, have had to negotiate exemptions to their customs unions to avoid hurting individual nations. 

  COMESA's member countries are Angola, Burundi, Comoros, Congo, Djibouti, Egypt, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya, Libya, Madagascar, Malawi, Mauritius, Rwanda, Seychelles, Sudan, Swaziland, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe. 

  Kenyan President Mwai Kibaki took over as chairman from Guelleh on Tuesday.

text:
UPDATE: Colombia Central Bank Ups Key Rate 25 BPs To 8.75%

 

  (Updates with comments from Central Bank govenrnor, finance minister) 

 

  BOGOTA (Dow Jones)--Colombia's Central Bank on Friday raised its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 8.75%, from 8.5%, in an expected move that was designed to reduce inflationary pressures. 

  "This decision was taken after taking into account April's inflation, which came in higher than expected," the monetary policy committee said in a statement after its monthly meeting. "Moreover demand and credit keep showing strong growth." 

  Ten out of 12 economists polled by Dow Jones Newswires before the decision had said they expected a 25-basis-point increase. 

  Strong demand for consumer goods accentuated by robust economic growth has put strong upward pressure on inflation. Twelve-month rolling inflation reached 6.26% at the end of April, well above the central bank's target for 2007 of between 3.5% and 4.5%. The bank reiterated at Friday's meeting that it is maintaining the same target. 

  "Inflation is clearly outside the target and inflation expectations are deteriorating fast," Goldman Sachs said in a research report before the decision. 

  JPMorgan said it expects another rate hike in June and wouldn't rule out further hikes if inflation and inflationary expectations don't show signs of easing by the end of June. 

  Barclays Capital sees a similar hike at the bank's June meeting, "after which we expect the central bank to pause," it said. "The April spike in inflation to 6.26% makes a total of 50 basis points in hikes in the short term very likely," Barclays said. "Nonetheless, the worst of the inflation surprises is likely behind us." 

  All three banks had forecasted a 25-basis-point increase. 

  Speaking after the decision, central bank governor Jose Dario Uribe said the 275 basis points of rate hikes since April 2006 will soon start to quell price pressures. 

  Uribe urged the central government to reduce spending, which would also help curb inflation. "I reiterate that an austere fiscal policy will improve the efficiency of the Colombian economy," Uribe said. 

  Finance Minister Oscar Ivan Zuluaga said the government expects to end the year with total debt of 147 trillion Colombian pesos ($74.2 billion), unchanged from last year. "Our spending is not increasing," Zuluaga said. 

  The central bank, meanwhile, said it believes measures it introduced May 6 will begin to take effect and contribute to promoting its monetary policy. The bank imposed higher reserve requirements on bank deposits and required 40% of the proceeds from foreign loans to be deposited with the Central Bank for six months without interest. The bank also limited the amounts banks and brokerages can invest in derivatives and hedging operations. 

  "Next week, we will evaluate how the measures have slowed down the flow of capital inflows," Zuluaga added. 

  But the bank didn't take any steps to try to influence the currency at Friday's meeting. Rising interest rates, coupled with strong export revenue and heavy foreign direct investment, have driven the peso higher against the U.S. dollar, and some analysts had expected action to offset Friday's interest rate hike. 

  Zuluaga, who sits on the Central Bank board, stressed the sharp appreciation comes from foreign direct investment and not from short-term portfolio investments. 

  Late Friday, the Colombian peso was stronger against the U.S. dollar in New York trading, at COP1,979 per U.S. dollar, from COP1,985 earlier. The currency has gained around 13% against the dollar so far this year. 

  The sharp appreciation of the peso has already left 15,000 people without jobs in the textile industry and a 6,000 jobs in the flower industry, according to Zuluaga. 

  Zuluaga said the government will announce a subsidy package to help exporters early next week. 

 

  -By Diana Delgado, Dow Jones Newswires; 57-1-600-1980; diana.delgado@dowjones.com (Matthew Cowley in New York contributed to this report.) 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
US Stocks Rise On Tame Inflation Data; GM, McDonald's Gain

 
   By Joanna Ossinger 
   Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL ONLINE 
 

  Stocks surged Tuesday amid tame inflation data that bolstered Wall Street's hopes for an interest-rate cut in the near future. 

  The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 122 to 13469. The S&P 500 added 9 to 1512, and the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 8 to 2554. 

  Advancers outnumbered decliners on the NYSE by more than two to one. 

  "I read [the CPI data] as very bullish for the economy," said Timothy Rogers, chief economist at Briefing.com. "I suspect that the reasons for the Fed to tighten [interest rates] have largely disappeared." 

  Early Tuesday, the Labor Department said the April consumer price index rose 0.4%, but the core CPI, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, advanced just 0.2%. The data, which largely matched Wall Street forecasts for a 0.5% CPI increase and 0.2% core rise, suggest inflation remains tame. That reinforced a growing belief among investors that Federal Reserve policy makers will cut rates later this year; Rogers expects a quarter-point drop in the fourth quarter. 

  Lower interest rates make borrowing cheaper and spur investment, so hopes for lower rates tend to boost stocks. However, they can also fuel inflation, which until recently was outside of the Fed's comfort zone. Now that price growth seems to have slowed, the Fed may feel freer to soften its vigilant stance on inflation, and perhaps even cut rates. 

  The Dow went on a tear after the CPI data came out, bolstered by a gain of 3.7% from General Motors and a 2.2% rise from McDonald's, among others. Amid strong global growth, Wall Street is starting to see large-cap companies as more attractive than small caps, a trend magnified in recent days by a mature bull run that has investors buying into the safety of blue chips. Tuesday midday, 25 of 30 Dow components were trading higher. 

  Wal-Mart reported an 8.1% increase in first-quarter net income amid gains abroad and at its Sam's Club chain, even as its namesake stores saw lower same-store sales, or sales in stores open a year or more. The world's largest retailer said second-quarter earnings may miss analysts' expectations. Wal-Mart shares fell 0.2%. 

  Home Depot's profit fell 30% in the first quarter, as the No. 1 U.S. home-improvement retailer continued to struggle amid a weak housing demand. Revenue fell 0.6% to $21.59 billion from $21.46 billion a year earlier and same-store sales, or sales at stores open at least a year, dropped 7.6%. Home Depot shares fell 0.3%. 

  Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke spoke about credit derivatives Tuesday at the Atlanta Fed's financial markets conference. He didn't address the economy or monetary policy. 

  DaimlerChrysler said its net income more than doubled, as the Mercedes group swung to a profit, even as its U.S. unit saw its losses widen on a restructuring plan. The stock added 2.6%. 

  Thomson and Reuters Group agreed on terms for a merger valued at more than $17 billion in cash and stock, cinching a deal that the two news and data providers outlined earlier this month. Reuters's shares rose 4.2%. 

  Amgen shares fell 5.1% after the government's Medicare program proposed limiting payments for the use of anti-anemia drugs based on safety concerns. 

  Agilent Technologies rose 4.5% after its current quarter earnings per share and revenue outlook topped analyst estimates. 

  Crude-oil futures rose 52 cents to $62.98 a barrel. 

 
   In major market action: 
 

  Stocks rose. On the New York Stock Exchange Tuesday,2,180 stocks gained and 922 declined, on volume of 637 million shares traded on the exchange. 

  Bonds fell. The 10-year Treasury note was down 1/32, or 31.25 cents for every $1,000 invested, yielding 4.704% Tuesday. The 30-year bond fell 1/32, yielding 4.871%. 

  The dollar weakened. The euro traded at $1.3605 from $1.3544 late Monday, while the dollar was at 120.19 yen from 120.35 yen.

text:
Russian Fin Min Kudrin Sees 2007 GDP Up 6.5% - 6.7%

 

  SAINT PETERSBURG (Dow Jones)-Russia's gross domestic product should grow 6.5% to 6.7% in 2007, Finance Minister  Alexei Kudrin told journalists Saturday. 

  This is about 0.5% higher than the government's initial forecasts, Kudrin said at an economic forum. 

  He also said the the country will meet also meet the targeted rate of a rise of no more than 8% in consumer prices. 

  He said, however, that the massive net capital inflows are causing a headache for the Central Bank's and government's monetary policy. 

  "We have to maneuver among several options here and limit the overall monetary mass on the market," Kudrin said. One of the options, already exercised by the bank was the increase in minimum reserve requirements in the banking system, starting July 1. 

  " If these instruments appear insufficient then the Central Bank has to increase the exchange rate," Kudrin said. 

  He predicted that by the year's end, capital inflows, which have become a cardinal factor in monetary conditions since the abolition of capital controls 12 months ago, will exceed $70 billion this year. Earlier in the day, Deputy Prime Minister Sergei Naryshkin put the figure as high as $90 billion. 

  Kudrin said the second half of the year should see much lower net capital inflows, but he also warned that "it depends on agreements in the private sector." 

  Separately, Kudrin reiterated that there are no plans of investing the Stabilization Fund money on the stock exchange market. 

  "This would create a bubble on the market that would keep growing without proportion," Kudrin said.

Turkey Finance Minister Unhappy With Strength Of New Lira-IHA

 

  ESKISEHIR, Turkey (Dow Jones)--Turkish Finance Minister Kemal Unakitan said he isn't happy with the strength of the new Turkish lira, but added that the central bank is independent and controls monetary policy, the Ihlas news agency, or IHA, reported Monday. 

  "Actually, it doesn't make me happy to see the Turkish lira firming so much," Unakitan said during a meeting with businessmen Saturday. "The independence of the central bank makes it impossible for us to interfere." 

  "The new lira being this strong puts exporters in a difficult position while imports of intermediate goods increase, which leads the current account deficit to rise," he said. "In my opinion, it is not correct that the Turkish lira is so strong, but it's the central bank that directs monetary policy." 

  Exporters have criticized the ruling AK Party government in recent years for allowing the new lira to appreciate. Turkey is due to hold general elections July 22. 

  A spike in inflation last year triggered a 29% slide in the new lira against the dollar and led the central bank to raise interest rates by 425 basis points. The new lira is currently trading at TRY1.2880 to the dollar, about 4.5% stronger than it was in May 2006 before it slumped. 

  Unakitan said the government is supporting the central bank's fight against inflation by not raising liquidity in the market. 

  "We support fiscal discipline," he said. "We don't inject too much money into the markets. But after the elections, markets will see more liquidity."

text:
Eurobonds: CDS Indexes Wider On US Subprime, Data Worries

 

  By Michael Wilson 

  Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 

 

  LONDON (Dow Jones)--Spreads on the European credit-default swap iTraxx indexes widened early Tuesday due to more concern about the U.S. subprime mortgage market and upcoming data releases. 

  Spreads had tightened in recent days following high levels of volatility last week, but a deterioration in the ABX subprime derivatives index overnight signaled that worries over the U.S. subprime mortgage market are still present, pushing European credit spreads wider again. 

  "There was no conviction to the recent rally, and it now seems to have stalled," said a Dresdner Kleinwort analyst, who recommended investors take a defensive position. 

  The BBB portion of the ABX.HE 07-1 subprime derivatives index, which tracks credit derivatives written on subprime mortgages, lost four points Monday, hitting an all-time low of 45 cents. 

  Concerns over risky mortgage debt were exacerbated by two reports released Monday by ratings agency Fitch Ratings, highlighting the excessive use of leverage by credit hedge funds and the expected rise of defaults in the commercial-mortgage sector. 

  Unicredit said U.S. producer price index data, due at 1230 GMT, could also prove negative for credit, as an above-consensus result may feed fears that the rate of headline inflation is rising. 

  Continued high levels of inflation could prevent the Federal Reserve from lowering interest rates, dashing the hopes of investors who believe that a fall in house prices will be halted by a cut in the cost of borrowing. 

  The iTraxx Crossover index of 50 weaker-rated credits widened during the morning session to 285/286 basis points from 277/280 basis points at the open. The index widened significantly overnight, opening more than 10 basis points wider from its 267.5 basis points close Monday. 

  The Europe Main index of 125 investment-grade names also widened to 29.5/29.75 basis points from its 28/29 opening level. The index hit its widest point of 30 basis points early Tuesday, amid "good volumes of protection buying all morning," said a European credit strategist. 

  Single names moved slightly wider with the market Tuesday, but saw no real moves as worries about systemic risk grabbed the attention. 

  "All investment-grade single names are marked one to two basis points weaker, but all the concentration is on the indexes this morning," said a trader. 

  The primary market seems to be in wait-and-see mode given the recent market volatility. A rise in the level of risk-aversion means that investors are now demanding a higher premium to hold risk, which is driving up the cost of funding. 

  Late Monday, Russian state-controlled oil producer OAO Rosneft postponed its two-tranche Eurobond issue according to the deal's lead managers. 

  Rosneft had been preparing to issue up to $5 billion of debt to refinance recent acquisitions, and bankers familiar with the matter had said it wanted to issue $2 billion-equivalent of Eurobonds in separate tranches and currencies, with maturities of five and 10 years. 

  Rosneft is looking to refinance part of the $22 billion of debt it took on to buy most of the assets of OAO Yukos at the company's liquidation earlier this year.

Forex Focus: Euro Support May Grow As Oil Prices Rally

 

  By Nicholas Hastings 

  A DOW JONES NEWSWIRES COLUMN 

 

  LONDON (Dow Jones)--Expect the euro to keep on climbing against the dollar. 

  With oil prices rising, money supply growing and labor markets tightening, the European Central Bank's concern about inflation could step up a notch, even though current inflation levels in the euro zone remain subdued. 

  This is likely to contrast with the U.S. Federal Reserve. While the rise in crude prices will hardly encourage the Fed to relinquish its hawkish stance, the damage higher gasoline prices poses to U.S. growth prospects could mean that the U.S. central bank starts leaning towards easing rates again. 

  This likely shift in investor support in the euro's favor emerged at the end of last week as the price of crude futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange rallied over $70 a barrel for the first time in 10 months. 

  In itself, the rise may not be so remarkable, given other recent gyrations in the price of crude. But, this time round, analysts say that the rally is sustainable as it's being driven largely by a deterioration in U.S. refining  that will bring further tightness in the U.S. gasoline market.

text:
US MONEY WK AHEAD: Tsys May Gain More Support From Subprime

 

  (This article was originally published Friday) 

 
   By Laurence Norman 
   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--The usual summer calm looks set to be postponed at least another week in the Treasury market, with the 10-year yield falling through the key 5% level Friday and investors remaining very sensitive to developments in the troubled subprime mortgage market. 

  While growth data next week should remind investors that the U.S. economy bounced back in the second quarter, that may not be enough to subdue flight-to-quality buying which has knocked 15 basis points off the 10-year yield since Monday, and sent prices soaring. 

  Friday brought the sharpest Treasury gains, following Standard & Poor's announcement that it lowered the ratings on 14 European synthetic collateralized debt obligations, or CDO, tranches. The announcement helped widen risk premiums in credit markets and added to declines in stock markets and the dollar. The move was also strong enough to force the 10-year yield decisively below 5% and to its lowest level since early June. 

  Friday afternoon, the 10-year Treasury was up 19/32 for a 4.95% yield, while the long bond was up 28/32 for 5.06%. The two-year note was up 4/32 for 4.78%. 

  "The fundamentals are going to continue to take a backstage...unless there's some really good news" in next Friday's gross domestic product data, said George Goncalves, chief Treasury, TIPS and agency strategist at Morgan Stanley in New York. "Investors are in this risk reduction mode and so long as that's the case, I wouldn't want to stand in the way of the price action." 

  The market's focus on the impact of subprime - home loans to borrowers with poor credit histories - was given sharper focus this week by comments from Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke. While the Fed has consistently argued that the economic impact of the subprime market's struggles has so far been contained, Bernanke cited estimates to senators Thursday that suggested the subprime-related credit losses could amount to between $50 billion and $100 billion. Frequent speculation of subprime related losses at U.S. and overseas banks or hedge funds have kept investors jittery. 

  Goncalves said with the full picture unlikely to become clear for some time, the subprime story could continue to subdue Treasury yields - keeping them well below the Fed's 5.25% target funds rate. 

  "I think we'll stay at these richer levels next week," he said, adding that the yield curve should steepen as shorter-term Treasurys see the biggest bid. 

 
    Growth, Housing Data Top The Bill 
 

  For Andrew Richman, managing director at SunTrust Personal Asset Management with around $8 billion in fixed income assets under management, "there's certainly fear" that the subprime story could spread to the prime market and have a sharper impact on fixed income assets. 

  Given the jitters, he said the 10-year yield could easily fall toward 4.85% in the days ahead. However, he believes the subprime story will ultimately be contained and thinks Treasurys are likely settling into a 4.85%-5.25% range. 

  "Yields already don't look that attractive" at Friday's sub-5% levels. "We'd opportunistically take advantage" to sell when the 10-year yield falls to 4.85% and buy when it tops 5.20%, he said. 

  If anything will pressure Treasury prices lower and yields higher next week, it's likely to be the GDP data. The economy is expected to have expanded 3.2% in the second quarter, according to economists surveyed by Dow Jones Newswires. Annualized first quarter growth was 0.7%. 

  John Miller, head of funds management at Nuveen Asset Management, said the report should provide "a vote of confidence in the diversity and broad-based resilience of the economy." However, he acknowledged that with expectations for the number already high and some concerns that the economy's "momentum could be waning a little bit in the second half of the year," investors' reaction to the data could be subdued. 

  The other major data next week are housing numbers, with June existing home sales seen falling to an annualized 5.90 million from 5.99 million in May when it's reported Wednesday. On Thursday, new home sales are expected at an annualized 900,000 from 915,000 in May. 

  Again however, Miller said that with the weak housing story well absorbed by markets, the data will largely "reinforce concerns that are already out there." 

  Next week also sees several Treasury Department auctions, with the government selling $6 billion in reopened 20-year Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities on Tuesday. There are also two- and five-year Treasurys auctions. 

  SunTrust's Richman said that with buyers currently active, the sales "should go fairly well," although with the bigger subprime story dominating the headlines, "I don't see tremendous upside or downside risk" for the market from the auctions.

Vietnam Preliminary July CPI +8.39% On Yr, +0.94% On Month

 

  HANOI (Dow Jones)--Vietnam's consumer price index is projected to have risen 8.39% in July from the same month last year, due mainly to higher food and housing costs, government data issued Tuesday showed. 

  The index is expected to have risen 0.94% from June, based on preliminary data, the Government Statistics Office said. 

  A Ministry of Agriculture official said food prices were higher because Vietnam's key winter-spring rice crop produced only 17.1 million tons of paddy rice, down 3% on year. 

  Bird flu and bacterial infections among pigs have also hurt many farmers across the country, resulting in higher prices for foodstuffs in many provinces in Vietnam, the official said. 

  Food and food services prices are expected to have climbed 11.13% on year and 1.59% on month. Rice and other cereal prices are projected to have risen 15.03% on year, and 0.54% on month. 

  Housing and construction materials costs are estimated to have increased 10.93% on year and risen 0.73% on month. 

  Vietnam is aiming for a full-year inflation rate below its gross domestic product growth rate, which is targeted at 8.5% this year. 

  The subindex that measures prices in cities is estimated to have risen 8.98% from a year earlier and 0.84% from June. Prices in rural areas are estimated to be 7.81% higher than a year earlier and up 0.97% from June. 

  Gold prices probably rose 5.51% on year and were down 0.59% on month. 

  The statistics office also said that the U.S. dollar will have gained 0.95% against the Vietnamese dong since July last year, and 0.12% since June of this year. The central bank set the dollar's value Monday at VND16,139. 

  The government usually issues CPI figures based on estimates before the end of the reporting period.
