U.S. SUMMARY & ASIAN OUTLOOK: 

  STOCKS: 

  U.S. stocks fell sharply after the Federal Reserve reacted less drastically to the "credit crunch" than many traders had hoped, cutting the federal funds rate to 4.25% from 4.5% and the discount rate by 25 basis points to 4.75%. 

  After several hints of cuts from Fed members and the government's trumpeted concerns about conditions in mortgage markets, some traders had anticipated a more decisive move from the central bank. When that didn't come, optimism on financials was flushed out of the market, and momentum changed, said Pete McCorry, senior equity trader at Keefe Bruyette & Woods. 

  "It pushes off a sense of recovery" from financial woes, McCorry said. 

  The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 294.26, or 2.1%, to 13432.77, its biggest drop in nearly five weeks. The Nasdaq Composite Index plunged 66.60, or 2.4%, to 2652.35. 

  Among individual stocks, General Electric lost 1% to 37.03. The industrial and financial conglomerate projected 2008 per-share earnings below analysts' expectations, reflecting "a slowing U.S. economy." 

  Washington Mutual dropped 12% to 17.42. The largest U.S. savings and loan plans to slash its dividend by 73%, raise $2.5 billion in fresh capital and cut more than 3,000 jobs to address "unprecedented challenges in the mortgage and credit markets." 

  While WaMu had its own issues, banks were decimated in the aftermath of the Fed's action, as declines were marked by all 80 members of the S&P 500's financial sector. 

  Dow industrial AT&T rose 4.1% to 39.46. The telecommunications giant announced a 12.7% increase in its quarterly dividend, the biggest boost on an annual basis in its history; a new 400 million-share repurchase plan; and financial forecasts for the next few years that topped expectations. 

  Crude oil futures rose above $90 a barrel in New York as ice storms stopped flow through key U.S. oil pipelines and after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates. 

  The base metals ended the London Metal Exchange trading session in recent ranges ahead of the U.S. Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates. Gold futures moved mildly higher in New York as trading was subdued ahead of the announcement. 

  FOREX: 

  The yen bested the euro and dollar in New York after financial markets befell a spell of risk aversion when the Federal Open Market Committee announced a third consecutive cut to interest rates to defend the U.S. economy against recession. 

  The yen surged on a sharp decline in U.S. stocks, which were disappointed by the mere 25-basis point cut to the fed funds rate, instead of a 50-basis point reduction - although few market watchers actually expected the latter. 

  "This is the bare minimum that was expected," said Marc Chandler, global head of foreign exchange at Brown Brothers Harriman in New York. 

  Consequently, the euro dropped almost three yen from its intraday high and the dollar declined almost one-and-a-half yen from its intraday high after the announcement. The euro's significant fall, just one day after striking a one-month high of Y164.58, helped boost the dollar against the single currency. 

  The dollar was also boosted against the euro, said Robert Sinche, head of global foreign exchange at Bank of America in New York, because it is more attractive than it would have been if there was a 50-basis point cut. 

  A cut to the fed funds rate of any size suggests downside risks for the U.S. currency because lower rates reduce investors' returns on dollar-denominated assets. 

  However, the dollar's reaction wasn't as large as seen in the past, perhaps because the Fed itself stressed the current uncertainty. "For now, the foreign exchange markets will be taking their cue from other markets, like the commodity and equity markets," Sinche added. 

  Tuesday afternoon in New York, the euro was at $1.4651 from $1.4713 late Monday, while the dollar was at Y110.67 from Y111.64. The euro was at Y162.14 from Y164.25, according to EBS. The U.K. pound was at $2.0334 from $2.0470, while the dollar was quoted at CHF1.1312 from CHF1.1283 late Monday. 

  The Federal Open Market Committee voted 9-1 to reduce the federal funds rate to 4.25% from 4.5%, its third-straight reduction since September totaling 100 basis points. It also cut the discount rate it charges banks that borrow directly from the Fed by 25 basis points to 4.75%. 

  The market anticipated a cut after statements from several officials early last month, most pointedly by Fed Governor Randall Kroszner, who said on Nov. 16 that "the current stance of monetary policy should help the economy get through the rough patch during the next year." 

  The dollar had retreated from its lifetime lows against the euro following that speech on the positive momentum it created in U.S. equities. 

  "Incoming information suggests that economic growth is slowing," the FOMC said in its statement, reflecting the "intensification" of the housing slump and slower business and consumer spending. 

  The statement signaled an about-face from the previous Fed meeting, when the board suggested further easing was off the table. The Fed also dropped its previous assertion that growth and inflation risks were roughly balanced, opting instead for an open-ended view, and pledged to "act as needed" to keep the economy growing and inflation in check. 

  The buck and euro's subsequent decline versus the yen followed a typical low-risk appetite trading pattern. The yen benefits during times of risk aversion because Japan's ultra-low interest rates make the yen a funding currency for riskier assets when the market has a more positive sentiment. When that perspective shifts, the funds shift back into the yen. A similar pattern often aids the dollar against the euro and currencies like the Brazilian real, as it did Tuesday. 

  However, currency analysts say that the Fed's downside view of the economy indicates that this is no dollar rebound. 

  BONDS: 

  U.S. Treasury prices soared after the U.S. Federal Reserve cut its target rate by 25 basis points, as investors interpreted the move as insufficient to help considerably ease conditions in strained credit markets. 

  While investors had widely expected the quarter point cut to the fed funds rate, many had anticipated a heftier ease in the discount window rate to loosen up strained money markets, where interbank lending rates have remained stubbornly high. When that didn't materialize, investors grew more convinced that financial market conditions will worsen, a reaction that sent Treasury yields lower as stocks fell. Bond prices move inversely to yields. 

  With shorter-term Treasurys gaining the most, the yield curve also steepened. In late trade, the two-year note was up 14/32 at 2.92% and the 10-year note was up 1 14/32 at 3.97%, leaving Treasurys benchmark yield curve, the spread between the two- and 10-year note yields, at plus 105 basis points.   Just before the announcement, the two-year Treasury note was yielding 3.13% and the 10-year note was yielding 4.10%. 

  Treasury bills were also boosted by the news as investors sought out the safest possible assets, with the three-month T-bill bond equivalent yield down 14 basis points at 2.91% and the six month T-bill bond equivalent yield down 13 basis points at 3.18%. 

  "The expectation in the market was that they needed to move the discount rate below the funds rate," said Tom di Galoma, head of Treasurys at Jefferies & Co. in New York. 

  The fact that policymakers chose not to make a more dramatic move was surely "a big disappointment for the credit markets," said David Ader, head of government bond strategy at RBS Greenwich Capital in Greenwich, Conn., with the move "undoubtedly bullish for Treasurys relative to just about everything else." Ader said he has his eye on the 2.80% level for the two-year note as a possibly attractive selling spot. 

  In its meeting statement, the Fed also dropped the assertion from its previous statement that the risks to growth and to inflation were roughly equal. The Fed pledged to "act as needed" to keep the economy growing and control inflation. 

  The day's decision further boosted shorter-term Treasurys, the most sensitive to the Fed's decisions, which have been gaining recently on renewed signs that banks are wary to lend to each other given concerns about their exposure to shaky subprime and structured finance investments. Cash-hoarding ahead of year-end has also kept money market rates high. 

  With the Fed and markets not seeing eye to eye on the outlook for money markets and the impact of the credit crunch on the economy, interest rate futures remain priced for further rate cuts in 2008, with Treasurys likely to remain in favor. 

  "The Fed and the market are just not on the same page," said Richard Gilhooly, senior fixed income strategist at BNP Paribas in New York. 

  (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires

  DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 

 

  Consumer prices in Istanbul, Turkey's largest city, increased 0.95% on the month in December, slowing from a 1.94% increase in November, the Istanbul Chamber of Commerce, or ITO, said Tuesday, the Ihlas News Agency reported. 

  On the year, however, inflation in Istanbul decreased to 12.46% in December from 12.64% in November, the ITO said. 

  Although the ITO calculates its data in a different way from the official Turkish Statistics Institute, or TUIK, the chamber's data are viewed as a good indicator of the national trend, as Istanbul is considered the country's financial capital, IHS reported. 

  TUIK is due to publish December national inflation data on Thursday. 

  In the most recent central bank survey on Dec. 24, expectations for average year-end national inflation were slightly lower, at 8.64%, compared with 8.66% in the preceding survey conducted Dec. 7. 

  IHS reported that monthly inflation expectations for December were also at 0.58% in the survey, unchanged from the previous forecast made Dec. 7. 

  At the beginning of the year, the Turkish central bank set the annual inflation target at 4%. Annual inflation stood at 9.65% in 2006, and many analysts have said the 2007 target is too ambitious.

text:
UPDATE:NY Regulator:Key To Resolve Bond Insurers Problems Quickly

 

  (Updates with Fitch downgrades, share prices, spokespeople's comments; adds context) 

 
   By Romy Varghese 
   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Regulators Thursday acknowledged that it will take time to deal with problems that embattled bond insurers are facing just as a second company lost its coveted triple-A ranking. 

  "Clearly, it is important to resolve issues related to the bond insurers as soon as possible," New York State Insurance Superintendent Eric Dinallo said in a written statement. 

  The press release came shortly after Fitch Ratings downgraded XL Capital Assurance five notches to A, and the holding company, Security Capital Assurance (SCA), was slashed from triple-A to triple-B, near the bottom of the investment-grade ladder. 

  Fitch's decision and Dinallo's statement suggest investors may have gotten ahead of themselves Wednesday when they heard about Dinallo's attempts to harness banks' capital to save the bond insurers, whose tenuous hold on their top ratings have spread concern throughout financial markets. 

  Stocks of bond insurers were down Thursday, a day after Ambac Financial Group (ABK), which was cut to double-A by Fitch Ratings and is on watch by the other two ratings agencies, saw its shares soar 72%. They're now down by 6%. MBIA Inc. (MBI), which saw its shares gain 33% Wednesday, has fallen by 8%. SCA has plummeted 17%. 

  Dinallo may have tempered hopes of an imminent deal, as he said that there are "complicated issues" with many parties involved. "Any effective plan will take some time to finalize," he said. "In the meantime, we will not respond to the inevitable rumors." 

  The New York Times reported that Dinallo told a group of Wall Street executives Wednesday that it should move in 48 hours to set up a deal on the bond insurers. 

  But a banker involved in the discussions called them "very preliminary," according to The Wall Street Journal. 

  Complex securities guaranteed by the bond insurers, such as subprime mortgage-backed deals, have plummeted in value amid the credit market turmoil. The insurers guarantee about $2.4 trillion in outstanding debt, and the loss of their top-notch ratings means a repricing of insured debt and a chilling effect on the industry. 

  Also, it could trigger further downgrades at banks and brokers, who already are reeling from subprime losses and are searching for additional capital themselves. Wall Street firms had bought protection from the insurers as a way to reduce their capital needs, but is now facing the possibility of having to put the losses on their own balance sheets. 

  An MBIA spokeswoman declined to comment Thursday on the bailout discussions, and Ambac didn't return a call for comment. The insurers weren't present at the meeting between Dinallo and bank executives, the Wall Street Journal reported. 

  Credit default swaps, which are contracts allowing investors to wager on firms' creditworthiness, tightened significantly Wednesday for MBIA and Ambac on bailout hopes but widened somewhat Thursday morning. They were unchanged after the Fitch and Dinallo releases, at 455 basis points for MBIA and 460 basis points for Ambac. That means the annual cost of protecting a notional $10 million of MBIA bonds against default for five years is $455,000 and for Ambac bonds, $460,000. 

 

  -By Romy Varghese, Dow Jones Newswires; 201-938-4287; romy.varghese@dowjones.com 

  (Kate Haywood contributed to this report.) 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

UPDATE: Hungarian Dec CPI +7.4%YY, Exceeds Expectations

   (Adds further details) 
 
   By Margit Feher 
   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 
========================================================== 
Dec Consumer Price Inflation     !                       ! 
                    On Mo On Yr  !                       ! 
            Dec     +0.4% +7.4%  !Median: +7.2%/Yr       ! 
            Mo ago  +0.6% +7.1%  !Fact:   +7.4%/Yr       ! 
   Core CPI Dec     +0.6% +4.8%  !                       ! 
            Mo ago  +0.5% +4.6%  !                       ! 
========================================================== 

  BUDAPEST (Dow Jones)--Hungary's headline consumer price inflation accelerated in December, exceeding analyst expectations, as food and energy prices remained at an elevated level, the Central Statistics Office, or KSH said Tuesday. 

  Headline consumer prices rose 0.4% on the month and were up 7.4% from a year earlier in December, rising considerably faster than the median forecast of 15 analysts polled by Dow Jones Newswires, who had predicted a rise of 7.2%. Forecasts had come in a relatively narrow range of 7.2% and 7.5%. 

  "I can't say new things - it's evidently food and energy prices again, cooking oil, milk, dairy products and eggs...the rise in the other categories was negligible," a KSH statistician told Dow Jones Newswires at the time of the release. 

  Food prices rose 0.8% and car fuel prices increased 2.0% on the month, slowing somewhat from monthly rises of 1.4% and 3.3% respectively in November. The slower increase was expected by analysts. The price of cooking oil jumped 9.2% on the month while cheese rose 2.8% and eggs rose 1.7% in the same period. 

  Although food and energy prices boosted headline inflation, services prices, which are also closely watched by analysts, rose only 0.1%. Consumer durables prices fell 0.1% and clothing prices were unchanged on the month in December. 

  Core inflation, excluding volatile energy and food prices, also picked up in December. 

  "Unprocessed food prices such as (the price of) eggs are excluded from the core reading but processed food prices are not," Minary added. She cited milk as a booster for core prices as well as for the headline reading, as milk prices rose 2.4% on the month. 

  Minary declined to be specific on the outlook for inflation. She noted, however, that price hikes reported in the local press by local governments of certain services prices such as public transport, utilities, and other centrally mandated price rises as postal services will boost January inflation, as most probably will a full liberalization of the power market. 

  Inflation was 8.0% on average in 2007, up sharply from 3.9% in 2006, but in line with analysts' forecasts in a poll carried out by Dow Jones Newswires.

text:
Irvine Energy: 1st Hydrocarbon Sales, Niobrara To Commence

 

  Edited Press Release 

 

  LONDON (Dow Jones)--Irvine Energy, a AIM-listed oil and gas exploration and production company, said Tuesday that production has commenced within its 162,000 acre portfolio of onshore oil and gas projects in the USA. 

 

  Highlights 

  * Irvine Net Production from Jan 9 to Jan 31 was 6.973 million standard cubic feet of gas and 76 BBLS of oil, from 18 wells in Oklahoma, marking Irvine's first hydrocarbon sales. Production due to commence at Niobrara from 20 wells following completion of workover programmes 
 * Four wells completed in Oklahoma and workover programmes initiated on a further three wells 
 * Initial well locations identified in Kansas targeting the Arbuckle and Mississippian formation in the highly prospective Cooley oil fields 
 * 3D seismic programmes at Ares and Udall project areas in Kansas underway to identify multiple drill targets 
 * Current 2008 drill programme includes 30+ wells to raise reserve base and increase oil and gas production across portfolio 
 * Production phase now reached leading to cash flow - 18 producing wells, three shut in and four being completed with intention to raise the number across the portfolio to 45 by mid 2008 

  The Compay's Managing Director, Aaron Close, said: "This is a transformational period for the Company as we develop our prospective oil and gas targets in the U.S. and enter the production phase. 

  "With an extensive portfolio already in place, we will now rapidly increase our reserve base through exploration and our cash flow through a ramp-up in production as more wells come on stream. 

  "Our strategy of focussing on shallow, low-cost drilling projects in areas of stacked pay zones and existing infrastructure is proving itself across our portfolio. At our current rate of development, we aim to be producing in our three areas of operation by April." 

  Attributable production in Oklahoma began on Jan. 9 following the completion of the final closing agreements between Metro Energy Group and Irvine. 

  Irvine produced 7.973 million standard cubic feet of natural gas and 76 bbls of oil net to its interest during the month of Jan. 

   Workover work is under way on three existing wells that did not report production during Jan. 

  Drilling of the Patriot 3-15, the Priegle 2-10 and Summers 1-3 operated by Metro, as well as the Ross 3-27 operated by Williams Energy, has been completed. Additional drilling and workover programmes are underway and will be announced as results become available. 

  In Kansas, the first of the 3D seismic shoots has been interpreted and the initial well location has been selected. Drilling is planned to begin at the end of Feb. and is expected to take two to three weeks. 

  If successful, the completion processes are expected to take a further three weeks. The well will be targeting primarily oil pay in the Arbuckle formation as an extension of the highly productive Cooley oil field. 

  The Ares and Udall project areas 3D seismic programmes are in progress and the Ares 3D is underway and expected to finish by March. The seismic crew will move directly to the Udall area and begin shooting there upon completion of the Ares. 

  Once completed, processing is expected to take 30 days and interpretation will take an additional 30 days. This is being conducted to identify multiple drill targets in accordance with the Company's development plan. 

  Following an evaluation programme of the Niobrara Project in Kansas during the second half of 2007, 20 initial wells were selected for development. All of these now have pumping units and gas gathering lines in place. 

  The water disposal permit has been approved and the water disposal well is being prepared for use. The gas sales contracts are in place and a gas compressor is being prepared. 

  Production is targeted at 500 mcf/ d net to Irvine, with current prices in the region of $7.00/mcf. First gas sales are expected in March. 

  Development of the extensive inventory of undrilled well locations in this project is expected to begin in Q2, after production from the initial 20 wells has stabilised and production rates are confirmed to be in line with Irvine's expectations.

text:
FOCUS: German Unions Prepping Strikes As Talks Drag On

   By Roman Kessler   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  FRANKFURT (Dow Jones)--Ignoring pleas for wage restraint, Germany's two largest unions are lining up more warning strikes to back some of the biggest wage demands in the euro zone. 

  Nearly 2,000 Eastern German steel workers from the big IG Metall union Tuesday staged warning strikes for an 8% pay raise at two steel plants, including the Arcelor Mittal GmbH plant at Eisenhuettenstadt, a unit of the ArcelorMittal group (MT). 

  IG Metall, with 2.3 million members, seeks an 8% pay rise for more than 100,000 steel workers and says it's ready to do more for its other members in the months ahead, including auto workers and electrical workers. 

  The Ver.di services union, also demanding an 8% pay hike, Tuesday resumed talks with government representatives threatening to stage warning strikes later in the week. Federal and local governments are standing by their offer of 5% in three steps over two years. 

  The warning strikes are precursors to possible open-ended labor actions if truce periods end without a deal. The IG Metal negotiations are set to end on Feb. 19. The public-sector talks are set to run until March 7, but the unions can break off talks any time and call an open-ended walkout. 

  German auto makers Daimler AG (DAI.XE), Porsche AG (POR3.XE) and Volkswagen AG (VOW.XE), BMW AG (BMW.XE) among others will have to come back to the negotiating table with IG Metall before their current wage contracts expire Sept. 30. 

  Unions are showing new resolve after years of being weakened by defections and job losses to globalization, the rank-and-file are demanding their piece of a bumper earnings year after years of wage restraint. 

  Another reason is the toll rising inflation is taking on households. The European Central Bank has warned against demanding more pay to compensate, rising a wage-price spiral that will spin a currently 3.2% inflation still higher. But unions are digging in for a fight. 

  For public sector workers, the offer of a 5% raise over two years isn't deemed to be nearly enough. 

  "This offer is a joke," a 55-year old garbage collector in Frankfurt said while pushing trash cans to the lorry. He has a family and said higher taxes, rising health insurance contributions and rent are exhausting his earnings before the end of the month. 

  "We're ready to go on strike. Three weeks, if necessary. Imagine how this city would look like if we stop taking out its trash. It would be catastrophic." His colleagues nod. 

  Ver.di union is focusing on inflation in one of the most important wage rounds this year that affect 2.2 million public-sector employees, including private health care and social institutions.   "We're already thinking of strike strategies that really hurt the employers," said Werner Romuender, a labor representative for 320 road sweepers and garbage collectors in the City of Kassel, central Germany. "Think of striking ticket controllers in public transport: when we announce they'll walk out, why should people get a ticket?" 

  German unions were emboldened by the small GDL train drain drivers union, which after a series of open-ended strikes late last year wrested an 11% pay hike out of the Deutsche Bahn AG national railway. 

  "Our people saw that, of course," Romuender said. "They have a feeling that its time for significantly higher pay." 

  Many workers left the German unions since the 1990s and Germany had the fewest strikes per hour worked by euro zone standards in recent years. Bargaining power also declined as employers threatened to move abroad. 

  "The atmosphere is generally heated - not only in the steel sector. In many sectors Germans want to participate in the economic success," the chairman of the association of steel-sector employers AGV Helmut F. Koch said. "And we can't say that our sector is ailing." 

  But the wage demands come amid signs that, after a year of growth, the German economic recovery is losing steam with the rest of the euro zone. 

  The European Central Bank has warned that Europe will be affected by the slowdown in the U.S. The German government now expects the export-driven economy to slow to a 1.7% growth rate in 2008 from 2.5% in 2007. 

  There are also little signs that consumption could pick up as data show that consumers are unwilling to loosen their purse strings. Rather than adopt the ECB's caution against inflation, the unions take the tack that higher wages could help stimulate domestic demand. 

  "There are signs that the economic growth is retreating in 2008. That's exactly why it is of the essence to strengthen domestic private consumption with higher wages," ver.di's chief economist Michael Schlecht said. 

  -By Roman Kessler, Dow Jones Newswires, +4969 2972 5514, roman.kessler@dowjones.com

text:
3rd UPDATE: ECB Bini Smaghi:Downside GDP Risk,Upside CPI Risk

 

  (Adds further quote on market turmoil.) 

 

  FLORENCE, Italy (Dow Jones)--Downside risks to growth and upside risks to the inflation rate prevail in the euro zone, senior European Central Bank official Lorenzo Bini Smaghi said Wednesday. 

  The next ECB staff projections, due to be released March 6, will contain "novelties," Bini Smaghi said on the sidelines of a conference. The new projections will reflect greater possibilities that growth will slow more than expected, while price trends move higher than anticipated, he said. 

  "Some news is positive, some news is negative," he said about recent economic data from the euro zone. Germany's Ifo business sentiment index unexpectedly rose in February, while other indicators have been weakening. 

  Bini Smaghi also said the ECB's "baseline scenario" is that the U.S. economy won't enter a recession. "The fundamentals of the U.S. economy are sound," he said. 

  "The American economy is being influenced by the financial market turmoil, which in Europe seems to be more limited," he added. 

  However, a slower U.S. economy will inevitably have an impact on the euro zone, he said. The two large economies may be somewhat diverging, but they are in the same cycle, he said. 

  The rising oil and raw materials prices are a "big worry, because they reflect the scarcity of resources," he said. 

  "We have to avoid letting these hikes trigger inflationary forces," he added. "We must limit the effects of (raw material prices) on wages." 

  The ECB has left interest rates unchanged since credit markets ground to a halt last summer, while offering large-scale liquidity injections into the banking system. 

  The market turmoil "will take some time to be digested," Bini Smaghi said. 

  The main problem, he added, is that "banks don't trust each other." 

  "Confidence in the financial system's ability to assess some financial instruments has crumbled," the central banker said. 

  That has stymied the interbank lending market, which in turn has pushed up short-term money market rates. Banks are concerned that counterparty collateral may be exposed to U.S. subprime mortgages and other weakening credits. 

  "It's probably a more complex process than in the past," Bini Smaghi said, referring to the current credit market turmoil compared with the Asian crisis of the late 1990s or the crash in technology stocks that began in 2000. 

 

  -By Luca Di Leo, Dow Jones Newswires; +39-335 617 1960; luca.dileo@dowjones.com 

  (Valeria Santoro of MF-Dow Jones in Florence contributed to this report.)

text:
UPDATE: Australian Wages Data Affirm Case For RBA Hikes

 

  By Sam Holmes 

  Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 

  SYDNEY (Dow Jones)--Australian wages growth remained strong in the fourth quarter of 2007, in line with expectations, likely adding to the Reserve Bank of Australia's concerns that cost pressures from the tight labor market are now feeding into the broader inflationary landscape. 

  The figures have added to the already strong case for a quarter of a percentage point interest rate hike in March and build on arguments for a followup move in May. 

  It also shows that inflationary pressures in Australia, driven by strong domestic demand, high commodities prices and capacity constraints, are broadening as the RBA has recently warned. 

  Australian wages excluding bonuses rose 1.1% in the fourth quarter of 2007 from the third quarter and rose 4.2% from a year earlier, Australian Bureau of Statistics labor price data issued Wednesday show. 

  In the private sector, wages excluding bonuses rose 1.1% in the fourth quarter from the third quarter and rose 4.3% from a year earlier. Public-sector wages rose 1.0% in the quarter and increased 4.1% from a year earlier. 

  Wages including bonuses rose 1.1% in the quarter and rose 4.5% on the year. 

  ICAP chief economist Matthew Johnson says while the figures were as-expected, it still pointed to the RBA remained poised for a round of near-term tightening. 

  "That trend in the private sector data is a little bit worrying and that would reflect what the RBA is saying about these sorts of wage pressures out there," Johnson said. 

  "There is nothing in this data to suggest that the RBA was wrong to be worried about wages...however, there is nothing in the data that really sounds the alarm bells." 

  In the last week-and-a-half, the central bank has delivered several warnings the wage increases were beginning to spill over into price chains. 

  On Tuesday, RBA assistant governor Malcolm Edey said there had been some very recent evidence of higher wages growth. 

  This adds to what the RBA said in its very hawkish quarterly statement on monetary policy released last week, which all but confirmed a March rate hike. 

  The minutes from the RBA's Feb. 5 meeting, when it voted to lift rates a quarter of a percentage point to 7.0%, revealed Tuesday the central bank had even considered a 50 basis point increase this month. 

  TD Securities senior strategist Joshua Williamson said   wages growth remained uncomfortably high for the RBA at current levels. 

  "The RBA still has an inflation headache to deal with," he said. 

  "Broadly speaking, wages appear to be edging higher and for the RBA to soften its hawkish policy stance, the data needed to have a downward surprise. 

  "On an annualized basis, wages look to be heading from 4.0% to more than 4.5% year-on-year, and the RBA will view that as a threat to inflation." 

  ANZ senior economist Tony Pearson said the annual rate of growth in private sector wages was the highest reading since the series started in 1998. 

  "There's still evidence of a gradual swelling of wage pressures," he said. 

  "There hasn't been a wage breakout in the sense of a sharp uptick, but it does indicate a gradual acceleration of private sector wages. 

  "That's the series we've been focused on from a policy perspective." 

  However, other data released Wednesday pointed to a moderation in the economy. 

  The Westpac-Melbourne Institute economic leading indicator grew at an annualized rate of 4.7% in December, down from 6.1% in November, suggesting a moderation in the likely pace of economic growth toward long-term trend levels in the next three to nine months. 

  And an index of job vacancies for skilled workers in Australia fell by 2.2% in February from January, and was 6.4% lower from a year ago, the Department of Employment said. 

  The index currently stands at 97.7. 

  Despite the on-consensus wages date, the Australian dollar sold off as traders took back short positions on news the data weren't higher than expected. 

  The Australian dollar fell to US$0.9174 when the figures were published at 0030 GMT, from US$0.9194 earlier. At 0101 GMT, the Australian dollar was US$0.9191. Australian bonds were marginally stronger also on relief buying with both 3-year futures and 10-year futures up half a basis point each at 93.035 and 93.48, respectively. 

  -By Sam Holmes, Dow Jones Newswires; 

  61-2-8235-2964; samuel.holmes@dowjones.com

Petronas Funds Can't Be Used To Cut Fuel Prices - Govt

 

  KUALA LUMPUR (AP)--Malaysia cannot use funds from Petroliam Nasional Bhd. as a quick fix to lower fuel prices because the state oil company needs resources to expand and compete globally, a finance official was quoted as saying Monday. 

  Malaysia, a net oil exporter, heavily subsidizes retail fuel prices, but it has warned it may have to reduce subsidies this year after global oil prices recently breached US$100 a barrel. 

  Second Finance Minister Nor Mohamed Yakcop was quoted by the New Straits Times as saying that Petronas - as the national oil company is also known - was already financing various government projects and needs funds to expand abroad to ensure it remains competitive and profitable. 

  "Petronas has to look for new resources, as our natural oil and gas reserves are expected to run out by 2011," he said. 

  "This reinvestment effort comes at a huge cost, and we cannot simply stop Petronas from expanding just for the sake of a quick fix for global petrol price hikes." 

  He suggested it was better for Petronas - Malaysia's only Fortune 500 company and the country's most profitable firm - to use the money to invest in international markets and boost its capacity for the long term. 

  The government last raised prices of gasoline, diesel and liquefied petroleum gas in February 2006, when crude oil futures were near a then record high around US$70 a barrel. 

  The government says it spent MYR43.4 billion (US$13.6 billion) in 2007 to subsidize fuel and other essential items and that Malaysia's fuel prices remained among the lowest in Southeast Asia. 

  The anticipated hike in fuel prices, which will spark an overall rise in the cost of living, is a key challenge for Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi's ruling coalition in March 8 general elections. 

  Opposition parties have tapped into public unhappiness, promising to use profits from Petronas to raise fuel subsidies if they win. But the coalition is expected to easily win again, although with fewer seats. 

  Petronas posted a net profit of MYR46.4 billion for the fiscal year ending March 2007. During the year, it paid MYR48.3 billion in taxes, royalties, dividends and export duty, making it the single biggest tax payer in Malaysia. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
UPDATE:Rio Tinto Plays Hardball With Mills On Iron Ore Price

 
   By Matt Chambers and Stephen Bell 
   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  MELBOURNE (Dow Jones)--Pointing to soaring spot iron ore prices, Rio Tinto Ltd. (RTP) continues to play hardball with steel makers and is holding out for a more-than-71% increase in contract prices with Asian mills. 

  London-based Rio Tinto, the world's second-biggest iron ore exporter, is defying convention and refusing to step into line with a price rise of between 66% and 71% agreed to by Companhia Vale do Rio Doce (RIO) last month. Rio's Australian iron ore mines are much closer to Asia than those of Brazil's Vale, and Rio says steel mills should pay extra because they don't have to ship the material as far. 

  Rio Tinto will "do what we can to secure an appropriate return for our shareholders," iron ore unit chief Sam Walsh said Wednesday at a conference in Perth, referring to Rio Tinto's push for a price rise higher than those secured by Vale. Rio Tinto's ore continues to be sold "without the premium we believe it merits for being so much cheaper to import than iron ore from elsewhere." 

  Usually the world's three big iron producers - Vale, Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton (BHP) - fall into line once one of them secures a contract with a major steel maker for the Japanese fiscal year. But Rio Tinto is this year defending a takeover bid from BHP and doing all it can to boost its bottom line. BHP, which is yet to settle contracts but hasn't publicly said it is looking for an extra hike, unsuccessfully held out for a freight premium in 2005. 

  Walsh said spot prices are now US$100 a metric ton more than current contract prices and have risen by US$20 a ton since Vale settled. Spot prices in China and India rose as high as US$216/ton March 1, according to Merrill Lynch, still about 50% higher than the new price secured by Vale for Japanese fiscal 2008, which starts April 1. 

  Unusually, Vale's deal this year included two different price categories, with higher quality ore getting a 71% gain. 

 
   No Rush To Settle 
 

  The recent gains in the spot market mean Rio Tinto is prepared to be patient and won't rush to follow Vale's earlier-than-expected settlement. Also, with iron representing a bigger slice of Rio Tinto's bottom line than BHP's, a bigger price hike would work in favor of defending BHP's all-stock bid. 

  "We are sitting tight, waiting for the market to recognize the fundamentals," Walsh said, adding a deal with its steel mill customers isn't imminent. "I'd remind you that a couple of years ago, it wasn't until June that the price was settled." 

  Merrill Lynch analysts said they expect Australian iron ore producers to achieve a minimum 71% hike, which is the price rise Vale gained for its better-quality Carajas ore. 

  "We were surprised the (Vale) settlement was so early, and that the increase was not higher," Merrill Lynch said in a research note this week, adding Vale's talks about merging with Xstrata PLC (XTA.LN) may have  influenced the timing. "A higher price increase would have been supported by the elevated spot prices, supply disruptions, the tight steel markets and strong Chinese demand." 

  The iron ore miners achieved contract gains of 9.5% in 2007, 19% in 2006 and 71.5% in 2005. In recent years, negotiations have tended to stretch past the April 1 start of the Japanese fiscal year. 

  Walsh said he expects the current system of setting benchmark contract prices to change gradually, but doesn't expect to see miners and mills "rushing to an LME-based system with futures." Late last year, BHP said it favors an index pricing system for iron ore sales. 

  Merrill Lynch said a new, third-party managed iron ore index "appears inevitable" in two or three years. 

 

  -By Matt Chambers and Stephen Bell, Dow Jones Newswires; 61-3-9671-4393;  matt.chambers@dowjones.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  MUMBAI (Dow Jones)--Indian government bond prices fell Monday on speculation that a sharp increase in the inflation rate may prompt the central bank to take action to curb rising prices before its scheduled monetary policy review at the end of April, traders said. 

  The benchmark 7.99% 2017-dated bond ended at INR100.30, down from INR100.52 at Friday's close. Its yield rose four basis points to 7.94%. 

  "Everybody is now expecting the RBI (Reserve Bank of India) to act with possibly a cash reserve ratio hike," said a foreign bank's bond dealer. 

  Cash reserve ratio, or the share of deposits banks must keep with the RBI, is currently 7.50%. The RBI has hiked the cash reserve ratio 250 basis points since December 2006 to absorb inflation-fueling excess cash from the banking system. 

  The central bank will review its monetary policy April 29. 

  Inflation, measured by wholesale prices, accelerated to over a one-year high of 6.68% in the week ended March 15, data showed Friday. 

  "If the current trend continues, inflation could well average above 6.5% for FY08/09 versus our current expectations of 5.7%," said Standard Chartered Bank's senior economist Shuchita Mehta in a research note. 

  India's financial year runs from April to March. 

  "Low inflation with financial stability is our aim...the emphasis on price stability will continue," RBI Deputy Governor Rakesh Mohan said Friday after market hours. 

  "I would have to say that inflation in the last two weeks has been higher than our expectation...We have to examine the international and domestic price trends more closely," Mohan said. 

  India's Cabinet Committee on Prices, a top ministers' panel led by the Prime Minister Manmohan Singh is meeting at 1430 GMT Monday to discuss the issue of rising prices. 

  Bond trading volumes were lower Monday as many players awaited sovereign debt auctions lined up for April. The government is scheduled to sell INR200 billion of bonds during the month under its market borrowing program. 

  The first auction of INR100 billion is scheduled April 4-11. 

  In the currency market, the Indian rupee weakened against the U.S. dollar Monday, as a fall in local stocks triggered capital outflows. 

  The dollar ended at INR40.10, up from INR39.90 at Friday's close. 

  "I don't see any major gains in the rupee, since the volume of capital inflows aren't going to be as heavy as last year," said V. Rajagopal, head of foreign exchange trading at Kotak Mahindra Bank. 

  India's stocks fell Monday, with the benchmark Bombay Stock Exchange's Sensex declining 726.85 points, or 4.4%, to end at 15644.44. 

  Rajagopal said he expects the dollar to trade in a band of INR39.75-INR40.25 during April.

text:
WSJ(3/5) Ahead Of The Tape

   (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL) 
   By Mark Gongloff 

  Where Fed 

  Marches, Others 

  May Follow 

 

  Among the world's major central banks, the Federal Reserve looks as out-of-place as a person showing up to a black-tie affair in a Halloween costume. 

  Since September, the Fed has slashed its federal-funds-rate target by 2 1/2 percentage points to 3%, as aggressive as its cuts going into the 2001 recession. 

  Other central bankers have been loath to follow the Fed's lead. The Bank of England has cut its target rate just twice since December, by just a half percentage point in total. The European Central Bank and the Bank of Japan haven't touched rates since credit problems emerged last year. The Reserve Bank of Australia has been raising rates, with the most recent increase coming yesterday. 

  ECB and Bank of England policy makers meet this week and are expected to keep rates unchanged. Despite signs of economic weakness, inflation in Europe and the United Kingdom has been high, making them reluctant to pursue stimulative rate cuts. 

  Why the disconnect? The Fed might be on the wrong course. Many complain its easy-money policy is fueling global commodity inflation, making it harder for other central banks to do their jobs. 

  Another possibility is that other nations are insulated from America's woes and are correctly staying out of the U.S. mess. If the global economy was really slowing, this argument goes, commodity prices would be falling, not soaring. 

  A third possibility, and probably the most likely, is that the rest of the world will eventually have to catch up to the Fed. The Australian central bank, even as it raised interest rates, noted tighter credit conditions and softer business and consumer sentiment in commodity-rich Australia and warned that "global growth will be below trend in 2008." Canada's central bank has also gotten into the rate-cutting act, saying the U.S. slump would have "significant spillover effects on the global economy." 

  Central bank easing policies will eventually converge, says Lena Komileva, Group-of-Seven economist at Tullett Prebon. The slow response of others means their economies might keep slowing even after a U.S. recovery sets in. 

 

  Corporate Insiders Decide 

  It's Time to Buy Shares 

 

  Here's a silver lining in the market. Corporate executives are gobbling up their own companies' shares. 

  Insider buying in February was 26% higher than the average for the month over the past six years, while selling was about half the average, Thomson Financial says. Nearly half of the buying came from large-cap companies, including hard-hit financial and technology companies. 

  Some investors watch how executives treat their own companies' shares; they might buy when seeing opportunities other investors don't. 

  "I like to see that management thinks their company is at a price that represents some value," says Robert Pavlik, chief investment officer at Oaktree Asset Management. 

  The catch is that insiders aren't always the smartest money or the best signal about a stock. Sometimes executives don't know what's about to hit them, or they're buying or selling for reasons that don't mesh with the rest of the market. Despite a number of MBIA insider buys in late 2007, for example, the shares are down more than 30% this year. 

  -- Scott Patterson 

  --- 

  Email mark.gongloff@wsj.com or scott.patterson@wsj.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  March 04, 2008 23:04 ET (04:04 GMT)

  The benchmark 7.99% 2017 10-year bond ended at INR102.63, up from INR102.39 Monday. Its yield fell 3 basis points to 7.59%. 

  "The sentiment is a little better now with most commodity prices coming off their highs, but a sustained rally looks difficult unless inflation pressures ease substantially," said a dealer at a foreign bank. 

  Inflationary pressures have been keeping the bond market subdued, as the central bank and the federal government join the global battle to curb inflation and put the issue of lower interest rates on the back burner. 

  India's wholesale price index-based weekly inflation rate is now hovering above the central bank's stated comfort level of 5%, and experts expect it will stay there, or above, for some time to come. 

  "In the short-term, bond market sentiments are likely to stay cautious as negative factors such as advance tax outflows, uncertainty on the liquidity front, currently outweigh the positives," Kotak Mahindra Bank said in a note to clients. 

  Some INR450 billion to INR550 billion of funds are expected to leave the system when advance tax payments by local companies are completed. 

  In the currency market, the Indian rupee ended higher against the dollar Tuesday as local shares rose, improving sentiment and prompting dollar selling across the board, dealers said. 

  The dollar slipped to INR40.51 from a six-month high of INR40.73 Monday, ahead of a crucial U.S. Federal Reserve Open Market Committee meeting later Tuesday. 

  The market expects the Fed to lower its interest rates by up to 100 basis points to anchor a teetering economy. The latest in a series of rate cuts is likely to widen the differential between India and the U.S. to 5.75 percentage points and may give a boost to dwindling capital inflows into India. 

  But some analysts say rate arbitrage may not be enough to ease the rupee's depreciation. 

  "Even if the Fed cuts its rates further, I'm not sure how much role a wider rate arbitrage will play in attracting foreign funds if the equities sentiment remains damp... What we need is investor confidence returning," said Rohan Lasrado, head of foreign exchange trading at HDFC Bank.

2ndUPDATE: F&P Appliances Shifts Production, Restructures Ops

 
   (updates with background, comments from trade minister and fund manager) 
 

  By Rebecca Howard 

  Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 

 
 

  WELLINGTON (Dow Jones)--Fisher & Paykel Appliances Ltd. (FPA.NZ) is relocating three of its manufacturing sites to low-cost countries in a bid to lift earnings hit by high labor costs, rising global steel prices and a strong New Zealand dollar. 

  Chief Executive John Bongard cited ongoing escalation in manufacturing costs, particularly in New Zealand and Australia, as the main reason for relocating production to Thailand, Mexico and Italy. A free trade agreement between New Zealand and China, inked earlier this month, was also a contributory factor, Bongard said. 

  The home appliances manufacturer has been hard hit by high labor costs, soaring global oil and steel prices, a strong local currency and the country's high interest rates denting consumption. 

  "We have been faced for many years with an extremely unhelpful exchange rate fueled by high interest rates. Increasingly complex and costly compliance costs of manufacturing in our home countries have not assisted," Bongard said. 

  He added that "free trade agreements with low cost labor countries like China and Thailand have created a playing field we are unable to compete in." 

  Bongard's comments sparked a swift reaction from New Zealand Minister of Trade Phil Goff. 

  "I do not believe...that free trade agreements by New Zealand, such as that with China, are a key factor in the decision to relocate," Goff said in a statement. 

   Around 1,070 of the company's employees will lose their jobs as a result of the move, including 430 from its Range & DishDrawer factory in Dunedin, New Zealand. 

  Rickey Ward, joint domestic equity manager at Tyndall Investment Management, said the decision had been forced upon the company by several factors. 

  "This is a reflection of the current economic environment and the challenges that a company like this faces when it tries to grow," said Ward. 

  Ward said that the move was positive as Fisher & Paykel Appliances will be closer to its main markets, curbing transport costs. 

  "Getting closer to your markets is a better idea for them and to a certain extent this is quite reflective of that, trying to get closer to markets where they have got growth," he said. 

   Investors cheered the company's move, sending the stock surging 13.6% to a five-week high of NZ$2.50 around 0133 GMT. The spike came after the stock slid to  NZ$2.11 Wednesday, the lowest level since its split from Fisher & Paykel Healthcare  in late 2001. 

  "Here is a company that was somewhat beaten up because of short-term news, clearly if the numbers are to be believed from what (CEO John Bongard) was saying it will be enormously beneficial to the share price," Ward said. 

 

  Relocation Benefits 

 

  Fisher & Paykel Appliances mainly operates in New Zealand, Australia, the U.S. and Europe. 

  According to the company, the move is expected to save at least NZ$50 million a year. 

  The Range & DishDrawer factory in Dunedin, New Zealand, along with the refrigerator plant in Brisbane, Australia and the Dynamic Cooking Systems or DCS cooking factory in California, U.S. will all be relocated over the next 12-18 months. 

  Fisher & Paykel Appliances was already in the process of moving some of its electronics and laundry appliances facilities to Thailand in a bid to compete with low-cost rivals. 

  It will make use of that site, existing sites in Italy and a new refrigeration production plant it has agreed to buy in Mexico from Whirlpool Corp. for US$33 million. 

  The remaining production facilities in Auckland, New Zealand (Refrigeration and Production Machinery Ltd), Ohio, U.S. (Laundry) and Borso del Grappa, Italy (Cooking) will not be affected, the company said. 

  Hamilton Hindin Greene adviser James Smalley said: "Its just a reflection of the fact that if companies want to remain competitive in the global environment they've got to minimize their costs as much as they can." 

  There will be a one-off cost of approximately NZ$50 million and the capital expenditure is estimated around NZ$100 million. 

  The cost of the moves will be substantially funded from the sale of what will become surplus property in New Zealand and Australia," and expected to net NZ$100 million, the company added. 

  The head office will remain located in New Zealand and the products will continue to be developed in New Zealand by Fisher & Paykel Appliances engineers, said Bongard. 

 

  - By Rebecca Howard, Dow Jones Newswires; 64-4-471-5990; rebecca.howard@dowjones.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

text:
2nd UPDATE:Haiti Lawmakers Vote To Dismiss PM Over Food Riots

 

  (Updates with more comment from Haitians, U.N. mission) 

 

  PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP)--Haitian lawmakers on Saturday dismissed Prime Minister Jacques Edouard Alexis, hoping to defuse widespread anger of rising food prices that had led to days of deadly protests and looting. 

  President Rene Preval, who earlier in the day announced plans to cut the price of rice, immediately said he would seek a replacement for Alexis, who took office in 2006 with Preval's backing to head a Cabinet meant to unite the poor and fractious nation. 

  "I think that will satisfy the people," said Sen. Youri Latortue following the vote in parliament in which 16 of 27 lawmakers backed Alexis' ouster. Latortue said lawmakers ousted the prime minister because he did not boost food production and refused to set a date for the departure of U.N. peacekeepers. 

  But about 25 people gathered outside the national palace after the dismissal, chanting "Aristide or death," in reference to exiled former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. 

  U.N. peacekeepers called Alexis' dismissal a "serious setback" and said they look forward to the early appointment of a new government, according to mission spokeswoman Sophie Boutaud de la Combe. 

  The prime minister's ouster reflects frustration over soaring food prices in a nation where most people live on less than $2 a day and chronic hunger had become unbearable in recent months. 

  The rage erupted in days violent clashes with U.N. peacekeepers and looting across Haiti that had abated by late Thursday, but not before leaving five people dead. Protesters even stormed the presidential palace on Tuesday, charging its main gate with a rolling dumpster and yelling for Preval to step down. 

  On Saturday, U.N. military commander Maj. Gen. Carlos Alberto Dos Santos Cruz told The Associated Press that calm was returning across the country, with some transportation resuming and people going back to work. 

  But Haiti could encounter more chaos with Alexis' ousting, according to Eduardo Gamarra, director of the Latin America and Caribbean Center at Florida International University. He said the dismissal creates a political vacuum and that senators might now go after Preval because he hasn't implemented many changes. 

  "President Preval has to be careful. Anytime President Preval has to engage himself speaking, he also needs to engage the private sector in his discussions," said Senator Jean Hector Anacasis, a member of Preval's Lespwa party. 

  Emmanuel Joseph, a 26-year-old from the seaside slum of Cite Soleil, said residents there are still planning to protest Monday because they are hungry. 

  Some residents felt their plight wouldn't improve regardless of the dismissal. 

  "Alexis left? What's the difference?" asked Jackson Aubri, a 28-year-old chicken vendor. 

  In another bid to deal with anger of food prices, Preval said Saturday that the price of a 50-pound bag of rice will drop from $51 to $43. 

  The price reduction went into effect immediately and will last for one month, at which point government officials will reassess the economic situation. 

  The Haitian president said the government will use international aid money to subsidize the price of rice and that the private sector has agreed to knock $3 off the price of each bag. 

  Globally, food prices have risen 40% since mid-2007. Haiti is particularly affected because it imports nearly all of its food, including more than 80% of its rice. Much of its once-productive farmland has been abandoned as farmers struggle to grow crops in soil decimated by erosion, deforestation, flooding and tropical storms. 

  On Friday, the U.S. State Department issued a statement banning government officials from traveling to Haiti following the violent demonstrations. 

  It also advised American citizens to consider leaving the impoverished Caribbean country where protests over high costs of living left five dead in the countryside. The warning comes despite a general sense of calm settling over Port-au-Prince. 

  "If you don't need to stay, you might consider departing," said James Ellickson-Brown, spokesman for the U.S. Embassy in Port-au-Prince. 

  An estimated 19,000 U.S. citizens live in Haiti, most dual-nationals who live in the capital. More than 140 American citizens have been kidnapped since 2005, but few were short-term visitors, the U.S. Embassy said. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  April 12, 2008 16:54 ET (20:54 GMT)

text:
WSJ(4/23) Philippines Pressed To Rethink Rice Subsidies

   (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL) 
   By James Hookway in Manila and Karen Lane in Singapore 

  Asia has enough rice stocks to meet demand despite low inventories, according to the Asian Development Bank, but prices are showing no sign of receding. 

  Some politicians and economists are pressing the Philippines -- the world's biggest importer of rice -- to change how it subsidizes the staple grain because of the distortions such measures can introduce into the rice market. 

  Rice prices have risen 150% this year, with Thai medium grade rice -- a de facto benchmark -- reaching a record $960 a ton this week. The reasons for the run-up include rising demand among fast-growing Asian economies, poor harvests and stiff competition from biofuels for cultivated land. But some economists and politicians say the impact is being exacerbated by the way some governments restrict exports or distort the market through elaborate and corruption-prone subsidies. 

  In the Philippines, Sen. Edgardo Angara is among a small but growing movement of people asking the government to give up subsidies that are designed to make rice affordable to the poorest Filipinos, but that distort the market and lead to hoarding. Mr. Angara argues that the Philippines' state-run National Food Authority should give up its monopolistic powers to import and subsidize rice and leave the job to the private sector. 

  "If private rice traders are allowed to import and sell rice without any restriction, the supply and price of rice will likely stabilize," he said in a speech to the Senate on Monday. Mr. Angara, who once served as secretary of agriculture, also pressed his case to President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo during a legislative conference Tuesday. 

  Rajat Nag, managing director general of the Asian Development Bank, told reporters in Singapore Tuesday that steps taken by some countries to curb rice exports or introduce price controls are having "counterproductive effects" on what farmers choose to plant and when. Vietnam, Cambodia and Indonesia have limited rice exports, increasing the demand for rice from the biggest exporter, Thailand. Mr. Nag said export bans could hurt other countries and damage longer-term trade relations. 

  He added that Asia shouldn't panic about rice supplies because the region has enough stocks to cover demand, even though they are at their lowest level in decades. 

  The United Nations' Food and Agriculture Organization this month forecast this year's global rice production will expand 1.8% from a year earlier, relieving the pressure on prices. In the Philippines, removing rice subsidies would help eliminate theft and corruption in the state-controlled rice-distribution systems, Mr. Angara says. 

  Philippine investigators have filed several complaints against rice traders who have taken subsidized rice and repackaged it for sale at double the price on the commercial market -- pricing out many poorer Filipinos who were supposed to get it. With the money saved from scrapping subsidies -- projected to be at least $1.3 billion this year -- the Philippines could establish a fund to directly provide money to the people who most need it to buy rice, said Mr. Angara. He said the Philippines did this during previous rice shortages. 

  Perhaps most important, the Philippines also could invest money now spent to subsidize rice consumption on improving its rice output, Mr. Angara says. Like the Philippines, many governments in the region have assumed they would be able to easily and cheaply make up shortfalls in domestic production on the international market. But as this year has shown, stable pricing can't always be taken for granted. 

  Ms. Arroyo has earmarked $1 billion to improve the country's rice-producing capabilities and has called for a freeze on converting agricultural land into housing or industrial developments in a bid to jump-start a new wave of rice farming. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

UPDATE:UAE Carrefour To Keep 52 Basic Foods At 07 Prices

 

  (Adds further Carrefour comments, analyst comment) 

  DUBAI (Zawya Dow Jones)--MAF Hypermarkets signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the United Arab Emirates Ministry of Economy Thursday to maintain the 2007 prices of 52 basic food commodities in all Carrefour stores in the Persian Gulf state. 

  The MoU is in line with "continuous efforts by the   Ministry to stabilize prices, reduce inflation levels, maintain market balance and protect the consumer," said Mohammed Al Shihhi, undersecretary at the Ministry of Economy. 

  The government aims to reduce inflation in the U.A.E. from 10.9% to 5% this year through a series of economic measures, but not through dropping its peg to the weak dollar which economists say accounts for up to 40% of total inflation in the country. 

  Food items that will have prices capped include rice, eggs, milk, meat, bread, tea, water, sugar, salt, vegetable oil and beans among others. 

  The initiative, which applies to all buyers regardless of whether they are U.A.E. nationals or expatriates, will be effective from Sunday till December 2008, said Henri Changeux, Senior Vice President of Carrefour. 

  Up to 70% of the items on the list are Carrefour's most popular brands and Carrefour will not be raising prices of other goods to make up for the expected loss in revenues, Changeux said, adding the initiative was part of its "social responsibility". 

  "We support this initiative, our job is to fulfill the needs of the customer at the best price," Changeux told reporters at a press conference in Dubai. 

  Last week Lulu Hypermarket Group signed a similar MoU to cap prices of 32 goods. Its Chairman Yousif Ali said in a statement: "The Group responded quickly to the MoE's initiative based on its conviction about the importance of such programs to eliminate any negative practices that threaten free competition in the UAE." 

  Ali went on to say the UAE's private sector should "not focus solely on profits" and pointed out "the danger of inflation for both the society and the economy". 

  BACKDOOR DEAL 

  But analysts said both profit-making businesses were unlikely to have agreed to such an initiative without an agreement with the government to make up for losses to be incurred. 

  "There must have been some sort of backdoor deal because there are definitely losses and someone needs to shoulder these losses," said Eckart Woertz, chief economist at Gulf Research Center. 

  He added the government was likely reimbursing them in some way such as lowering rents or electricity rates. 

  Both Lulu and Carrefour were unavailable for comment on potential losses to revenues when contacted by Zawya Dow Jones. 

  In March the Union Cooperative Society in Dubai agreed to fix prices on 16 basic goods at 2007 levels. 

  MAF hypermarkets operate Carrefour stores through a joint venture. 

  -By Tahani Karrar, Dow Jones Newswires; +9714 364 4965; tahani.karrar@dowjones.com

text:
FOCUS: Copper Bulls Dominate As CESCO Week Starts In Chile

 
   By Andrea Hotter 
   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES 
 

  SANTIAGO (Dow Jones)--If copper industry commentaries ahead of the annual CESCO week dinner in Santiago and associated events are anything to go by, the bull run in prices remains firmly intact, with new record highs likely over the next few months. 

  Producers, analysts and traders alike have been extremely bullish on copper since the market's bull run got fully underway a couple of years ago. 

  With the occasional lull in trading activity as participants took profits, copper has been buoyed by a persistent contraction in supplies amid ever-increasing demand from the world's biggest buyer of the metal, China. 

  In March, London Metal Exchange copper prices peaked at an all-time high of $8,820 a metric ton. But while these factors remain, on the surface at least, ongoing bullish factors for copper, the weight of speculative money and fears that the U.S. recession will spread are new themes that are continually cropping up. 

  Opinions over copper's future price direction remain mixed, with the sector looking to CESCO to provide sentiment going forward. 

  "Metal markets seem to be torn between rallying on the back of a weaker dollar on the one hand, and selling off on those occasions when the realization sets in that slowing growth, which is driving the dollar lower in the first place, has the potential to knock demand back," said U.S.-based MF Global analyst Ed Meir. 

  "How this tussle eventually plays out remains to be seen, but the demand component will eventually prevail and exert downward pressure on metals," he added. 

  This will be especially true if the U.S. slowdown starts to spread to Europe, Japan, and then on to Asian economies, as may already be happening, Meir noted. 

  Yet for the moment, market sentiment remains mostly in a bullish mood, optimistic that any recession in the U.S. will be short-lived, and more than offset by strength from China and other emerging markets. And for sure, the latest round of generally poor economic data out of the U.S. is still failing to deter investors. 

  "The copper market obviously sees solid fundamental value in the medium term, given prices edged higher (last week) on the back of U.S. economic data that in other circumstances would have sent investors running," said Michael Lewis, Deutsche Bank's global head of commodities research. 

  "The institute of Supply Management's manufacturing and non-manufacturing monthly indices both came in at levels that indicate a contraction in the economy, but copper investors took heart because they both came in higher than the previous month," he added. 

  While this positive attitude is undoubtedly helping to sustain copper prices, traders are now starting to warn that a more cautious approach is needed. Noting copper prices have exceeded pre-credit crunch levels, traders said this is partly because the market has adapted to the new environment, and partly because analyst reports remain staunchly bullish, despite the U.S. Federal Reserve officially using the word 'recession.' 

  "This sort of frank Fed-speak talk is very rare and surely an omen of what is really coming down the pipe," said RBC Capital Market's London-based director and head of base metals Alex Heath. 

  Noting that bullish commentaries on a weak dollar boosting demand amid low inventories and supply side worries "have been the underlying support of the metal for a while now," Heath said that "ultimately the reason we may make new contract highs (in copper) in the short term is the power of investment money as it feeds on momentum." 

 
   Copper A Speculative Bubble? 
 

  Investor flows into commodities have been well documented for some time now, and are widely viewed as a new fundamental factor in the market. While it's difficult to quantify the exact worth of this money flow, consensus estimates calculate that around $30 billion of fresh investment entered commodities in the first quarter of the year. 

  While this has driven prices higher, copper's also slumped as investors reassessed likely commodity-demand levels - and therefore also prices - after their bull run. And this realization that copper price appreciation is no longer a safe one-way bet has brought fears that copper may be a speculative bubble waiting to burst. 

  What makes it difficult for participants to be sure that investor flows are top-heavy and that copper is set for a sharp decline is the fact that supply/demand fundamentals for the industrial metal have so far proven to be much stronger than expected in 2008. 

  This is largely on account of ongoing supply losses at the mine level, and weather-related production problems at Chinese smelters and refineries at the start of the year. 

  Even output in Chile, the world's biggest copper producer and home to the world's largest mines, is coming under scrutiny. 

  State-owned producer Codelco, the world's largest, has been hit by falling production over the last few years, and this will fall again due to declining ore grades and delays to new projects, the company has said. 

  The threat of strikes is a current and very serious problem, while energy, water and sulfuric acid shortages are also threatening to crimp already reduced output. Around 25% of the world's copper production relies on acid to process oxide ores, and with the raw material at record high prices, this is an additional burden to smaller producers in particular. 

  Looking ahead, new production growth is under threat. Countries like Congo and Zambia are widely expected to see delays to new projects and larger projects, analysts said, with energy problems once again rearing their head. 

  Even larger projects like Tenke Fungurume, KOV and Kolwezi Tailings could encounter further delays, given severe electricity shortages in Congo's Katanga Province. 

  According to Credit Suisse analyst Jeremy Gray, who recently visited Congo, much of the spare power in the region has now been taken by smaller Chinese copper smelters that are producing between 100,000 to 150,000 tons of contained blister copper. 

  "As the license review in Congo dragged on, the Chinese used the window to take the spare power away from many of the larger projects," Gray said. "Tenke, KOV and Kolwezi Tailings may only account for some 500,000 tons of additional supply, but in our estimates, they still account for 11% of future copper supply in the next six years," he added. 

  All this as copper stocks in global warehouses continue to slide. There have been numerous conspiracy theories over this, including that hedge funds and merchants have been buying metal to store it in private warehouses or ship it between ports so it doesn't show up in supply and demand statistics, making the market look tighter as a result. 

  If this is true, it seems to be working. Official data suggests that although demand in the rest of the world will be at best flat this year, analysts said the fate of the copper market rests squarely on the shoulders of China, which accounts for over 25% of world demand. 

  With CESCO week set to discuss whether China has truly decoupled from the developed world or not, data so far suggests that Chinese copper demand is be around 10%-12% this year. 

  While this is down from over 20% last year, largely due to a drop in the export portion, analysts said the domestic portion looks likely to stay strong. Apparent copper demand growth has slowed in the past two months not due to any slowdown in underlying consumption, analysts say, but due to bad winter weather and the surge in copper prices discouraging buying. 

  If world demand for copper re-accelerates once more, it will catch many consumers, who've been living hand-to-mouth, unawares. But if it doesn't, and the weight of investment money heads for the exit, copper's future price gains look anything but assured. 

 

  -By Andrea Hotter, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9413; andrea.hotter@dowjones.com 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

Vietnam Rice Export Prices Up 10% On Tight Local Supply

 

  HANOI (Dow Jones)--Export prices of Vietnamese rice were 10% higher in the week ended Tuesday after the government reaffirmed that the country will only export between 3.5 million and 4.0 million tons of rice, due to tight local supply, traders said. Last year, the country exported 4.5 million tons. 

  "The recent rice crises last week in the two big cities of Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh, where 16 million people are living, have prompted the government to increase state reserves of rice, resulting in more pressure for higher prices," said a trader with a rice export firm in Vinh Long province. 

  He said higher rice prices have encouraged farmers to expand paddy cultivation, but farmers also have to pay higher production costs estimated at more than $800 per metric ton for 5% high-quality rice. 

  Traders who are based in the Mekong delta region predict export prices will remain above $1,000/ton in the next two or three months due to strong global demand. 

  In Ho Chi Minh City and the Mekong delta region, private traders were quoting high-quality 5% broken rice at $1,100 a metric ton freight on board, up from $1,000 last week. They didn't offer 25% broken grade. 

  Traders said retail prices of high-quality rice for domestic consumption in the Mekong delta region are VND14 million-VND15 million ($870-$930) a metric ton, and in Hanoi are VND16 million/ton.

text:
WSJA(5/12) Inflation Spurs India To Limit Futures Trade

   (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL ASIA) 
   By Niraj Sheth 

  New Delhi -- IN AN EFFORT to curb inflation, India's government has suspended futures trade in four commodities, and many economists expect further restrictions in this nascent market. 

  Inflation at the wholesale level has been hovering above 7% on an annual basis, well above the government's comfort zone. The government sees futures markets as contributors to India's staggering rise in food prices and banned futures trading in rice and wheat last year. Last week, it banned futures trading in soy oil, chick peas, potatoes and rubber for at least four months. 

  But critics said the ban will exacerbate rather than relieve inflation by shutting down valuable market-pricing mechanisms and encouraging traders to move to the country's untaxed and unregulated black market of so-called dabba traders. 

  The new suspensions came as a surprise after a government-appointed committee reported last month that it couldn't find any conclusive evidence that futures trading drove up prices. It declined to recommend a trading suspension. But with national elections coming within a year, the ruling coalition, which is led by the Congress Party, faces protests and dissent from left-wing partners, who have been clamoring for action to bring down the price of food staples. 

  Even some in the government have doubts that the suspension will have an effect on prices. "We were opposed to the suspensions," said B.C. Khatua, chairman of the Forwards Markets Commission, which supervises the country's futures exchanges. "But in a democracy, you have to compromise." 

  India's futures markets include only a small proportion of the participants in the agricultural sector. The average daily volume traded on the National Commodities and Derivatives Exchange, the main market for agricultural futures, is $600 million. India's overall agricultural output was $129 billion in 2006, the latest data available. The small size of the market means that, at best, it has little effect on food prices and, at worst, it can be easily manipulated by relatively small sums of money, traders and analysts said. 

  One major concern is that banning futures trading takes away early warnings about price jumps. Farmers, who could look to futures prices as a gauge of the market, now have little alternative but to sell at the spot-market price. 

  Futures trading represents "the canary in the coal mine," said Ajay Shah, senior fellow at the government-funded National Institute of Public Finance and Policy. "It's not right to blame futures trading as the cause of price rises." 

  The government has made the case that global factors and speculation are pushing up food prices as much as supply-and-demand issues. "Worse than a price rise is the sentiment of a price rise; worse than inflation is the fear of inflation," Kamal Nath, minister of Commerce and Industry, said in a recent interview. "People tend to stock up and create artificial demand." 

  Many traders and analysts said that if inflation doesn't dissipate, a wider ban on agricultural-futures trading is likely. The government said it has no such plans now. 

  Already, the suspensions on futures trading may be pushing more people to dabba traders. These illegal brokers take prices from official exchanges and let individuals "buy" commodities. However, unlike in the official markets, no actual deliverable product is involved in the transaction, and buyers are just betting on changes in prices. Such traders -- dabba means "box" in Hindi -- aren't taxed or regulated, leaving participants with little security if a broker turns hostile. "Because the Indian commodities-futures market is not allowed to operate, people feel aggrieved and go into this type of trading to keep their risk management maintained," said Mr. Khatua, of the Forwards Markets Commission. 

  Even as India clamps down on futures trading at home, it quietly has been placing its own orders on wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade, two people familiar with the situation said. Over the past year, the government slowly has built up a stack of options to buy 100 million tons of wheat in case of domestic shortages -- a stance some saw as hypocritical, considering the government's stance on futures trading in India. Government officials couldn't be reached to comment over the weekend. 

  --- 

  Joanna Slater in New York contributed to this article. 

 

  (END) Dow Jones Newswires

  May 11, 2008 17:30 ET (21:30 GMT)
